Even after everything, soba still serves as a great comfort to Shouto. And so when Fuyumi calls him one evening with the promise of just that, he sees no reason to turn her down.Dinner is silent, an absence Shouto would usually appreciate if not for the fact that this is his sister, and her silence can only mean that something is wrong. He blinks up from his shaku plate, slurping around a cold noodle before disrupting the null stillness. “Where’s Natsu?”With a relieved exhale, she breathes back to life — and by default, Shouto is relieved too. After their mother had been hospitalized, Fuyumi gave herself no other choice but to adapt, fulfilling the role of the figure they lost and actively setting the tone of the Todoroki household since. She put in the effort when no one else deemed her objective plausible: to become a family again.Now, it’s less plausible than ever. And they’re left to ruminate in the aftermath with each other, of ever daring to feel whole again. If Shouto had begun to feel even a semblance of hope, it’d all been for nothing. He should’ve known better than to put faith in the man who only ever made it hurt, who’d been the reason they needed any fixing at all. “He’s been busier than ever with college and all. But I'm sure once everything settles down, we can do this again with the three of us! Doesn’t that sound nice?”The corner of his lips twitches at the reappearance of her usual chattiness as he nods in agreement.“Oh! And maybe you can bring those friends of yours too. Midoriya and Bakugou.”“Maybe.”“How are they, by the way?”Shouto pauses for a brief moment, chopsticks hovering over his mouth. He isn’t sure how to tell his sister that there are some experiences you can’t walk away from the same, that when you find yourself in the heart of a battle you don’t completely understand, surrounded by carnage and widespread havoc, when the enemy becomes increasingly less clear, when it starts to feel like a conflict with yourself more than anyone else; it’s difficult to find the right answer, so he offers a simple, “Alive,” and hopes that it’s enough. Judging by the look on her face, it isn’t, but she accepts the nonspecific, Shouto-fashion response anyway, and chews her bottom lip in contemplation — an ugly habit, but one of the tamer between his siblings. At least she hasn't picked up smoking like Natsuo — in what looks like her own inner conflict, hot turmoil brewing and spilling over, because she’d never been good at keeping quiet for too long. Something Shouto has always been grateful for, with his inability to understand humanity as a whole. Sociable was a trait his father beat out of him before he could ever attain the valuable characteristic. “Did you hear from mom?” 
 Oh. That’s what this is about.  
Fuyumi leans over to refill his drink, bubbles floating to the top of the glass, fizzling between them like white noise. He latches onto the sight of pressure being released in the form of carbonated water, the sharp crackling noise muffling his surroundings. This time, the silence is loud. Fuyumi waits patiently for his answer.“I haven’t gotten around to writing back yet,” he admits, peering down at the spread across the table. An overkill of food for just the two of them, but nothing unexpected. Fuyumi takes care of him well. Smothering and doting on him like an overzealous mother would, and now more than ever. Perhaps guilt gnaws away at her too.She holds onto that  yet. “I’m sure she understands. UA is tough,” she offers a tender smile. He wants to preserve that warmth for the harsh winter. Despite his quirk being suited for withstanding sudden drops in temperature, he bets it’s different when it comes from someone who cares about you, when it isn’t an innate ability meticulously crafted by your father, but an air of homeliness. A mother wrapping a scarf around your neck before she sends you off to school. “She won’t be discharged anytime soon like we anticipated. But it’s nothing worth fussing over! Hope isn’t lost as long as there’s something to work towards, right?”“Sure,” he half-heartedly agrees, if not to soothe her wavering certainty. Hope was lost the moment Touya died, when the last of him crumbled away between Shouto’s fingertips in his final, desperate attempt to save the damned soul of his long-lost brother. In the end, his alias became a self-fulfilled prophecy. In the end, Shouto failed. When they finish eating, he helps with the dishes. The faucet drips in intervals. Shouto leans over to put on his shoes. First his left, then his right. He wears the jacket Fuyumi holds out to him, muttering his thanks as he slips his arms through the sleeves. “I’m going to go now,” he announces. Fuyumi doesn’t react, lost in thought as she stands stock-still in front of him, eyes searching for something across his face. He waits for her to come back, for a proper farewell. To reaffirm that this is only temporary. Tomorrow he will wake up to a good morning message with a myriad of smiley faces and hearts illuminating his screen, just like every other morning. Fuyumi will ask him to come by for dinner again sometime, and there’ll always be that option. He’ll never have to forget the taste of his sister’s cooking. “Wait here.”Shouto watches her scramble down the hall. She returns with a bag and forces it into his grasp, using both of her hands to close his into a fist. “Mapo tofu,” she says. “For your friends, they seemed to enjoy it last time. Promise me you’ll invite them over?”“I promise. They’ve missed your cooking, so it shouldn’t be hard to convince them.” Shouto remembers Katsuki’s petulant grumbling when he discovered how much of a novice he is in the kitchen — as it turns out, culinary prowess is not a congenital trait within the Todoroki family. He thinks about the others, hopes that they aren’t lounging in the common area when he gets back home. Not wanting to upset anyone with the serving size.Then it dawns on him what he just thought: home. Isn’t he there already?He snaps out of his stupor when he’s suddenly pulled into a tight embrace, arms squeezing almost painfully around him. It takes Shouto a moment to realize that this is a hug. Fuyumi is hugging him. “Fuyumi?”“Get back safe, okay?”“I will.”She pulls back with a firm grip on his shoulders. “Okay,” she says, letting go and wiping her palms down her sides. “Right, okay then. Well, I won’t hold you hostage.”On the way home, the chauffeur attempts to make small talk. Shouto hums and speaks in stiff one-word responses until the conversation dies down and the hum of the city is the only thing filling the silence. The warmth on his lap and the smell of spices are almost comforting as he stares out at the city lights, a city that had been demolished not too long ago before picking itself back up and moving on. Perhaps it will never be whole again; nothing will go back to the way it once was.His phone pings.Bakugou Katsuki  (20:16):

prompt: write a story about Haikyuu!!,  General Audiences No Archive Warnings Apply Gen 僕のヒーローアカデミア | Boku no Hero Academia | My Hero Academia (Anime & Manga) Aizawa Shouta | Eraserhead & Midoriya Izuku Aizawa Shouta | Eraserhead Midoriya Izuku Aizawa Shouta | Eraserhead is a Good Teacher Suspected Traitor Midoriya Izuku Except in reverse Late Night Conversations Quirk Accident (My Hero Academia)
completion:
For Shouta, the night has been slow. All the kids are presumably asleep, and the dorm has been quiet for the past two hours. He would know since he’s in charge of monitoring everything tonight. Because for all intents and purposes he’s “on-call” for the dorms tonight. Usually, that just entails keeping an open ear and being a light sleeper for that night. Tonight, he’s only awake a bit later than usual because of the papers he has to grade. Everyone was given the same topic but used different materials. It makes grading a bit tougher on him, but it’ll help them learn. Eyewitness testimony, and the ample room it has to fail or mislead, is pretty important for them to know about. It’s just his luck that the second he decides to take a break is when he gets the dreaded knock on his door. His students are pretty independent people, so it isn’t often that one comes, but when it does the knocks usually pertain to illness or something a bit more dire. He tries not to think about the time Sero pierced his own ear and it became infected. A quick look at the camera display next to his computer shows a familiar head of green hair standing outside of his door. Midoriya’s figure is shifting nervously from side to side and Shouta is not excited. If tonight’s problem has to do with the, arguably, most independent (in all the worst ways) of his class, it’ll be a long one. That’s for sure. This is especially true considering that Midoriya just had a work-study day today. Shouta hasn’t gotten around to reading the report from Midoriya’s supervisor yet, but anything could’ve happened. He has to prepare himself for a variety of issues that could’ve arisen in the few hours that Midoriya’s been back in the dorms. The worst-case scenario is that Midoriya got an injury and didn’t tell anyone about it. Unfortunately, this is almost the most likely scenario considering the teen’s past behavior. He sets aside his grading and makes sure it can’t be seen, for privacy reasons, before he heads over to the door. When he finally opens the door, Midoriya looks like he was halfway about to leave. When he sets his eyes on Shouta, his nervous expression just gets worse as it is seeped with dread. “Sorry for the interruption, Aizawa-sensei,” the kid says with a small bow, “But, I had to tell you-“ Shouta can already tell this is gonna take a lot of effort, “Don’t rush yourself. Go sit down and I’ll make us some tea. Whatever it is, I can tell it’d be best if you had calmed down first.”
 
Shouta uses the process of making tea as a relaxer for himself. Grading all those papers had escalated his stress levels and it was clear that Midoriya was already uncomfortable with confronting his teachers – Shouta’s stressed face wouldn’t help anyone. Once it’s all allotted in cups, he takes it back to the seating area where Midoriya is sitting in what must be the most uncomfortable position to exist. It hardly even looks like Midoriya is sitting on the couch. His back is straight and he’s practically hovering over the cushions in an effort to ‘not impose’ or whatever is going through the teen’s mind. He puts a cup of tea in front of Midoriya on the coffee table and Midoriya jolts at the action, “Thank you, sensei,” Midoriya says politely before taking a sip from the cup. Shouta waits a few sips before he deigns to broach the issue, “So, what happened?” Midoriya puts the cup down and his head sinks down. Oddly enough, for a kid who’s always so confident in his poor decisions, he looks like he’s being weighed down with guilt of whatever he’s done. His mouth opens and closes a few times before hoods hands curl up on his pants - fingers clutching the fabric – and he says, “I’m a traitor,” those very words release the floodgates. Midoriya sinks down into the couch and covers his face to sob into his hands. Shouta tenses at first. The admission is regarding something he’d been thinking about a lot lately. Since the summer camp intrusion, they hadn’t had any encounters with the League of Villains. He was constantly wondering how to prepare – himself and the kids. But for Midoriya to announce that, Shouta simply can’t imagine it. He thinks back to everything that’s happened. The USJ, summer camp, the battle against Stain that Shouta wasn’t supposed to know about, Kamino Ward then their fight against the Yakuza. Sure, most of it could make sense. Perhaps he’d done it all out of a sense of guilt, but it just didn’t fit him. Midoriya wore his heart on his sleeve. All Shouta is left to do is chuckle, it’s low and barely noticeable, but doesn’t escape Midoriya’s attention. The teens head snaps up in fear, “Did you already know?” he surmises. Shouta simply shakes his head, “No, it’s just that you being the traitor is impossible. Plus, we haven’t even confirmed that there is a traitor. This admission is ridiculous. Surely, you know that,” Shouta says, “Even if you were, why would you only confess now? I simply can’t believe you.” “But-“ Midoriya begins to protest Shouta’s words, “I know it’s the truth. The things I’ve done,” the kid looks like he wants to throw up. “Tell me what you’ve done,” Shouta says. He doesn’t know the specifics of Midoriya’s current frame of mind, but he suspects this is the work of some sort of quirk. Midoriya looks around the teacher’s apartment shiftily, as if scared to say something. But he takes a deep breath in and starts with some specifics. Midoriya talks a bit about how he had been in contact with Shigaraki. He reports giving Shigaraki the idea to break in and look at the schedule. His internship encounter with Stain was planned because Shigaraki hated what Stain stood for but couldn’t take the man down himself. Then, during the mall incident, he and Shigaraki had simply been reconvening to exchange information about the summer camp. Supposedly, it was thanks to a tracker that they’d been able to find the location. He tells a very convincing story. Or rather, it sounds like he’s convincing himself further and further. The whole time, he’s stuck in his head – messing up his words, looking all around when he can’t ‘remember’ something, and the like. “This phone, you mention you used to get in contact with Shigaraki with,” he prompts, “Where did it go?” This stalls Midoriya for a second, “I think, I lost it? Or, no, it was broken during USJ.” “I see, then how did you know Shigaraki wanted Stain taken care of?” Before Izuku can answer that question, “Or rather, did you know you could take out Stain, or would get the chance, or could get help from your friends when he asked? Why did he trust you with such a task? During Kamino Ward, did he ask you to save Bakugou – who he went to such lengths to kidnap? Am I supposed to believe that Bakugou is a traitor as well?” This last question gets a stir out of Midoriya, “Of course not! Kacchan would never be a traitor he’s a hero!” “Then why did you save him? Why would Shigaraki want you to save him? I don’t want you to answer all of these questions right now. I’m only asking because I think it’s ridiculous that you would end up in such a situation.” Shouta seems to have said something to quiet Midoriya as he considers the situation, “I simply cannot believe you are a traitor. Because, last of all, you came to tell me. I don’t believe something could have spurned you to be overcome with guilt now, of all times, rather than earlier. Midoriya, you care too much about other people. It is often to your own detriment. But right now, it’s because of that, that I know you are being deluded.” Midoriya takes in these words. But he still looks conflicted. “You should go to bed; I’ll go over your report from today and we’re going to figure it out.” He says, going for a sip of his tea – Midoriya’s remains untouched aside from that initial sip. “But!” Midoriya says in a sharp voice, Shouta’s eyes go upward above his cup, “What if, what if you’re wrong? And I really am a traitor! I could hurt them, or something bad could happen!” Midoriya stresses, yet again proving how he couldn’t be a traitor, in that he’s so worried about hurting his friends. His eyes are still red from his momentary crying spell and his face heats up in his desperation. “Then you can sleep here on my couch,” Midoriya still looks worried, “I could take you on in my sleep, don’t think you’d be able to hurt me,” he adds on. Thankfully, Midoriya seems relieved by this information. He releases the grip he has on his hands and leans forward slowly to grab his tea, “Okay,” he agrees in a small voice. Shouta helps his student get settled in and goes back to his desk. He ignores the papers that need grading and pulls up Midoriya’s work-study record. He can’t truly imagine what is going through Midoriya’s mind nor what kind of situation he got this delusion from. But it’s his job to figure it out. Midoriya trusted him enough to come clean about a belief that would usually get him locked up and interrogated, it’s only right that he repay that trust with dedication. Wednesday, August 23
 7:03 PMFighting was like battling against the waves in an ocean. Back and forth, move, sway, flow. So gentle yet so, so ruthless.Izuku was no stranger to fighting. He'd fought all his life; with Kacchan and his peers and the villains and Katsuki and more villains and Kacchan again. Fighting swelled in his veins and overflowed in a flood of heavy fists and well-aimed kicks and glinting knives and chilling screams.He fought for others only, always."Deku! Watch your left!"A swivel, a thrust, a solid hit. Ingenium's perception in battle never disappointed.These were his people, his heroes, his friends. Iida, Uraraka, Todoroki. His back pressed against another; dual temperatures aiding comfort in the midst of fear and excitement and adrenaline."I'll freeze their feet. Surround them, disarm them." A subtle press to Izuku's right shoulder told him which way to go, and the presence against him dissipated. Shouto's strategies solidified the growing belief that they would be triumphant.Shadows fell over him as he slipped to the right. Uravity, from above. Anticipation, waiting, holding their breaths.A simple signal, drilled into them since fifteen. Now. Go. Move. Attack.The waves of the battle pulsed in tune with his beating heart, faster, slower. Duck, punch, fourty-five percent. Enough to hinder, enough to hurt.We're winning. Together, they forced back the creature, lashing out at its certain downfall, huddled fearfully in a corner. Trapped. Beaten.Izuku relaxed, tension receeding like the tide, quick and smooth and leaving behind little presents of appreciation in its wake. Gratitude in the form of words, so many words, from so many people.A simple outing, a trip to the mall with friends, turned disastrous with the makings of the news station's next headline. 'Good thing the Heroes were close by', he could imagine the civilians whisper. 'They've saved the day once again.'The concrete cracked, grumbled, groaned under his feet, then crumbled with the vibration of an earthquake, or what seemed like one. Surprise, mingled with curiosity and panic, overtook him. The creature in front of them, hands placed firmly on the ground, shaking the building to its core, grinned maniacally up at him, eyes nothing more than dark pupils against bright white.Dust rained down as the building's foundation shuddered and broke. People screamed, fell, ran, and Izuku glanced up.A beam. Sharp - too sharp - heavy, steel, dislodged from its place in the strip mall's ceiling. Hurtling towards them, towards her, and in the blink of an eye, Izuku took her place.Like a tidal wave, his end crashed down upon him. The tide that had left; too abrupt and hurried to be anything but a looming tsunami.He tasted metal. That's odd, he thought. He didn't eat the thing, just tried to catch it.It went right through him.No, he pleaded to nothing in particular. No, this cannot be.Funny, it did not hurt. Numbness spread from the chasm in his stomach to his elbows and knees to the very tips of his fingers and toes and stopping just short of his jaw. He could not move, even if he wanted to.He didn't want to.Someone was crying. It landed across the constellations of his cheeks and trickled down to tickle at his ears. A watery, blurry film covered his eyes, distorting the images above him.Was it himself? Were the tears that created wet tracks down his cheeks and nestled themselves in his tangled hair from him? He couldn't tell, he couldn't feel, he couldn't breathe, he couldn't - Kacchan.He wanted to see Kacchan.Over and over again his mind screamed; Kacchan, Kacchan, Kacchan until the numbness in his limb was not an issue at all and he felt new, invigorated power encouraging him to sit up, to stand, to run and find his Kacchan."Lay back. Don't move." A hand against his shoulder, grounding and steady and holding him back despite his struggle.He needed to apologize, to kiss Kacchan's cheeks and eyelids and lips and whisper his wrongdoings in fervent fear of loss and brokenness.But he could not move, despite his growing want, his aching need, to do just that.He could not move.Now, here he was, dying, filled with regrets; hating the way things ended, and the way he acted, and wishing he could see Kacchan's eyes one last time."Izuku!"So beautiful, he thought, as the ceiling blurred and his eyes threatened to close, Kacchan's eyes... were always so beautiful.The tides that flowed and covered and tugged at his body grew stronger, but Izuku held on to a last little fragment of hope. He swore he heard it; Kacchan's voice, even for just a moment. Was he there? Did he come back to him?There were so many people around, an amalgamation of colors and words and way too bright lights. His friends, he thought, or civilians, or paramedics, impossible to tell within the sporadic glimpses through the filmy haze covering his eyes. Or maybe he was just closing them and opening them again. Blinking, or dying, slowly fading.A harsh, unyielding pressure against his stomach forced a wail through clenched teeth. Pain. So much pain, blossoming throughout his midriff and crawling up his skin with every beat of his withering heart. It stained his teeth and soaked into his flesh like an unwanted tatoo, vibrant pigmentation stark against paling skin, growing paler. Dying, he remembered, he's dying.Voices, not Kacchan's this time (and perhaps it never was), but still familiar wheedled their way through the cotton stuffed in his ears, melding together into something he couldn't understand yet tried to anyways. Words. So many words; losing, attack, hospital, heroes, blood, Izuku, Izuku, Izuku. Stay. Fight. Love.But he was so, so tired, and sleep sounded so wonderful, and his eyes wanted to close. Sleeping, not dying.The waves pulsed around him again, harder this time, a siren's call of longing and despair and of goodbyes and hellos, of everything he'd ever lost and everything he ever hoped for. He could see it now, clearer than anything he'd ever seen before. Kacchan. Kacchan. Yes, he begged, yes. A home with Kacchan, a life with Kacchan, a love with Kacchan, all in front of him, within his arm's reach and heart's hold and-Stay. Fight. Love. Deku.He was so, so tired. And the waves were so gentle and his eyes were finally closed and his heart was finally open and he was finally going to be with Kacchan."Ka...cch...an..."With a smile as bright as the stars themselves, Izuku followed the call into darkness.<<EOFANFIC>>

Denki states matter-of-factly.  Rikido chuckles and Shoto lets out a small laugh. "You just made Shoto get her a new one a few months ago, and a new one two before that! How many collars does that cat even have at this point?" Rikido questions.   "She deserves to be bedazzled, it's not my fault I care more about Shoto's cat's style than he does. That shade of blue didn't compliment her fur like the new pink and yellow floral one does." Denki retorts with a slight pout.  Shoto eyes his friend. "I'm the one paying for all of Jewel's new things."   "Whatever, she's  your  cat, it's your job! I'm not taking this crap anymore."   Denki dramatically crosses his arms and furrows his eyebrows, dropping his utensils onto his plate. All three of the boys burst into laughter, Rikido and Denki's tone loud and contagious while Shoto's stays comparatively quiet and hushed.  Sometimes they would chat frequently as they ate, almost missing their next class as they neglected their food and other times they would sit in comfortable silence, eating together without need for noise. Whatever the day or mood brought, even in difference of opinion, the three couldn't deny their unique closeness. They were a team, and Rikido hoped it would stay that way for as long as possible.   — — —   If you were to ask Rikido what he feels about the seat arrangement in Class 1-A, he would say that he's honestly grateful. Rikido's learned that Shoto is a good project partner to have – concise, not often distracted from the task at hand, and as long as you're literal and clear in your choice of words, there'll be no communication issue.   As much as Rikido appreciates and cherishes Denki, he and Kirishima fit better together with their mutual chattiness and constant banter than Rikido thinks Denki and himself would. Rikido really  does  try his best not to get distracted but hasn't mastered the skill as well as Shoto yet.  Rikido is brought out of his thoughts (that, ironically, are distracting him) by the sound of Todoroki's voice. Rikido nods along in hopes that Shoto will elaborate more now, only half aware of what he's agreeing to.   "I was expecting you to say that that seems overboard. You don't have any questions or anything to add on?"   "No, your idea's good."   Shoto turns away and faces his own assignment. "Good, then we can both start working on our own paper now."   A moment of silence passes as Shoto starts writing and Rikido tries to look at his friend's work to try and understand what he was just ignoring, to no avail.   ".. Can you explain the idea a bit more?" Rikido sheepishly asks. Shoto side-eyes him in knowing silence before sighing lightly and starting over.  — — —  "Do you really think it's okay if we wait in Shoto's room for him to get out of training? He already gets in enough of a bad mood having to work with Bakugo... I wouldn't want to make that worse."   Rikido closes the door behind him only to see Denki already sprawled out on the futon. "He'll be fine, we're his best buddies! He'll probably grumble about it, but he loves us, he won't get  too pissy. He shouldn't have copied a key for me if he didn't want me coming in here."   Jewel jumps down from a small cat tree in the room, one that Denki probably guilted Shoto into buying, and slowly strolls over to Denki, nudging his knee that dangles off the futon for pets. Rikido sighs, half fond and half incredulous, setting his book bag down and settling in himself.  The two chat and play with Jewel absentmindedly for about half an hour until the third musketeer trudges into the room and drops his backpack and costume bag carelessly.   Shoto turns and stares at them in silence for a moment. Denki wiggles his eyebrows, his attempt at coercion failing.   "You both mean a lot to me but I'm so tired now.. Please go. His was a quiet love.

Any affectionate outbursts were a product of the people around him, much like how even the mildest of children will show an aggressive love when faced with their siblings. In his heart, his love was that of a mist that gently spreads out to blanket the moor. It was slow and delicate, slowly encompassing everything until it filled all of his mind and clouded his thoughts.

His love was as irrational as it was inevitable.

Growing up, staring at the posters that showed 

his

 blinding smile, Shouta never thought he’d grow to love the man. Admiration? Respect? Yes. But 

love

? Surely not.

The masses adored All Might: their symbol of peace and stability. There was a time when Shouta may have adored him too, aspiring to be a hero like him that could put people at ease and soothe their fear, but then his world crashed down with the concrete of that building one fateful day and the illusion of a perfect world shattered. Forced to accept the cruel reality that permeated every corner of existence, he began to resent a man who did not rightfully deserve his ire.

To Shouta, All Might was the face of the gold-coated reality that masked a harsh and uncaring world, and he couldn’t stand it. Never giving up on the dream to save people, which he clutched so closely to his chest, his respect became begrudging. Despite everything, how could he truly 

hate

 a man who saved so many?

Love though? He wasn’t a member of the adoring masses that so deeply integrated their vision of a man they did not know into their hearts that they had an illusion of who All Might was. Shouta would never know the man personally, and therefore could never love him. And even if fate twisted and turned to throw him in such an unlikely situation as their being acquainted with each other, he was long past the time of opening his heart to someone like that.


(He’d once already loved a man who represented the sky and the heavens. Look how that turned out.)


Shouta was 

wrong.


Oh he was wrong about a great many things, as he was harshly learning day after day in the new reality that was facing a true monster, but there was nothing he was grossly unprepared for as what bloomed inside him.


Love.


It grew gradually. Standing in his field, the sky overcast and heavy with a rain that would never fall, he did not notice the fog that crept around his feet, curling and swirling about him.

Yagi Toshinori was the man he loved, but it began with All Might.

Body destroyed, pain his only form of existence, it was not the desperate firing of his nerves telling him 

wrong wrong, we are broken, dying

 that took over his mind but instead 

fear.

 Not for himself, but for the twenty lives he was responsible for. 

They can’t die. They can’t.



Please, I’ll give anything.


Was she okay? He couldn’t see–perhaps he never would again–and he couldn’t 

know.

 Was he fast enough? 

Was she okay?


His senses were lost to him beyond the wall of all-encompassing pain and the darkness was quickly taking over. Latching onto consciousness like the dying man he was, he prayed to the gods he didn’t believe in that someone would come.

That 

he 

could come.


And he did.


It was a dream to hear his voice, to feel the intense chill that swelled into the air with his arrival. It was a pitiful attempt by his dying mind to give him some sort of hope: to provide him with a euphoric sense of relief in his final moments. 

He

 was here and the children would be okay: what a wonderful thought to die with. 

(If only it were the truth).


When he woke up, filled to the brink with pain but 

alive

, he learned that it was no dream.

How could he feel anything but 

love

?

The following weeks were an awful haze of muddled consciousness where his nightmares existed even in his waking hours. The drugs trapped him in a spiraling existence of fear, constantly convinced that all of his students had died and only he remained, cursed and forever marked by what he couldn’t do for them, and then he would remember. His brain echoing everything he could have lost in a sluggish mental prison. (He tried to get away with not taking them, but the agony was too much. The price of reprieve from his own invisible hell was the inability to teach his classes, and that was not a cost worth giving. His students had to see him–

had

 to believe that everything was alright. It was the least he owed them, and so he accepted the personal consequences).

He was not alone, however, and the love spread.

Yagi Toshinori was an affectionate man, whether or not he himself realized it. He was careful to never cross any boundaries, but contact was inevitable with Shouta’s arms out of commission. A delicate touch to his shoulder brought a reassuring warmth to Shouta’s body, seeping into his very core and calming his heart. Completely unaware of what he was doing, the man brought Shouta comfort when he needed it most. Each touch was a reprieve from the constant clouded state he lived in. It was never too much.

Bright, blinding sunlight washing over him from a small parting in the clouds would have been too much. Had the encouragement come from All Might it would have been overwhelming.


But from Toshinori?


It was welcoming. Not the harsh light from the sun but the solace of a lit hearth on a cold winter night. In his field of mist he was wrapped in a warm wool coat, a scarf tucked carefully about his neck. Yagi’s tenderness was a pair of mittens keeping his fingers from going numb from the frost.

The man’s mere presence evoked fondness and safety.


Was this how they all felt about All Might?


No, it wasn’t exactly the same. All Might was everyone’s protector. For some reason, after the incident at the USJ, Yagi Toshinori felt like Shouta’s specifically.

Of course he’d never whisper a word of these feelings. There was no point in adding more weight to the burden that Yagi carried. Instead, Shouta’s love and devotion silently grew.

And then the League attacked again: an attack which culminated in the surfacing of the worst villain Japan (and possibly the world) had ever known.

Staring at that monitor, unable to do anything as physical distance kept him from the man who was fighting for the lives of his students (

the lives of 


all


 of Japan

), Shouta felt his heart breaking.


Not again.


The fog grew violent, threatening to choke him, but even though All Might died Yagi Toshinori lived, and it was enough.

Enough to settle the mist as his tears fell, unseen as he hid in his dark room, alone but not abandoned. (

Not this time.

)

There was more to it than the act of a great hero–Yagi persisted even without his quirk. His enhanced strength may have left him, but his power did not. Bright (

lovely

) smiles accompanied encouraging words as the man guided their kids, leading them down the path to a good future.


How could he not love him?


Shouta came to terms with his feelings–feelings he was sure would never leave him (

and he didn’t want them to).


But it was a quiet acceptance, not intended to ever see the light of day. Yagi Toshinori was a greater man than Shouta would ever be and there was a certain peace to loving him from afar. Even as the fog climbed and climbed, nearly obscuring his vision, he was satisfied with his love.

To have even the friendship–the listening ear–of such a shining man as Yagi was more than he could ever hope for.
 
The final battle came: the culmination of a war waged for two-hundred years. They all fought, even Shouta with his failing quirk and impaired vision. Yagi came and Shouta understood why.


Their children.


They had to protect the children.

But Shouta had more than their kids to protect. Yagi survived death once and he was going to do it a second time.

It was a carefully measured attack, specifically targeting Yagi when his attention was divided. Shouta saw it before anyone else, but he lacked the speed and mobility he once had. Physical therapy was helpful, yet it hadn’t been that long. It was understandable that he hadn’t regained anything near the ability of before.

Blood spat from his mouth following the piercing impact. The blackened spike was far longer than his arm and wide in girth, coming to an impossibly sharp point. Striking him directly in the solar plexus it tore a hole through his body.


His

 body. Not 

Yagi’s.


The look that Yagi Toshinori wore was one that wasn’t meant to grace his features. Brilliant blue eyes stared down at him, wide with horror, as the man he loved cradled Shouta’s bleeding body.

One thing people don’t realize is how odd humans’ response to pain can be. Despite the foreign object sticking out from either side of his torso, Shouta felt fine. His injuries at the USJ and in the previous fight where he lost his leg were one thing, but in that moment his eyes were on Toshinori and it was okay. There was nothing physical to fear, only that which he cradled so carefully in his heart: 

love.


Lifting a hand, he gently held Toshinori’s face.

“It’s alright,” he whispered. “Because you are here.”
 
His was a quiet love, but perhaps it was time to be loud.

The first was the hardest. Putting cold steel to warm flesh and daring himself to take the final step made him shaky with indecision. Self harm was touched on briefly in health classes as something incredibly bad, almost taboo. But Izuku knew from research that it was very common and the endorphin rush was claimed to relieve other types of pain. When he finally took the plunge he psyched himself up with the knowledge that his very existence was taboo, being quirkless. It stung but he quickly found himself fascinated with the blood welling up. He caused that. Not Kacchan. Not Tsubasa. Not any other nameless and faceless bullies. Freaky Deku was controlling something in his own life for once.  
Cutting his legs and thighs quickly became a source of relief. The momentary pain was soon followed by calm and relaxation. Having some small measure of choice to look forward to curbed his anxiety and allowed him to focus more on surviving his daily obligations. He maintained a tight balance, refusing to let it slip into addiction by denying the urge when it struck unbidden. It would no longer be in his control if he couldn't stop himself from doing it and that was what he enjoyed the most.
 
The blade in question was a beautifully designed butterfly knife that he found under a playground tube slide while hiding from Kacchan and his friends. The hilt was a chromatic rainbow, colors shifting depending on lighting and angle. The flat of the blade was etched with a scene of tranquil koi curled around each other to mimic the yin and yang symbol. He'd initially intended to turn it in to the police in case it was related to a crime but the more he examined it the more he grew attached. Plus he would likely get scolded for possessing it despite the intended good deed. So home it went. He never intended to use it but needs change.

Everything Izuku ever read claimed that taking a life was a soul-shattering action that would forever haunt the killer. He never felt more free as he pulled the butterfly knife out to plunge it into a more fatal spot. The foreign blood trickling onto him entranced as much as it repulsed. His body protested as he heaved the spasming figure off of him. Bright crimson eyes stared in blank defiance at the darkening sky. Kacchan always believed he was untouchable, invincible. His spirit must be raging at being taken out by a quirkless freak using quirkless methods.
 
Blood pulled tacky and tight against Izuku's skin, not all of it Kacchan's, as he forced himself to his feet. His face throbbed from the fight, in time with his crooked wrist, as he hobbled away to find the notebook that had triggered Kacchan's fury that day. The beating had been a warning. Breaking his dominant arm had been a promise only Izuku had the guts to follow through on in instinctive self preservation. Taking the knife to school to relieve midday stress had been a fortunate mistake. 
 
Cold calculations ran through Izuku's head as he gathered all the evidence of his involvement that he could. The odds that the runty kid with no powers would be charged for a murder was low normally. But Kacchan was the promising star of Alder Junior High, with a flashy quirk made for heroism. Everyone there would be quick to point fingers even if no CCTV cameras picked up Izuku's mad sprint to flee from the bully after school. The school would want to solve the mystery quickly and with as little fanfare as possible to cover up their own culpability. It might take a couple days for the body to be found in the woods of their childhood stomping ground but the location itself would be a clue for Kacchan's friends. And if Izuku was arrested, if he even made it to a courtroom, he would be killed as soon as his quirk status was revealed in prison.
 
Thinking quickly, he pulled off his school blazer and stuffed it into the bottom of his backpack. The blood stained undershirt was hidden beneath his gym shirt. The knife was folded closed and went back in his pants pocket. There was nothing he could do about the pants themselves and his shoes but lengthening shadows would conceal the stains at a casual glance. Finally, he headed home at a brisk jog, keeping to back roads and footpaths.

Several people had died in recent years because he didn't get them to medical personnel after saving them from villains. Dozens of quirkless individuals had applied to general studies, business, and support only to be rejected despite passing the exams. Izuku would have no hope of getting into the hero course.

Chapter Text

Izuku groaned as he dragged himself through the doors of Heights Alliance. He was absolutely exhausted. A combination of classes, training, and back to back patrols mixed poorly with chronic insomnia and anxiety. Add to that the new…development with his quirk, it was no wonder that Izuku felt as if he hadn’t slept in years. 

The green haired boy staggered to the common room couch and slumped down. He nearly missed sitting on Katsuki in the process. The blonde squawked, but Izuku was too tired to even apologize. He let out another groan, sinking down into the cushions below him. It felt as if his bones were melting, pooling underneath his skin and seeping between the couch cushions. It felt almost like a balloon deflating, a stuffed pillow losing the last of its stuffing. 

Izuku closed his eyes. The warm light of the common room filtered through his eyelids, painting his vision in glowing hues.

A broad hand brushed down his cheek before tracing the lines of his face up to his forehead. The palm of the hand pressed against his forehead. He felt the texture of the other’s callouses against the fragile skin of his forehead. Warmth spread from the point where they were connected. 

A gruff voice rumbled gently against his ear. “Shit, nerd. You good?” Izuku made a noncommittal noise, more focused on burrowing further into the warmth around him than replying to the question. “You don’t feel hot. Have you been sleeping enough?

Izuku’s eyes fluttered open at the question. He shook his head, the movement slow and laborious. Katuki frowned, leaning close to him.

“And why the hell not, Deku?” Izuku shrugged in reply. He let his eyes slide closed again, too tired to keep them open and also reply to Katsuki.

“Too many thoughts, not enough space.” He heard Katsuki hum in acknowledgement. The hand on his forehead fell away. Izuku briefly mourned its loss. Not for long, however, because Katsuki proceeded to pull Izuku to the side of his broad chest, a muscled arm wrapping around his shoulders. He melted at the sensation, slumping into Katsuki’s side. The rise and fall of the blonde’s chest was soothing underneath him. A hand came up, scratching gently at his scalp.

If he had been able to, Izuku would have started purring. Katsuki chuckled as Izuku wiggled in his arms. 

“C’mon, nerd,” he said, “Bed.” Izuku grumbled and pouted but allowed the blonde to maneuver him up and to the elevator. Izuku slumped against the wall, face half-buried into Katsuki’s muscled shoulder. The elevator chimed as the doors slid open. Izuku let out a long, exhausted sigh before shuffling forwards. Katsuki followed behind him. 

The keys in his hand didn’t seem to want to cooperate as Izuku tried to unlock his dorm door. After the third fumbling attempt at inserting the key that eventually led to them clanging against the floor, Katsuki snatched them from the ground before Izuku processed the situation enough to reach down. Katsuki pushed the door open and, standing behind him, grabbed Izuku’s shoulders and steered him to the closet. Izuku blinked slowly as Katsuki rifled through his things. His vision suddenly went dark and the feeling of fabric slid against his hair. He reached up and pulled the darkness away from his eyes to see that the blonde had pulled out a pair of pajamas for him to use. He felt the worn fabric as he slid his thumb through the shirt. A tiny smile made itself known on his face. He looked up at Katsuki.

“Thanks, Kacchan.” Katsuki flushed a tiny bit and looked away.

“‘S whatever, nerd. Just get changed so I can make sure your dumbass actually goes to bed instead of getting into yet another insomnia-induced anxiety spiral.” Katsuki turned fully away from him, reaching back and making a shoo’ing motion with his hand. Izuku snorted but began to change. Even the feeling of taking off his sweaty clothes and slipping into the softness of the proffered pajamas, was soothing, lulling him further into a stupor. The shorts he wore to bed - he was honestly surprised that Katsuki had remembered that he hated wearing long pants to bed - let the gentle air of the dorm air conditioner wash over his skin, soothing the skin that had been trapped in stuffy, uncomfortable, sweaty clothing all day long. Izuku let out a sigh of relief at the sensation. 

“You done, dumbass?” Katsuki barked at him. It might’ve just been the sleep deprivation, but Izuku thought that he detected a hint of fondness in the other’s voice. 

“Yeah, Kacchan.” Katsuki turned back to face him, rolling his eyes as he steered Izuku to his bed. The blonde flung his bed covers to the side and pushed him into a sitting position. Izuku sank down onto his mattress. 

The mattress itself wasn’t the most luxurious thing in the world, but at that moment it felt like heaven. He flopped backwards, barely summoning the energy to swing his legs onto the bed. Izuku let out a groan. His head flopped to the side just in time to see Katsuki turn towards the door. Something inside him ached at the thought of the other leaving. Maybe it was the lack of sleep, maybe it was the loneliness that he felt even when surrounded by other people, maybe it was the comfort that Katsuki’s very presence gave him. Maybe it was the fact that Izuku had a massive feelings-soup for the blonde boy and the lack of sleep had lowered his inhibitions. 

Izuku sat up and reached out, catching Katsuki’s sleeve in his hand. Katsuki stopped at the sensation, looking over his shoulder at the other. Suddenly, Izuku felt foolish. He flushed and looked away. His hand was still tangled in Katsuki’s sleeve. 

“Somethin’ wrong, nerd?”

“...stay with me?” Izuku’s voice was hesitant. His free hand rubbed distractedly against one of his eyes. Something in Katsuki’s expression softened. 

“Sure, nerd. Gimme a minute to get changed.” Izuku yawned, trying to crack his back as he stretched backwards.

“You can borrow somethin’a mine, Kacchan,” Izuku said. His words slurred together a bit. “‘F you can find something that can fit your dumb, Dorito body.” Izuku flopped back down onto his bed as Katsuki snorted at his comment. He drifted as the sound of fabric rustling filled his ears. After a few minutes, the sheets above him shifted.

“Shove over, nerd.” Izuku hummed and flopped onto one side. Rustling filled his ears once again before a heaviness descended over him. It was a magical feeling. 

Just as Izuku drifted off, he felt a warm hand brush his bangs back and lips press against his forehead.

“G’night, Izu.”

Izuku mumbled out something that vaguely resembled words before falling into the emptiness of sleep. 
    
Izuku blinked awake in the Vestige realm. Before he could greet any of his predecessors, a loud voice rang out.

“WHERE THE FUCK AM I?”

<<EOFANFIC>>

Deku merchandise is expensive, and hard to find. That’s to be expected of someone who has such a massive following. And as his #1 fan, that is a problem for Tomura. How else would he show his boyfriend support other than buying 

every. single. piece.

 of Deku merch.
 
  Tomura has it all, the shirts, the figures, blankets, plushies, 

body pillows, 

hell, he had all three of the Deku dildo’s that were on the market (none of them got his size right, always too long and not thick enough)

. 

If it has his beloved on it, he owns it, no matter how cheesy or low quality. He’s even gotten into dozens of bidding wars with the users DadMight, IcyHot and KingOfExplosions, three other hardcore Deku fans who seem to have his goal. 

Own all of the merch.

 
  This last bidding war, however, Tomura lost. It wasn’t even his fault, the power went out in his building, and he wasn’t able to place a bid in time. KingOfExplosions won, and he was gloating. He was posting all over his Twitter and his Reddit about the rare Deku merch he had acquired and how he had two of the one singular piece Tomura needed for his collection. 
 
  No, he isn’t sulking. He’s just…thinking. About how to get this piece. Murder was an option before, but Izuku put him under a strict “no murder unless it’s self defense” rule. He needs this piece, it’s the only one he doesn’t have.
 
  It’s a figure of Deku, but in his Sports Festival uniform from his first year at UA. The merch team had apparently been holding out on him, because Tomura had never seen this amount of detail in a figure before. The bounciness of Deku’s hair had never been captured right in figure form, always too still or too messy, but this was perfect. The pose was from his fight with Shoto, with his bruised hand in front of him, and his broken arm behind him. It was gruesome, but it was possibly the coolest figure of Deku ever. 
 
  Searching online gave him few results. It was an expensive figure to begin with, being 65,000 yen. But online sellers were trying to nearly quadruple that, and those were the cheap ones. There were very few listings, and each one was sketchier than the one before it. 
 
“Hey, Mura, what are you getting up to up there?”
 
  Izuku’s voice broke Tomura’s thoughts as he looked down. Izuku was sitting beside his gaming chair, leaning his head against Tomura’s legs, giving him ample space to run his hands through green fluff (with a finger cot on, of course). He had his Nintendo Switch with him, playing Pokemon or something, (maybe Stardew Valley?). 
 
“Izu, baby, your merch is cool, but I wish it wasn’t so expensive.”
 
  Izuku laughed, his entire body shaking as his laughter got louder, his switch tossed aside as his focus became entirely on Tomura, who leaned down to see and talk to the hero better. .
 
“Mura, I’ve told you before, you don’t have to buy all of my merch.”
 
“Like hell I don’t. How else am I supposed to show you how much I love you? You make me like something about heroes, and that’s you. I’ll get all of your merch, hell, I’ll get duplicates of every piece if I have to.”
 
  A quick kiss on chapped lips was the only response necessary to shut up the villain, a hasty defeat by the young hero.
 
“Tomura, save your money.”
 
~~~~~~~

  Bringing it inside his room made Tomura realize just how 

heavy

 a deceivingly small box could be. It had to weigh at least 40 pounds.

For My #1 Fan

 
  Excitement was a drug that was best supplied by Izuku. Always full of surprises and ideas that left Tomura breathless and craving more.
 
  The smallest box called Tomura the most, so he opened it first. He nearly dropped it when he saw what was inside. It was the figure, the one he had been hunting for. It was in the box, unopened, and signed by hero Deku, not Izuku. KingOfExplosions was going to shit bricks when he saw Tomura’s new collectible.

vibrating 

with excitement when he reached in to unbox them.
 
The middle box was next. It was lighter than the others, and had a note attached with tape.
 

This never got the green-light. I wish it did though. It’s more my style.

 
  A t-shirt. It was white, with simple black lettering. 
 
Deku Hero Merch Shirt
 
  Yet wrapped inside, was another figure of Deku. It was in a box much smaller than the others . He was in his first “pro-hero” costume and had face plates and interchangeable limbs to reflect when he broke his arms at the beginning of his run as a hero.

prototype 

piece. Something that nobody else would ever be able to own. This could never belong to anyone else but him. Something Tomura alone would have in his collection. He could feel tears begin to well in his eyes. 
 
His boyfriend was incredible.

Finally, the night before the date was supposed to happen, he couldn’t take it anymore. He texted Kirishima and practically begged him to un-blind the date and tell Katsuki who would be sitting across the table from him. But Kirishima wouldn’t tell him.This was new. He had been friends with Kirishima since UA (would even begrudgingly admit that Kirishima was his best friend, but not out loud), and Kirishima always knew when he was pushing Katsuki too far. This was the first time he had denied Katsuki something that he (thought he) needed. This must be a big deal to Kirishima. After a few more text messages attempting to blackmail Kirishima by threatening to tell Tetsutetsu embarrassing stories about him, Katsuki gave up on learning the identity of his blind date and went to sleep.The day of the date, Katsuki actually put some effort into his appearance. He felt jittery, and almost a little nervous, and he didn’t understand why. What was different about this date? Why was he worried about this one, more than any of the other ones? He managed to convince himself that he wanted it to be a good date for Kirishima, because he had been pining after Tetsutetsu since high school, and he put it out of his brain for a few hours.And then he was standing in front of a nondescript restaurant in downtown Musutafu, tousling his hair bit extra to make sure it looked just right. He took a breath, reminded himself that he was never nervous about anything, and went into the restaurant. Kirishima and Tetsutetsu were already seated in a booth - sitting next to each other - so Katsuki took the bench across from them and slid in. “Bakubro! Your date’s running a few minutes late, but I got his order so we can get food whenever you’re ready.”Kirishima was the same as always. Katsuki grunted hello to Tetsu and quickly buried himself in the menu, trying not to let his thoughts swirl too much. As much as he always presented himself as fearless and unshakeable, he was actually an anxious mess whenever he was confronted with something new or uncertain. And this was both. Who was his mystery date? Kirishima had said “his,” meaning it was a guy, at least. What if it was someone he already knew? What if they never showed up? Katsuki wasn’t sure which option worried him more, so he did his best to focus only on the menu, which carried the exact same Japanese fare as every other restaurant downtown. After deciding to get the same thing he always got, he joined Kirishima and Tetsu in their small talk, anxiously playing with the hem of his jacket underneath the table. He had always been able to keep his anxious tics subtle, but he was having trouble now. What was worrying him so much about this blind date? He had gone on so many of them before, and this was a double date, which should have made it less nerve wracking. He thought he would feel better after ordering, but having the menus off the table gave him one less thing to think about while he waited. Thankfully, it was only a few more minutes of painful small talk with the hardheaded idiots before Kirishima looked at the door, grinned, and said, “Here he is!” Katsuki turned to look at the door and his heart swooped and then fell in one swift motion. He recognized that messy, green hair, those freckled cheeks, those green eyes, the scarred hands - the man coming into the restaurant, walking over to their table, greeting Kirishima and Tetsu and sliding into the booth next to him, the man he was allegedly on a date with - was Deku.

_______"I'm sorry..!" The first words that no one should speak as a child, especially as it only earned them another thwack upside the head. Her mother should have been proud of speaking so clearly but for some reason it only made her angrier at the quivering and crawling child. "I fix, I fix mummy!" Those desperate pleads only fell on deaf ears as they covered their own face, now allowing tears to fall semi freely as 'mummy' finally walked towards the kitchen, phone still clinched just as tightly in her hand as if her life depended on it."Something had to have gone wrong, a quirk from our blood isn't supposed to leave them as fragile as this! How the fuck did she lose her eyesight from it?!" Very little could be heard from the other side of the phone as Jumika embraced the newfound darkness around her. It was almost peaceful, so why was mother so upset at her? Did she not like her quirk as much as she did? Was it not good enough? The thought made her shudder. Mother always told her no matter what 'gift' she was given, it would be perfect. It's just a simple water quirk that she hardly could even use anyways. "I could handle the cripple part. But this? It's too much. I already have Kit to change, bathe, and feed, but this? I'm not doing this au-"Silence. Just what was needed as Jumika finally found where the couch was, not that she could sit in it. Her little arms could hardly pick herself up from her wheelchair. But at least she found something familiar. "You'd… Do that? For me? Really? The great heroine thinks I need charity? And let me guess, I'll need to pay them to keep her as well?" Red watery hair wisped quietly at the conversation that its owner couldn't quite understand. Keep her? Keep her where? Hopefully somewhere better than here, but even if she couldn't see it, she felt her mother's gaze shift onto her as the sound of the phone finally being hung up caught her attention."You stay there." Her mother ordered, making the redhead nod quickly. Not like she could go anywhere anyways. Kit wasn't crying so she wasn't leaving to see her little sibling. No, the shallow but quick paced footsteps seemed to be heading towards her normally locked room.The sounds of thrashing made its way to the child's ears soon after. Was mother really that angry with her? Or was it something else? Another thought attack was bordering on the edge of Jumika's mind, but the turning of the front door thankfully pulled her away from such a thing. The sound was worrying for a newly blind child, but a gentle voice calmed such a fear along with the warm breeze from outside rushed in to greet the little ones still wet with tears skin. "Takeru? I may have broken the speed limit a bit but I was already a few blocks over so I thought it wouldn't be a problem." That voice had only been heard a few times in her lifetime, but it was one that Jumika would soon learn to trust with her life.But yet she couldn't call her auntie, only hum progressively loud until her mother banged on the bedroom wall. The pink haired woman was quick to flinch along with Jumika before making her way towards the 3 year old by the couch, making sure to bend her head to avoid hitting the doorway to the living room. "Hi sweetie! Momma is getting your bag ready I'm hoping huh?" The tall woman calmly spoke before leaning and attempting to pat the confused child on the head, only to be met with a groan and flinch of disapproval as the hand made contact with her wavy red locks. "Oh oh, I'm sorry, dear." The red mark on Jumika's forehead was beginning to bruise already, much to Nodoka's dismay. A part of her wished that she had come sooner, but family law was something ever someone like her was afraid to disobey during times like this.But this silence would continue for much longer as Auntie Nodoka found herself waiting as well for word from Jumika's mother. However long that would take…~°Small timeskip°~Finally, Jumika's legs were starting to feel phantom pain from sitting so long, but the joy in her mother's voice made it so worth it! Whatever could she be happy about though? "5 shirts, 6 pants, I don't know underwear count so don't ask, and I also packed a few toys so you don't have to deal with tantrums in the car. Here." By toys, she meant one. An old but soft plushie in the shape of a cloud that had a barely noticeable smiley face on it. One that Jumika immediately latched onto as soon as her mother threw it at her. A familiar feeling of home, and the last feeling she'll ever truly have of it._________

Chapter Text

 Fun story to break from all the seriousness of OFA & AFO, there’s a reason I never go on vacations: the first one ended up going so wrong. I’ve been on 1 in my life, which was a trip to Spain that ended in a lot of pain, paperwork, and me having to see a specialist from the United States. 

 No vacations. Never again… 

One For All, All For One, & The Knowledge of Two Kings: The Notes Of Enzo King
It was a typical day at U.A., and everything was surprisingly normal. The cultural festival had occurred the day prior, with 1-A’s band performance surprising literally everyone. Unfortunately for Romano and Enzo, they were busy dealing with a different issue at the time, with the sudden appearance of a certain Gentle Criminal near UA right before the concert, causing them to miss the early portion of the festival.The two foreigners soon ended up being bored (no big surprise to those who knew them), and decided to pay a visit to the 1-A dorms, to congratulate the students on their band performance. They had to omit the part where they had to watch an upload of the performance instead of seeing it live because of the incident, but nonetheless, the students thanked them for the praise. The two of them decided to stay and hang out with the class, with Romano relaxing on one of the couches, and Enzo chatting with several of the students. Eventually, the topic of the conversation changed to what the worst vacation each of them had ever been on.Several of them mentioned vacations where either they were bored the whole time, or a family member ruined it (or in the case of Aoyama, describing literally everything wrong with the United Kingdom, which ended up as a 5 minute rant). Eventually, the conversation went back to Enzo, with the Canadian-born hero only saying 1 word in response: “Spain”. Romano, who overheard their conversation, turned to glare at Enzo, before saying “remind me to dump you in Antarctica later”.Everyone was seemingly confused by that little interaction. From the reaction of Romano, the reaction to hearing the word Spain must’ve brought back some sort of bad memory for the Italian, however, they didn’t even know the context of what had happened. Enzo noticed the looks of confusion amongst all of them, and sighed. “I guess I owe you guys the story then. It all happened a year ago…”And this was the story he told…
 1 Year Prior… 
Enzo and Romano were bored. They were just finishing up some paperwork at “The Transferer Agency”,  which was Romano’s very own agency in Rome, a few days after Enzo got his pro license in the country. Unfortunately for the Canadian-born hero, he was involved in a grand total of 5 major villain attacks within the first 3 days of getting his license, and was slowly losing his mind.Romano soon began to notice the subtle shift in Enzo’s behaviour, and had an idea. “I know, why don’t we take a vacation? We could use a break from hero work for once.”Enzo turned to his uncle in confusion. “The fuck is a vacation?”. Enzo himself had been under decently tight management by the Polish Hero Federation until his 15th birthday, when he decided to temporarily relocate to Italy to work alongside his uncle. Prior to that, the only time he ever had off was limited, and even then, he wasn’t allowed to travel outside the city he was based in. Romano had decided to ignore Enzo’s reaction to his question, as he knew Enzo didn’t know what he was even talking about. “So is that a yes?”“Fine I guess. So what are we going to do then?”“Spain”Enzo soon glared at Romano, before saying “remind me to dump you in the Mediterranean later”.Now, Enzo’s opinion of Spaniards hadn’t been good up until this point. He had only ever met 2 Spaniards in his life, but he hated both of them. One was a hero-in-training he had met in the same program as himself that was an arrogant, egotistical asshole ( damn, that explained why Bakugo’s actions seemed familiar) , while the other was a supervillain that tried to kill him at an old airport in Warsaw.“So, yes?”“Yeah, I guess…”“Then it’s settled,” Romano declared, with a hint of excitement in his voice. “I’ve already booked the flight to Madrid for Sunday.”Enzo sighed. Sunday was still two days away, so it would give him some time to not only figure out what to bring, but also give him a chance to relax after the constant villain attacks he’d been through. “Let’s hope this trip doesn’t end up becoming a full-on brawl like Monza.”——————————————————————————————————————————Eventually, the two of them had arrived in Spain, at the Madrid International Airport, which had been built 30 years prior on the site of the old Madrid-Barajas Airport. By the time they had gotten there, Enzo questioned Romano as to why he didn’t just warp them there, to which he responded “I just wanted to see your reaction to modern air travel.”As soon as they walked out of the airport, they had already managed to catch three thieves trying to steal parked cars using their quirks. After that little incident, they started walking around Madrid, touring the city. Eventually, the two of them found the Estadio Santiago Bernabeu, one of Spain’s few surviving stadiums from prior to the dawn of quirks. After spending the day in the city, they decided to catch a high-speed train to Seville, with Enzo questioning why they were taking the train there the entire time. All Romano told him was that while it might seem pointless, they’d get to view more of the country. Eventually, they arrived at Sevilla-Santa Justa, the main railway station in Seville. As they started walking around the city, things went wrong for them again…
 KABOOM 
A loud explosion rang out a few blocks away from them. With the small mumbling of Romano saying “why today of all days”, the two of them found the site of the explosion. It was a decently-sized parking lot, which now had a giant crater on the inside, and the damaged remains of several cars. People were fleeing as fast as they could, however, the villain kept targeting random citizens.The two pros decided to try to restrain him as much as possible. They had deduced that the villain’s quirk allowed him to shoot missiles from his exposed skin. And since said villain was wearing a tank top, there was a lot of exposed skin. Within a few seconds, other pro heroes arrived at the scene, including Spain’s No. 6 hero “Señorita Roca”, who’s quirk allowed her to shoot large rocks at her opponents like bullets.Seeing as the other heroes had arrived, Enzo and Romano switched plans, from restraining the villain, to helping with the evacuation. Beside them, was a news agency, which while not seriously damaged, still had people in it. Enzo went in, to try to rescue them from the danger. As he got the last of them out, the wall beside him exploded with a familiar  KABOOM , and the wall & roof near him collapsed. Since the building was a few floors tall, a decent chunk of debris crashed down onto Enzo. He could no longer feel certain parts of his body, like his left arm, and his right leg, but he still tried to get out.He struggled continuously, losing the feeling of several more parts of his body, before fully losing consciousness a few seconds later…——————————————————————————————————————————Enzo woke up in a hospital bed two days later, casts surrounding a majority of his body. “Well this couldn’t have gone worse…”, he declared, as he stared at the wall in front of him. The TV in front of him was playing a replay of a soccer match from the day prior, a second tier match between Real Betis and Deportivo La Coruna, which Enzo somewhat appreciated. He was a soccer fan himself, and nearly quit his hero career to play professionally in Italy not even a year prior.Suddenly, a nurse came in. Enzo could barely understand her, due to her speaking Spanish, with the only things he understood from the original message being the words “news” and “completely destroyed”. He knew that a news agency was damaged during the attack, so maybe it had something to do with that? Around an hour later, Romano entered the room, with a look of pure panic. “Enzo, you idiot. Do you realize how much damage you’ve done to yourself?”“Not really,” Enzo replied. “The nurse was speaking in Spanish, so I couldn’t really understand what she was saying. All I really caught from her were the words ‘news’ and ‘completely destroyed’.”Romano sighed. He himself knew Spanish, so he knew how bad his nephew’s injuries were, but apparently, Enzo never figured out how bad it was (even with his body covered in casts). “Kid, the only reason you’re alive is that your quirk is literally holding yourself together. Literally. Most of your bones are heavily damaged, and they’ve recommended a specialist from the United States to fix them.”It took another week for the specialist to show up, and another month for him to fully recover. In that time, he ended up having to watch the UA Sports Festival from the hospital. The only thing he remembered from that year’s tournament was the intense quarter-final match of the second year Sports Festival between 2-A’s Nejire Hado and 2-B’s Mirio Togata, which saw the shock of the tournament as Hado eliminated Togata. When they arrived back in Italy, they simultaneously agreed to never do something like that again…“And that’s why I’m never going to Spain again,” Enzo concluded. “Any questions? No? Good. Anyways-”. The conversation continued on with random topics, eventually leading to Enzo showing off some of the scars on his body to the class at one point. After a few hours, the two of them decided to head back to the teacher’s dorms, in order to get some rest for the following day.Well, at least they now know why both Enzo & Romano hate Spain…
<<EOFANFIC>>

He gets some looks for the amount of stuff he’s carrying, but since he was the one to bring himself out the door, it’s not obvious why he’s out there. He ventures farther into the beaten down parts of Musutafu, and looks around for a building to take as a home. Can’t be homeless if you’ve got a place to go and it’s in a building, right? Whatever. He makes his way to a building that looks completely untouched within the last 5 months, and goes inside via open window. When his shift ended, he put his uniform in his bag and headed out for the café. It was 5 a.m. now, and he could head to the library before the café opened. And so he did. He sat in a bean bag chair in the back of the library, and opened his laptop, which was plugged into the wall. Today he was simply going to explore the deeper parts of the internet. It wasn’t a normal activity, per say, but living in an abandoned building wasn’t either. He had recently found a hidden forum on how to hack, and took free online coding classes. He’d like to think he’s proficient in it. He spent 2 hours in the library, then headed out for the café. From the library, it was only 10 minutes to the café. Once he made it, he walked in and greeted the cashier. The boy told him his name was Shinsō, and Izuku gave his name to Shinsō as well. It was perfect for his needed privacy.He began to upload his analysis. It was all transferred to the forum from his notebooks, but he takes pictures of the sketches. He sighed and returned inside. Ari sighed too, she was growing impatient as well. It's past dusk, where is he? Suddenly there was a shift in the air. A shift in energy. Ari looked to her side and saw a golden spark. It began to spin faster and faster until a sparking ring of light was formed. The ring's center glowed yellow and Ari watched as an arm shot out from the light. It was followed by another until a whole body stepped through, a man with toffee brown skin and bright amber eyes. Eyes that narrowed at the sight of her, "You're late," he said coldly."I didn't call you for a lecture," Ari retorted, "This way," she said, leading the man to the cave. She saw Sonic and Shadow standing protectively over the sleeping Silver, "It's alright. This is Xavier. He's one of the best healers in my guild," he looked from Ari to the hedgehogs and back again. She gave her father a look that said she'd explain later. He nodded, "Which one is the worst?”."Silver, the one asleep there. He's been out for a whole day and he's barely moved," her father nodded and walked up to him. Held his hand over him and it glowed gold as he activated his magic. Sonic lurched forward, but Ari grabbed his arm and shook her head, "Well?""Broken ribs and a concussion are his physical injuries, but his chi blocked. That's why he's been out, his body is trying to restore it. I can give it a boost and heal his injuries," and his gaze ran over the other two hedgehogs, "I can heal all their injuries, but they'll be restricted one way or another,"Ari looked at Sonic and Shadow, who looked at each other before nodding to her, "Anything to get going,"

The black hedgehog can run but if his ankle starts hurting he needs to stop. The blue one can also run but needs to take it easy with his arms, don't let him push it. As for the gray one in the back, he'll be awake in the morning, he has no physical restrictions, but he cannot use his magic. I was able to restore his chi, but it still needs to gather its strength,""But they're well enough to travel now?"Her father nodded, "Yes, however, there is another matter that we need to discuss. And you know exactly what it is," Ari cringed, "That's right. How long were you planning on staying here without sending correspondence? Without telling anyone what was going on?" he demanded."I'm sorry, but I couldn't! Jupiter has been up my ass ever since I found Shadow. He sighed, "Now, why do you have these creatures and where are you trying to take them?""Home," Ari said solidly, "I'm taking them home,""Why?""Because it's the right thing to do," Ari replied, "They were snatched from their home, brought here against their will. They need to go home, where they belong,""And where is their home?""South Island," Her father flinched, "No, absolutely not. You are not taking them,""I made a promise and I’m for damn sure not breaking it,""Aria, you know the law. No one under the age of eighteen is allowed to go off-continent," her father scolded."No, the rule is you can't take jobs off-continent. This originated here," Ari pointed out."Aria, the law is very clear and you know it!" he shouted, "You'll be breaking guild law!""So, what, you want me to walk in there and say, 'sorry, guys, but I can't take you back to the home you were stolen from because of a stupid rule, maybe in two years I can'?" Ari shot back, "Who are you going to send in my place, hmm? They won't trust anyone you send, not to mention I'm the only person in Mercury who has a contact who isn't afraid to take them there!" "Rules are there for a reason, Aria! Even if you don't like them, doesn't mean you should disrespect them!""If I wanted to disrespect them, I would've gone with Todoroki the second I learned they were leaving!" Ari snapped, "But no, I didn't. I stayed here because another law states that Life Quests take priority! Besides, I'm staying within continental seas," "But you're still off the continent, there is no way around it!""Then what about when I'm in the Valley, huh? Everyone on this side of the Northern Mountains considers it a separate entity. Another world entirely. So why is it that I can go somewhere that requires special permission, but can't go a hundred miles off the coast?""Because you have proven to have the skills to be able to handle anything you may encounter there, but you're getting off subject,""Oh am I?" Ari growled, "Then tell me if going off the coast is 'off-continent', then what about going to the other side of the Dividing Line?" her father blinked, "That river is connected to both oceans, making the southern half of the Valley technically an island. I already know you've made up your mind,""Damn straight, and there's nothing you can do to stop me," Ari glared and headed back for the cave."I wasn't trying to," she stopped, "I was trying to warn you that since you're going ahead with this, there will be consequences.""There is no punishment that she can dish out that I haven't already had," Ari retorted."I know, that is why this one is special," he walked over to her, "When you return, you will head straight for the Valley from South Island giving the Bakugo family the same treatment you gave Mercury,""Same treatment?""The silent treatment," Ari's eyes grew wide, "You are not allowed to contact any of them to tell them where you are or what you are doing,""You can't be serious! Everyone at the guild knew that much, can't he know?"Her father raised an eyebrow, "He?" Ari flinched, she wasn't ready to tell them about her last visit.Ari kept a cool complexion, "You know how protective he can be. Her father's gaze was thoughtful, "You wanted this scheme of ours secret and, for once, silence will destroy it,"He sighed, "Very well, I will speak to him. Go seek,"Ari watched her father step into the portal and it vanished, leaving her alone in the dark. She turned to face the entrance and heard a scrape. She sighed, "If you're going to eavesdrop, at least do it more quietly," she watched the edge as Sonic peeked out."Who was that?" he asked as Ari walked in, her eyes met Shadow's as she passed him."My father," she told him and started to sit on the ground when a grunt from Shadow caught her attention. He glared at her until she rolled her eyes and sat where he usually slept, "He was the only one I could call that wouldn't freak when seeing you,""And the whole thing about breaking rules?" Shadow asked pointedly."You heard the conversation," Ari retorted, "I'm not supposed to leave the continent until I turn eighteen, so I'm breaking rules,""And the punishment?" We've got a lot of traveling to do in the morning," Ari said, narrowing her eyes. The black hedgehog gave her a look that said he had questions but then closed them as if to say 'I'll ask later'. She sighed as the cavern filled with the sounds of sleeping breaths, making her feel alone as they slumbered. Alone to fight the worries as they slowly crawled back...I wonder what Papa will say...<<EOFANFIC>>
