Chapter Text

The Multiverse Alliance was officially 1 collective time-zone year old.

Formed after the multiple collisions of worlds across the multiverse, the Alliance was created to combat any threats that dared to invade the others, spilling from one to its neighbour. That and the fact that many residents simply enjoyed the cultural exchange and interactions.

Breakthroughs could be made for the daily lives of citizens, different kinds of magic and science flourished, and overall, the Alliance benefitted each world. The only regulations they had in place were that no worlds more than 100 years apart in relative terms could trade their developments, as to preserve the pace of development.

The Alliance was founded in the world of Heroes, serving as a hub and meeting ground for important meetings due to its wide accessibility, along with numerous representatives from the Bunker and Tree. But on the day it was founded, there was one that a number thought to have deserved a seat, but had to isolate themselves for the plan to succeed. That was Dr Kondraki.

Believing the Foundation would rather crack down and contain the entire multiverse than enter the Alliance, he chose to hide all traces of his interactions when he returned to his own world. Some others followed his example, and chose to hide the existence of a multiverse from their own worlds, like the Library.

And so, when coming and going to visit acquaintances across the multiverse were common, things were calm for a time.

—----------------------------------------------------

“EAT CHAINSAWS YOU SONS OF BITCHEEEEEEEEEES!”

Kondraki and his horde of butterflies grabbed the chainsaw loving co-worker by the arms and dragged him to their only chance of escape, which was hard when he was firing a physics defying cannon of chainsaws. 

“Bright! Get moving, you idiot!”

The Foundation was in shambles. Across the globe, humanity was snuffed out, as anomalies tore through all in their path. The Serpent’s Library was burned to ash, Cults of flesh and technology torn apart, and the humans who dabbled in the anomalous were utterly destroyed.

In this specific site, Dr Clef met his end by the talons of SCP-682, while Bright, Kondraki, Gears and Crow were locked into Kondraki’s personal office, alongside the dozen or so MTF and researchers they had managed to save. With them were also SCP-999, SCP-191, SCP-109, SCP-495.

“Kondraki, if you had a plan when you brought us here, I would recommend you execute it now.” Gears was nervous for the first time in anyone’s tenure in the Foundation, and no one could blame him. 

For the Devourer was free, God was dead, and the Scarlet King had arrived, to reduce their dimension to nothing.

“Give me a second, Gears! Where did I put that…got it!” Kondraki fished through his desk to find a hidden compartment, and pulled out a small remote-shaped device.

“That’s it? A television remote?” Crow’s dog mouth pronouncing human words would never get old with how it flapped about.

“Oh come on you old dog, you know nothing’s normal around here.” Kondraki pressed the button, and a hole in reality opened itself, leading to a normal looking city. The staff would immediately notice the presence of non-humans mixed in with the citizens, of which were beginning to take heed of the portal that had opened in mid air to a group of panicking guards and scientists. “Now get in!”

As always, Bright was quite eager, jumping through before looking back at the others with a disappointed look on his face. “Come on already! Any world’s better than this one!”

Gears shrugged, and grabbed Crow as he jumped through, much to the dog’s panicked yelps, then being shortly followed by everyone else. As 682’s laughter approached, Kondraki closed the portal.

“Whew. Haven’t been here in a while.”

“Kondraki, as far as you’ve gotten us out of the frying pan, are you certain this isn’t a fryer?”

“Looks nice to me! Great skyline and everything! And a flaming man!”

Flaming man? Kondraki looked up, and saw Endeavour scanning the crowd. He waved, and a look of recognition immediately came across the No.2 Hero’s face, as he came down in front of them.

“Kondraki?”

“No time to explain, Endeavour. We need somewhere for these people to live, liquid nutrients for the cyborg, and somewhere I can meet with the others. You bunch did go through with the Alliance plan right?”

Endeavour’s face scrunched up as the Foundation scientists gossiped in the background behind Kondraki. “...You have a lot of explaining to do.”

—------------------------------------------------------------

The Scarlet King laughed. The universe’s reckoning was at hand, and all of creation would bow to him. All else would be destroyed, whether they be mortal or god.

And yet, outside his knowledge, and his universe, another being watched him on a TV while eating popcorn.

“All will bow to the Scarlet King!”

“ ‘

All will bow to nemenemenye’

 Been there, heard that. Scarlet idiot is somehow the most annoying thing in the plan.”

The being stood up from their seat, black substance drifting from their form as they took a few steps to a nearby table. On it, a map was slowly updating, as a small crack began to form in between numerous circles.

“Move faster already, would you?” It traced a smoke-like finger across the gap, ever widening in between the many circles. “I have so much to do, so much more to manage.”

The being sighed, and with a wave of its hand, the TV, chair, and popcorn disappeared. All that was left was it and the table in a never ending sea of white void.

“Ah well. Don’t turn boring, you bunch. The madness has just begun.”

<<EOFANFIC>>

completion:
Chapter Text
The sounds of distant sirens and the bustling city life were used by shadowy figures to sneak into the dark corners and seedy alleys that most upstanding citizens of society tended to avoid or worse fear (with the right reason) as it was these locations that tended to be crawling with criminals and villains that slipped the eyes of heroes and law enforcement.  It was these places that Kaneki used to roam around the city, hidden from eyes that would seek to capture him. He had enough of people binding him down in chains. No matter which side of the moral scale they claim to fall under. Tonight was his feeding time, this time he could schedule the least amount of times he had to hunt long pig. Kaneki sneaked around, hidden under the city’s shadows, his nimble feet flying across the urban terrain. Ever since he became a freak of nature, a Ghoul with Rize’s organs, he had to adjust his eating habits, specifically the fact that he was now a cannibal.  Although can you really call it cannibalism if the cannibal is no longer wholly human?   However, since his arrival into this new world, that was in, his opinion -absolutely crazy.  Whoever heard of heroism be a career and not a title you earned?  This world was strange, somehow he could eat human food  (albeit only small portions.)  Which was a peculiar experience after years of being desensitized to the human palate, It was a strange sensation, akin to that of a twilight zone experience to take delight in eating his favorite meal when he was once a human  —Burger Steak with meat from an actual cow. Still, his body needed the Rc cells, through an unfortunate discovery where his body deteriorated and lost functionality from the low Rc cell count. Therefore human flesh was still his primary source of food. Unfortunately for him, there were no Ghouls here for him to cannibalize. It was difficult to tread this world with underground heroes lurking in the dark and villains looking to either kill or recruit him into their makeshift gangs with their ego forgetting that  ‘even monkeys can fall from trees.’ (猿も木から落ち) As he glided from rooftop to rooftop, making sure to stay near alleyways to allow both a high vantage point and an accessible way for him to fall from the roof and surprise his meal. A shriek alerted him to an alley closely situated near the territory of the straggling yakuza, the Shie Hassakai if he remembered correctly. Wondering if it was a wise choice to wander near Overhaul’s territory a second shriek had made him choose. 
 ‘Better for me to eat now or let daylight slowly rise.’ 
 Unfurling his rinkaku, his kagune wrapped around a fire escape staircase and used it to propel himself towards the sound. His kagune dissipated under a mist of blood and dropped on top of the roof immediately on top of the alley. Jumping down into the surprisingly clean alley  (well as clean as a dark alley could be) He focused on the man stabbing a woman’s face with his steel covered hand. Cracking his knuckles, he shifted into his kakuja form wrapping the man and the woman with his centipede kagune he unzipped his mask and started eating the dead woman first, the blood spilling everywhere and bones crunched with every bite. The man with the steel hands quirk yelled and tried stabbing his kagune. Kaneki paid it no heed, focusing on eating his current meal. The man currently trapped in the centipede kagune, tried to resist harder as he sensed that the man in the mask was nearly finished with his meal. “Get the fuck away from me you freak!”  The purse robber continued his efforts in punching and slashing at the kagune with his steel hands, however, this was to no effect as the masked man simply twisted his steel arms like moldable clay. “Argk!” An anguished scream erupted from the restrained man, blood and filth smeared across his face. Using his other kagune he crushed the man’s head. His struggling body became limp, steel reverting back to human flesh  (eatable) He ripped apart his head throwing it to the side and he tilted the headless body, grabbed it by the legs, and slurped the flowing sanguine ichor. The blood tasted foul, like curdled milk. Choking in disgust, Kaneki spits out the blood, throwing the body away dropping beside the dumpster with a sickening crunch.  ‘This world was like eating food blindfolded and one of the options was poisoned.’ Kaneki theorized that it was due to the quirks. Gives the meat an unpredictable flavor. Kaneki jumped up in between the alley buildings up into the roof, the rising sun peeking from the horizon. He kept running faster and faster, his rinkaku kagune jutting out and propelling him faster away from the scene of the crime and the yakuza territory. Luckily it seemed as though they didn’t care or bother to check on the screams near his territory.  ‘Must be a usual sound to hear around these parts or the citizens are used to heroes risking their lives for them to actually care.’ Kaneki mused, cleaning his face with a disposable wipe as best as he could so he could blend in with the late-night crowd without any of the patrolling heroes stopping him, or just suspicious people glancing anyway. He threw it in the garbage bin and jogged out of the place he hid in to walk with the crowd. “Over there! The screams came from over there!” 
 ‘Looks like the patrolling heroes finally noticed something happened.’ 
 As Kaneki walked, carefully trying to blend into the citizens and making sure not to attract attention, he sidestepped a couple of rushing heroes and police officers screaming for the crowd to move out of the way. He failed to notice a display mannequin’s eyes following his retreating back before the lively eyes faded into a plastic sheen.
<<EOFANFIC>>

completion: Haki walked around a small wooded area by the bar with Toga, finding the blonde girl’s presence to be somewhat soothing as they surrounded themselves with nature that persisted despite man’s best efforts. The sunlight breaking through the leaves overhead made Haki feel energised, and they felt more alive in the sun and surrounded by flora than they ever did inside the bar, the flowers growing on their hair seeming to brighten and look a bit less wilted as the teen took in the area around them with bright emerald-forest-jardin green eyes.“Haki-chan, you look like a little woodland fairy!” Toga smiled, looking far less crazed than she had a few months ago.The reason for that being that Haki had no trouble letting the girl take a bit of her blood every few days to sate her Quirk’s extra dietary requirements. The others living at the bar with them, upon realising why Toga wasn’t acting so crazy and bloodthirsty, had offered their own blood to help with Toga’s Quirk requirements. Some more reluctantly than others (*cough* Shigaraki *cough*).“You really think so, Miko-chan?” Haki asked, smiling and feeling their Quirk thrive beneath their skin despite them still not remembering how to use it.Toga grinned at the casual nickname, the way she did whenever someone she’d grown to genuinely care for referred to her as something other than her family name.“Course I do!” Toga laughed, and the two began engaging in a casual game of tag to get some of their energy out before they went back to the bar where the rest of Haki’s friends lived.The two were running around the trees happily, playing knife tag (Toga was ‘it’ currently) when someone gasped in surprise at something nearby. Haki paused where they stood, and looked over to where the sound had come from. A teen with messy dark purple hair and matching eyes, his pointy ears sticking out from the sides of his head enough to be seen.Jiki-senpai! Something from within the hidden recesses of Haki’s amnesia-ridden mind called out almost joyously.They knew him! He was someone from their past, maybe he knew what their name had been and how their Quirk worked.“S… senpai?” Haki said, tasting how the word felt on their tongue as they looked at the boy they’d known once but didn’t now.It didn’t feel unnatural, but it also didn’t bring any connotation with it like seeing the pointy-eared boy had. Seeing him had triggered something, a memory or snapshot or something that revealed to them that the indigo-haired boy was someone they’d known before they’d lost their memories.“Bura-kouhai?” The indigo-haired boy seemed to collect himself, staring at Haki like he couldn’t believe what he was seeing.Bura? Was that part of their name? Was it part of their family name or their given name?“Tag!” Toga said, poking Haki on the arm with the knife just enough for them to feel it.Haki didn’t take the knife, though they were ‘it’ now. The pointy-eared boy stared a moment more, and then Haki blinked and he was running off somewhere out of sight. One of the flowers in their hair that had begun looking more alive the longer they spent outside wilted a little, and Haki stared at where he’d been contemplatively.Something was wrong. That boy, Jiki-senpai, had looked at them like he was seeing a ghost. It did bring back to mind how there had been nothing on the news about them, or even someone who looked similar to them, being missing. There wouldn’t be any news of them being missing if people thought they were dead, and that boy’s reaction had made Haki reconsider that their new friends just hadn’t been looking in the right places for their identity. They’d been looking for a missing person report, but what if they should’ve been looking at death reports instead?“Haki-chan?” Toga asked, realising something was amiss with the green-haired teen.“I knew him. He’s part of my memories from before Dabi-nii found me.” Haki said almost airily, trying to figure out how exactly they’d known him and how he’d triggered whatever that was.Jiki-senpai. Somehow, Haki felt like they’d finally found at least part of the key to regaining their memories and finding out who they used to be, before Dabi-nii had found them on the ground in that alley and had cauterised their neck wound before they could bleed out and die.They wanted to remember, but they were afraid to remember at the same time. What if who Haki was now was entirely different from who they’d been before that alley? It wasn’t fair, but Haki wanted to remember at the same time they were scared to death of who they used to be. They’d looked happy in the photos that lived in their phone from before, and Sako had informed them that the ring they wore on the chain around their neck looked like it was handmade and had a high chance of being an engagement ring of some sort that they’d been given. Haki likely had a fiancé waiting for them, a fiancé that they couldn’t remember and didn’t know, a fiancé that probably wouldn’t want them anymore because they were too different from before they’d lost their memories. Dabi-nii looked sad whenever he looked at the burn scar on their neck from when he’d been forced to cauterise it so they wouldn’t bleed out and die in that alley, and Haki had taken to covering it up with a scarf that Spinner had made them so that he wasn’t forced into seeing it every time Haki saw the man who had saved their life.“Who? There’s no one here but us.” Toga tilted her head curiously, and one of her buns threatened to unravel.“He had pointy ears, and dark purple hair and eyes. He- he saw me, and he called me ‘Bura-kouhai’ , and he looked like he saw a ghost when he saw me. I- I recognised him, Miko-chan. I knew him.” Haki said, still looking in the direction of where Jiki-senpai had gone like he was going to come back any moment with the answers about their past that Haki both wanted and was terrified of receiving.<<EOFANFIC>>

Wounds that would call for real explanations.( It caused him to isolate himself.)The most damning of all Bakugou liked watching him cry………… He suspect it gets him hard.

completion:
Chapter Text
Dabi yawned for the third time in the last five minutes and hoped he didn’t straight pass out on the desk. The money counter was taking its sweet ass time counting the deposit for the day and Dabi briefly wondered if smacking it would make it go faster.He was tired and sore and ready to be anywhere but work. Don’t get him wrong, he loved being a tattoo artist. He got to come to work at noon, had the freedom to choose his own clients, and his boss wasn’t too much of an asshat. But he’d just pulled a ten hour shift and he was beat.When the god awful machine finally decided to work for its keep, Dabi wasted no time putting the bills in the deposit bag, filling out the slip and dropping it all into the safe for Shigaraki to deal with in the morning. He slammed the door with a little too much glee and headed out of the office.His mind wandered blissfully as he planned the rest of his night. Go home, grab some food, maybe draw for a bit... As he reached the end of the hallway, he could hear Toga’s high pitched laughing, which was nothing new. But what made him pause in his tracks was the new voice he didn’t recognize.
That damn brat better not have let another customer in, Dabi thought irately as he turned the corner. And when he did, he paused for an entirely different reason.
Because he certainly recognized the person sitting in one of their tattoo chairs, talking animatedly to Shigaraki.
What the hell is Hawks doing here? Dabi thought, momentarily panicking as he wondered what the hell Shigaraki could have been up to behind his back. I swear to god if that dried up little raisin gets me arrested…
But after watching the scene for a few moments, Dabi didn’t feel any better when he realized that Hawks was drunk out of his mind.“—and then just like make sure that it looks like me, mkay?” he was telling Shigaraki as he swayed back and forth in the chair, “Cuz like if it doesn’t it won’t work.”“Yeah, yeah,” said Shigaraki, “I can do that, no problem.”“Boss,” Dabi snarled, “What the hell is going on here?”Hawks looked over and Dabi froze under those sharp eyes. They looked almost… inhuman. A startling shade of gold and outlined in black with little markings. They were a little too focused, despite Hawks’ obviously altered state of mind. Then they landed on the staples on Dabi’s face.“Whoah,” said Hawks. Dabi swore Hawks’ pupils started to dilate, like a cat, “You’re like, so shiny.”“Uhh… thanks. Boss, what exactly are you doing?”“Hmm?” Shigaraki was busy setting up one of the tattoo machines he’d just put away, “Mr. Number Two hero wants a tattoo.”“Oh yeah!” Said Hawks. He practically vibrated on the seat, “I want a tattoo of my face!”“Tell him where,” said Toga, laughing into her hands.“On my face!”Dabi heaved a big sigh. He should have known the night couldn’t end all nice and quiet like he wanted it to. I’m blaming you, stupid money counter, “Boss, no,” he decided to take hold of the situation before it spiraled even more out of control, “You’re not doing that.”“What?” Shigaraki snapped, giving him a dirty look, “Why not?”“Besides the fact that he’s shitfaced? Boss he’s the number two hero. When he wakes up tomorrow and sees his ‘new tattoo’, he’s gonna track us down and sue the hell out of us. We’ll be lucky if we ever find work again.”Shigaraki paused to think. He looked at Dabi with what might be puppy dog eyes if Shigaraki weren’t… well, Shigaraki, “But Dabi,” he said, “It would be so hilarious.”“Yeah Dabi!” Said Toga, “When else are we gonna get a chance like this?”“Yeah Dabi!” Said Hawks, “Don’t be a fun ruiner!”Dabi glared at him, “You are coming with me.”Hawks whined as Dabi marched over and pulled him out of the chair. Hawks stumbled and would have flatlined on the ground if Dabi hadn’t caught him.After a moment of struggling, Dabi managed to pull Hawks into an awkward piggyback ride. Awkward because Hawks kept complaining the whole time and refused to hold onto Dabi’s shoulders properly. But also awkward because Dabi had bent his knees in preparation to use his legs to lift Hawks only to realize that… he weighed next to nothing.“Why… why are you so light?” Dabi found himself saying in disbelief.“Because I’m a bird!” Hawks said, as if that answered everything.“Right,” Dabi said over the sound of Toga’s giggling.“Where are you taking him?” Shigaraki asked, still pouting at his tattoo gun.“To the police station,” Dabi answered, “Then I’m going ho—“The air was knocked out of his lungs when he was suddenly thrust forward. He caught himself on the chair and whirled around to see Hawks landing a few feet away.Dabi's disbelief only heightened when Hawks pointed an accusing finger at him, one hand on his hip. Did he learn that pose from a comic book?“No! I’m not going to the police!”Dabi rubbed his face. Really, all he wanted to do was sleep.“Hawks,” he said, “You’re drunk. You need to go to the police—““No! Never!”Dabi was getting frustrated, “You’re a hero, why the hell not?”Hawks crossed his arms, “They’re tattle tails! They’ll tell the commission!”“And?”Hawks looked unsure for a moment, and Dabi hoped the bird would just come quietly. Then Hawks stomped his foot, “They… it’s all their fault anyway! If they hadn’t told me to date that stupid jerk… none of this would have ever happened!”“Ooh!” Toga squealed, “Spill the tea!”“No,” said Dabi. He looked back at Hawks, “Listen, you can’t stay here. We’re about to close. If we leave, you’re locked in until noon tomorrow. If you won’t go to the police, do you at least live around here?”“Umm…” Hawks looked up, realized he was inside, then looked out the window, “Yeah! I mean, I think so.”Dabi sighed, “Then come on,” he grabbed Hawks by the arm and steered him to the door, “Thanks for nothing, assholes,” he snapped at the two idiots.“Oh don’t be like that, Dabi!” Said Toga, “It would have been a great tattoo!”Dabi grumbled and stormed out.It was starting to get chilly at night again which Dabi was thankful for. He and his siblings had always done better in cold weather. Something about it put Dabi at ease, despite his fire quirk that might suggest otherwise. Still though, he couldn’t wait to be in his warm bed and dead to the world. Hopefully Hawks lived close.But after a few minutes of wandering, it became abundantly clear that Hawks had no idea where he was.Dabi tried to stay patient but it was very difficult when Hawks kept trying to poke his staples.“Will you stop,” he snapped for the millionth time, catching Hawks’ hand before it could get any closer to his face.“But I wanna touch!” Hawks complained, “They’re shiny and pretty!”That gave Dabi pause. What kind of idiot thought medical staples were pretty? A drunk one, he reminded himself.“No,” said Dabi, dropping his hand.“I’ll let you touch my feathers!”“No.”Hawks pouted, eyes so downcast he walked into a street light.After Dabi collected him from the ground, he looked around at the desolate neighborhood they wound up in and glanced back at Hawks, “Hawks, is this where you live?”Hawks looked around too, like he was realizing for the first time where they had ended up, “Umm… no.”“Do you know how to get to your house from here?”“I uh… no.”Dabi groaned in frustration and did what he should have from the start and pulled out his phone, “Well what’s your address? I’ll get directions,”“It’s… it’s a tall building with a penthouse. I’m on the top floor. Oh! It’s got a big balcony that’s easy to land on!”It was then that Dabi realized his mistake and he kind of hated himself for it. This idiot flew everywhere so of course he couldn’t navigate from the ground.Dabi felt like dropping to the street and throwing a tantrum but he was an adult so he looked around again, saw a familiar street and pulled Hawks towards it.“Come on,” he said, “I guess you’re sleeping over.”
<<EOFANFIC>>

completion: Sensei never celebrated Tomura’s birthday past that first year with him. He made it a big thing. A nice thing, a fancy thing. Expensive food, expensive gifts, big cake. Spent the whole day with Tomura doing normal things, even deigned himself to play a game or two. It was all a way to secure Tomura’s loyalty, of course, but that didn’t make it mean any less. (“See how much better things are here, Tomura? You don’t ever have to miss your old home. There’s nothing to miss. This is your home now.”)A birthday like that never happened again. Tomura tells himself it’s not a big deal. He doesn’t need those big, expensive things. Tomura tells himself it’s not a big deal.As the years go by, Tomura doesn’t even get that. On his first birthday with the League, he’s not expecting anything. Sure, Dabi’s birthday was a few months ago and they celebrated that. Dabi bitched and moaned the whole time, but he sat there silent and let them sing happy birthday over a cupcake with electric blue frosting. But Tomura stopped expecting things from his birthday when he was eight years old and Sensei didn’t say a word to him. So walking into the League’s new hideout to see the leftover streamers and balloons from Dabi’s birthday, and a sloppily made ‘Happy Birthday Shiggy’ banner made from spare papers all taped together all pinned to the wall, Tomura freezes. “Happy birthday!” Toga and Twice yell, throwing confetti at him. Upon closer inspection, it’s easy to see that the ‘confetti’ is colored and torn paper.“What.” Tomura’s voice is scratchier than it usually is in his shock. “It’s your birthday!” Toga runs up to him, barely stopping short of hugging him. They know how cagey he gets with touch, and are finally respecting that. “Don’t tell me we got the date wrong! Kurogiri said--” “No, it’s the right date.” Tomura just can’t believe they would do all this. Kurogiri, sure. But the rest of the League? Tomura doesn’t know what he did to inspire this kind of care. Not when he’s just gotten them beaten down at every turn. “Good!” Twice claps. “Who cares?  We decorated! Dabi and Kurogiri are baking!”“Dabi being able to bake was a surprise,” Spinner comes into the room with Compress, a plastic bag in hand. “Our dear flame user is full of surprises,” Compress says. He’s without his mask today, a rare treat he saves for special occasions. He smiles at Tomura, eyes crinkling. “Happy birthday.”It strikes Tomura that this is a special occasion for him. Tomura’s birthday is special. His chest aches with the thought. All Tomura has done for him is make him lose an arm, why would he--“Happy birthday, boss,” Spinner hands over the bag. Tomura takes it carefully between just a few fingers. “It’s not much, but we got it legally, so.”Tomura opens the bag, trying in vain to ignore the growing warmth in his chest. Toga is bouncing on her heels, Twice humming in excitement beside her. Tomura looks into the bag to see--Gloves. A pair of gloves.  Quirk gloves. For touch-activated quirks. Tomura had pairs of these before when he was younger. Sensei hated when he dusted things by accident. He wasn’t allowed to wear them often-- he needed to learn to control his quirk, it was for his own good. But when he was in the Doctor’s labs or sleeping he was allowed.  Encouraged. (“Don’t even think of touching anything without those gloves,” the Doctor would hiss. “You ruin one of my experiments and  you’ll be in the tube next.”“No more mistakes, now, Tomura,” Sensei would croon. “If you decay your bed again, you will not be getting a new one. You must learn to control yourself, even if you still have nightmares at your age. It’s a problem, but you must grow out of it soon.”)Tomura hasn’t had a new pair of these in a while. Not for a few years at least. “We noticed your old pair is too small,” Compress says. “A little worn down. You deserve some new ones.”Tomura swallows against the lump in his throat. He doesn’t deserve much. Not when he’s been such a failure of a leader. Not when Dabi’s neck still twinges sometimes from being knocked out during Kamino. Not when Compress’ arm aches terribly still. Not when the loss of Magne is still so fresh. Not when-- “If you don’t like them or they don’t fit, we can exchange them,” Spinner says when Tomura stays silent for too long. “It’s important that you like them and they’re comfortable.”“Thanks,” Tomura chokes out, just to get that nervous look off Spinner’s face. They shouldn’t be nervous about giving him a  gift. Tomura removes the gloves from the bag and slips them on carefully.Even if they’re too small, or pull at his skin, or are too tight, or too loose, or hinder his mobility, he’ll wear them. They were a  gift, and Tomura knows better than to be ungrateful for gifts. Besides, it’s not like he needs comfortable things. He doesn’t need things he likes. He doesn’t deserve--They fit-- well. They fit like a glove. “They’re perfect,” Tomura says. Softly but genuine. “Perfect!” Toga squeals. “Yay! We should go check on the kitchen. It’s a miracle Dabi hasn’t sent something on fire yet.” Toga continues to chatter and pulls Tomura into the kitchen. By his hand. Tomura almost hisses. Almost yanks his hand away. Far,  far away from any chance of hurting her. But he doesn’t. Tomura doesn’t need to. Their tiny kitchen is not on fire, but Dabi is muttering to himself as he vigorously mixes something. “Happy birthday, freak,” Dabi tosses over his shoulder as soon as Tomura steps foot in the kitchen. He examines Tomura closely for a moment, and Tomura is just about to snap at him before Dabi turns back to his bowl with a curse. He reaches for something, but Dabi grabs it too quickly for Tomura to see. Kurogiri turns from the stove. “Happy birthday, Tomura,” he says, voice full of the warmth his facial expressions could never show. But Tomura always knew. “Thank you,” Tomura replies. He thinks he means it. Tomura’s birthday cupcake has frosting the same red as his eyes. The candle barely survives the blue flame long enough for the League to sing happy birthday. He gets told to make a wish, but Tomura can’t think of a single thing he wants other than this. Other than for them all to be happy. Tomura knows the path they’re on is dangerous. They’ve already lost one member. They might lose more. The heroes put more and more focus on finding and stopping them every day. The League’s reputation waffles in the criminal underground between being weak and dangerous. The loss of All for One hit them hard. Ruining Overhaul gave them a leg up. Every day they don’t get caught is a miracle. Every plan they make that might work is a miracle. But right now, Tomura tries not to worry about all that. Right now, Tomura ends his birthday surrounded by his League. Tomura ends his birthday surrounded by his family. <<EOFANFIC>>

completion: It's another anniversary... Every time it rains, it's like the world itself is crying. Sure, it sounds strange, but that's reality. Every time he wanted to forget, the date was marked on his calendar with a marker as red as blood. And today was no different from previous anniversary days. He taught lessons in the morning, tried to relax in the afternoon, but could not, for in his mind kept swirling the image... the image of whose anniversary he was celebrating. And so it was every time.Aizawa didn't want to admit that he missed him as much as he did the day he lost his best friend under the rubble of a building. Of course, his pain was shared by Yamada and Kayama, but he was still hurt much more by the death.Still, he was there for him, and could have saved him, but he didn't see or react in time... which caused his best friend to lose his life. *Everything for Aizawa died that day. He felt he had no reason to live anymore. Of course, he stayed in the mental hospital at the time, for not only did he become hysterical in the face of tragedy, not only did he break his image as an indifferent and resistant guy, but... he developed a wild desire to cut himself in order to bring his end closer faster than he had to. His hands had been bandaged when he'd managed to cut them on the shards of an accidentally broken glass the first day. Thankfully at least he didn't cut them off at all. Before he got out of the hospital, they carried his water and food in exclusively disposable cups and plates with plastic knives and forks. As he got out, his tendencies didn't go anywhere; on the contrary, they increased. At home, he often cut his hands with box cutters, feeling the searing pain that distracted him from the thought that his friend was gone.Was his friend gone?Aizawa liked Shirakumo. He was like the sun to him, lighting his way. So warm and soft... as if he were ready to be covered. Shouta liked Oboro. They were best friends and perfect partners in battle. One distracts with his eccentricity and cloud cover, while the other finishes them off from behind, erasing the enemy's quirk. They went to practice together, and had been in a lot of scrapes together before.Aizawa always had some feeling in his soul that he could not describe in words. A pleasant warmth in his chest when he saw Shirakumo's smile that was directed only at him, as it almost always seemed to him. He skillfully hid his strange feelings, like all feelings in principle, behind a mask of indifference, and knew that his best friend could not read people like Yamada, for example. And now he wished he had talked to him about it.After months without Oboro, Shouta realized that he had simply been in love with his smile, his positivity, his desire to live... And now that had been taken from him.His sun had set over the horizon.*"Are you going to go to that place?"Yamada's voice caught Aizawa off guard. He was so engrossed in his thoughts, bandaging his arm for the umpteenth time, that he didn't notice his only close friend walk up to him. Hisashi put his hand on Shouta's shoulder, watching the bandages turn reddish. He knew what his friend was doing backstage when no one was around, but he still didn't understand how bringing pain to himself could somehow take his mind off the pain inside."Yeah. You know, Yamada, I always go there on this day.""Are you sure you want to go there?"Aizawa just looked Yamada in the eye, which made his friend let him go and let him leave the bathroom. It was hard to get his thoughts together before going, especially considering the circumstances. But he had to go. *The building had been rebuilt after the attack back then. At the time he didn't understand why it had been rebuilt, but over time he came to terms with it.Now he carries flowers to that house every day. He leaves them in the crack that they left for the memory of the tragedy, still, it is not every day that a student dies in the performance of his heroic duty. Aizawa always brought white lilies. He didn't know if he liked them, but he knew the meaning of these flowers. Grief.Of course, he understood that his best friend would never return. Still, it had been many years, and he himself had been to his grave. The little grave was a second place that reminded him of him. He went there every fifth of May to wish his best friend a happy birthday.But today was different."Hey... I know you might not hear me, Shirakumo... But... I just wanted to say that I'm glad you were my best friend. And even a little more than a friend."The wind seemed to carry his words into the clouds, trying to make his friend hear everything... But he wouldn't, of course. The dead don't come back.They don't come back... do they?*Of course, he was all needles when Aizawa found out the reason for his and Yamada's trip. They couldn't believe it, it couldn't be true... "I...I can't believe he...could be alive."Of course, for the most part, hope played in him that the man he loved might be alive, but given how many years had passed, that hope was like a bird trapped in a cage - small, barely fluttering and silent. He wanted to believe, he really did, and yet reality always put him on his feet.He couldn't be as naive as Shirakumo was.But here they were, sitting in front of the glass, staring at a shapeless figure covered in a dark haze. Aizawa thought it was even ironic that his name was Kurogiri, when his best friend's last name was Shirakumo. It was as if it was a spit in their direction.True, considering Kurogiri's character as well. His concern for someone so strong-that he was willing to be caught and even likely killed, but not to betray any of his loved ones, even if it was his mission- reminded Aizawa so much of Shirakumo that he wanted to scream.So he screamed. His heart and soul screamed, uttering all the pain he had endured over the years. He wanted to know if whoever was sitting in front of him was really just a walking corpse of his friend. And when Shirakumo's face appeared from under the haze, Aizawa felt his heart skip a beat.For the first time in so many years.Of course, he knew it wasn't for long, but the utterance: "Shouta" from Oboro's lips was all that could make the man weep. His eyes were ready to weep, he was ready to fall to the floor, but he had to hold on. He did not fall to the floor, but he did cry. He wept for all the years he had spent without him, for all the years he had seen the covered body in his nightmares, with the blood stain on the bedspread, for all the years he had whispered: "Happy Birthday, Oboro" on his grave, for all those years of leaving flowers...And for all those years of not being able to tell him that he loved him.As Aizawa and Yamada returned home, there was complete silence in the car. Until the moment Hizashi opened his mouth:"You loved him, didn't you, Shouta?"Aizawa was silent, but that was enough of an answer as Yamada fell behind, continuing to stare at the road.Would he believe it was possible to bring Oboro back? He did not know. He wanted to believe, especially considering what little Eri could do... But he didn't want to give himself false hope.Inside himself, though, he was holding out hope that his Oboro could return. He prayed that he could return... not so much because he wanted to be near him again, but because he might finally be given a chance to live the life that had been taken from him.Maybe... things would get better? <<EOFANFIC>>

You promised you’d be a distraction to let him take away Geten’s range advantage, although not much could help against his sheer power.Feeling as if a thousand paper cuts ripped along your skin in the falling snow, his beam pierced your abdomen. Uraraka, Bakugou, Iida, and Izuku all stood around you, with various degrees of concern on their faces.“Oi!  Idiot, there’s a big difference between being a hero and being a fool. I want to kick your ass some more.”Oddly, that was among the nicest things the blonde has ever said to you.“What happened to me?” You ask, “All I remember is throwing a shield out, then things went black”Uraraka flashed a concerned look to Iida, who gave her a nod,“Well, you kind of threw yourself in front of Gene’s attack to guard Deku. You’re my friend and I…” he hiccuped, tears streaming down his face, “I don’t want to see you die.”Despite Iida’s warnings, Izuku felt it necessary, he wrapped his arms around your body, pulling your chest in close to him.  “No one will ever hurt you again.” His tone suddenly became stern as his tears dampened your shoulder.While the piercing pain was present as he squeezed you tight, you also enjoyed the warmth of his embrace.  The ice on your skin made his soft flesh a delightful temperature, helping alleviate the constant stinging of Geten’s quirk.“Izuku…”. You began“Yes?”“Whenever I am not stuck in this,” you gestured to the gurney you were crumpled in “Can you hold me again?”A soft smile painted his face as he wiped away the tears, “Absolutely.”You let out a sigh of relief,  as he ran his hands through your hair, sitting in the chair next to your resting place.“Now,” he whispered into your ear, sending chills down your spine, “You need some rest, but I’ll stay with you until you fall asleep, okay?  And I’ll be here first thing in the morning when the nurses let me in.”He carried on stroking your hair as he hummed softly, lulling you into a deep sleep“You can rest now.”₊˚ ✧ ‿︵‿୨୧‿︵‿ ✧ ₊˚“Guess what day it is?!”  Denki beamed, carrying in a suitcase for your belongings, “You’re free from hospital jail!”The past month had been painful, from daily cleanings of the cuts to being poked and prodded for the sake of “research.” You rarely found yourself able to relax, but you knew that was about to change when you saw your best friend in the doorway.You slowly pushed yourself to stand at the end of the gurney, where Izuku immediately wrapped his arm around you for support.  You didn’t fully need it, as you had been working hard at physical therapy to get back to doing things on your own, but the softness of his sweater and the familiar scent was comforting.“Let’s get you down to the car, okay?  Mr. Aizawa called us a taxi to get you back to UA, and we made one of the common rooms into a temporary bedroom for you so you don’t have to deal with all of the stairs.  If there’s anything else you need we can get it too, alright?”You simply nodded, enjoying the normalcy of a conversation once again.  It hadn’t been long, and people visited you, but it felt nice to not be asked for your age, birthday, and symptoms once more.Denki rode on your suitcase down the hallway, “WAIT FOR ME, GUYS” he shouted, before sliding into the elevator with your belongings, “Kaminari is safe, home run!” He chanted, causing you to chuckle.The drive back to UA was uneventful, aside from Izuku blocking every time Denki tried to “Punchbuggy” you.  Once you were situated on the floor, wrapped in your blanket near the fireplace, a wave of exhaustion hit you.  Momo, having just helped you unpack your bags, noticed your fatigue, and quickly brought you a pillow and dimmed the lights.  But before you could fall asleep, you felt two strong arms wrap around your waist from behind, as a soft voice whispered in your ear“How does some extra warmth sound?  I wouldn’t want to break my promise to you.”  Izuku cuddled close to you, fulfilling the warmth on your backside that your front had the fireplace to provide.“I’d love that,” You chirp, nuzzling into the embrace, as he places a soft kiss on your shoulder.Never before did you think your quirk would be useful, never before had you thought you’d make friends, never before had you thought people would care for you in the way your classmates and professors do.  Alas, life is full of the sweetest surprises, and as you cuddle into the warmth surrounding you, you drift off into sleep, smelling the scent of the freshly baked cake Sato has made as a get-well present.“You are loved.”“You can rest now.”₊˚ ✧ ‿︵‿୨୧‿︵‿ ✧ ₊˚<<EOFANFIC>>

prompt: write a story about Haikyuu!!,  General Audiences Creator Chose Not To Use Archive Warnings Gen 僕のヒーローアカデミア | Boku no Hero Academia | My Hero Academia (Anime & Manga) Midoriya Izuku & Shigaraki Tomura | Shimura Tenko Shigaraki Tomura | Shimura Tenko & Shimura Hana Midoriya Izuku & Shimura Hana Midoriya Inko (mentioned) Midoriya Izuku Shigaraki Tomura | Shimura Tenko Shimura Hana Shimura Kotarou Shimura Nao Shimura Nana (Mentioned) Mon-chan (My Hero Academia) Sibling Bonding implied/referenced child abandonment not to Tenko he actually has a good life in this fic Short One Shot Happy Birthday Shigaraki Tomura | Shimura Tenko Hana is a good older sibling when she wants to be Good Parent Shimura Kotarou kind of he's learning Shigaraki Tomura | Shimura Tenko is Not a Villain Good Older Sibling Shigaraki Tomura | Shimura Tenko Alternate Universe - Everyone Lives/Nobody Dies Kid Fic Crack Treated Seriously Midoriya Inko is a Shimura Midoriya Izuku and Shigaraki Tomura | Shimura Tenko are Cousins
completion:
“Happy seventh birthday, little brother!” Hana shouts, throwing a rectangular-shaped present at him. It lands off course, hitting the side of his bean bag chair. Probably because his sister refuses to put their baby cousin down. 
 
Izuku was dropped off by Auntie Inko a few weeks after he was born. Their parents never told them why, only that their cousin was going to stay with them for a while. It must have been bad, though, because Auntie Inko still hasn’t come back a year-and-a-half later. 
 
Either way, Izuku-or Zuchan as Hana and he like to call him-has fit into their family seamlessly. Even their father has eased up on all his rules and restrictions, at least enough to allow them all to play heroes in the backyard and let Tenko have an All Might-themed birthday party. 
 
Their mom and father have tried to explain to them, Zuchan included, that he is their cousin. But it’s always fruitless. When it comes to Izuku, no one can remember to refer to themselves or others in the correct relation to him (“go ask your m- aunt,” he remembers his father catching himself. “Izu, your brother and sister-” he overheard his mom say.)




Sometimes, he secretly hopes auntie never comes back. 
 
He looks down at the present, pausing his video game. With eight fingers he picks it up. The wrapping paper is sleek and shiny, All Might’s catchphrase is printed in cursive writing across all sides of the package. 
 
Tenko rips into the wrapping paper, being mindful not to disintegrate the present. He allows the last of the paper to turn to ash and fall to his bedroom floor (he’ll have to sweep later, his dad might be scary when grandma is mentioned, but mom is scarier when it comes to keeping a neat house). He pulls out a brown box.
 
With a dramatic sigh that makes his siblings laugh, Tenko uses decay on the box. A piece of folded cloth falls into his lap.
 
“Huh?” He says, carefully holding it up. “What is this?”
 
“You don’t know?” Hana asks, sounding genuinely surprised. 
 
“Obviously not.” He tilts his head from side-to-side. It resembles a large, white curtain with a small golden chain connecting one corner to the other. 
 
It’s Hana’s turn to give a dramatic sigh, though only Zuchan laughs. “Tenko, that’s grandma’s cape!”
 
Fearing the worst, Tenko throws the offending item out of his hands. If their father sees-
 
“Father was the one that wrapped the gift, if 

that’s 

what you’re worried about.”
 
He sends her a skeptical look. 
 
Their father, despite how relaxed he’s become in regard to heroes, has held steadfast in his hatred of their grandma. It seems odd that he’d willingly give this to Tenko. He forces himself to move past his shock, in favor of asking another burning question.
 
“But…don’t 

you 

want to be a hero?” 
 
“Nah, I love playing with you and Zuchan, but I think I wanna be a teacher. Father asked me if I wanted it, and I said no.”
 
“Oh,” he responds, gathering the cape onto his lap. “What made him change his mind about grandma?” 
 
Hana shrugs her shoulders. “I have no idea. Probably hit his head or something. Or maybe he got replaced with a doppelganger.” 
 
Tenko shakes his head, giving his sister a double take. “Doppelganger?” He asks, standing up. 
 
“Mhm! Ava- the really popular girl in my class with a water quirk, told me that it’s really common. Everyone has one. One day you’ll just be minding your business, and your doppelganger will-”
 
“Kids, time for dinner!” Their mom calls. 
 
“Saved by the bell,” Tenko mutters to himself, petting his baby brother’s soft curls. A horrified look has taken over his angelic face. “Don’t listen to Hana, Zuchan, she tends to make stuff up.”
 
Hana looks absolutely indignant. She huffs, stomping her foot. “Do not!”
 
“Do too!” Tenko shoots back, hands on his hips. 
 
“No!”
 
“Yes!”
 
“Booger-eater!”
 
“Well, you used to eat crayons!”
 
“Nuh, uh!” Hana yells. 
 
Izuku looks between his two older siblings, like it’s an intense tennis match. 




 
“Yeah, huh, mom told me so!”
 
“Kids!” Their father calls up to them. 
 
Hana makes a noise that doesn’t sound even remotely human. She turns on her heels, leaving his bedroom. 
 
Tenko gives a small, reassuring wave at Izuku. He’s still too small to realize that their insults are all in good fun. But rest assured, one day, he too will be forced to partake in being insulted. 
 
Apparently it’s good practice in being humbled, or so Hana claims. 
 
Once they’ve left, he smiles down at the- no, 

his 

cape. His very first one! And this one used to belong to a real life hero! 





He hugs it close to his chest, bouncing in place. 





Wow! He can just picture it now, fighting villains and saving people. 
 
Even though grandma wasn’t the best mom, Tenko hopes he can make her proud!
 
-x-x-x-




“This is sooo good, thank you, grandma,” Hana says between mouthfuls of food. It takes exactly one disapproving glance from their father for her to shut up. 
 
“It’s no problem, dear.”
 
Tenko eats his gyoza, staying quiet. His grandma, Mako, makes the best gyoza. Something about it makes his mouth water just thinking about it. 
 
Izuku sits in his highchair beside him. Gyoza has been cut up on his plate into little pieces, along with a small helping of rice porridge. The stuff never fails to make Tenko gag, it looks repulsive. But apparently his baby brother enjoys it, so to each their own (he supposes). 
 
“Tenko,” his father starts, once dinner has been cleared away, “did Hana give you our present?”
 
Mon-Chan, who must have been sleeping somewhere for the last hour, brushes up against him. Casually and not at all very obvious, Tenko reaches down to scratch her fluffy head. “Yes, sir, she did.”
 
“And did you like it?”
 
He takes a minute to analyze his father’s words, trying to see if there’s a possibility this is a trap. Cautiously, he nods. “Yes, a lot, thank you.”
 
And, to Tenko’s shock, his dad gives a bright smile. It, in an odd way, reminds him of that photograph Hana showed him a while back. 
 
“I’m happy you like it. Your grandma would have wanted one of you to have it.” He looks down at the table, smile lessening a bit. “She would have been….so proud.” 
 
His mom pats dad’s shoulder. A calm presence, to their dad’s chaos.
 
Tenko can feel his eyes misting up. He wipes his eyes with the back of his hand. 
 
“Thank you,” he murmurs, because that’s all the reassurance he needs to continue on his path to becoming a hero. It’s not a “sorry” exactly, but it’s a step forward in the right direction. 
 
-x-x-x-
 
Later that night, curled up in bed, Tenko can’t stop smiling. 
 
Directly across from him, he can see his baby brother sleeping peacefully. The sight makes him smile even larger. He giggles, turning over to face the wall. 
 
This has to be his best birthday ever!
<<EOFANFIC>>

completion: He couldn’t be sure if it was the pain medication and antibiotics being pumped in through his lower back, or if it was the blood loss, but this hazy, warm feeling overtook his brain, reminding him of a time when he had chased this sensation regularly, and how different things contrasted from back then.Back then, barely an adult, technically dead to the world, and oblivious due to sleeping through his teen years, Dabi had nowhere to go and nothing to do. In his rage and sense of betrayal, he had burned down the facility that had housed other bodies meant to replace Tomura if he had passed or failed in becoming that old demon lord’s true protege. He was pretty sure the other kids were whisked out of there before his flames consumed them all, but he couldn’t be sure, and the fear and guilt had gnawed at him. He searched in vain for a way to survive, held together by the sheerest of spite, and it was easy for him to get swept up in the darker side of things.The various pills, powders, sloshing bottles, and dollars that had been passed into his hands for being a good boy for the clients was his synthetic joy, and it was much easier to earn than his father’s praise. In painful bouts of clarity, his heart was kept alight with the same flicker of loathing at his father that he saw in the news and media constantly. It eventually turned his fractured mind sour against his new authority figures that had been stringing along his naive, broken self, and well, he supposed they couldn’t take his heat.This place was different from the dark hotels, downtown club back rooms, and makeshift dormitory that he had usually stayed or worked in back then. The high ceiling and glinting chandelier stretched high over his head, and the refractions scattered all over the pale walls and white pillars, shining over the black and white marble floor while he sat on a medical tarp and a mat, the infusion numbing his already greatly reduced sense of pain while he watched pieces of severely burnt flesh being cut away by slender, gloved hands.He had insisted on being allowed to be awake for the procedure—his nerves were shot anyway—and he felt more fascinated than horrified by the way his unofficial surgeon peeled away blistered, stiff, and necrosed skin, eyebrows drawn together behind the plastic shield in extreme focus while he gazed down at his bandaged, singed body without a hint of disgust, fuschia-colored eyes narrowed. When he blinked, Dabi could see his long eyelashes flutter, brushing against the shield. They started out strong and black, but the tips turned white like a snow rabbit that hasn’t grown into its summer coat. While his nose and mouth were covered by a mask, he could imagine his near-red lips pursed thoughtfully, and he felt an unusual wave of calm wash over him, watching his younger friend remove dead tissue and soak up blood with sterile instruments and cotton before transferring it all into a metal box lined with a red garbage bag, meaning it was biohazardous despite the fact no one here really cared about infectious disease or blood-borne pathogens.“Alright,” the boy suddenly said, changing and replacing his double-gloved hands before reaching into a different cold box and raising a long sheet of pure-white skin and cutting it like one would tissue paper before gingerly spreading it over his right arm. “Since it was grown to match different areas of your skin, there shouldn’t be too bad of a rejection rate,” he commented, meeting Dabi’s eyes, a piece of pastel pink hair sneaking out from under his blue, plastic surgical cap. Dabi was unsure of where he had even obtained all the equipment, let alone how he had been able to grow custom skin for him in only a few days, let alone in such a massive quantity. Memories of the old villainous doctor entered his mind, and he stared at this boy, who, despite his evident knowledge and skill in a similar field, differed from him in every way.While Garaki was decidedly evil, uncompassionate, cruel, and ancient, Hanako was young and went above and beyond to help him simply because he considered Dabi his friend. His eyes shimmered with sympathy and concern. The skin that Garaki had used was likely obtained in horrific and unethical means that he had never allowed himself to ponder too deeply, but Hanako grew the skin from samples of Dabi’s skin. Granted, he had assistance in the process, but it still showed a lot of ambition and intellect, especially compared to Dabi, who had forgotten a majority of his sciences and mathematics from before his coma. “Organic, homemade skin,” Dabi murmured to himself, chuckling inwardly.“Are you okay?” Hanako prompted suddenly, his naturally soft voice further muffled by the mask.Dabi blinked, nodding, not bothering to reassure him yet again that he could barely feel a thing, turning his attention from his soft stare to the way he sutured the new skin into place, gingerly overlaying the muscle with the warm attentiveness that he was sure no one had shown him since maybe his mother bathed him when he was a toddler—not that he remembered it happening. Hanako wrapped his arm tightly in clean bandages, humming softly.The operation had been going on for several hours, and not once did Hanako pause for a break despite the heavy mental concentration it required. Dabi wasn’t sure why Hanako was even doing this. He hadn’t asked it of him. He was fine with being charred beyond recognition, looking even worse and inhuman than he already did yesterday, but seeing his father has sparked something in him, and he couldn’t control his anger or resentment. The burns were so severe that Hanako had acted immediately, and he wasn’t entirely sure why he hadn’t just left him to his devices the way everyone else seemed to.“Let me know if you need anything, okay?” Hanako urged, studying Dabi’s expression. “And if anything goes wrong, I’m not above knocking you out for your own good.” He shook the bag that was supplying drugs into his body emphatically, but it was in a manner where the line wasn’t jerked about and causing him additional harm.“I don’t need anything,” Dabi told him, “I’m fine.”“This whole situation isn’t something I’d categorize as ‘fine,’ but alright,” Hanako chided, and Dabi could sense the teasing grin he had on underneath his mask.“Can you take that off?” he found himself asking, and then blinking in confusion at his own question.“Take what off?”“The mask.”“...Man, do you understand how infection works? I worked hard to get this to be a semi-sterile environment-”Dabi, with extremely stiff, awkward movements, grabbed hold of the face shield and mask Hanako wore, tore them off, and threw them as far as he was currently physically capable, which was not very far, but both landed on the floor rather than the tarp.“What the hell?” Hanako grumbled, reaching for a new face mask, so Dabi spat on the box, causing the younger boy to pause and stare at him, blinking for several seconds while he mentally seemed to process what just happened. “Why would you do that?”“I wanted to see your face,” Dabi informed him.Hanako gave him a puzzled frown before sighing. “Fine, clearly the drugs are messing with your priorities, but honestly this whole thing is a disaster anyway, so fine, let’s throw caution to the wind and have me operate on you while I’m breathing all over you. Makes sense.”“Your voice isn’t muffled anymore,” Dabi pointed out, grinning, raising a burnt finger toward Hanako, tracing the swollen, black flesh over Hanako’s left lower jaw before abruptly losing consciousness.When he woke back up several minutes later, Hanako was sitting over him, having completed the new skin grafting, and Dabi smiled up at him blearily, thinking that he looked like the personification of Cupid himself in the haziness caused by the morphine in his bloodstream. “Hey,” he greeted.“Hey,” Hanako said back. “I’m finally done. Because of my ability, you should be able to start to use your muscles alright already, but that doesn’t mean you won’t need it. Only downside is most of your tattoos are gone now, but maybe you can get new ones someday? Anyway, please avoid using your Quirk too much. I’d rather not have to do this bullshit again. I made a cream that should help keep your new skin healthy–”Dabi blinked, noticing now that some of his haziness was not from the drugs still in his system, but from senses that had been dulled or dead for a long time. He could feel the cold air moving around in the room, the way the air shifted over his arms and throat. He could feel his neck, chest, and jaw expanding slightly with every breath and swallow. He could feel the soft cottony clothes draped over his skin like a light, comforting blanket. He could feel his hair touching his ears, tickling it. He felt a dull ache in his spine. He blinked again. He could feel. He could feel. He could feel.Almost on instinct, Dabi snagged Hanako’s hand, gripping it in his own, and he could feel the softness of his skin, the slight imprints of his fingernails against his palms, and the way their fingers interlaced, touching. “Oh my god,” Dabi said. “I can feel that. Like really feel that. It’s not just some pressure. It’s a real feeling, I can feel your hand. I forgot what that felt like, what that really felt like.”“What?” Hanako stammered, gently squeezing Dabi’s hand as he spoke.Tears sprang to his eyes—tears he hadn’t been able to produce for years because of how burnt the skin under and around his eyes had been—and poured down his cheeks. He could feel the warm liquid seeping past his jaw and dripping off his chin, making him cry more. “Sorry,” he found himself saying, “Sorry, I don’t know why I’m crying, Hanako, sorry. Thank you. I just forgot what that felt like.” He wiped his eyes on the back of his hands.“It’s okay,” Hanako said gingerly. “I understand it’s probably a little overwhelming right now, but you’ll get used to it.”Dabi nodded, wiping his eyes again. “Thank you,” he repeated.“Of course,” Hanako told him, grinning. “I’m glad you’re okay.”Dabi smiled back at him. “I’m glad too.”<<EOFANFIC>>

prompt: write a story about Haikyuu!!,  Not Rated No Archive Warnings Apply Gen 僕のヒーローアカデミア | Boku no Hero Academia | My Hero Academia (Anime & Manga) League of Villains (My Hero Academia) Class 1-A (My Hero Academia) My Hero Academia Ensemble
completion:
Chapter Text
     Shigaraki sits at the bar of the League’s hideout, tracing the patterns of the wooden countertop with one finger. Ever since he woke up that morning, he can’t shake the feeling that he is forgetting something. But after hours of wracking his brain for some hint of what it could be, Shigaraki is as clueless as he was when his eyes blinked open for the first time that day.      Kurogiri suddenly appears to Shigaraki’s right, visibly startling the puzzled villain out of his thoughts. “Kurogiri,” Shigaraki rasps, “I thought I told you to announce when you would pop out of thin air.”     “My apologies, Tomura,” Kurogiri states, “but you are beckoned by your fellow League members.”     "Beckoned?” Shigaraki questions, swiveling on the faded red stool he sits on so he faces his babysitter of sorts.“     "Yes, I can take you to them. It would save time.”      Shigaraki studies Kurogiri's vaporous head, looking for some sign that would indicate if this “beckoning” is a trap or not. The others like to pull the occasional prank. But Kurogiri wears no expression as usual and Shigaraki stands from his chair.      “This better not be a waste of my time,” Shigaraki mumbles under his breath. He steps into the warp gate that Kurogiri had summoned while Shigaraki was staring at him.     There is no fully accurate way to describe going through one of Kurogiri’s warp gates. Shigaraki explains it as a cold dark purple void, however, there is a vague sense of solidness to it, as if keeping whoever goes through it from being sucked into that void. Shigaraki can’t help but slightly shiver at the entrance to the purple portal but the sensation is quickly over once he arrives in a dark room.     Shigaraki is about to call out the trap when a light is turned on and the faces of the League of Villains are illuminated. “HAPPY BIRTHDAY!” they all shout, even Dabi joins in.     Toga runs up to Shigaraki, who is still standing where he was teleported to and hugs him tightly. Spinner and Twice closely follow, both holding multiple crudely wrapped gifts, with Magne trailing them holding a small chocolate cake with white frosting and silver sprinkles. Mr. Compress’s usual top hat is replaced with a small colorful cone hat and is currently off to the side of the room trying to get Dabi to wear a matching one. Twice, Spinner, Magne, and Toga are all wearing similar if not the same paper hats.     It dawns on Shigaraki that this is what he was forgetting about the whole day. It is his birthday! Dabi stops defending himself against Compress’s efforts when he notices Shigaraki’s shocked and realizing expression.     “Did you not remember your own birthday?” Dabi asks, tilting his slightly head to the side, allowing Mr. Compress to strap the hat to Dabi’s spiky black hair.     Toga pulls away from her one-sided embrace with Shigaraki and looks up at him. “That’s so sad!”     “Agreed, birthdays are important!” Twice shouts. “Villains don’t need to remember such trivial things!” Twice counters himself.     Shigaraki can’t help but agree with Twice’s inconsistency but he finds himself being pulled forward by Toga to a small table to the left side of the room. Shigaraki notices that the room they are in is a small storage space that the League doesn’t use all that often in their hideout. A pile against the opposite wall is the only remnant of the boxes and random items that once cluttered most of the room.      They must have cleaned it out, Shigaraki thinks.     Toga leads Shigaraki to a chair next to the table and motions with her free hand for Shigaraki to sit there, which he does. Mr. Compress walks over from Dabi to Shigaraki and turns one of his marbles into a birthday hat. He fastens it onto Shigaraki’s head despite the pale-haired villain’s complaints. The League, other than Shigaraki and Compress, set a few presents on the far side of the table, the cake right in front of the birthday villain, and a knife, a few disposable plates, and utensils next to it.     “Are you alright, Shigaraki?” Mr. Compress looks at Shigaraki with a worried gaze.     Shigaraki meets the magician’s eyes and gives him a small smile, making everyone slow down to see the rare occurrence happening before them. “Yeah. Just surprised you all did this… for me,” Shigaraki bluntly explains.     “Of course we did!” Twice and Toga yell at the same time, no contradiction from Twice.     “We care for you,” Kurogiri says from where he warped Shigaraki into the room.     “You’re our friend as well as our boss,” Spinner grins back at Shigaraki.     Shigaraki turns back to the arrangement of birthday materials before him and doesn’t bother to remove the tiny upwards curl his lips have. “Does someone want to cut the cake?” he asks the others.     “Wait! You have to blow out the candles!” Magne exclaims and pulls out three candles from her pocket. She steps over to the table and sticks the simple candles into the top of the cake. They are all different colors: one is blue, another is yellow with white swirls, and the third is red.     As Magne scoots away, Dabi comes over and sets only his pointer finger ablaze with his quirk and lights the candles until Shigaraki has a pretty decent-looking birthday cake with blue flamed candles sitting in front of him. He hasn’t had a birthday party or, really, a birthday with people he considered himself close to in years. Shigaraki is sure the others haven't either.     “Now make a wish and blow them out!” Toga squeals excitedly, jumping up and down with her arms crossed in front of her chest and hands squeezing her cheeks.     Shigaraki inhales deeply and after a second of debating what to wish for, blows at the candles. The blue flames wave wildly, as if they are dancing, until extinguished by the onslaught of air.     “What did you wish for? Don’t tell!” Twice shakes his hands up and down as an impatient child would.     “Don’t say, Shigaraki, or it won’t come true,” Mr. Compress warns as Magne once again steps to the table. She removes the melting candles and places them on a napkin she must have had in her pocket. Magne takes the knife and cuts the cake into even slices.     “I won’t,” Shigaraki reassures Compress. Plus, if Shigaraki told them that he wished that they could defeat the heroes without losing each other in the process, they might have lost confidence in him being a strong leader.     Magne hands Shigaraki the first plated slice of cake and Spinner has to hold Twice back from grabbing it out of the birthday villain’s hands. Soon everyone in the League, including Kurogiri who finally came over to join the festivities, has a slice of chocolate cake with vanilla icing and sprinkles. Twice eats his cake fast while everyone else takes it slower. Shigaraki takes a bit more time than the others since he has to handle his fork with only three fingers and his thumb. But years of practice and improvement help him both not disintegrate the utensil and eat quicker than he would have in the past.    “That was good cake! It was fattening,” Twice compliments and observes.     “Now for the gifts!” Toga leaps up from her place on the floor and bolts over to the presents that Twice and Spinner had set on the table. “Open mine first!” She grabs an object covered in newspaper comics and hurriedly places it into Shigaraki’s lap.      One by one, Shigaraki’s colleagues give Shigaraki their presents. He’s always gentle when he opens them, one finger constantly lifted in the air. Toga gifts Shigaraki a pair of mismatched cat socks, Spinner an empty picture frame for whatever Shigaraki wants to put in it, Dabi an old lighter, Twice a sleeping mask with eyelashes styled on it, Mr. Compress a new set of darts for the hideout’s dartboard, Magne a mini notepad and pen, and Kurogiri a black trenchcoat.     “Thank you,” Shigaraki rasps to his fellow League members.     “Just remember your birthday next time. And ours!” Twice advises Shigaraki. Mr. Compress nods and Dabi scoffs with a smile.     Unbeknownst to his friends, Shigaraki knew he would never forget their birthdays. And Shigaraki would never forget the best birthday he has had in years. 
<<EOFANFIC>>

completion: It was supposed to be a routine mission - just another day in the life of a hero. But things quickly went wrong, and before they knew it, Aizawa and his team were fighting for their lives against a group of powerful villains.The battle was intense, and Aizawa couldn't help but feel a sense of dread as he watched his students and fellow heroes being pushed to their limits. But it was Izuku Midoriya who caught his attention, as always.Despite being battered and bruised, Izuku fought on with a fierce determination that Aizawa couldn't help but admire. He was like a force of nature, unstoppable and unbreakable.As the battle raged on, Aizawa found himself becoming increasingly protective of Izuku. He couldn't bear the thought of anything happening to the young hero, and he made sure to keep a close eye on him at all times.When the mission was finally over and they were back at U.A., Aizawa found himself unable to shake off the sense of unease that had settled in his stomach. He knew he needed to talk to Izuku, to make sure he was okay.He found the young hero sitting on the roof, staring out at the city below. Aizawa took a deep breath and sat down next to him, careful not to startle him."Izuku," he began, his voice soft but firm. "I need to know that you're okay. That you're not hurt, physically or mentally."Izuku looked up at him, his eyes wide and earnest. "I'm fine, Aizawa-sensei," he said, his voice steady despite the exhaustion that showed on his face.Aizawa didn't believe him, not entirely. He knew how much pressure Izuku put on himself, how much he pushed himself to be the best hero he could be. He didn't want to see the boy break under the weight of that burden.So he did something he never thought he would do - he opened up to Izuku."I'm scared for you," he admitted, his voice barely above a whisper. "You mean a lot to me, and I don't know what I would do if anything ever happened to you."Izuku looked at him, surprised but understanding. "I know," he said. "And I feel the same way about you. You're like a dad to me, Aizawa-sensei."The words hit Aizawa like a ton of bricks. He had never thought of himself as a father figure before, but he couldn't deny the connection he felt with Izuku. They had been through so much together, and he knew that bond wasn't something that could be easily broken.As the days went on, Aizawa found himself spending more and more time with Izuku. completion: The sprinklers had just went off. The grass was sparkling under the street lights, the small lights leading up the house illuminated the wet sidewalk and you could see their silhouettes behind the curtains in the living room window. Your feet felt so heavy and your heart — God, the muscle felt like a boulder in your chest. Some strangers had walked out of the front door, you didn’t know them nor did they you, and you felt their eyes as they sidestepped you, nicely stepping off the sidewalk and into the wet grass to go around your frozen body, but not nice enough to stop whispering, “Who is she?” “She looks so familiar.”Did you look the familiar? Would they think so? There was once an imprint of your body, flattened in the grass. You remembered when he picked you up from the lawn so gently, so careful like you would shatter if he pressed too hard. He brought you inside, up the stairs and onto the bed. You remember the water running for a little while until it stopped and he passed under the threshold of door into the bedroom. He just stood there — staring at the ghost that had possessed your body. His lips moved but nothing registered in your ears. He’d said your name — without hearing him, you know. You had memorized his lips; you could speak to him with just eye contact — fuck there was so much pain in his eyes. You lifted your arms and he tossed your shirt into the clothes hamper and he flinched. So many new scars littered your body. His lips moved again and you felt a wet drop on top of your head. The war had taken such a toll on you both. He’d nearly died — please don’t leave me, you cried over his body when Edgeshot sat next to you. Katsuki’s head laid in your lap, your hands were covered in blood. You prayed to an empty to just let him live. Take me instead. You prayed and he lived but that night, sitting on the bed, sober enough to think about the water getting cold in the bathtub, you caught a glimpse of your face and you didn’t recognize yourself — you wonder if he did. You don’t think so. Sometimes you see him at staring at you like he’s trying to remember before — Winter was coming. You could feel the chill in the air and see the brown patches of the grass that was starting to die. You wonder why he still has his sprinkles set. Maybe he hasn’t thought about it — maybe he just wanted to keep it alive a little bit longer until the frost came and layered itself on the surface. One foot moved forward, the other itched to follow and the door opened. Red hair poked out, a smaller pink figure came a second after. They were giggling. Kirishima opened his jacket up for Mina allowing her to wrap herself in his warmth. They hadn’t noticed you and they both had blushes adoring their faces. Kirishima rocked Mina almost dancing in a circle when his eyes met yours. His mouth moved and you think he said your name by how Mina swirled around so fast he had to ground her. The smallest wave from you was the validation she needed to jump from the porch, her shadow dancing around in the streetlights before she pulled you in her arms. ”It’s been too long,” she cried in your shoulder and your arms wrap around her small frame. Kirishima disappeared back inside. “I missed you so much.” She squeezed you and started to pull away but you only held on tighter. “Not yet,” you whispered. “When did you get back?” she asked, rubbing your back. Yesterday. “You should’ve called me.” ”I slept at the cemetery.” The gravestones engraved with such familiar names — you didn’t mean to fall asleep really. Your throat felt raw from crying and Mina pulled back to look at your face. Her cold fingers soothed the puffiness under your eyes, still sensitive from the fabric of your jacket. She whispered your name and you shook your head. “I’m okay now — well better, I guess. It was nice — the rehab.” She nodded. She understood. Mina smiled, a sparkle in her eye and smoothed down your hair. She was the first person you’d said goodbye to — the second hardest. Your eyes snapped back to the porch when the door closed and there he was — the last goodbye, the hardest one to pull away from — the tear stains in his jacket, the crescent shaped marks in your palms. Katsuki said your name and Mina stepped aside, a hand on your back pushing you forward. He met you halfway and the two of you grappled each other. Your face tucked into the crook of his neck and shoulder — deep breathes ghosting his skin — his hand on the back of your head, making sure you’re there and you’re solid. “Do you want to come inside?” he asked, whispering and you nod. He pulled away but still close when he took your hand. He closed the door behind him. The house was warm and still buzzing with the energy left from your friends. He led you into the kitchen — there was various bottles of alcohol on the island, you noted. He did too and started to clear them away. He doesn’t want to tempt you. “Do you want some orange juice?” You nod. “I bought it for Izuku. Since Ochako had the baby, he doesn’t drink.” ”She told me she was pregnant the week I left.” Tears swelled in your eyes, you blinked them away before the traitors could fall. “So much has changed.” Katsuki looked at you then. He opened his mouth, but closed it. “I’ve changed. My face —“ you loosely gestured to the scar across the left side of your face, left behind during the war, “my heart has changed. I think it’s beating right now, but other times — I don’t know,” the tears invaded, “my soul — it’s so angry still.” His hand enveloped yours. Calloused and scarred but alive. “I haven’t had drink in six months.” The clocked chimed on the twelve. “On the dot.” You meet his eyes then. Those vermilion wonders. “I’m so glad you came to visit,” he said. “I’m glad you’re home.” Katsuki smiled and you gripped his hand so tight. He pulled you to him, cheek to chest, “Not everything has changed. You’re welcome here. I’ve been waiting for you to come home — for so long, I’ve been waiting. I knew you would.” You wanted him to ask more questions. Why’d you go? But he’s just looking at you, so lovely, so gently. You swallowed your words and look back him, trying so convey the same emotion in your eyes. It’s too much, you take a sip of the orange juice — high pulp. “You carried on without me.” You don’t mean it to sound accusatory, you don’t. “I didn’t,” he said, voice tight. “I missed you — so much —.” He doesn’t tell you how Kirishima and Mina found him, screaming your name in the streets, hoping you were playing a childish game of hide and seek. How angry he was when Mina told him where you’d gone because why would you tell her instead of him; why’d you trust her instead of him. But looking at you in that moment, his hands cradling your face, your eyes no longer bloodshot, cheeks full again, he forgave you. He’d always forgive you. “You did what you had to do. It’s okay.” It’s okay. “Can you hold me?” And he did. Carried you from the kitchen, up the stairs and through the threshold of the bedroom.
