completion: Quite frankly Katsuki had felt like shit all week. Final exams were right around the corner, and he was studying constantly, in the middle of a depressive episode no less. His mom had just cut him off officially after he had told her he had a boyfriend. On top of that he couldn’t see said boyfriend, since he was a member of the LOV. He was just so done, he wanted to do good, he wanted to BE good, but with all this shit how was he supposed to do that?Katsuki was sitting on his bed; it was too early to go to sleep, but he couldn’t work anymore. His thoughts were all jumbled, and he couldn’t get himself to even read a sentence from his textbook. So, he set his books aside and just thought. Rookie mistake, seeing as he was hyperventilating moments later. Everything finally caught up with him and he just couldn’t function. So, he did the only thing he could think of and stumbled over to the bathroom. There he opened the cabinet and fumbled for his razor blade and then he cut.He hadn’t meant to relapse; he really hadn’t but it cleared his mind. It made his loud stupid thoughts shut up, even if it was just a minute. And in some twisted way it made him feel justified. Like he had scars to show that he had been through something. That he was actually hurting and that mattered. He knew it was fucked but it was all he knew to do. Usually when he felt like this, felt like cutting himself, he would call Touya. Because Touya understood him like nobody else. Touya understood his anger at his mother, at the world, and even at himself. He could talk him down, hug him, kiss him, and most importantly really listen to him.That's what Katsuki thought about as he sobbed his heart out on the bathroom floor with blood streaming down his arms in angry red waves. He was going through one of the worst weeks in his life and all he wanted was one person, his boyfriend, and he couldn’t even have that. What was he going to do? Just sob all week? Call in sick and miss all his exams? WHAT THE FUCK COULD HE DO?You could kill yourself. Just get it over with alreadyA tiny voice in the back of his brain suggested. And for the first time in a long time, he listened. He grabbed the blade from where it had fallen next to him as he was cutting and brought it to his left wrist. He was just about to drag the blade over his skin and end his pitiful life when he heard his window open.“Kat? Sorry I didn’t text back; I was still out on my mission.” Touya's beautiful deep voice called out.Katsuki just cried louder when he heard it and dropped his blade. Touya noticed the, now loud, crying noises of course and rushed to their source. There he was greeted by his sobbing boyfriend on the verge of killing himself. He quickly grabbed the blade from next to Katsuki and threw it out the bathroom window.“Kat… Can I touch you?” Could he touch him? Was he kidding of course he could touch him. In fact, Katsuki thought he might die if he didn’t. But he wasn’t quite ready to speak so he just threw himself at Touya’s feet. Touya crouched down and scooped the slightly younger teen into his arms. They sat like that till Katsuki’s blood began to seep through Touya’s T-shirt.“Katsuki, darling, I'm going to bandage you up, ok?” Katsuki nodded slowly but didn’t make any move to get off Touya. So Touya simply picked him up, set him on the counter, and grabbed some cleaning alcohol and bandages from the medicine cabinet. He delicately cleaned his wounds trying his best to make sure it was as painless as possible. When he was done, he bandaged up his cuts and brought Katsuki to his chest for a long hug.“I love you Kat. I love all of you. I love your anger, I love your eyes, I love your body, I love that you’re gay, I love everything about you. And I know everything feels like shit and I can’t fix that but please, if nothing else, remember I’m here for you.”“Touya, I'm sorry. I love you too and I want to be here with you. I just... It’s so hard” Katsuki choked out.“Never apologize, I’m here for you and I care about you. So, what do you need right now?”“I… can you stay the night? Maybe we could cuddle?”Touya smiled, the kind of smile he reserved only for Katsuki and said, “I would love to,”With that he led Katsuki to his bed and helped him lay down. And then he lay down next to him and held him close, so glad that he was still there. He stroked his soft blonde hair and whispered to him all the things that were amazing about him. Whispered about how good he was and all the good things he was capable of doing. Told him about all the amazing dates they would go on and the beautiful apartment they would buy when they were older, and Katsuki had graduated. Told him just how much he mattered to him and more. And for the first time all week Katsuki smiled, sure this didn’t fix everything, he still felt pretty shitty. But he had remembered what it felt like to want to live.  He had remembered that he was in control of his life, and he remembered that he wanted to get better and that he could. There were people there for him, people who loved him. And that tiny little voice that wanted him to kill himself so badly did not define him or his life. He was going to get better; he was going to survive long enough to move in with Touya. He just had to get through two more years of school, and he knew with Touya’s help he could do that. So, he closed his eyes and let himself sleep in his lover’s arms.<<EOFANFIC>>

completion:
Chapter Text
After every death, Tenko's heart felt lighter. He watched Hana go, Mama go, Gran go, Pops go, and finally Papa go. He knew the intent he had when he attacked Papa. He wanted to kill. And he still wanted to be a hero. What a joke.
He had been bumping into people, something Papa told him was a terrible thing to do. 

.
.
.

Papa wasn't here anymore.
The realization was sinking into Tenko's heart, and he felt the itches start up again. As he scratched, he bumped into someone. Looking up, he saw an old man, with a cigar in his mouth and a beer in a grocery bag. "What are you looking at, kid?" He asked gruffly.
Tenko tried to speak, but it felt as though he was wearing an invisible muzzle, made by guilt.
"Get outta my way!" The man snarled, shoving Tenko to the side. One simple move of his hand and he could end this man.
He flexed his fingers, but he was on the ground and the man had moved away.
Tenko hated this. The bumping into someone, the climax of the itching, the flexing of the fingers- and the want to destroy. But then they would move away, and the itching would go down to a minimum, and he would realize what he almost just did, what he tried to do, how would he ever become a hero, he couldn't just stand there though, he wanted to destroy, the itching would stop, finally, anything for it to just stop, anything-




Shouta was, and always had been, a quiet child.
His parents were always busy, what with work, each other, or some unfathomable reason that they couldn't pay attention to him, so why make noise if he wasn't heard? He learned to control his breathing, to keep calm, to walk lightly. He was always sneaking up on the kids in his class, but they were just noisy. He was more able to keep quiet, that was all.
But his ears adapted to his change, and he could pick up on the slightest of sounds.
This was why, when on his way to Emi's house, he picked up on the quiet yet shallow breaths coming from an alleyway.
He paused, then ran into the allyway. There was a small bridge overhead, as this street was crowded and some walkways were on top of the buildings. But curled under the bridge, between two trashcans, was a child. Shouta thought they were only half his age.
He ran toward them, mentally noting the dried blood on their appearance. Shouta sat down infront of them, watching them look up with terrified eyes. They had grey hair, with bloodred irises and pale skin with grey dust all over, along with the rust color of dried blood.

.
.
.

"Are you alright?"
The child seemed to process these words at very low speed. After about a minute, Shouta asked another question.
"What's your name?"
"Tenko."
Shouta started to breath again. He was responding clearly, at least. 
"Good. I'm Shouta. Can you tell me where you are, and where you want to go?" Tenko's breathing was steadying, so that was a good sign.
"I-I'm in an alleyway, and... I-I was looking f-for help. I- I don't know where my house is, a-and it- it-"
"Tenko. Breath for me, okay? I'll take you to my friends house." It wasn't the best solution, but Emi was calling him over so they could do a snack party and watch anime, which meant her parents weren't home. It would have to make do.
"Tenko, do you know what a piggyback is?" Shouta asked, trying to get him excited. Tenko, however, was scratching his neck, panicking.
"NO! I-I'll hurt you!"
Shouta sighed. So, from what he had gathered, he has some sort of out of control quirk, related to his hands judging by how they were soaked in blood and he kept on wringing them. It also seemed to have an effect with dust, or powder. Well, he could fix that.
"Hey Tenko, you won't hurt me, my quirk does something special! For a short period of time, I can stop people's quirks! My friends house is just down the street, I can keep your quirk in check, I promise!" The effect was immediate. "Really?" Shouta smiled and nodded. His eyes glowed red and his hair floated upwards. Tenko gasped, realizing he couldn't feel his quirk. "Quickly! Lets gogogo!" Shouta said as he scooped Tenko up.
"Off to Emi's we go!" Tenko smiled. Mentally, Shouta noticed he forgot about itching.




<<EOFANFIC>>

completion:
The effects of Orobas Coco’s bloodline ability on a target were unpredictable. Those with strong wills could shake off the effects given that they understood their surroundings were no longer real. Demons who have experienced great trauma in their lives could be completely shattered by the illusions they see. Or, they could be liberated.As Orobos watched Suzuki Iruma amble through the cave with the small Nafra at his side, he wondered idly what this boy would see under the effects of his Trauma. His kind smile and seemingly effortless popularity alongside the rest of the Abnormal Class infuriated him to the core. He was not a demon who deserved what he had, and if he broke the principal’s grandson and won the Harvest Festival, he could prove that the Coco line was no longer number two. He would strike a blow for the little guy and prove himself once and for all.
With his mind overflowing with jealousy and hatred born of his inferiority complex, he steeled himself and channeled his ability to its absolute fullest at that boy. There was no way of knowing what he was going to see under the effects of Trauma, but as he watched the boy immediately falter and step back, he knew that it was working exactly as intended. The terror over his face was palpable, his shaking hands and ashen face filled Orobas with a peculiar feeling that he could not name.
Despite Nafra’s furious pulling, Iruma made one final step and fell over the edge down into the darkness below.To his right, Ocho was ecstatic. “So brilliant, you make me fall for you! Ocho’s so impressed!” The shorter demon jumped up and down gleefully with a sickening smile plastered on his face. In his mind, he knew Baal-sama would be thrilled with this development.
“Making him fall was an accident. He’ll be tormented by traumatic visions for the rest of the festival. Let’s continue on and finish this…” On that note, Orobas turned around and walked out of the cave with his victory in the Harvest Festival feeling far closer to reality than a daydream while Ocho merrily skipped along beside him.___Down below, each vision he saw under the effect of Trauma felt like daggers plunging into his body. Seeing his parents again after living in the underworld terrified him to his core. The thought that he would soon lose the bonds that he had formed here was too much to take. He was wholly unprepared for the heartbreak Alice and Clara’s words would bring him until they escaped their mouths. The two of them proclaiming him a traitor and a liar before turning on a heel and walking away turned his blood to ice.Ameri, Kalego-sensei and finally Oji-chan and Opera each took turns making his worst nightmare into a reality with their cruel words. Just when he knew he couldn’t take it anymore, their forms shifted into the monster that had caused him to fall off the cliff in the first place. With a final promise to take him home to his parents in the human world, the monster lunged and Iruma ran faster than he ever had in his life.Hiding behind a stone pillar in the cave, he attempted to soothe himself. “There’s no way that they would say those things… This is an illusion! It must be! I’m sure of it.” Attempting to calm his raging heart and breathing deeply, Iruma slumped against the pillar. Curiously, the leg that was bloodied by the fall was completely healed. He hadn’t even felt a twinge of pain when he was running from the monster. That was impossible. As soon as he woke up down here, the leg was positively throbbing with pain and bleeding. Could that have been part of the illusion too...?Running his fingers over the spot where the wound once occupied, the skin was smooth and unblemished. As he looked at it though, tears filled his eyes. The words spoken to him by the fakes had hurt him deeply. In his heart, he was now even more terrified of ever telling them
the truth when he escaped this. In that moment, he wondered if he was cut out to live in the underworld after all. Could Opera-san have been right? The thought made him clutch his chest as more tears silently escaped his eyes.The wound on his body might have closed, but the wounds left on his heart by the loneliness that he had felt every day in the human world felt more raw than they ever. In that moment, down in the bottom of the cave, Iruma felt truly and completely alone. He knew that there was no point in despairing, it wouldn’t help him out of this situation. But his head was beginning to pound in a way it never had before in his life. It felt as if he was splitting apart at the seams. Something in his mind was breaking, and he and no idea what it was.Knowing that the monster would soon be round the corner, he attempted to stand and soon fell to a knee. The sinister crawl soon shifted into a different sound – a sound that felt very familiar. Heavy, assured footsteps coming toward him like a predator closing in on his next meal. An intense frisson rocked through his body like a wave. His terror at hearing these footsteps was primal, and completely unavoidable. The sensation was different from before. Soon the footsteps stopped directly in front of him.He looked up and was met with a man in a dark black suit and a face that was completely covered in scar tissue. He had no eyes, and his mouth was stretched into a mocking smile. His aura was immensely strong and somehow felt familiar… Looking at this man and being crushed by his immense aura was enough to root him in his spot.
“Has my own child forgotten me so quickly? Perhaps I should have been stricter with you. To think that you would steal One for All and run away from me like that. I suppose gluttony does run in the family after all. You truly are my son.” The man’s words were dripping with his superiority and sent renewed chills down his spine. He knew that this man was immensely dangerous, but the proclamation that he was his son shook him for reasons he could not understand.“Who are you?! You’re not my father! He was just here, just now! I know you’re not him, you can’t be him!” He was worked up into a frenzy, with the pain in his head reaching new heights with every word.Ignoring him, the man continued. “I still remember when you awakened our quirk for the first time. At first, I had planned to steal it from you and give you something more suitable. You could have lived your life freely with a strong quirk and become the hero you always dreamed of being. But when I saw you steal your first quirk from that boy who bullied you so relentlessly, it was like looking into a mirror.”No longer able to respond, Iruma was forced to his knees and unable to control his body. His body felt heavy and the palms of his hands were itching painfully. Thinking that this was the end, he chanced one final look at the man to see his smile wider than before.
“There is no reason to be afraid, Iruma. You are the next me after all. My story may have been put on hold in the world above, but yours is just beginning! In this world of demons, a more perfect demon lord will be born. This is the story of how you become the greatest demon lord of all!”In that moment, the splitting pain in his head stopped completely and he felt more at peace than he ever had before. Lifting a hand to his face, he saw the hole located in the palm of his hand and understood what had happened. The real memories that had been sealed away by this man in front of him burst to the surface and the absolute fear that he felt just moments ago began to melt away. He let the hand drop down to his side and stood tall to face the man in front of him.
“I will never be like you...! I will laugh and smile and live my life normally here in the underworld with everyone no matter what! With everything I’ve got, I’ll beat you and become who I need to be with my own power!! You’re just a demon from my past. I’ll never be who you want me to be.”In that man’s eyes, there was a flash of some emotion that was difficult to decipher. Anger, pride, joy – they all blended into one. “You already are exactly who I want you to be. No matter what you do, a little part of me will always be inside you. At the center of all those quirks you stole, is me. Just as surely as those pathetic past holders of One for All live on in you, so do I. One day, you’ll understand that everything I built was for you.”Having heard enough, Iruma raised his hand to face the man and multicolored lightning crackled to life all around the arm. The quirks that had been utterly lost to him and sealed away by this man boiled underneath his skin. In order to make a point, he decided to use one of his favorite combinations to blow away this vision of the past.Bright red muscle fibers burst out of the arm to strengthen it, nearly quadrupling it in size to support the blowback. The muscles coiled and twisted all over the arm, and in an instant an enormous shockwave ripped through the cave and obliterated the man who called himself his father. In the process, the blast demolished a huge hole in the wall of the cave, bringing light to the darkness that he was trapped in. The immense stress of the encounters and the awakening culminated in his eyes rolling back in his head and passing out amidst the destruction that he had just unleashed.As he fell, Iruma felt oddly blissful. It was as if a huge weight had been removed from his shoulders. A part of himself that he did not know was missing, was suddenly nestled back into place and it felt so right. He hit the ground with a smile on his face.
A seemingly small action can have immense consequences, all it really takes is a little push to alter fate. One boy’s desire to win and assert his superiority over the abnormal class in the Harvest Festival had caused an awakening that would shake the foundations of the underworld. Whether he liked it or not, this would be the start of how Suzuki Iruma became the greatest Demon King of all.<<EOFANFIC>>

prompt: write a story about Haikyuu!!,  General Audiences No Archive Warnings Apply Gen 僕のヒーローアカデミア | Boku no Hero Academia | My Hero Academia (Anime & Manga) Welcome to Night Vale Midoriya Izuku & Dark planet Midoriya Izuku Not really a WTNV crossover I just thought "What if Izuku saw the dark planet" and boom this
completion:
It was late at night in the UA dorms, and Izuku was hunched over his desk, head supported by one hand while the other was holding a pen. The cause of his stress and lack of sleep was a simple assignment from Present Mic that was resting on his desk, still pristine as he hadn't even tried to start it yet.
The assignment was very simple; they were supposed to write about a constant in their lives and then read it out loud for the class. This way, the students would improve their writing and speaking in English while overcoming their fears of speaking in another language.
Midoriya had many constants in his life, including his quirklessness, bullying, and chronic pain in his arm and hands. "I could write about always wanting to be a hero," he mused out loud before discarding the idea. "No, that would be too obvious. Everyone will probably do it too..."
He stood up and started pacing around the room with Full Cowling at its minimum to keep himself awake. It worked, but no idea came into his mind. Frustrated, he ended up bumping into the shelf, causing a single notebook to fall.
"Ow!" he exclaimed, holding his shoulder before crouching to pick up the fallen notebook. The Hero Analysis in question was the first one he ever wrote on that fateful day when he was four. It was lying face down, open on a page, and Midoriya carefully picked it up from the ground and looked at it, expecting to see it crumpled up. Instead, he saw a drawing from his younger self.
The drawing was very childish; it pictured him as a stick figure looking up at something. This something was a large circular shape that covered all of the sheet above Izuku. It was impressive how dark it was for a crayon drawing, as if his past self spent a lot of time covering each white space with a black crayon.
It took Izuku half a second to realize what that meant, then he smiled and closed the notebook shut. "This is it!" he said, rushing to his desk again.

His hands were sweaty and slightly trembling as he walked to the podium. Present Mic was smiling to encourage all the students, but it did little to soothe his nerves. He placed his assignment on the podium and breathed deeply, imagining the looming sensation that was a constant in his life, and then he started reading.
“When I was four, I was misdiagnosed as quirkless. That day, I learned two truths. The first one was that not all people are created equal. The second one, however, was much more obscure. You see, on that day, when I exited the clinic, I saw a dark planet of awesome size, lit by no sun. An invisible titan, all thick black forests and jagged mountains and deep turbulent oceans.” His voice deepened and became monotone when describing the planet. “It covered the whole sky, and it was still so far away. So desolate. And so impossibly, terrifyingly dark.”
His voice returned to his normal tone. "I blinked, and it was gone, just like that. You may be thinking right now that this isn't possible and that I must be hallucinating. I thought so too, but it still kept bugging me, always in the back of my mind."
"The second time I was older, some kids decided to teach me a lesson, so they dragged me into the back of school and attacked me, several times," Midoriya spoke sadly, remembering his childhood. "They only left me when I was on the ground, fading in and out of consciousness."
"That's when I saw it again, that looming presence over me, covering the whole sky while perched on its sunless void. It called for me, not with words but with feelings. I thought that maybe if I lifted my arm just enough, I would be able to touch it. I didn't have a chance, as I passed out, quickly, after seeing it." Again, his voice took on that strange tone while talking about the planet. It sounded deep, old, and almost like several voices layered on top of each other.
"The two next times were quite peculiar because I saw them on the same day." Izuku giggled before continuing, but the fun part was lost to the class. "On this day, I was attacked by the sludge villain, and while he tried to suffocate me and steal my body, I saw it again."
"A couple of hours later, for reasons I won't disclose, I was on a rooftop alone, and with my dreams broken. It was so close that time,that I swear I could even see details on its midnight surface." Midoriya's eyes squinted, as if trying to see the details again.
"Were those cities that I saw upon it? Vast and cavernous cities? Empty windows and empty rooms. Alas, I feel like when I get the answer, it won't really matter anymore." He asked himself, trying to remember, "Anyway, I was almost reaching for it this time, and I only stopped because I heard Kacchan's explosions. And again, just like that, it was gone, and the sky was back in its place." He concluded, returning to what he had written.
"I kept seeing it more frequently after that. One time at Dagobah when a pile of trash almost fell on me. When I was free-falling at the entrance exam. At the quirk evaluation exam when Aizawa said I didn't have potential. At the USJ. At the sports festival, against Todoroki. In Hosu against Stain. Against Muscular and rescuing Bakugou later. On I-Island." It would be funny how he could recite all of these from the top of his head if he hadn't almost died in most of them.
"I think I saw it more here at UA than I ever did my whole life, but I can't find it to be scary. Imminent and foreboding maybe, but not scary. It feels like an old friend whom I haven't seen in forever." Midoriya's voice had a fondness to it like it would have if he was talking about any of his friends.
"And I know you guys might be thinking that I lost it. So, before I finish, let's do an imagination exercise with our eyes closed, please."
His eyes lost their light, and his voice became layered again, and all of Class 1A felt compelled, by something much more ancient, to obey. "Imagine there is a dark planet of awesome size, lit by no sun. An invisible titan with thick black forests, jagged mountains, and deep, turbulent oceans. It is so far away, so desolate, so impossibly, terrifyingly dark. And as much as we try to avoid it, we will go there."
"Imagine the feeling of the ground beneath your feet on that planet. The soft, cold grit of sand that once was rock, that once was mountains. You won't be able to see the sand. You won't be able to see anything except the faint glimmer of the stars." He described the planet for them to imagine. Before adding with his voice laced with melancholy, "There's always light somewhere, just not here."
He then began to ask himself, almost as if forgetting what he was doing, "What does it smell like on the planet, I wonder? The salt tang of invisible oceans? The bitter sap of ancient forest? I don't think it smells of rot. I don't think it smells of fire or food. I think it smells empty, like a home that you lived in for many years but have cleaned out and painted, and are standing in for the last time, and it is once again a stranger to you." He sighed before continuing, "Yeah... I think it smells like that."
Midoriya began to walk from one side to the other while speaking "Its orbit is wild, it serpentines through space. Even with the most powerful telescopes, we would not be able to find it. And yet, at some point, we will all see it, clear and plain as our own faces, in the blue of the sky," He stopped and looked up, never once changing his tone, "We will look up on a day where we had an assignment to do, where we had to patrol the streets by 4, where the sports festival was on down at the bar, and there will be a planet of awesome size, lit by no sun. Simple as that."
His tone became confused, and yet the layered voices on top of it couldn't be more certain. "I feel that I walked there once long ago. I know the bitter crunch of its lifeless soil. I know the ice fizz of the waves along its shores. I know the smooth glass of its mountainsides. The dark there is complete," Izuku's voice grew fond, and his eyes softened as he looked at his friends, "I wish I could take you by the hand, and together, you and I could step onto its surface. We could know it the way one knows a home. We could find warmth in its absolute chill. We could make light in its total darkness."
"But that won't happen. Because when we visit that planet, we each must visit it alone. But we can take comfort in those who have gone before, and those who will come after. There is a dark planet lit by no sun, and one day we will go there."
"Thanks for listening," Midoriya said as he bowed, his voice normal as if it had never changed.
After he finished, Midoriya felt tired, as if he had run a marathon. He didn't write that last part, and yet it still came naturally to him, for some reason. After Izuku recovered his bearings, he looked at the class and didn't expect to see everyone with their eyes closed still. Some, like Present Mic, were openly crying, while others were just teary-eyed. Izuku smiled at his friends. He didn't know if they had seen the planet too, or if it was just in his mind, but he could bet that they were feeling exactly like he felt every time he saw it. "Plus Ultra," he whispered to himself, returning to his seat and comforting his classmates along the way.





 








 



<<EOFANFIC>>

completion:
July 15th. July 15th, the day Midoriya Izuku was born into this world. The day when his life began. The day they would forever regret putting on the calendar. Life was great, to say the least. He had two loving parents, Midoriya Inko and Midoriya Hisashi. They were the couple their neighbors envied, the type one would put on the front cover of a magazine. They had been high school sweethearts and got married not long after graduation. They had a ray of sunshine as a child, father was the number 7 hero, Inko was a stay-at-home loving mother; life was... Well perfect. However, nothing lasts forever. That's true whether it's a relationship or a human life. It all changed in a matter of seconds. All because of an extra toe joint. ---“I’m sorry ma’am, he’s quirkless.” The doctor stated bluntly as if he hadn't just ruined a person's life.“Oh,” His mother said, looking shell-shocked. “A-are you sure? That has to be a mistake!”“I'm sorry ma’am but as you can see with these x-rays-” he said pointing to a small screen, “-he has an extra joint in his pinky toe. People with quirks only have one toe joint because, well how do I say this… they're somewhat further along in evolution. This is one way their bodies have adapted to be able to support their quirks”.His mother stared at the ground, picking up the toy her son had dropped. “Well thank you for the information doctor… we’ll be on our way” his mother said. His mother quickly grabbed her son's wrist and dragged him out to their car.“M-mommy that hurts…” the boy said to his mother quietly. She loosened her grip a bit.He slid into the back seat and put on his seat belt watching his mother shakily take the wheel. He looked down at his foot and wondered if he could still be a hero like All Might.He looked out the window and noticed they weren't on the normal route home.Shouta opened his computer, sighing at the new email from Tsukauchi.Another quirkless child had gone missing. Izuku Midoriya, quirkless, 4 years old, was reported missing by Mitsuki Bakugo. It was likely he had been missing long before she reported this. He was most likely abandoned judging by how he wasn't reported missing by his mother. Attached was an image of the child. A small green-haired boy was beaming at the camera face dotted with freckles. He sighed, adding it to his ever-growing file on the quirkless before he went to refill his coffee.Finally going on his break. standing in his kitchen sipping on his black coffee.“Finally, I thought you'd never come out of that office!” Hizashi shouted, laughing.“I Knew I should’ve put in my earplugs…” He grumbled. He sat down on the couch across from his husband. “So how’s work going?”“Another kid missing”“Any leads?”“No, but judging by his quirk status, he was most likely abandoned…”“Quirkless, correct? I swear parents these days, I don't understand how they can throw a child on the street”. Aizawa nodded and sighed exasperatedly. His husband, seeing his face, asked if they wanted to watch something together. They eventually decided on the news as nothing else was on. A man was reporting on a recent villain fight. He was probably going to have to do paperwork on this fight later—Suddenly screams from the TV shook him out of his thoughts. The villain had escaped using some sort of strength-enhancing quirk and had collapsed a nearby apartment building. 
 He was definitely going to have to do paperwork on this now… 
Izuku ran as fast as his legs would take him. His mother left him on the side of the road the same day he was diagnosed. He had been living on the streets for almost 6 years now, eating out of garbage bins behind supermarkets and cafes. The store owner had caught him and was chasing him, most likely using a speed-enhancing quirk as he was much faster than most people he'd met. with a quirk like that, he could be a hero instead of chasing a 10-year-old around, he thought while turning a corner into an alleyway.Every once in a while someone would give him something out of pity but it was rare. Most people either recognized the red shoes or just didn't care for some stray.He had tried to get into a few homeless shelters but would be denied entry after learning his quirk status. Nobody wanted him, not his father, not society, not heroes. Despite this, he aimed to go to UA, not that he had a choice when it came to colleges seeing as UA was the only one to accept the quirkless into heroics. He had heard from people that America was generally more accepting of his kind. He turned to see if he was still being chased but instead ran into a wall he hadn't seen.He looked around but was trapped in the alleyway. The store owner turned the corner and started making his way toward him. His attempts to climb the wall were futile as he was quickly grabbed and thrown against the concrete by the man. completion:
Even after everything he’s been through I’ve never found Kacchan to be any less beautiful than I did before. 
 
Underneath his angry exterior is a gentleness that only I’ve been lucky enough to experience. It’s like that side is reserved only for me. No one else knows that Kacchan likes it when I lightly trace my fingers up and down his spine when we cuddle, how he refuses to leave the house without giving me a goodbye kiss, or how he picks flowers out of people’s gardens for me on his way home from patrolling. Those little things have made me fall even more in love with Kacchan.
 
They also happened to be what I had thought of to try and help keep me calm as I sat in the waiting room of the hospital all those years ago. Kacchan was on overnight patrol when I received the call that he had been in an accident. 
 
I immediately rushed to the hospital but I was too slow. By time I made it there he had already been taken into surgery. I trudged into the waiting room and sat heavily, surrounded by people who were all anxiously waiting just as I was. Every time a nurse came through the doors we all looked up, just hoping they would call our name next. After the first two hours passed I stopped looking up. I didn’t realize how much time had passed truthfully but when I looked at the clock I had just passed the 6 hour mark. 
 

“Mr. Midoriya?” a nurse called from the door, looking around at all the people in the room surrounding me. After her second call I quickly jumped to my feet and practically ran to her. “That’s me. Is he out of surgery? Is he okay? Can I see him?” 

 

She politely held up her hand to silence my rambling. “He’s out of surgery.” 

 

“Can I please go back now?” 

 

She nodded. “His Doctor would like to meet with you first. I’ll take you to a consultation room and then afterwards he will take you to Mr. Bakugo’s room.” With a wave of her hand she indicated for me to follow her down the hall behind her. The hallway was dimly lit, the lights casting a soft yellow glow on the ghostly white walls and floors. We passed by 4 rooms before the nurse opened the door to the 5th. 

 

“Please wait here. He will be right in.”

 

She closed the door with a soft click and I was left to wait again. I leaned my head back against the wall, staring at the ceiling as my leg bounced anxiously. Thankfully the nurse hadn’t lied and the doctor came in just a moment later. My mind didn’t have time to wander like before. 

 

He gave me a soft, comforting smile. “Hello, you must be Mr. Bakugo’s…?”

 

“Boyfriend” I filled in for him. He silently nodded before taking a seat across from me. “Mr. Bakugo’s surgery was successful but there’s some things I think you need to be aware of before being allowed to see him.”

 

“The injuries he sustained were nearly fatal. Nearly his entire right side was damaged, mostly covered in severe burns which will leave behind some intense scarring. As a result of that, he also most likely lost his sight and hearing on that side. We won’t know until he is awake and we can do proper testing.”

 

I covered my mouth, trying to suppress a gag. I felt so sick to hear him say those words to me. He couldn’t be talking about Kacchan. Kacchan was strong and amazing and couldn’t be taken down by anything. I felt the tears slide down my cheeks, I didn’t bother to wipe them away. 

 

“We believe he will make a full recovery, outside of the sight and hearing that is. He will require physical therapy once he has healed enough.” He paused for a moment, giving me time to process. “He will need you. I felt it would be only fair for you to understand the entire situation so you can help him through it. Are you ready to see him?” 

 

I wiped away the tears and took a few deep breaths before nodding my head. He stood and guided me down the hall a few more rooms before stopping outside of his room. The placard read 
K. Bakugo.

 

I mentally prepared myself, slowly pulling back the curtain just inside the door. I could barely hear the beeping of the monitoring systems over the pounding of my heart in my ears. Kacchan was lying in the bed still sedated from the surgery. The doctor hadn’t been exaggerating when he said it was nearly his entire right side. I could barely see him under all the bandages covering his body. 

 

As I walked around the foot of the bed I found his left side to be littered in new bruises and cuts that had been freshly stitched. Seeing him like this was like a sucker punch to the gut even if I had been prepared. 

 
“Dinners almost done ‘Zuku” Kacchan called from the kitchen, pulling me from my thoughts. I had been sitting in the living room staring off into space, the All-Might documentary left unwatched. I padded across the wooden floors to where he was in the kitchen. His bare back was to me, putting all his scars on display. They were a deep pink color while the rest of his unscarred skin was pale. They were intensified under the bright kitchen lights. 
 
They wrapped around his ribs on the right down to his lower back. He also had them on his right arm and shoulder, wrapping all the way around the back of his neck. I could see them peeking out from his shorts on his right thigh and where they skipped to random places down his calf. 
 
I wrapped my arms around his waist and began to pepper his shoulders with kisses. I just wanted to be close to him, to feel him against me. Those memories of him lying in that hospital bed always put me in a bad state of mind and he was the only thing to reassure me that things were truly alright. 
 
“Someone’s in the mood” Kacchan purred. I pressed my forehead to his back, willing the tears to go away to not ruin the moment but it was no use. I sniffled quietly and I felt him stiffen in my arms. He moved slowly, setting the spatula on the kitchen counter before turning to face me, my arms still wrapped around his waist. 
 
I tried hiding my face against his chest but he cradled my cheeks in his hands forcing me to look up at him. “Hey, what’s wrong?” he asked softly as he wiped away the tears with his thumbs. I could smell the familiar sweet scent of the nitroglycerin. It reminded me of caramel. “I’m just being a crybaby. What else is new?” I joked before looking up to meet his mismatched eyes. His left eye glimmered its familiar red color, the right was now a milky white color. The scars stretched from his ear across his cheek to the corner of his mouth, stretching up to his hairline and down to his chin. 
 
“You’re not a very good liar” he chided. 
 
“I’m just- I’m really happy. That you’re here with me.” I stretched up on my toes and kissed him softly to reinforce my words. 
 
“You better not be blubbering over me” he half-scolded between kisses. This wasn’t the first, or going to be the last time, that I cried over those memories. They were the closest I came to losing him and I never wanted to experience that again. 
 
“I blubber over everything” I said, avoiding his accusation. I raised a hand up, gently cradling his right cheek. Even though he barely had any feeling he still leaned into my touch. “Ya can’t get rid of me that easy, nerd. I ain’t going anywhere” he said as he brought my hand to his lips, kissing the ring on my third finger. 
 
“That’s not going to help me stop crying” I said as more tears welled up from his sweet gesture. 
 
“As long as you’re happy then I don’t care” he said, pulling me close and kissing me fiercely. I didn’t need anything else in this world as long as I had my Kacchan. 
<<EOFANFIC>>

completion: The night was quiet Izuku supposed as he stretched out his joints, his patrol almost over.  It was close to time for the bars to let out too, but those out on a Tuesday night would be an issue for police officers mostly unless something startling crossed his path.  He wasn’t sure if he still had plans after patrol or if he would just be going home and unwinding, reading a book with a cat on his lap.Izuku sat down while he waited for either a text or an arrival, looking out over the city from his spot on the rooftop, considering how things had changed over the few years.  His work as an underground hero was going well, he’d connected with new people, and he was healing, moving forward.The phone in his pocket buzzed and he smiled, pulling it out and looking down at it, hoping it was a message to share plans were still on, though prepared for a cancellation if something had happened on his partner’s patrol.  But it buzzed again, and his face fell at what was currently flashing across the screen.  It wasn’t the word Dear with the little heart next to it.  It wasn’t a name at all, but a number from a previously deleted contact, a number that was still burned into his brain.Laying back he stared up at the stars, letting the phone continue to buzz, his heart picking up speed with each vibration until he knew it would eventually go to voicemail.   It had been months since his phone rang like this but the scene was still familiar, one he’d recognize if he answered.  He closed his eyes and could see him in a bar, the half empty glass in his hand as the bartender announced last call.How many times had he answered to hear those whiskey fueled words rasped through the speaker, ones of love and asking for him to come get him, full of the unspoken promises that they could work things out.  He’d go without question, find him there as the bartender was taking his glass, red eyes hazy with drink searching for him with a smirk and a, “There you are.”  And Izuku would forget the arguments, the issues, the way he was always made to feel like less.  He’d forget the texts he found to other men, the nights he fell asleep alone wondering if he’d wake up to the blonde there or to a cold empty bed.Their lips would meet and that moment would be an intoxicant causing his own personal bit of amnesia, painting a fantasy where he would think it could all be different.  That this time when they fell into bed, Katsuki would mean the words, that they’d wake up in the morning with the fantasy that he had imagined when they were young.The phone stopped, leaving only the buzzing in Izuku’s head.  He didn’t want to go back to that, he was happier now, happy not being someone’s last call when the night didn't go how they wanted, when the drink had gotten to them and they wanted something warm and familiar.  But the call brought up so many memories, ones that plagued his mind still of a relationship that both was and wasn’t; something long ended that he spent too long thinking he could fix, he could have again.Crunching gravel caught his attention and he glanced sideways, recognizing the shadow moving towards him.  He said nothing as he took a seat next to him, silver eye glancing over, the other covered with a patch.“Hey,” Izuku eventually said, setting the phone on the roof so he could reach out, so warm fingers could intertwine with his, grounding and familiar now.“Hey,” the deep voice answered back before the phone buzzed once more, Izuku glancing down to see the symbol for a new voicemail showing on the lit up screen  “You need to check that?” the man with him asked.“No,” Izuku let out a deep breath.  “I know what it says and it means nothing.  Not from him anymore.”“He called?” Shouta asked with furrowed brows.Izuku leaned over, pressing a kiss to his cheek.  “Yes, but I’m ok,” he promised, knowing Shouta knew about his prior relationship, about the words said and the hurt caused, about the years of being pulled back in just to be left again, the tears he’d shed, the pain he’d felt.  “Besides, I have something much better now.”Shouta shifted, looking at him carefully.  “Are you sure you’re ok?” he asked, voice calm, even as he brushes a green curl behind his ear.Izuku smiled at him, at the man who gave him space to feel, encouraged him to, who wanted him to be himself.  “Honestly, it dragged up a lot of memories, but it was thoughts about how many times before I would have answered.  About how miserable I would be every time I realized it meant nothing and I was living in some make believe world.  I’d rather be up here alone letting it go to voicemail than there.”  He leaned up and pressed a kiss to Shouta’s lips this time, soft and sweet.  “Though being here with you is an even better option.”“Then I’m glad I showed up.  Did you still want to get a bite?” he asked gently.  “Or we could go back to my place and watch a movie until you fall asleep on the couch?”“I will not fall asleep,” he laughed, sticking the phone in his pocket as he got up, falling gently into Shouta’s side.  “Maybe we can pick something up and watch a movie?  I’m not sure I’m up for going out.”“That’s fine with me,” Shouta promised, pulling out his phone to put in the late night order at the diner they were planning to visit.  Izuku sat there while he did, thinking for a moment how nice this was.  After graduation and years of doing his own thing, they’d met again as colleagues and moved quickly to friends.  It was six months ago when everything had changed; the moment he had let Shouta in this way, sitting on a rooftop for another night of pouring his heart out to the man.  When he’d admitted he was ready for something real.  “Food will be ready for pickup in 15.  We should head that way,” he offered with a smile and a squeeze of Izuku’s hand.It was so much more than a last call at a bar.  It was a quiet walk to the diner with soft talk about how their days went.  It was holding a hand that he knew would catch him if he fell.  It was curling into his side wearing comfy clothes, eyes already fluttering as the movie played on the screen, a steady voice teasing him lovingly for being a sleepy little kitten even as Shouta pulled a blanket up over them.  It was the way he could fall into a peaceful sleep, not a worry rolling through his mind about if Shouta would be there tomorrow.All thoughts of an unanswered call pushed away by the gentle care of his new love.*✭˚･ﾟ✧*･ﾟ*✭˚･ﾟ✧*･ﾟ*He was surprised to wake the next morning tucked into Shouta’s sheets, curls half spread out on a pillow and half in his face.  The smell of coffee fluttered through the apartment and he was certain after he’d fallen asleep on the couch Shouta had moved him to the bed then still been up before him.  He burrowed into the sheets a bit more, the scent of coffee, spice and smoke hanging on them, warm and comforting like Shouta once you got past the stern exterior he’d seen when he was younger.If his relationship with Katsuki had been explosive and volatile, something that would burn you down, his relationship with Shouta was a hearth: a warming flame, cozy, part of the home.  His home now.A head of dark hair poked into the room, “I’m making breakfast, it’ll be done soon.  You want to join me in the kitchen or bring it in here?”Izuku hummed, looking at him sleepily, “I’ll come in there or I may fall back asleep.”“I’ll call you when it’s ready,” Shouta promised, stopping before he turned around.  “I plugged your phone in for you, it’s still on the nightstand.”“Thanks,” Izuku called before reaching for his phone. Then he opened up his call log, staring at the missed call a moment before he blocked the number.  “Last call, Kacchan,” he said softly, feeling a lightness at closing that chapter.“Breakfast is ready,” Shouta’s voice called.“Coming,” Izuku responded, tossing the phone back on the nightstand and crawling from the bed to join his love.<<EOFANFIC>>

completion:
This had been a lot harder than he thought. When his mother left him, he tried to rationalize everything. He thought he could make money through a regular job, but no one would hire him. Then he thought he could feed himself by selling his skills, but no one wanted to hear what he had to say. Then he thought he could do odd jobs that no one else wanted; that would be perfect. No one else wanted those jobs anyway…but no one would hire him. There was a reason quirkless suicide rates were so high. 

Izuku would not take his own life, though. No, he fought tooth and nail to get this far. His mother may have given up and moved away. He may have been kicked out of his home; he may be running on just enough yen to get water and, if he was lucky, a bento box from the store. 

One meal a day was hardly enough. He was withering away into skin and bones. His features were gaunt from months of this hardship, and all he ever wanted to do was sleep even though his stomach ached for something- anything. Of course, for his one meal, he chose to have dinner of all things. It was hard to sleep on an empty stomach, so he at least tried to soothe the ache of hunger for when he most needed it. 

He took a large drink of water and then opened the scant bento box with two onigiri, fried pork cutlet, and veggies. It wasn’t a pork cutlet bowl, but he could still imagine it was. He missed his mother’s cooking. He wanted to hate her so badly for leaving him, but he couldn’t. Who would want a useless child like him? She deserved a child that was worth something, and he hoped she could find that. 

He picked up one of the salmon onigiris and let the smell warm his nose before he took a bite. He closed his eyes, savoring each bite before opening them again. It was hard to pace himself when all he wanted was a full stomach, but he continued doing this for the second onigiri as well. He hesitated when it came to the pork cutlet. Just looking at it made his eyes burn with tears for what he had lost. Regardless, he used his chopsticks to pick up a slice and bit into the slightly dry pork. 

He took a deep breath as he let the juices of the meat sink into his tongue and wash over him. Then he opened his eyes, and he was no longer sitting in a dark alleyway. He was sitting in a driveway with no food in sight. At first, he panicked, that was until arms wrapped around him, and suddenly he felt safe and, more importantly, warm. “What are you doing out here? Come have dinner with me.” a smooth voice said.

When he turned around, he saw a red and white-haired boy with eyes that looked at him like he was the whole world. He didn’t know who this person was, but somehow it didn’t matter. Whoever this was, it felt like he had known him forever. Izuku stood up, his body was no longer gaunt with hunger but strong, and he was tall, at least taller than he was supposed to be.

The mismatched boy slipped his hand into Izuku’s, hooking their fingers, and started toward a big beautiful house. It was a house Izuku could only dream of. The inside was far more beautiful than the outside, and the smell of a bountiful dinner filled the interior. He was led to a kotatsu in a wonderful, traditionally decorated living room where two pork cutlet bowls awaited them, along with an array of vegetable plates and drinks.

Izuku was impatient as he sat down and started to scarf down as much of the food as he could. It was as if all his manners had gone out the window the moment he realized he didn’t need to savor the flavor because there was so much food. “Slow down. You’ll choke.” The other said, their voice almost seeming too dreamy to be real. Was it real? Had he just gone through a daydream that felt too real? He wasn’t sure, and he didn’t want to think about it.

He ate his fill, humming in satisfaction before opening his eyes to see he was back in the alley and his bento box was gone. He stared down at the empty plastic box, eyes burning as he realized he had been hallucinating. His body shook with silent sobs as he dug through his pockets, pulling out whatever change had been thrown at him throughout the day. He had enough for another bento, just barely. 

He stood up and walked toward the store. His legs hurt, and his balance was nearly non-existent as he shambled along the road to his destination. He quickly bought a second bento and left, holding it close until he found another alley to get comfy in. Izuku repeated the steps. First, he savored the onigiris, then moved on to savoring the fried pork. He closed his eyes, let the juices wash over his tongue, and fill him with warmth once more. 

When he opened his eyes, he was back under the kotatsu, warm and being held. There was something he didn’t realize. He had been touch starved for so long that he could live the rest of his life in the arms of this strange but handsome person. He took a deep breath, shifting to turn around. His hallucination lover was very handsome, and his hugs were so warm. “I wish I could stay here forever…” he murmured, which was met with a smile and a hum.

“Why would you leave?” they murmured.

Izuku could feel himself starting to get sleepy and drift away. Why did he have to leave? Why couldn’t he stay? Maybe if he wished hard enough, he would be able to stay. “I don’t know…” Izuku replied with a soothing hand caressing his curls. 

“You’ve fought so hard…” the male’s voice soothed. “It’s time for you to come home. It’s time for you to be happy.” 
 
Izuku fell asleep, the empty bento beside him and his arms wrapped around himself. 
<<EOFANFIC>>

completion:
“I haven’t been sure if I should indulge talking to you.”Hikage spoke upward, while his back soaked in warmth from the rock beneath him. A dappling of light stared back, the sun somewhere up there behind the trees' infant spring canopy.“I think that… what I’ll do, is I’ll allow it once a year. I won’t expect it either, or require it; that might come with bad priorities. It’s just a limit. If it hasn’t been a year yet, then I have to wait, so that I don’t get lost in this kind of thing. It’s to keep from forming a habit that could convince me you hear me, even when I know otherwise. That would be dangerous,” said Hikage, and he swallowed. “But I think I have to talk, or I might stop knowing it happened."I was never like that before. No one in the world would ever confirm the things I knew to be true, but I didn’t have any problem surviving not talking. Things never felt like they were going to disappear, or like I’d question myself.“Survivor’s guilt is supposed to come. It actually hasn’t yet. I’m on the run, I am tired; for… at least two months, there hasn’t been a day on which I don’t fantasize about just collapsing instead of training; I have no one, and I’m glad I’m alive.“I didn’t have anyone before, either, and I never considered not wanting to live. There’s just so much death everywhere. You would think it would have occurred to me by now. I’m like a weed.”The light winked. There was just enough of a breeze for that. It poked its head in all through the day for just a couple seconds' visit and then stilled again, in and out.“If I’ve escaped that in all this time, then I suspect I’ll escape it for a while. I really am like a weed. I’ve only ever minded how people sneer. I’ve never minded it enough to want to stop growing, just to wish something would change in them.“I don’t wish I was where you are. I wish you were here.”“The gift you gave me has made Danger Sense stronger. If you were here, I probably would still ask for it, things being how they are. I would probably still ask for it. ...You’re better suited to training its strength, so I might try to let that last as long as it could, but I think a Danger Sense as strong as it’s become now is what we would need. Times being what they are. You always struck me as practical, and I don’t think I’ve ever thought of anything before you. You might have given it to me anyway.“You deserve to hear something from me, but I don’t know what.” His heart beat in the back of his head, the way you can feel it when it rests against things. Like the sound in bed, against a pillow.“I’m not strong enough yet,” he said. He talked with his hands now, as if it might add something, but it didn't help him articulate much, and after the experiment ran its course for the length of a couple sentences, he found he didn't need them to. “You didn’t think I would be by now, either. I’m ahead of where I thought I would be. I’m just acknowledging it. The hill left to climb.“You’re dead,” said Hikage. “I never said that. Other people have, you’ve been acknowledged. I hope they still talk about you all the time. I hope they’re still functional. I hope they’re still surviving more than I hope they’re still fighting. They would deserve to hide as much as I do, until we can win.“…But they’re getting us there, too, I suppose. Someone has to be fighting now, if things are going to get incrementally better. Even if they’re going to die for it.” Hikage pondered that, picked his nail over the texture of a very small crag filled with grass that he’d found. Tried not to pick any of it, just to feel. “And I have to live.“There’s survivor’s guilt, I talked myself into it. Is it…?” He flicked the cut grass away from between his fingernails, brushed held his hands up over the sun in his eyes in front of him. “Maybe this was a bad idea. But I do have to make connections that I wouldn’t instinctively make inside my own mind somehow. That one took me two years. It might have taken seconds if I had just talked sooner. Things are more obvious once you say them and need to defend them to someone else, even someone imagined.”“I’m— sorry. I’m sorry. I don’t think you’re imagined. Oh God, I don’t think you’re imagined. I am trying so, so hard to stay sane here, to stay ready, and to do that, I thought I had to— I’m sorry. I don’t think you’re imagined. What a horrible thing to say. I don’t think that.“You do know that I don’t actually think that, if you’re in me. I know that you most likely must. I’m still sorry. “Thank you. For being with me. I think that’s it, I’m done.” “I should have fought you,“ said Hikage. “You didn’t need to fight him. You weren’t going to win. I should have fought you. You should be here."I won’t give in that easily again. The next time I have a person to give into at all.” What he had sat down for at the start of this all was meditation, and he had only gotten partway into it before he stopped and followed this looping thought. So he sat back up, legs still folded full-lotus with the top of each foot resting atop its opposite thigh, and finished that. He closed his eyes, and let the sun bleed red through his eyelids. And when it was done, there was dinner to cook, and camp to finish setting. Hikage could always feel more sensations after a good meditation. The sun-soaked rock texture underneath the pad of his foot, the still-healing muscle he'd pulled in his lower back radiating a quiet sting as he finished standing. “Thank you. For being with me.”Things came to him as he was drifting off to sleep. We hold the card that matters right now. He hasn’t won, and he doesn’t know how. He doesn't know where it is. 
We’ll win.
That was good. Many of the things it mattered to say had eluded him. Half of those missed ideas and sentences he could have used were coming to him now, emerging with much more clarity. The words were already rearranging themselves and rearranging themselves now that he’d done it once.The last brief sprinkling of snow they were likely to get this year ended ten days ago. Hikage didn't know much about seasons, and he did remember that weather was all over the place and a bad way to note the date—there had been years when he didn't talk to other people about much except the weather, and it was always 'snow, really, this late in Spring?' or 'I swear, every year the rain comes sooner.' Still, though, he went ahead and used it to make note of the date.Next year.<<EOFANFIC>>

Chapter Text
Destroy, the voice whispers.The club lights are dim and colorful. They hide the way his eyes burn, always just a little too bright, hot as blue can be. As he steps inside, the smell of tobacco, booze and heavy incense envelops him. The one they’re burning is always eucalyptus.He’s not here every night, but he might as well be, with the way the bouncer has begun to recognize him, with the way the bartender knows his order of smoky whiskey sour without need for words. Tonight, he asks for something even stronger. It, too, burns going down. He dibs his fingers on the ashes on the burner plate, where the incense stick is still smoking. He draws a line over his wrist, rubs it in, orders a second drink.He finds Spinner at a table next to the dance floor, him and Magne both. She’s put in effort today, he can tell, and it goes wasted hiding in a booth like this. He sheds his leather jacket and joins them.“Dabi!” She greets him and has to half-shout over the music.“Didn’t think you’d show up before Toga,” Spinner comments. He’s got a beer, and by the looks of things, it’s not his first.“Toga shouldn’t fucking be coming here.” Dabi drinks and lets the liquid sit on his tongue. Its bitter taste is lost under how strong it is.“We’ll look after her,” Magne promises. “She won’t have nothin’.”“Like you looked after her last time?” Dabi glares at them. Last time Toga had ended up puking her guts out in the back alley, crying and laughing and stumbling like a shot deer. The memory stings.“Give her a break, man,” Spinner sighs, finishing his beer and staring at the empty glass. “This shit ain’t easy on her either. Fuck. This glass is filthy.”Spinner’s got a point. Toga is seventeen – the youngest of them all, and it’s not like Dabi wasn’t handling this just as badly when he’d been her age. In fact, he’d been worse off.Time passes. Dabi’s not sure how long it’s been. In the beginning, it always crawls. He’s bored. The dancers don’t interest him. He won’t meet their eyes or return their smiles. Then the alcohol begins to work at the senses and hours bleed into one another. Toga never shows up. He doesn’t know if he should be worried or not. It happens so often now that he’s becoming numb to that too. Magne is different. She stands up and leaves the club to find her. Dabi doesn’t think she’ll succeed. Toga could be anywhere, and it’s not like she always wants to be found.Destroy, it whispers again. His head hurts, and he rubs his temples with his fingers. The ash on his skin has ceased to soothe it, then.“Fuck,” he hisses, and Spinner gives him an understanding look. “Give me a minute.”Dabi stands up and stalks to the bathroom. He hates touching anything there, knowing damn well that they don’t clean anything here properly, but he needs to collect himself. The light in the toilet is deep blue to discourage using anything stronger, but even in this light, he can see his eyes burn a brighter blue. He grits his teeth. He can feel how the fire inside tears at his already scarred skin, begging for him to let it out.He stares at the scarring on his arm darkly. It climbs past his wrist, ruins his palm, the back of his hand. It’s all his fucking fault. I’ll kill him for this.Kill, the voice agrees. It just doesn’t care about whom.The burn that alcohol brings stopped soothing it when Dabi was nineteen. No matter how much more he drank, it wouldn’t fool it anymore. Now booze only soothes him with its familiarity. Sometimes he flicks matches, watches them light up and flip in the air and go out on the ground. Sometimes he takes out a lighter and burns himself. Ash helps too, but only for a while.Cigarettes still work, even though he’s smoked for as long as he’s drunk. Maybe it’s because there’s real fire and smoke. And Dabi does not want to set the club ablaze, no matter how grimy it is.So he steps out the back door into the rainy, cold November. Whatever snow had been there yesterday has melted into a dirty slosh that slips in through the worn heel of his left shoe and wets his sock. Dabi leans against the brick wall of the building next to them and lights a cigarette, drawing in the smoke, letting it sit in his lungs. Usually that calms the thing inside him, if just enough to put the inevitable off for another night. Right now, though, for some reason, it’s not really doing it. Maybe he just needs to smoke another after this one. Dabi exhales. Wisps of smoke curl in the air.He stares at one of the dumpsters and remembers Toga slumping down against it, her knees bloody from hitting the asphalt one too many times. He finds himself praying that Magne will find her and that she has enough sense to take her home.It’s still not calming it down. If anything, he’s starting to feel it shift under his skin. There’s a flicker of a flame licking his finger, and he forces it to go out with a groan.“Stop,” he hisses out loud. “We’re fine. We’re fucking fine. Stop freaking.” He takes another long drag, trying to drown out the growing need to incinerate with a flimsy Lucky Strike.Something wet drips down the wall and onto his shoulder. Something warm.Dabi brings his hand to the stain, and when he pulls it back, his fingers are soaked red. The thing inside him roars, and the cigarette in his hand goes up in blue flames that erupt from his palms.He jerks away from the wall and whirls around, looking up just in time to meet a pair of glowing yellow eyes up...
Holy shit, it’s against the wall.
He can’t see its face, save for the eyes, but it’s a man or something pretending to be one. Sharp claws stick out of its fingers and feet, letting it cling into the brick, dark wings flaring out as soon Dabi chokes on the smoke still spilling from his lips. The wall is glistening, wet with what he now knows is blood. He hears a wet crunch and a chew. It’s eating something.
How did I not fucking see that?!
The bird man detaches itself from the wall with a horrid scraping noise. Pieces of brick fall down onto the street, and then, after them, something big that splatters more blood all over. The bird man hovers up in the air, shoulders hunched, claws curling. Dabi throws his hands up, fire roaring and forming a wall between them, free at last. The figure screeches, the sound of it horrifying and inhuman. Before he can see any more of it, it disappears into the night.Dabi whirls around, fire licking the sleeves of his hoodie until they sizzle and burn, until his skin starts to char with the fabric, but the bird man is gone. As soon as he’s certain it won’t swoop down and tear him to pieces, he falls down to his knees, cursing and shaking his hands, trying to put the fire out. He slams his palms into the muddy slosh until it all sizzles out. His eyes are burning too, he knows, he needs water to wash his face before he blinds himself for days again.He’s still looking around, expecting to see the creature flying towards him any moment now. Instead, his eyes land on whatever it was the bird man dropped. He stares at it, slowly making out an arm and two legs, the ripped apart torso, the neck that's clearly been eaten from. It’s missing a head.He needs to get the fuck out of here and run.Inside him, the voice delights, begs to be let out again. Destroy.

Chapter Text
When I had opened my eyes again, I had felt how my flame was weak. I could not understand why at first, I had thought that perhaps I was finally given the oh so punishments that they would always curse on me while my time as the princess of the fire nation. It was the only thing that made sense.Even still, I fought. I was weak, hitting walls and swimming around in nothingness. I had wondered why I was in this chamber of oil and stain, why it had to be me. but it made sense in a horrible way. I was Azula, princess of the fire nation, war monger, the strongest general there was, the power of flames and lightning bended to my will so seamlessly. The gods must have weakened me, knowing what I’ve done. I should have felt flattered, but I was much too angry to care about the implications of forcefully being weakened into a blob of pathetic skin and bones.It never hit me until I was finally birthed that day. Born on the hottest day of the year, I had cried, like the baby I was. I saw the men above me, looking down at my tiny, bare body."It's a girl!" I had heard a voice called out.I felt myself being carried around, being cleaned and wrapped up. When I was finally handed over to her, I had saw it. My new mother.In that moment, I had realized what had happened to me. I was reborn, like a phoenix rising from the ashes.I saw how she stared down, tired and sweaty. She smiled nevertheless, seeing my small, fragile face "Welcome home, Azula."I couldn't believe it. Agni had given me a second chance. I didn't believe it, I just couldn't. So i cried. Very Loudly, might i add. Other Mother and Other Father, as i started to call them in my head, always had a hard time dealing with me. Even before my bending, or “quirk” as they would call it came to me, I was always a hard kid to deal with. I felt the same way. It was unfortunate how i had to relearn so many things, knowing very well who i was. talking, walking, running, fighting. It was like muscle memory to me, but it wasn't like that for my body. It’s like knowing how to do something but not being able to do it effectively. That’s how it was for me for a long time. It was somewhat humiliating to me, but I was determined to take back the strength i once had. So i trained, and i trained hard. I retrained myself how to stand, how to walk, how to run, how to crawl. Other Mother would always be so surprised, calling me an early bloomer. Other Father thought I would be a hardworking woman when i got older. In a way, he was right. My Other Father, Juro, was a stern man, but despite that he never reminded me of father Ozai. I had never seen a father with such a soft smile and calming personality. He had a simple spark quirk, making small sparks between his fingers. It wasn't anything much, but he always found a way to get creative with it. When i had first realized he was nothing like Ozai, I remembered breaking down in front of him. At the time, I couldn’t understand how someone like him, who i had assumed would be so cold, ended up so warm. He smiled at me with such warmth, it felt so foreign at the time.I was only a few months when it had happened however, and he thought he had accidentally scared me. He ended up crying as well, running to Other mother for guidance as he thought I was scared of him and felt hurt because of it. My Other Mother, Yukari, Was a polite and nice woman. She was one of the most bubbly people I’ve met. She always had a smile on her, her bright blond hair tied up in a neat bun. She was always patient with me, even when I fought back. Her quirk was a sunshine quirk, her energy coming from the sun. The longer she stayed out there, the more energy she could use. It was useful for outside yard work really. Of course, I had never seen her as my mother until was Three, about to be four. right after I had gotten my quirk.It was a sunny day when it happened. I was fighting a kid outside on the field for insulting me and during our battle I had punched him with a tiny fire punch out of rage. It didn't hurt the boy that badly, just a small bruise, but he ended up crying out of fear and running away. I had looked down and saw my flame. It was red, but i could see the hint of blue in it. The excess of my old power, hidden in the flame. After that my parents were called, and I ended up getting in trouble for the fight. They did end up congratulating me about my quirk after the lecture. That night I had sat on my carpet floor, staring at the flame on my hand. It was tiny, but it burned brightly. I could feel my old power in it, somewhere, locked away from me. I had remembered my training during my times in the palace when i was younger. 5 hours a day, the entire week. I worked hard to get to my full strength, but not everyone saw how hard i worked…I felt my flame get brighter as I remembered Ursa. She may have said she loved me, but all of those times when I had tried to impress or showcase my strength to her, she had Always turned a blind eye to me. Zuzu always thought she was the perfect mother, but I knew the truth. Our father may have been the most psychotic war monger, but that didn't mean Ursa was suddenly an angel just because she spend more time with her more “heroic” brother then the “villainous” Azula that everyone saw me as. I knew how she saw me. She saw me as a Monster. I hadn’t even realized i was silently crying until My Other Mother opened the door, seeing me on the floor with tears spilling out of my eyes as i held the dancing flame in my palm. My Other Mother walked over, sliding down to my level as she sat next to me “Azula dear, what’s wrong?” I closed my eyes for a moment, knowing the look she would give me. I looked back at her, but instead of seeing that scared look Ursa would always give when i had my fire out, Other mother simply stared at me with a warm, concerned look. I balled my hand up, turning out the flame “i…” i stared. So many questions were in my head, but they were not for other mother. I rubbed away my tears, my childish voice low “do… you think im a monster?” I saw how Other Mothers eyes widened “Azula? Why would you ask that? Did someone call you that?” yea, a lot of people did, they always did. I knew I couldn’t say anything like that however, so i simply shook my head. “Well… why did you ask that?” She said, scooting closer to me. I could feel her hand wrap around me in her attempt to get me to open up more “its just…” i stared down at my balled up hand that held my flame just moments agoShe stared at my hand with me, and she came to her own conclusion. testing to see if it was correct, she leaned into me “Are you… scared of your quirk?” Scared of my own power… it was a stupid concept, but… “a little… What if i…” flashes of me using my fire bending came to me “hurt someone?” She stared at me, but I couldn’t tell what part of that surprised her. Her surprised look turned soft “oh, my little azula…” she said, pushing a strand of my hair behind my ears “I know how scary it might be to get your own quirk. You never know how strong it’ll get. But i know you. You’re smart, so much smarter than the other kids. You’d never hurt someone on purpose…” I felt my eyes furrowed, remembering how damaging the flames could be. How they scarred Zuko, how it burned villages, how it even burned the insides of my thoat after the failure of the Agni Kai battle. She knew how much the fire could hurt “Fire burns…” I said, knowing very well how it feltOther Mother simply hummed, pulling me onto her lap  “Perhaps it does…” she started, looking down at my clenched hand “but, when you think about it, any quirk can be dangerous…” I felt my Other Mothers hands slide down to my much smaller ones. Seeing how tiny i was compared to her… it was weird. “It doesn’t matter how dangerous a quirk is, it only matters how you choose to use it. Any Quirk can be beautiful when used correctly…” I could feel her hands open up my balled up hand, the flame appearing once again. “Azula, I know you. You’re smart, you’re strong, and you understand so much for a child so young…” I felt my back be pressed against her as she hugged me from behind “I assure you Azula, you are no monster. You are Azula, just Azula, and I love Azula. I love you.” Those words, the words some part of me always wanted to hear. I never felt so… seen before. In that moment, I was just the three year old Azula. Daughter of Yukari, child with the fire quirk. For just a moment… I felt like a normal kid.  I ended up sobbing into her chest after that. She never understood where my strange perspective of myself came from, but honestly I didn't want her to know. I still don't.  
Never waste an opportunity, Azula 
Ozai may have been a horrible person, but some of the things he taught me really did help. Just not in the way he expected. 
<<EOFANFIC>>

Chapter Text
Aizawa Shouta is well-known in UA for his stoic composure and uncaring nature. He is known for his intimidation tactics and how he runs on logic. He knows how word spread about how last year the whole class of students was expelled within the first half of the week.He knows these things.But he also knows that he doesn’t do something without logic.
