He knows that he probably crushed many dreams,however that was a chance he was willing to take to ensure they didn’t get them-self massacred on the field.The Hero Commission idolise the limelight hero’s too much, using All Might’s smile to lure unsuitable children into the hands of villains. Like an army of teenagers lives were merely just a sick game to them.So yes, Aizawa Shouta is the man who ‘doesn’t give a shit’ and expelled a whole class of students last year.And no, he doesn’t regret it one bit.So when this year’s 20 students entered his classroom, wasting valuable time with light-hearted chatter and laughs, he wasn’t expecting much.
Even if 2 of his students were pulled in through recommendations. They are usually too ignorant and egotistical to give a shit about the real nature and evil hidden within heroics. Pole stuck too far up their ass that not even All Might himself could pull it out with 100% of his power.
Or at-least that’s what he had originally thought.How he was proved so, so wrong.Don’t get him wrong, he was planning on expelling the green-haired self-sacrificial idiot, also known as Izuku Midoriya, during the fitness test on the first day.But as that very teenager fought through the test, smiling at him with a determined light in his eyes right after blowing up the bones in his finger,he decided that maybe, just maybe, this class wouldn’t be a major waste of his time.His piercing gaze scanned his class of students this time round. Instead of seeing a mob of misled teenagers taking the route to fame, he saw a hope for the future.So he kept this class for a little longer, to see whether they were worth his effort.
Oh how he thanked himself for this decision later on,

after all, isn’t it common sense to trust your gut instincts within this profession?
—————————————————————————Shouta admits, he may be closer with this class than he has been with, well, any class he’s ever taught.But, can you really blame him?Within the first week, his class had got him caught in a villain attack while on a school trip to the USJ. A rescue centre.The irony would make him laugh, if the situation wasn’t so severe that he was very close to losing many of his students, and was made into a walking mummy himself.And Shouta was never really the type to laugh. His poker face as trained as ever.
However, with new connections welcome new concerns.
—————————————————————————The first concerns to arise with the resident dual-haired Todoroki was his concerning lack of social cues - which, were noticeable as soon as you meet the teenager.And he understands that being the son of the Number two hero, Endeavor, meant that he probably didn’t get as much freedome as the usual teenager.Hell, knowing Endeavor he wouldn’t be surprised if Todoroki was home-schooled; Endeavor has always stuck his nose up at anyone below him anyway.But with Todoroki’s lack of social cues?
It’s like he’s never even spoke to anyone before.

Shouta decided to keep an eye on him.
. The second of many concerns was shown during the Sports festival.Now, don’t fault him on this, he did notice the refusal in Todoroki’s training when he was asked about his fire.And, Shouta being Shouta, had already thought of many reasons why Todoroki would only be persistent in ignoring his left side completely.
And none of them painted a pretty picture.
But the sports festival opened his eyes on many concerning factors.The way Endeavor spoke to the younger Todoroki, the way right after Endeavor spoke to him he’d let his anger out with a huge shard of ice endangering Sero and the crowd.The way Midoriya yelled something that made him light up in flames.Midoriya knows something important.
Midoriya knows something he doesn’t.


And he will get to the bottom of it.

(Shouta didn’t realise how quickly things would come to light, however.)—————————————————————————‘Do you need anything, Problem Child?’ Aizawa’s monotone voice echoed through the near - empty classroom.It was the end of homeroom, and Midoriya ushered his friends off to lunch without him, insisting he needed to talk to sensei.
And isn’t that interesting?
But with the boys social awkwardness, he just seemed to stand there mumbling to himself, face crumpled in what can only be described as concentration as he seemed to form thoughts and ideas in his head. After about a minute if this, Shouta decided that his impatience was getting wary and he should just get whatever this was over with.
This will cause sleepless nights and many more headaches to come.
So Shouta spoke out, causing Midoriya to jump as if he forgot he was in the classroom. Huh.‘A-ah sensei! I’m sorry for uh- you know- but um- do you have a minute..? Its- it’s important..’ He murmured the last bit, his posture rigid as his knuckles are white clasping on the backpack straps, eyes glued to his abomination pair of shoes.Now, if it were the start of the year and Midoriya spoke them exact words, Shouta wouldn’t make it a big deal - after all, the boy was a stuttering mess when he first joined.But they worked on the stutter. It’s been months since he last stuttered.
So why was the stutter back all of a sudden?
Aizawa straightened his posture.‘Midoriya, would you prefer if we spoke within the confidentiality of my office?’ Tone unbothered as ever as he asks his student, offers his student privacy.Midoriya seems to stall for a moment before nodding his head, a sight rock of his feet as he does so.Is he really that incapable of standing still for one minute? Aizawa humours himself as he lazily steps up from his desk, bones popping at the stretch.

Keigo blinked. “Fortune? Like reading the future?”

“Mmhm!” She nodded her head fervently, her choppy blue and pink hair bouncing with the motion. Then she paused and grinned sheepishly, rubbing the back of her head awkwardly. “Well, not really. The way I understand it, it’s more of a guidance thing? Like, you ask it a question and then it’ll provide advice.”

Kaina shook her head. Paused. A look of uncertainty crossed her face. “I guess?” She shrugged. “Here, it’ll be easier for me to show you.” She set the deck on the floor between them. “Okay, the first step is to-”

When the Devil shows up in a reading, it can bring these dark forces into your conscious awareness, and provides a chance to break free from dark forces. As the Devil is a major arcana, it is unlikely these forces will disappear overnight. It might take a great amount of willpower and strength to free yourself from their influences, but know it is possible to break free, and it is up to you to overcome these forces.’”

Kaina made a considering noise, tilting her head back and forth with a concentrated expression for a few seconds before she answered. “Libra? Yeah. September twenty-third to October twenty-second.”

Kaina’s back straightened and she puffed out her chest, a smug look on her face. “Justice! That’s my arcana.”

“I know, right? Poor Keigo, stuck with the Devil. I suppose it’s my job to defeat you, what a shame.”

 be quiet,” Kaina said, waving him off as she glanced away with a nonchalant look. “I’m kidding, I’m not gonna hurt you. You’re enough of a danger to yourself and your fragile chicken bones on your own, you don’t need me to help out with that.”

“I didn’t realize you were so old, Oneesan.”

brat-”


Kaina had never considered herself a particularly superstitious woman.

She’d followed schoolyard trends, she made origami fortune tellers with her friends, she’d poke fun at friends who broke their combs about their upcoming misfortune, but she’d never really truly believed in any of it. She’d believed in them in the same fashion that one believed in a movie — it could get her heart racing, but it was more suspension of disbelief than a genuine feeling.

She’d enjoyed tarot well enough, however. She would fiddle and shuffle the cards when she was stressed or nervous, thankful for the distraction of something to do with her hands, and it was something to laugh about in the school cafeteria. There was a technique and thought process to it, which Kaina found more interesting than looking up horoscopes or slapping her hand over the mouth of someone who whistled after the sun went down. It was like making up small little stories each time.

Keigo had always been fascinated by the practice, although Kaina was fairly sure half of it had been appreciation for the artwork on the cards. Maybe. Or the Commission’s curriculum for him didn’t educate him on things like superstitions and astrology, since they probably hadn’t expected him to be exposed to things like that.

It didn’t really matter. He turned out well enough, it seemed.

Not 

well,

 per se, more 

useful.


That was a more accurate way to describe someone who put themselves in the sort of situation where two of their limbs are burned off, all to follow orders.

She didn’t have that old deck of tarot cards anymore, it had disappeared along with the rest of her previous belongings when she went to Tartarus. The cards were still stiff and new, but the motions of shuffling and sifting through them were a familiar lull.

Kaina remembered Keigo’s disappointment each time he convinced her to do a reading and the Devil arcana didn’t show up. She’d expected him to be put off by the negative connotations of the title, but the small pre-teen boy had taken it in stride, always insisting that since it was the representation of Capricorns, it meant good luck.

She hadn’t corrected him on the fact that that wasn’t exactly how tarot worked. She admonished him for relying on luck instead of skill, however. That was usually enough to get him to stop bothering her about tarot readings and into a competition of accuracy, his feathers literally ruffled from his high-pitched indignation.

She’d given him the Devil arcana card from that deck when she debuted. She wondered if he still had it.

Keigo was foolishly sentimental, but he was foolishly obedient. She could see it going either way.

She shuffled the cards in her hands again, keeping a careful watch out over the skyline of Tokyo, ignoring the mutterings of Chisaki behind her. Her target would appear soon enough. Clouds were gathering overhead, and it would start to rain soon enough.

She idly flipped over the top card and pinched her lips to bite back her amusement.

A drop of rain hit the center of the card, and she tucked the deck into her pocket in anticipation of the storm.

It was well into spring, far past the time of Capricorns, but Keigo had always been a stubborn brat. He’d probably insist that it was lucky.

“You know you’re running out of time, Izuku.  Your scent isn’t going to stay fresh much longer, sweetie, so it’d be for the best to give those alphas a chance.  Let them court you and maybe you’ll find your happiness with them!”


Izuku’s mother had only wanted what was best for her son when she said those words.  But he knew that she could never understand the reason why he refused the countless attempts at courting from alphas he knew and those that he didn’t.  Because he couldn’t tell her that the alpha he desired most was the one he knew he could never manage to reach.

The haze of his latest heat still lingered in Izuku’s head, making it just a bit more difficult to manage his walk to work.  Once he reached the medical office where he worked, Izuku shared brief greetings to those he passed on his way to the locker room to change into his scrubs.  He didn’t miss how his fellow nurses and aides looked at him with pity in their eyes.

They knew he’d spent another heat alone, and for a 36 year old omega, it was obvious that Izuku had even less of a chance to find a mate that would be attracted to his fading scent.  Once presented, omegas had a limited opportunity to find a mate.  Every heat wore them down physically, giving them at most ten to fifteen years before the stress brought them too far down to be considered an acceptable mate.

The longer it took to find a mate, the more a chance the omega could ‘go sour’, where their scent would weaken and break down into an awful stench.  Once that happened, there was no hope of that omega ever finding a mate.  They were nothing but a lonely Sour Omega then.  And Izuku was veering so close to that point, despite his friend’s various warnings and invitations to outings that could have him find an alpha that could help him avoid that lonely future.

“Good morning, Doctor Tenko,” Izuku said as he entered his office, ready to be told the schedule for the day.  He’d applied for this practice because of their main doctor, Tenko Shimura.  He’d been his inspiration all throughout his schooling and nursing programs.  So if Tenko didn’t give up, neither would Izuku.  And that led him to working under his mentor in his practice, something he could never have expected.

But through all the years that Izuku had worked in Tenko’s office, he hadn’t once noticed Izuku’s intention and attraction to the alpha he worked for.  Knowing he was growing less desirable with each passing year, Izuku could only take a small joy in the fact that he could at least stay by Tenko’s side since he held no interest in the aging omega.

“Hello, Izuku,” Tenko said as he looked at the day’s schedule and relayed his expectations on how each meeting should be handled by the omega.  Izuku noticed a moment of hesitation before Tenko let him go to follow his orders.  If Izuku happened to glance at Tenko and find his eyes looking back at him with a softer look than usual, then maybe that’s just something for him to keep to himself.  Even if it left him feeling warmer than before.

Lunch time rolled around, and with most of his office taking the opportunity to get take out for their meal, Tenko decided to go to the break room to find a quick meal.  But rather than food, he found several of the office nurses and aides chattering to each other about Midoriya of all people.  He stayed hidden as he listened to their conversation.

“It’s sad that someone as nice as Izuku hasn’t found a mate yet.  He’s always been one of the best here at work, but it’s just so puzzling that he hasn’t been courted.”

Kaminari is humming something, and it is driving Kyoka mad that she cannot tell what it is.Normally, she’s very good at picking out what he – what anybody, really – has got stuck in their head. There’s a boyishly triumphant expression on his face that is almost endearing.It would be a lot more endearing if she could work out the darn song he was humming.Momo chooses this moment to walk in, her hair tied in a loose bun that’s at risk of falling apart and cascading over her chunky-knit sweater. She brushes her fingertips against Kyoka’s shoulder as she passes and knocks Kaminari with the same gesture as she looks for a mug.When she resurfaces from below the counter, she fixes him with a curious look. “Hey, is that Madama Buttefly?”He nods, expression brightening. “You listen to Puccini?”It’s as if Christmas has come early for Momo. “Oh my gosh, absolutely! I didn’t know anyone else did in class!”And the pair are away, both yabbering excitedly about librettos and arias and buffas and castratos, and it is all Kyoka can do to not simply let her jaw hit the floor.Momo being an opera fan doesn’t surprise her. Kaminari though? That’s a whole different story.“Hey, hey!” she says, cutting off the pair’s rapid-fire rapport before they drown out the whole common space. Their exuberance is infectious, but now half of 1A are looking at them with odd curiosity.Momo blushes, and skirts a bow of apology, but Kaminari seems utterly unrepentant, megawatt grin back in place.“You feeling left out, Jiro-Jack?” he quips, and she resists the urge to stab him with the appendage in question. Before she can do so, he has turned back to her best friend. “C’mon, I’ve got something to show you!”
Oh, hell no.
“I’m coming too,” she quickly cuts in. Momo casts her an odd look of surprise, but Kaminari just shrugs and laughs.“Fine by me! The more the merrier. Come on!”Which is how, five minutes later, she and her best friend find themselves sat on Kaminari’s bunk as he rustles around in his wardrobe. Both have a steaming mug of tea in hand; the packet of bacon fished out from the fridge earlier has been tossed, bizarrely, atop the vanity cabinet next to his mirror.“Aha!” comes his muffled voice and he suddenly re-emerges with a dusty clutch of vinyl records in his hand. Kyoka blinks.“You own a turntable?” she asks, slightly dumbfounded.“Yeah, duh,” he says with a wink. “Why would I just keep these lying around if I didn’t?”Frankly, she’s a little wounded he has not already spilled that information before, given her clear-cut passion for her music. She will admit opera is something of a blindspot – her father had simply said it was accompanied shouting for Italians and steered her towards a copy of In the Court of the Crimson King instead – but even so, it smarts a touch.Kaminari is rifling through them now, and then with a mock curtsey, bestows something into Momo’s lap. Her friend takes one look down and positively squeals.“Oh my gosh, you’ve got The Three Tenors in Concert on vinyl?” she half-shrieks in excitement. “How on earth did you get this? It’s super-rare!”He just grins again, that look that Kyoka once found frustratingly obnoxious and now finds maddeningly attractive, not that she will tell him that even after hell freezes over.“Trade secret,” he says, and then he catches her gaze. She snatches her eyes away, blush dusting her cheeks, and it seems to give him pause.“I, ah, inherited it,” he amends after a moment. “It was my grandmother’s. They’re all from her, in fact.”Momo reverently skates her fingers over the dust jacket. On the front, Kyoka can make out three men, though she only recognises Pavarotti among them.“Mine too,” she murmurs. “My parents just wanted me to learn to play the piano, but all I wanted to do was to be one of the ladies in Turandot when I was younger. It just seemed so… far away.”Kyoka hasn’t heard this side of her friend before, a girl with her heart firmly in the right place but one who has not always been too aware of what her social status has granted her above many of her peers. Kaminari clearly is touched too, and he rifles through the stack again.“Here –” And he passes across another record, this one with the opera’s name emblazoned in refined white script across a red sleeve. Momo does say a word this time, but lets out a soft oh of surprise as she delicately takes it from him.“It’s beautiful, Kaminari,” she says. “How long have you had these?”“About… three, four years?” he guesses. “Since she passed away, I guess. I lose track of the time.”He looks out towards the window, lost in thought. Kyoka opens her mouth to apologise but feels Momo’s wrist give her a glancing touch. She stares at her and gets a shake of the head in return.“Her favourite was Madama Butterfly,” he continues after a moment, and when he turns back to them both, his eyes are slightly watery. “I guess it still helps me feel like she’s here.”A pang of something uncomfortably like shame stings Kyoka, but before she can move to say or do anything else, Momo has gently placed the records down on her lap, before moving herself across the room to clinch Kaminari in an embrace.“She’d be happy to know you still do,” she tells him softly, and his lip wobbles, and then he buries his head in her shoulder.She feels like a voyeur, intruding on his grief, but she remains rooted to the bedspread, frozen in place, a small part of her jealously clawing at her, telling her that she should be the one comforting him –Except suddenly two arms are open and she moves to join them, wrapped into a strange three-way bear hug as Kaminari sinks his brow against her body, caught between her and Momo, and continues to be wracked with sobs.Over his head, Momo gives her a gentle, watery smile of her own. Kyoka grips them both tighter and burrows deeper in too.The best and the worst is yet to come for them all, but they’ll pull through it somehow.<<EOFANFIC>>

completion: Izuku Midoriya had always had to hide his true self from his classmates.It was easy when he was going to Aldera. Using their quirks was against the rules, even if it wasn’t strictly enforced. He had only moved there when he was 10. He had run from Camp Half-Blood and tried to hide out in the underworld after his sister’s death, but his dad had found him and basically kicked him out. He was lucky enough that his dad knew some mortals he could stay with. Thus, Izuku Midoriya was born.He had been forced to go back to camp a couple of years later, when he was twelve, and again the next summer, when he was thirteen. The wars were hard on everybody, and he came back much more traumatized than any pre-teen should be.But he was good at putting up a mask.In the four years Izuku had lived in Musutafu, he had never shown his “quirk” to anyone. He had originally been friends with this blond guy, Katsuki Bakugou, but he then kept being called a “quirkless Deku” by the boy when he refused to show everyone his powers. Soon, that caught on, and everyone in his school believed he didn’t have a quirk. Then, four years after he had moved to Musutafu, Izuku decided to go for the “impossible”. He tried out for UA’s Hero Course.And he got in.So, he started in class 1-A at UA. His classmates – and even his teachers – kept speculating as to what his quirk was. His classmates were starting to think that he didn’t really have one. His teachers knew he did, but they just saw it in his file as “classified” – which no student has ever had before. He went through term one, clashing heads with Bakugou along the way. On top of that, it seemed that bad luck seemed to follow him, as bad event after bad event seemed to happen to his class throughout the term.Term two was starting when they all had to move into their dorms together. This had been the first time he had been living with others since the Argo II after–He thought they might actually all have fun together. And, they did. They really did. Of course, Bakugou kept trying to push him over the edge, get him to fight back, but Izuku had more control than the blond gave him credit for.It was only a few weeks later, shortly after the second term started, that things seemed to go really wrong for Izuku.It was a normal training day. 1-A was out at Ground Beta with Aizawa-sensei, going over the rules for the drill they were about to run. That was when he heard itA roar.This was no ordinary roar. This roar was giant enough, loud enough, powerful enough that it shook the buildings surrounding them. Izuku could see several windows close to shattering. Out came the source of the roar.A giant beast was stalking down one of the roads, nose anchored towards the ground and sniffing loudly, searching or something.The creature had three heads, and was the size of a double-decker bus. The biggest head, the source of the loud roar, was a lion. Where the lion's torso would be, it conjoined with a goat. The goat’s head and neck were sticking out the top of the torso. Where the goat and lion met, the furs of the two animals melded together, creating a pattern of light brown and black spots streaking down, until it was just goat. The goat had no front legs but had large, spiky tan horns on the top of its head. The hind legs of the creature belonged to the goat, while the front legs belonged to the lion. At the back of the creature, where the goat’s small tail began, it morphed into a large snake. Izuku recognized this beast almost immediately.The Chimera. One of the few monsters that Percy had encountered that he hadn’t been able to defeat. The Chimera’s snake head held a deadly venom, which could kill a normal mortal within just a few minutes of being bitten, and would only give a demigod maybe 15 minutes to live. The goat head had razor-sharp horns that could easily tear a person to ribbons. The lion head was able to breathe fire so hot it was said it could melt even elements with the hottest melting points. Each head had its own brain, thoughts, and desire to kill demigods.And worst of all? It seemed to be staring straight at Izuku.Izuku’s classmates seemed to think that this was their training exercise, and some of the bolder – or more idiotic – ones went to charge the beast before Aizawa-sensei stopped them all. “This… isn’t the drill,” Aizawa said, holding an arm out to try to stop them. Izuku didn’t think anyone else could spot it, but Izuku was good at reading even his father. Even Aizawa was scared of this monster.Izuku was unfortunate enough to be at the head of the group, directly behind Aizawa-sensei and next to Bakugou. There was no way he could get away from the class unnoticed.Welp, looks like his secret is being revealed. Izuku broke into a sprint, running to his right. As he ran, he could hear the class yelling after him. They didn’t move, as the monster was still watching them.As the goat head stayed trained on the class, ensuring they didn’t attempt to interfere, the lion and snake heads both followed Izuku as he ran away from them, trying to ensure their safety during the fight that was bound to happen.As Izuku was running from the class, he let the Mist screen his father and various ghosts had taught him how to use fall away, revealing what he truly looked like.He now had pitch-black hair, black skinny jeans, a black skull shirt, and his aviator jacket on. There was a silver skull ring on his finger.Nico di Angelo was back.“Hey! Looking for me?” Nico yelled, like one of the aforementioned bold idiots in his class. The Chimera seemed to take that as a challenge, as it shot a column of scorching hot flame at him, which he barely dodged.“You’re gonna have to try a little harder than that if you wanna kill me!” Nico yelled again, apparently channeling Percy during this fight.The snake head swiped at him, trying to bite him. Fortunately, all it managed to do was toss him to the side at an incredibly high speed. Unfortunately, he was tossed directly at his class. Nico ended up barreling through his classmates as if he were a bowling ball hitting a bunch of bowling pins. One thing his classmates did that bowling pins didn’t, though, was realize that he was barreling towards them and move out of the way.Nico rolled in the path his classmates had made, roughly stopping as he hit the wall of the building directly behind them. He stayed slumped over for a second to catch his breath before he got to his feet. His class had surrounded him, but backed away a little when he got up and they saw the lowkey-murderous look on his face.As Nico started walking toward where the Chimera was starting to stalk towards them, his class gave him a wide berth, slowly creating a tunnel in front of him. They went back together after he passed, and he could hear them whispering about him and what was happening. They thought he had shape-shifting powers.They hadn’t even seen what he could really do yet.Once Nico had a clear path to the Chimera, all his classmates were out of the way, he grabbed his ring off his finger. He could hear his class gasping as it transformed into a three-foot-long black falcata sword, with a slight dark purple glow on the blade. Nico slowed his pace until he had stopped.“Rise, and obey,” Nico said as he plunged his sword into the ground in front of him, his voice reverberating through the area they were in with a dark edge to it. He could tell his friends and teacher had no idea what he was doing, as there was a delayed reaction, but then the ground started to shake. A couple of his classmates started to lose their balance before their friends steadied them. The ground shook violently before it cracked, creating gaping holes in the middle of the street. Skeletons and ghosts came out of the cracks, creating an undead army under his command. He lifted his sword and pointed it at the Chimera. His undead army quickly swarmed the monster, easily overpowering it. His chosen lieutenants were the ones that he had deliver the killing blows.The Chimera burst into a shower of gold, covering the entire road, class, and surrounding buildings. Nico let his army retreat back underground, and he quickly got lightheaded. After almost two years of not using his powers on that large a scale, mainly shadow traveling, using his powers that much that fast quickly tired him out. Nico turned around, staggering in his steps before he started to collapse. Bakugou, the closest to him, rushed forward and managed to catch him before he hit the ground.“Sorry…” Nico managed to whisper.Then, he blacked out.<<EOFANFIC>>

Chapter Text
When Keahilani became a hero, she expected to see tragedies, a poorly written play falling apart in front of her. She hoped to just be a side character, cast into meaningless roles yet detrimental to the story. And things had gone how she hoped! She got into hero school, met her boyfriend(s), and rose through the ranks as the youngest top hero to ever exist! She used her powers for good, and never once let greed drive her. She had firmly set morals, a good home life, and was willing to inspire and support those around her even if she didn't agree. That's what makes a good hero. That's what she was told.So why did her story end so soon? Who decided that her role came to a close? And why such a tragic end for such a good person? Nonetheless a painful, drawn-out death. It could have been prevented, yet no one came to save her as she had done for many.Even if the pages to her book ran out of ink and came to a close, pages in other books continued turning. Due to her death, others continued to thrive. And yes, maybe you could call it a noble sacrifice, a fate she couldn't outrun, but to her, it was the end of everything. A moment where not even her lovers could hold her hand and whisper sweet nothings until she passed. She didn't get that privilege. Instead, she had rebar protruding through her stomach as she was slowly frozen, and being ripped to shreds. A death that she did not deserve. And all she got in return was a segment on the news and a private funeral in which family was the only people allowed to say goodbye.And if she had been able to live through the event, or even give one last piece of advice she would mention the importance of how“In your life, you meet people. Some you never think about again. Some, you wonder what happened to them. There are some that you wonder if they ever think about you. And then there are some you wish you never had tothink about ever again. But you do. And that is a good thing, whether you wish it to be or not is another story.”Keahilani would never get to spend her days sitting with her boyfriends on the beach, melting the sand into glass pendants while the others swam and played. Keahilani could never sit in the library, with a cat in her lap and a hot drink in her hand. Keahilani would never see her hometown, or the beaches she grew up on again, all due to the lack of preparationfrom the adults she trusted. Keahilani was no older than 17 when she died.The only good news about Keahilani’s story is that you can turn back the pages and fix what has been done. After all, paper and ink are easy to replace with something new. And maybe, that's all Keahilani needs to get a happy ending.
<<EOFANFIC>>

prompt: write a story about Haikyuu!!,  Teen And Up Audiences Major Character Death Gen 僕のヒーローアカデミア | Boku no Hero Academia | My Hero Academia (Anime & Manga) Midoriya Inko & Midoriya Izuku Bakugou Katsuki & Midoriya Izuku Bakugou Mitsuki & Midoriya Inko Midoriya Inko Midoriya Izuku Bakugou Katsuki Bakugou Mitsuki Original Female Character(s) Dead Midoriya Izuku Quirkless Midoriya Izuku Sad Midoriya Inko Good Parent Midoriya Inko Sad Bakugou Katsuki Mentioned Bakugou Mitsuki Implied/Referenced Suicide Wakes & Funerals Mentioned Yagi Toshinori | All Might Bullying Suicide Notes Angst Hurt No Comfort Unreliable Narrator Memorials Moving On Mentioned Hero Public Safety Commission (My Hero Academia) Not Beta Read Mentioned Midoriya Hisashi Mentioned Sensei | All For One
completion:
He died on a rainy day. Midoriya Izuku I mean. Jumped off the roof of his school building. Not many cared. But some did. His mom, his so-called “childhood best friend” and… no I think that’s all. He was quirkless, so no one really cared, no one even noticed. Everyone just went about their days like how they did, it was just that they didn’t have to slam a kid against his locker after every class. Not that anyone’s complaining, one less pest to get rid of, one less kid to educate, one less child to look after, one less person to save. A week after his death, they held a funeral. His mom, Midoriya Inko, dressed in all black sat in the front. She stared into space, eyes unfocused. You could see how tired she looked, her red and swollen eyes and her lips pursed together as if she was trying to either not break down or kill everyone who caused her son’s death. Bakugou Katsuki, along with his family, sat beside her. He didn’t say anything, just looked down at his hands. He probably sees “Deku”’s blood smeared all over them. Bakugou Mitsuki was trying to console her friend, repeating the lines everyone says at funerals- “I’m sorry for your loss, he was a nice kid”
“He’s in a better place now”
“He wouldn’t want you to be sad”
“He would want you to move on”It was a whole load of bullshit if you asked me. If he was a nice kid, you would have stopped your kid from driving him to this point. From what I know of Midoriya Izuku, he wasn’t a person who would want to be in a better place, he was a person who wanted to make the world a better place for everyone else, even if it meant putting himself through the worst. And asking her to move on? Again, bullshit. The woman had just lost her son, to suicide nonetheless. Her entire life, she had lived for her son, trying to make sure he never felt the loss of his quirk, she worked day and night just to make sure he was comfortable, she worried like a mother, but she protected like a father (or you can say she tried), just to make sure he never felt the loss of not having one. He was her entire life, the reason for her happiness. And that had been snatched away from her. Midoriya Inko died with her son. Buried six feet underneath, right beside him. The woman who sat there in the front row is just the shell of the person she used to be. Midoriya Inko used to be. Just like how once Midoriya Izuku used to be. Once the ceremony was finished, they called Midoriya Inko to the stage to say a few words. I expected her to refuse, but she went up there and stared at the eight people who bothered to show up. She opened the piece of paper that I didn’t know she was holding.“I-” She spoke into the microphone. Her voice sounded hoarse, probably unused since the day she found out. She took a sip of water before continuing, “I would like to thank everyone who has come to attend the funeral. I don’t have anything to say, I feel it’s my fault, for neglecting and not being able to notice what Izuku was going through. It’s my fault that I wasn’t a big enough reason for him to keep living. While I was going through Izuku’s room, I found this”, She holds up the letter, “I opened it to see if it was anything important…”, Her voice trails off, and her eyes start to water. 
“It was a suicide note-” Her voice cracks. She closes her eyes and takes a few deep breaths through her mouth, before continuing, “I would like to read it to everyone present here today”.“I am sorry”, She reads. 
 
“I am sorry to the people I never got to meet, to the friends I couldn’t make, to the colleagues I couldn’t work with, to the enemies I never fought, to the kids I never had, to the lover I couldn’t love. I am sorry my quirklessness became a barrier between you and me, between me and the life I could have had… I am sorry”“I am sorry to all the people who looked down on me, I am sorry I was weak. I am sorry I never reached your expectations, I am sorry I wasn’t good enough. I am sorry that we couldn’t be friends…”“I am sorry to my dad, I am sorry I made you leave, I am sorry I was not the son you wanted, that I was the reason you couldn’t live a life with the woman you loved. I am sorry that you didn’t love me… and that I couldn’t make you stay”“I am sorry to All Might, that you had a worthless fan like me. I am sorry I was born the way I was, that I couldn’t be a hero like you… the next symbol of peace”“And I am sorry to… Katsuki”, Bakugou Katsuki flinches. An expected reaction if you ask me, probably never thought that the freckled boy would call him that. “I am sorry we couldn’t be friends, I am sorry I kept pestering you and following you because I liked you and looked up to you. I am sorry we couldn’t be pro heroes together and become partners, like how we thought of becoming when we were younger”When we were friends.

Midoriya Inko suppresses a sob. And so does Bakugou Katsuki. “I am sorry I made you waste your time on me, that I made analysis notes on you, that I was born without a quirk”.“I-” Midoriya Inko lets out a sob. “Izuku…” she whispers. No one goes up there to comfort her. They know she needs to finish this and let it out. She regains her composure quickly and wipes away the tears that don’t stop flowing down her face. “I am sorry I existed”In the front I see Bakugou Katsuki holding his chest as tears stream down his face. 
I am sorry
I am sorry
I am sorry
He repeats. “I am sorry, Kacchan, because I won’t know you in my next life, so you won’t be able to see if I really do get a quirk, now that I have taken a swan dive off the roof of the building…” And Bakugou Katsuki cries, almost as if he was the one who was in pain. As if he was the one who had hit the ground that day. As if he was the one who had died.“I am sorry I was a Deku”. Midoriya Inko finishes. But she wasn’t done. She turns the page because she needs these people to know what they have done to her little boy. Her little boy who would jump happily and beg her to watch one more video of All Might. Her little boy who held her and cried, “Can I be a hero too?”. They need to know. “I am sorry to my-” Her voice cracks, “to my mom. I am sorry I let you down. All your hopes and efforts are dead now. I am sorry that I have killed them with my own two hands. I am sorry-” She starts sobbing, unable to control herself anymore.She gets off the stage unable to continue reading anymore, and I assumed that it only got worse. The letter was placed there, to let others finish reading it. No one went up to read it. But I felt like it had to be read.They need to know. He needs them to know. I get up on stage to finish what she had started, “Excuse me, but I will finish reading the letter for everyone”, I see everyone giving me questionable glances. I know what they’re thinking, ‘Who is she?’ “I am sorry that it had to end this way, that we ended up this way.”“There are many people I could thank today, but I felt I had to apologize to them more. But the thing is, I am not sorry. I would have lived if it wasn’t for the people who had driven me to this point. I wanted to live, I wanted to be a hero. I wrote this letter because I need everyone in this world to know that quirkless people are not worthless. No one is worthless. Just because someone is quirkless doesn’t mean they can’t achieve great things. I need everyone to see the cruelty that is going on around them. I need this world to open their eyes and see.”That probably wasn’t even in the letter, but can you blame me, I got a bit emotional. I caught Midoriya Inko’s eyes, and she blinks. She knows that’s not what is in the letter, but she’s happy that I said it. She gives me a weak smile that doesn’t quite reach her eyes. Satisfied, I leave the stage. A year after Midoriya Izuku’s death, there is an uproar in the entire country. Many people start building memorials for him, a kid barely 15, who killed himself because he couldn’t handle the cruelty of this society. Protests take place all over the country, demanding the protection of the quirkless. Two years after his death, the HPSC finally gave in and created the Quirkless Person Protection Act XXXX or the QPPA. Under this Act, any violence caused to an innocent quirkless person will be punished accordingly. Punishments that range from Community Service to even Execution based on the severity of the violence caused. Schools were now supposed to protect and take care of their quirkless students, making sure no one else ended up like the boy named Midoriya Izuku. Seven years after the death of Midoriya Izuku, Pro Hero Dynamight, the now Number One, gives his speech during the Billboard Hero Rankings. He doesn’t thank his teachers, friends, or his family. Who he does thank is Midoriya Izuku. Ten years after the death of Midoriya Izuku, I visit his grave. “Are you Happy?”, I asked his ghost who still lingered. “I am”, he replies, “My mom moved on, and remarried. Kacchan too… the number one hero huh… I knew he could do it. Crime rates have dropped, and All for One is dead. You can tell that the world has moved on, even though I wasn’t in it, I am glad I played my part, and now it’s time for me to leave…”“I guess it's time then…” I get up, “Goodbye, Midoriya Izuku, it was nice knowing you”.“Goodbye…”, he fades away, now he’s nothing but memories that linger in our minds, and a rotting body six feet underneath. <<EOFANFIC>>

Chapter Text
Scars can be invisible. Scars can hide beneath the surface to lash out like a cat striking an unsuspecting animal. They can be miniscule and barely there or gashing out and leaking rays of fucking neon orange. Whatever the case scars are always there to remind us of the times we messed up. A sign to do better. But sometimes those signs don't come, they don't heal and they don't go away with time.Sometimes they fester. Build up. Overflow. Becoming too much for the mind to conjure up a solution so we find ways to overcome and stop the voices from breaking through.In some cases though that doesn't always work due to the fact that the nagging voice has latched itself onto its hosts insecurity like a leech. Feeding itself on their trauma, feeding itself on their rage. Feeding on their nightmares until all that's Ieft is a hollow shell.A very broken shell with a heart that's torn in so many different places that they don't know how to feel anymore. They feel like alienated outsiders  in their own skin struggling to save face, struggling to connect to not only themselves but the people that surround them, struggling to focus. Struggling to breath.Breath.Breathing.It sounds easy enough. A simple action. In and out. In through the nose, out through the mouth. A breath is an easy action that you can do unless other wise constricted.Constricted, confined, enclosed or surrounded by something which has you locked in a tight hold. Squeezing the very life you have from within while simultaneously forcing its way inside while you sit there gasping desperately for air. Panic bubbles to the surface when you are unable to save yourself from its stifling touch. Where it seeps into each and every orific like the glove that it wants to be fit snugly into while you choke on the excess. The remainder. Reminding you that at this very point in time while you see your vision go blurry and your hands go limp beside you. That your ultimately dead and there's nothing you can do about it.Red eyes snap open to the darkened room as he coughs up remnants of both memories and meals he silently pleaded to himself he would never wish to relive again, yet here he was day after day, night after night reliving the same story, seeing the same nightmare. Watching as the same impending doom was pressed upon him when the sludge villain took over his weak and helpless body while he struggled to make sense of his mortality as he believed himself to be all powerful. Better than anyone.Cheap talk, considering he couldn't even shake that oozing manifestation off his own body that was pouring out buckets of his own sweat to help him get away.The same sweat that was covering him now, yet for very different reasons. Sometimes he hated his quirk. Hated the way it made him feel, made him smell. The countless times he had to do laundry on the daily when his bedding and clothes became soaked up in his own DNA. Often times he found himself wondering if he should just sleep naked.He was now. Clothes only made his life a hindrance, made his body temperature colder when the sweat coated itself against his skin. Reminding him of said sludge.His low pitched hoarse and gravely voice panted and whined into the empty room while he laid there on his bed utterly ashamed of himself. That he was too weak to fend off visions of his past."Get it together asshole." His voice low. Speaking to himself as all these years later there was no one else around. Why would there be? "The world ain't gonna coddle your ass if it's weak. Get your head in the game and stop being such a damn pussy."His idea of coaching himself was unique."You are Bakugo effing Katsuki! Soon to be the world's next number one hero." He had tears running down his face. "Better than All Might. Better than anyone."_Some hero your turning out to be. All Might is in that weakened state because you were a distraction. A weakness. A hindrance. A- _He put an arm over his face and scowled. The voices were back with a vengeance. "It's too damn early for this." He muttered, stripping his bed, finding a clean pair of running clothes to go out for a jog.He built up a sweat, tiring both his mind and body out so it would be less inclined to come up with some bullcrap story that he knew for a fact was a  lie. Yes. The smart part of Katsuki knew all of it was nonsense that he could easily cut through with logic. But the other part, the one which tore through to his low self esteem and low self worth cut into him like a jagged knife. Like slow sharp, jagged nails slowly dragging themselves across the chalkboard.That didn't stop him though. He was out to prove a point to himself that he could do anything he set his mind to. No matter what his goals were Katsuki always, always sought to achieve them.Other people were either impressed or put off by his achievements in life. His drive, his speed, his bravery, and the confidence he had to challenge everyone while coming out on top.He obsessed over the details. Using his knowledge to take in his surroundings like a sponge did to water. In his mind just because something isn't there does not mean there's nothing to see. There was always a clue, always a stray piece of evidence left by someone else. Villains don't play fair so neither should he.His mind never wavered. Even behind the wheel he would observe the cars around him, he had gotten flack before from his mother about the way he was driving too slow but she stopped the moment the car on her side veered over several lanes of traffic suddenly. No blinkers were involved, just squealing tires.Anything could happen, at any moment. Just like another one of his random, doctor referred therapists he was given had decided to quit.Him. Not the practice."You refuse to take my advice and wise up." Some would say. "You only care about yourself." Which may have been true but also not the point."Get over your ego.""I'm tired of this.""We're just going around in circles." His last therapist had told him.  "You act as if you are the victim here when you've been nothing but an  arrogant, antisocial dick head throughout this entire ordeal." She got up. "I've had enough. There are other patients who are more worth my time. Stop acting like the victim here and grow up. Become a decent human being.""I am a victim damn it." Katsuki said in anger. "You're all just too damn blind to see it." Admitting he was hurting was a step in the right direction. Yet he was starting to give up hope that there was anyone who'd give him the time of day anymore.Granted, he also got a bit of an anxiety spike when he was put in front of a new face. It didn't help matters that his trust issues were shot. He couldn't just force himself to warm up to someone at the blink of an eye."Lord Explosion Murder God Dynamight." Came best Jeanists voice."What?" He asked as he got ready to go patrol."I heard you walked out of another session.""I walk-she's the one who told me it was over and then slammed the damn door in my face.""She has threatened us with a lawsuit.""What the hell for?""Harassment. Claims you did nothing but curse at her. Talk her down and forced her to pull the plug.""What do these people want from me? Of course I'm going to be walking in angry. I have to talk about my life while they listen and do their therapeutic bullcrap sifting through my stories with a microscope. I'm so damn done with all of them.""Your refusal to seek therapy means you cannot be out in the field." Katsuki stopped walking to turn on his heel to angrily glower at Best Jeanist. "You know this.""Fine. Give me the list of names again.""I already did so on your behalf. But the last one you went to made sure to call ahead and slander your name. Everyone on this list knows who you are, half you have already seen, while the other half heeds the previous callers advice.""Damn it.""I'll make arrangements outside the city, but for now. Just go home.""I don't want to just sit on my ass while the rest of the world burns.""Perhaps having some down time is exactly what you need."That's exactly what he didn't need. More fuel to add to his fire. His inner voice was gaining ground  but after what happened today he was just too tired to deal with life so he went home, crawled into bed and fell asleep.Only to relive his nightmares except this time it was to see that he wasn't the one in the sludge, it was Izuku. Small, helpless, quirkless Izuku reaching out his hand from the confines of the Sludge Villain. The more Katsuki pushed forward the harder it was to stay in forward motion. Almost as if something or someone had their claws in him.They were pulling back. Katsuki swiveled to see who the perpetrator was only to come face to face with Dabi with his hand over his throat. "Don't move or these brats will be burned alive."No! "Don't come Deku." He tried to say before he faded into blackness only to be woken by his very noisy alarm."Dammit." He had forgot to turn it off. Katsuki was about to try to fall back asleep when his ringtone chimed. "What?""Get up and get dressed.""Where's the fire?""I'm sending you a phone number and an address." Best Jeanist said over the phone. "Call it to make an appointment and Bakugo please, don't let this one slip through your fingers.""I'll play nice as long as they don't bite.""This one's different.""How so?""She called the agency and requested you specifically. She wants to take you on as a client.""Huh." Katsuki muttered as his brows lifted up past the bangs on his face. "Well isn't that something." He had no idea why a therapist even wanted to take him and his grouchy self but he wasn't about to pass on what probably was a once in a lifetime opportunity. It doesn't knock twice to open the door, it just knocks you down a few pegs.He sighed, trying to focus to bring his breathing to a normal level, he despised meeting new people, it was hard for him to trust after everything that happened. But he'd give it a shot.He needed someone in his corner.
<<EOFANFIC>>

completion:
Chapter Text

Izuku was absolutely exhausted. Ever since the war, he was suffering from horrible nightmares and chronic pain in several parts of his body. Second year was half over and he was so close to just saying fuck this. He had tried a few times to talk to Nedzu about it, but the principal just swept it under the rug and told him he signed up for it. His ‘friends’ just kept pushing him and using him. He was just.. tired. 
 
He walked into heroics class and looked around; they were sparring again today, and he just knew that he would be fighting Bakugou. The blonde just kept getting more aggressive over time and he just didn't think he could deal with him that day.
 
All Might stood there as the only heroics teacher. It was a normal sight now to just see him since Aizawa-sensei and Mic-sensei disappeared during the war. The school was still dealing with hiring a permanent 1A as well as law and ethics teacher, having filled the art class as well as English class easily enough. As of now, All Might was taking on the role of 1A homeroom and heroics teacher. 
 
"Alright. Today we are doing sparring. Your opponent has already been chosen, so stand by them when I call your name," All Might said. He began going through each student. Each name called sent a spike of anxiety through Izuku until, "Midoriya and Bakugou."
 
Izuku sighed but didn't complain, complaining just made them angry and he didn't want to do that. Not like anyone cared that he continued to be put with his abuser. He thought things had changed during the war, the blonde had helped him and seemed friendlier, turns out he was just trying to look good in front of others.  He walked over and stood next to Bakugou who grinned. 
 
“I'm going to kill you Deku.” He growled
 
Great. Nothing like a death threat to start off heroics. How was Bakugou even allowed to be in heroics when he was constantly threatening people? Oh right, it was only Izuku he threatened and everyone just thought it was a nice little rivalry. Before the war, at least Aizawa-sensei would have stopped him from hurting him in class or going too far. Now he was stuck with a teacher that let the battle trials happen.
 
“Alright, let's get into pairs and get started. I want to see some improvements here.” Yagi called out and the class separated and went to different mats. How stupid was this, one teacher could not safely watch this many students and keep them all from getting hurt, then again he didn't seem to care if he got hurt did he?
 
The fight started as it always did, a right hook. Izuku was tired and in his head though so as he fought he began to get sloppier. His body was starting to give out from over training and the abuse he was suffering from. Izuku felt pain shoot through his head as Bakugou hit him hard and he went down. Then a hand, hot and burning, was around his throat as bakugou squeezed and set off explosions against his skin. He screamed in pain.
 
The only thing going through Izuku's mind as the pain flared through him was to remove what was causing it. He activated his quirk to 25% and grabbed the other's wrist. He gripped onto it hard enough he could feel the bones shattering and wrapped his legs around the arm. He was able to pull the arm away from his throat and pulled down and away on the arm. He could vaguely feel a pop from the shoulder as he slammed the attacker to the ground. He pushed through the pain and the difficulty he had breathing from the wound on his throat as he sat up and quickly snapped the arm like it was nothing more than a twig before flipping his attacker over. He wasn't seeing who it was, mind flooded with pain. He just punched the person's face, feeling bones breaking under his fist.
 
He didn't come back to himself until he was thrown from his attacker and slammed into a wall. He blinked as his vision cleared even if he still couldn't breathe properly. He probably couldn't speak either.
 
“Young Midoriya! You went too far! You almost killed Young Bakugou!” Yagi yelled as he stood there glaring down at him. He could see several of his classmates standing there with shock on their faces.
 
Izuku blinked up at the man before trying to defend himself. However, it sent a cry of pain through him. He hurt so bad and not just his throat. His head hurt where he'd been hit as well as where it had hit against the wall. His back ached from the force as well and he could feel his knuckles were split. He tried to regulate his breathing as much as he could before pointing to his very obviously messed up throat. All Might couldn't seriously think that Bakugou did this without the intent to seriously maim or actually kill him, right? He wasn't that stupid.
 
Kirishima frowned. “That was an accident Midoriya, what you did was brutal, so unmanly.” 
 
“Class is dismissed, go back to the classroom and wait for your next class, Kirishima-kun, please help Bakugou to the infirmary. Young Midoriya, we need to have a talk.”
 
Izuku watched the others walk away. He couldn't believe it. His mind was starting to crack once more. He had been treated so badly for so long. His cracks had started to heal at one point after the rooftop incident but now, now he didn't know if he wanted to let them heal, he was so tired. Once everyone was gone Izuku braced himself.
 
Yagi glared down at Izuku, "Young Midoriya, I cannot believe you did that. There was no reason. You used lethal force with him. That is not heroic at all."  He walked up to Izuku and harshly gripped him by the hair, yanking it until Izuku was forced to move with him. "That is not how someone is supposed to use 

my 

quirk."
 
Izuku whined, a guttural pain filled sound through his damaged throat. It hurt, everything hurt. The quirk was his, he had it, he was chosen by the vestiges, they wanted him to do good with the quirk, but he had to admit as he hung there by the ex hero holding him by his hair, he had enjoyed hitting bakugou, he had enjoyed it a lot.
 
Pain flared as a punch hit him hard in the gut, even without one for all Yagi still had some strange strength to him. He had more trouble breathing as he was hit several times. “You need to give me my quirk back. You aren't worthy of it.”
 
Izuku tried to shake his head. No, it was his. Yagi threw Izuku onto the ground, his head bouncing off of the floor before hitting once more. There were stars in his vision as he felt Yagi harshly kick him in the ribs. He gave a gasped cry of pain. "Give me my quirk back. You are unworthy." He stomped harshly on Izuku's spine, knocking what little air he was able to keep in his lungs out of him.
 
He almost blacked out in pain and lack of oxygen. He could hear Yoichi and Nana yelling inside his head as the man continued to beat him. “Give me my quirk back and I will stop Young Midoriya. This is for your own good.” the man said as he kicked him hard in the face, he felt his eye socket shatter under the man's foot. He needed it to stop, he hurt and he felt like he was going to die, so he did the only thing he could and nodded his head a little.
 
Yagi stomped on Izuku's hand as he bent down and pulled a strand of hair out of Izuku's head. He could feel the quirk leaving him. Izuku wanted to cry, from the pain or the empty feeling inside of him he wasn't sure. "Thank you. I will give this to someone who is truly deserving of this quirk." completion: After a long day of travelling it was nice to finally be able to sit down and prepare dinner. Bakugo had caught a few fish earlier that afternoon and was looking forward to eating something fresh. Dried salted meats and berries can only go so far, the jerky was almost as tough as leather straps. He stabs the skewered fish into the ground near the campfire so they can start to cook, then shrugs his cloak off and places it beside him, the fire was warm enough for a night like this.While he waits for one side of the fish to cook he stares into the fire, the dancing flames help his mind stay quiet. Once enough time has passed he leans towards the fire to turn the sticks over when he catches movement in his peripheral vision.His cloak was moving.Bakugo turns fully now to see that yes, his cloak is now being jerked along the ground, kicking up twigs and leaves.And it’s heading towards the forest.“What the hell.” Bakugo mutters to himself as he quickly bolts up to chase the runaway clothing. It seems the cloak is trying to pick up the pace but one quick burst of his explosion magic lets Bakugo cover the short distance quickly, his boots landing directly on the tail end of the cloak. He hears a startled screech and in the next moment a small red dragon rolls forward from underneath the cloak, ending up in a dazed sprawl.“Heh. Caught myself a little thief hmm?” Bakugo taunts, crouching down to poke the dragon on its belly. The dragon lets out an indignant squeak, flailing its legs and wings to right itself.The dragon turns sideways, puffing out its chest and raising its wings high, trying to appear larger and threatening. Instead it reminded Bakugo of a feisty kitten and he snorted.The dragon didn’t like being laughed at so it let out a small growl and darted forward to snatch the cloak once more in its jaw.“Oi!” Bakugo snapped, grabbing the other end of the cloak closest to him in one hand, tugging it towards himself.The dragon dug its claws into the ground, jerking its neck side to side to try and yank it out of Bakugo’s grip.But that was a losing battle.“Why do you even want my cloak? It’s way too big for you anyway!” He barked, pulling the cloak even closer to himself. He can see the tiny claw marks indented into the dirt as he brought the cloak closer.The dragon growled.Bakugo gave one final tug upwards so the cloak was now dangling from his raised hand. As he looked down he saw the dragon was also dangling from the end of it, golden eyes glaring at him as it started to tug wildly on the cloak again.Bakugo smirks, impressed. “You’ve got guts, I’ll give you that-”He cuts himself off when he hears fabric tearing. A section of his cloak falls to the ground, along with the dragon who screeches again in surprise, kicking off the fabric to flail back into a defensive stance.Bakugo looks at the fallen fabric to his cloak to assess the damage. It tore unevenly, giving it a more distressed look, nothing too bad to get seriously mad over. He drapes the cloak around his own shoulders, staring at the dragon for a moment before he jerks his chin towards the fallen fabric.“I did say /my/ cloak was too big for you but I think that piece will be enough for you, sound fair?”The dragon pauses, relaxing its posture ever so slightly, still wary as it makes small steps towards the cloth. It looks up at him again, tilting its head and letting out a soft chirp.Bakugo watches it bite the fabric and he nods in encouragement, “There, glad that’s settled then, enjoy.” And with that settled he heads back to camp.The fish he left over the campfire was definitely burned to a crisp when he returned, he grunted at the loss but whatever. It’s too dark now to fish again. He chucked the burnt remains in the direction of the dragon encounter. He doesn’t know if the dragon is still around anymore but if not, at least another animal will get a free meal.Bakugo lets out a yawn. Might as well turn in now so he can wake up at dawn to hunt. He kicks dirt over the fire to extinguish it then picks up his knapsack, punching it a few times until it’s a  makeshift pillow before setting it down to lay on. He grabs his cloak to throw over himself as a blanket and closes his eyes. Nothing to do now than listen to the sounds of nature to eventually lull him to sleep.It must have only been an hour or so before he stirs to shuffling and chewing noises nearby, too small to be deemed a threat though.He slowly sits up to view the camp site, nothing is missing. Huh, whatever then.Bakugo flops back onto the ground and turns to his other side and was genuinely surprised to see a familiar little dragon only a few feet away bundled up in cloth, chomping on the burnt fish and staring right at him. He raises an eyebrow.“Enjoying your snack?”The dragon chirps in response, a few soft trills as it finishes the last of its meal. Afterwards the dragon snuggles back into the cocoon of fabric, only its tiny horns and wings can be seen.“Guess you’re staying the night then? Fine, I better not wake up to you running off with anything else.” Bakugo warns, only getting a muffled chirp in response.Bakugo lays back down, closing his eyes to get comfortable again. Ten minutes later he can hear a soft snore from the dragon, the noise stuttered and reminded him of a cat purring. It was oddly soothing that it was helping him relax, he could already feel sleep approaching him closely now.‘Huh, I could get used to this.’<<EOFANFIC>>

completion:
Izuku loved Pride.
 
He loved every aspect of it. The community, the belonging, the parades… all of it made him feel so at home in his identity that Izuku felt giddy thinking about it.
 
It definitely helped that he was surrounded by supportive people who really didn’t care who he was attracted to. Izuku knew from the very age of five years old that he was different from the other kids. He had come home from school one day, excitedly chattering about how one of his teachers was a man married to another man and how he had no idea that someone could even do that.
 

“Yes Izuku,” his mother had chuckled, smiling at him warmly. “As long as you love someone and treat them well, you can love whoever you wish.”

 

Izuku beamed, a happy feeling blooming in his chest. 

 
From then on, Izuku told his mom about all of his crushes. The girls, the boys, even the fleeting crush he had on Kacchan (before he realized that he just admired the boy). His mom always listened with a smile, teasing him lightly about each person. 
 
In middle school, he met his best friends who had all turned out to be LGBTQ+ in one way or another as well. Tsu, like him, was very comfortable in her sexuality and shared that fact about herself when Izuku did. Ochako called him one night in their year before highschool asking if it was okay to find girls attractive, and later figured out for herself that she was pan. Tenya knew he was aro ace, but took a while to come out to the group, as he was worried that they would think he was a ‘loveless robot’ like some other homophobes had told him before. 
 
They all accepted each other, and that’s what Izuku loved most about them.
 
Now, the four of them were on the way back from a Pride parade; decked out in glitter, pride stickers, and other colorful items. It was Izuku’s third year at a parade, but his first one going without his mother and going with his friends instead. Tenya and Ochako had never been to one before, so he and Tsu were ecstatic to bring them to one.
 
“Love, your hairpiece is crooked, let me fix it,” Tsu said to her girlfriend, bringing her hands towards Ochako’s hair gently and fixing the piece.
 
Tenya handed out water bottles, “It is important to hydrate! The weather was very warm and I don’t want any of you passing out from the heat!”
 
The four of them were on a train going back to Musutafu, where they would be sleeping over at Izuku’s. They laughed loudly, chattering about their experience and how much fun they had, when Izuku noticed someone out of the corner of his eye.
 
Todoroki Shoto, his hair was a dead giveaway; red and white that split down the middle. Izuku saw him in the hallways sometimes at school and they shared an English class, but they never really talked much. It was strange seeing him here.
 
He turned to fully look at the dual-colored boy. On his cheeks was glittery makeup and a tiny rainbow flag, his eyes donning sharp-winged eyeliner 

(that totally did not look extremely good on him what are you talking about)

. Izuku’s heart leaped in excitement before it stuttered to a stop when he saw what he was doing.
 
Todoroki was frantically rubbing at his face with a makeup wipe, using his phone camera to see if it would come off. Upon seeing that the rainbow and the glitter wasn’t coming off, he rubbed faster, looking increasingly more panicked.
 
Izuku’s heart panged and he knew what he had to do. Lifting his hand to his mouth he called, “Todoroki-kun! Come over here for a sec!”
 
The boy startled, looking over at him with a confused expression before it faded into something more neutral. Well, it would’ve looked more neutral if it wasn’t so obvious how nervous Todoroki was. He shuffled over to their group, Izuku’s friends looking at him in surprise.
 
“Todoroki!” Ochako smiled, waving to him as he came closer. “Fancy seeing you here!”
 
“Hello…” Todoroki’s eyes darted back and forth between all of them before finally settling on Izuku. “What did you need, Midoriya?”
 

He looks so on edge… 

Izuku smiled sheepishly, “O-oh! Sorry if I bothered you, but- you looked like you needed help.” He turned to Tsu, “Hey Tsu-chan, can I borrow some of your makeup wipes?”
 
“Sure,” Tsu turned to her backpack and started rifling through it.
 
Tenya looked at Todoroki, chopping his hand robotically as he spoke, “Todoroki-kun! Did you attend Pride as well?”
 
Todoroki tensed and looked away, muttering a quick “yeah” and started fidgeting with his own backpack. 
 
Izuku noticed how uncomfortable his classmate was by the question and smiled sympathetically, “Don’t worry. If you don’t want us to tell anyone that you were here, we won’t.”
 
Todoroki’s shoulders slumped in relief. Tsu handed him the makeup wipes and Izuku took one out of the pack. “Here, I can do it for you if you want,” he offered.
 
Todoroki just nodded and closed his eyes as Izuku scrubbed the makeup off his classmate’s face. Tsu’s makeup wipes were a godsend, the pride flag and the glitter coming off of his face relatively easily. Izuku smiled when he was done and stashed the used wipe in his bag to throw away later.
 
“...Thank you,” Todoroki said, his hand ghosting his face where the makeup used to be. “I don’t want to know what would have happened if my father saw it.”
 
The whole group grimaced. Todoroki Enji. A famous politician most known for his aggressive and rude nature, plus his extreme hatred towards the LGBTQ+ community. It was also rumored that the scar on Todoroki’s face was due to one of Enji’s rage-induced fits. Izuku couldn’t even imagine what he would’ve done if his mother was homophobic. It broke his heart to see Todoroki hiding himself like this.

Todoroki looked down at it, “Oh, yeah. It’s a cat holding the mlm flag,” a ghost of a smile was on his face for a second before it vanished. “My brother Touya gave it to me.”
 
Tenya smiled, “I am glad you have someone who supports you, Todoroki.”

Todoroki nodded, “I did.”
 
It’s true. Izuku was one of the only openly gay kids in the school, which unfortunately led him to be the target of bullying. That’s how he met his current group of friends, they stuck up for him when one of the upperclassmen was calling him slurs. Izuku hated it when people would look down on others over something that they couldn’t even control. Even when he and Kacchan went through their rough patch, he never bullied him for being gay and stood up for him against the bullies. 
 
“Was this your first Pride?” Izuku asked.
 
He nodded again. “Yeah. My father always said that these sorts of things were a waste of time, so I decided to go to one to see for myself.” Todoroki shrugged, “It was fun, but kind of overwhelming when you’re alone.”
 
“Well you’ll have to come with us next time!” Izuku blurted, before slapping a hand over his mouth. 

Oh no, what if he doesn’t want to go with us? I don’t want to force him into going when he barely knows us…

 
Noises of agreement rose in the group, though Izuku didn’t hear it as Todoroki gave his first real smile. “Thank you, I think I will.”

He handed it back to him and Izuku felt his mouth go dry at the contact name. “Shoto?” he squeaked. He glared at a smirking Tsu and a giggling Ochako next to him.
 
“Everyone always refers to me as my father’s name, and you know the most personal thing about me. I don’t want to be associated with him anymore.” Todo- 

Shoto

“Okay, Izuku,” the train jolted and came to a halt. “This is my stop, thanks again.”
 
Todoroki left as the others said bye and the train started moving again. When Izuku turned back to his friends after

“Thanks to me!” Ochako cheered.
 
Izuku rolled his eyes and thought back to when he first spotted Shoto. He looked so dejected, washing away and hiding a part of himself because of his father. Izuku never had to do that, but he still wanted to help in any way he could.
