completion:
Chapter Text
I’ve never known the feeling of dreading sleep. It used to come so easily that I took it for granted. Now, whenever I look at the unfamiliar bed in this unfamiliar room I can't help but be apprehensive. I know what’s going to come in a few hours, and it doesn't matter how exhausted I am. I can run myself ragged with training throughout the day and still wake up after 8 hours feeling like I’ve been up the entire night.But that's the thing. I have been up the entire night, I just don't realize it until the morning. The holes in the bedsheets- the smell of fibers burning- it all points to restlessness on a scale that I'm not comfortable with. I’ve been waking up to this scenario since… I’m not comfortable with that either.It's best if I just keep going. That’s the only thing you can do, right? Don’t let this define you. Keep pushing forward.

-=-  
Another night. I'm awake in this unfamiliar bed, surrounded by these unfamiliar walls. They want to keep me here because it's not safe for me to be anywhere else, right? The bullshit makes my blood boil just thinking about it.Not like I’d be better off at home. This… shit would happen there too. Waking up, drenched in sweat, smoke rising from bed sheets that were unfortunately in my way. But at least there I could leave if I wanted to. I spent so many nights after that disaster waking up at 1am and leaving the house to go run. I wouldn’t stop running until I felt like I was about to die, and then I’d run further. I’d run until my knees felt like they couldn't carry me back home. I’d run until my chest was on fire, until my vision got blurry, until I vomited in the bushes. Only then was my mind clear enough, was my body exhausted enough, to go to sleep and stay that way.But here I am trapped. These 4 unfamiliar walls are a pressure cooker. I don't want to be here anymore.“Hey, Bakugou.” A voice at the door? I can’t breathe. I cannot breathe. All I can do is lay here, motionless. If I stay quiet maybe this will pass. Maybe I’m still asleep, and this is still part of the fucked up dreams I’ve been having. That’s it. All I have to do is just disappear.Of course this is not a dream and I’m a fucking idiot. How can I be so dumb? How could I be so reckless? When did I become such a little bitch?
 You know when.  
Shut up. Just… shut up.  Pulling myself out of bed I square my shoulders and head to the door, making a point to let every step come down heavy. I’m such a child. This has worked before though… I can make this go away too. Get your game face on, Katsuki.I open up the door, expecting Aizawa or something. Anyone aside from who stood there.“The hell do you want?” I keep my voice low. It is bad enough that Kirishima is at my door. He knows too much already. I need him to leave, and I need him gone quickly. But, maybe he wasn’t here because of my burned sheets. Maybe he needs a cup of sugar or something? Keep dreaming, dumbass. "I heard something coming from your room and wanted to make sure you're okay?"Oh you’ve got to be kidding me. I can’t do this right now. I’m running on fumes here.You know now, don’t you? You can’t see me like this. I can't see myself like this. I have to look away from his earnest face, focus on anything but what is in front of me and what is inside of me. “I’m fine.”"You sure, man? If something's wrong, I'm here—"Just go the fuck away. “—I said I'm fucking fine, alright?" Oh, so you don’t believe me? I’ll make you believe me. Come on mother fucker I’m right here. Sparks dance across my fingers and I realize that they have formed fists. Fists? Right here? Like I’m going to fight him in the dorms? What the hell am I doing? I’m losing my shit and if he calls my bluff I’m screwed. But it will work. This always works."Okaaay...?" Kirishima blinks again, looking unfazed.Is his head as hard as his quirk? Leave. "Are you gonna let me sleep? Or are you just gonna keep standing there like a goddamn idiot?" Come on, you have to look at him, stare him dead in the eyes and let him know you’re serious."Oh. Right." He says, looking away from me. A sick little smirk reaches my lips as I see him relent, watching as he does that thing where he puts his hand behind his head and scratches it like a moron. Good. Get fucked. "Sorry for bothering you?"“Yeah.” God damn right you are. Keep eye contact, narrow them to make him even more uncomfortable. You’re a natural, Katsuki."Anyway. Goodnight."I turn my head and ‘tch’ loud enough for him to hear it before mumbling a half-assed “G’night” and slamming the door in his face. My bare shoulders touch the cold door and I lean on it as I listen to his footsteps fade. When my ears strain and still can't hear anything beyond my own breathing I finally deflate, sliding down the hard wood until my butt hits the floor. My eyes look at the bed, its sheets still smoldering, and I pull my legs up to my chest. Resting my head on my arms I watch as pale gray smoke slowly thins out and dissipates into the air.I’m ok right here. I’ll be fine right here.  
-=-

 I am terrified. This all encompassing malice is engulfing me. I can’t breath, I can only look straight ahead and let it do what it wants to me. It delves into my nostrils, squirms into the folds of my skin. It violates me. When it tries to go into my throat I panic, I struggle, I want to vomit. But I am helpless. It all fades to gray and then black as I reach out to All Might.Please… help me. Please…A familiar hiss rings into my ears, and before I can even fully wake up small, sporadic explosions are dancing around my fingertips.“Shit…” I hiss, turning onto my side and trying to pat the newborn flames out. “Shit shit shit…” I’m conscious of the fact that this is the fifth night in a row, but I’m quiet about it. And the explosions aren't too loud. If I can just get the flames put out I’ll be good to go, just like every other night.But then a door creaks down the hall, and its all about to go to shit again. I furrow my brow, my heart racing as the footsteps grow closer and closer until they are right at my door. I don't know how to feel, I don't want to think about feeling anything at the moment, because the amount of shame that will come from that actualization is too much for me to confront."Hey, Bakugou?" Yep, that is the same stupid voice from last time.Nope… Fuck introspection. This stupid son of a bitch needs to mind his business. If Kirishima wants to make it his problem, it can be his problem. Growling my complete and utter disdain, I storm to the door and open it, my red and ragged eyes meeting his and throwing him a look that could kill."The fuck could you possibly want now?""Four nights. In a row. Should I be concerned?" Kirishima says with a smirk. He smirks at me. At me. Oh he is lucky I cant do anything right now. The bastard has the upper hand, confronting me after midnight in our dorms and he knows it.I take a deep breath and square my shoulders, crossing my arms over my chest. Just play it cool, act unbothered.  “No.” I say, cocking a brow. “Leave. I’m trying to sleep.”"And failing, by the sound of it."Oh he is trying to die. "You're one to talk, keeping me up!" My voice raises only slightly, but its enough to put Kirishima on the defensive, as he raises his hands up."Hey last I checked, I don't make explosions. That's all on you, buddy."He is really going to go there. I groan in exasperation and lul my head back, basically spitting the words, “Fuck off.”"Fine! Fine!" Kirishima throws his hands up into the air. "Whatever! But the second this happens again, I'll be back."I stiffen, my expression growing deathly serious. "No the fuck you won't be."Kirishima raises a brow. "Promise?"I’m dumbfounded. I just want sleep. I just want to be left alone. “Whateve….” My words are cut off by the biggest yawn I’ve ever had in my life. Or so it feels like it. When its over my tired eyes read Kirishima’s expression, and I'm a little confused as to why it looks so bewildered. But Red Rocket tries to play it off by staying on subject and I'm not going to bite the bait either."Sooo," he says. "Completely ignoring the fact that whatever the hell you're doing is keeping me up on a nightly basis..." his voice lowers. "You know you can come to me if something's bothering you, right? I'll listen, I swear."It takes me awhile to process this. The words that come out of his mouth are foreign and unintelligible.. ‘If something’s bothering you I’ll listen, I swear’... Who in the hell does this guy think he is? You know what, I’m not even going to grace that with a response.“Goodnight.” As soon as the last syllable leaves my lips the door swings shut into its frame, separating us. Once again, I wait for his footsteps to fade down the hall, but this time I tuck into my bed. I curl the sheets around myself, wincing at a few extra-warm spots, but its nothing I’m not used to by now. I desperately need sleep, so I close my eyes and try to surf the abyss. But as I drift his words keep playing in my head.


"You know you can come to me if something's bothering you, right? I'll listen, I swear."
<<EOFANFIC>>

After all, she was tied to a chair, practically forced to work with a group of strangers.Suddenly, a metal door creaked open; Yaoyorozu glanced up. She saw that it was one of the guys she met in the alleyway, so she decided to strike up a conversation. Though it was difficult as he was approaching slowly with a knife, he came off as calm and more proud in a black and red suit this time.“Hey, Kirishima. Right? Heard your name when you accidentally said it yourself. What do you want?” Yaoyorozu spoke with a hint of sass in an attempt to know what his motives were and why he was here.Clearly annoyed at the placement she was put in, Kirishima spoke back in a calming voice. “Yea, you can call me Kirishima. Also can you take that smile off your face and get out of here!?”“Yeesh, didn’t know you could be feisty. Now please calm down, I’m trying to do you a favor. What I was gonna say is that I got orders to give you a few more freedoms. But please, can you at least not sound like you’re about to kill me?” Kirishima explained the orders he received from Bakugo, after twisting his arm a bit into helping Momo out. She still wasn’t taking it well, but sighed when brought to the realization that there wasn’t anything that she could do other than take his word for granted. Seeing that he could calm her down somewhat, Kirishima moved forward to cut off the restraints made by Sero.She moved her hands as she became free. Momo felt some joy that was clearly hidden, but she would remember this moment.“So, you gonna say thank you or something? Anyways, welcome to the United Villains Association, or UVA for short. That spikey leader Bakugo made it…” Kirishima spoke while welcoming her to the group; she was zoned out, as the girl was a little impressed that he actually let her out.“Say, don’t you have some special quirk of yours that could get you out of any situation? Why didn’t you do that?” he added while she was in her own thoughts, questioning if this simple act of chivalry was planned or not.“Uhmm, yeah. I’m sure you know my quirk then, I can create most things as long as I understand the molecular structure. Though I need enough lipids, which is why I can’t create anything unless I want it to be useless and dull. So, why did you let me out?” Momo responded with the question in the end, hoping for him to answer. Out of everyone she’d met so far, she’d taken a liking to Kirishima, knowing he’d done the nicest thing out of them all, despite it being small.“It was just some convincing I did with the boss last night, nothing much. I thought it would be respectful, at least, as you’re still a person and not just some factory, like how he sees you. But that’s another thing, Yaoyorozu. By the way, you’ll be getting your own room and everything…” Kirishima explained and welcomed her into the group, treating her like an actual person instead of an object or prisoner. Though, his speech began to slow as he glanced away for a moment, seeing shadows on the ground projected from the sunrise.Glancing upwards, both of them saw that someone or a group of people were on the roof.“The fu-?” Kirishima said, glancing up in confusion.Suddenly, the same metal door that Kirishima entered through opened again with Bakugo walking through in a black shirt and cargo pants that matched, already having small explosions go off in his palms.“Step aside, Extras. Why did you even come all this way to get here?” Bakugo yelled at Deku while everyone watched around them, almost frozen, ready to take the fight or flight.“I never knew you would go this far, Kacchan! We’re not kids anymore! Of course you and your brigade would’ve believed in those lies we’ve been fed. I was hoping you’d follow in my tracks. Anyways, we can talk about this another time. I’ve been waiting for this!” he yelled at the heroes in a declaration of a fight.Watching this chaos unfold, Momo had no other choice than to run. It was an opportunity that she was forced to take. Only Kirishima was there to notice her escape, but couldn’t stop her as he needed to support Bakugo.Hours passed after the fight, the UVA stood victorious after beating the Deku Squad to a pulp which forced them to retreat. Though both sides lost in this battle, Bakugo lost the factory to his operation as he thought of it. That’s why he had to call in his last but strongest card from his deck.It was on the cold night where Bakugo leaned back in his office chair waiting for their arrival, the photo on his desk was crushed while he had bandaging on his arms revealed by his short sleeved black shirt and cargo pants. Suddenly, a knock could be heard by the door.“Come in. story :

Kazuki Matsuda was born in the third generation of quirks, a time of great change and upheaval in the world of heroes and villains. Despite his incredible quirk, Kazuki grew up in a humble home, raised by hardworking parents who valued education and discipline above all else.
From a young age, Kazuki showed an aptitude for his quirk, which allowed him to manipulate time and space in ways that no one had ever seen before. However, he struggled to understand the true nature of his abilities, and spent much of his childhood experimenting with different ways to harness their power.
It wasn't until Kazuki reached his teenage years that he began to grasp the full potential of his quirk. With newfound confidence and skill, he became obsessed with the idea of achieving eternal life and reaching a kind of heaven-like existence. He would spend hours each day practicing his powers, trying to manipulate time and space in ways that would allow him to transcend the mortal world.
As his obsession deepened, Kazuki began to neglect his health and well-being. He would often go days without eating or drinking, so focused was he on his goal of achieving immortality. His parents tried to intervene, but Kazuki was so single-minded in his pursuit that he refused to listen to their concerns.
In the end, Kazuki's obsession proved to be his undoing. One hot summer day, he collapsed in his room, severely dehydrated and malnourished. Despite his parents' efforts to save him, he died a few hours later, his body too weak to withstand the strain of his quirk.
Kazuki's death was a shock to everyone who knew him, and his story became a cautionary tale among the hero community. Though he had possessed incredible power, he had been unable to see the beauty and wonder of the world around him, so focused was he on his own desires. In the end, Kazuki's legacy served as a reminder that even the most powerful quirk could not grant true happiness or fulfillment, and that it was the journey itself that mattered most.

backstory :
Your mother gave birth to you when she was only 16 years old. As a teenager, she was not ready to take care of a child, especially since she was still pursuing her studies. So, she made the difficult decision to leave you at an orphanage, hoping that you would have a better life with people who could take care of you.
At the orphanage, you met Hitoshi Shinso, who was also abandoned by his parents. Despite being babies, you both quickly became best friends and grew up together in the same orphanage. Since you had no one else, you relied on each other for support and companionship.
When you were five years old, you and Hitoshi were both adopted by different families. Hitoshi went to live with Shota Aizawa, a hero who had a unique quirk that allowed him to control people's actions by speaking to them. Meanwhile, you were adopted by All Might, one of the most famous and powerful heroes in the world.
Growing up with All Might as your father figure, you were inspired to become a hero yourself. At the age of eight, you started training on your own, pushing yourself to become stronger and more skilled. All Might helped you along the way, teaching you how to control your quirk and hone your physical abilities. You also trained your mental fortitude, knowing that your quirk had a powerful effect on people's minds.
As you grew older, you became more and more skilled, taking on increasingly difficult challenges to test your abilities. You learned how to open doors with larger and larger things, gradually building up your strength and precision. You also worked on your stealth, agility, and speed, becoming a true all-around hero.
When you turned 14 years old, All Might revealed to you that he had chosen a successor to his quirk, One For All. At first, you were upset that he had not chosen you, as he had promised you before. However, you soon came to accept his decision and began to support his new successor.
Both you and the successor enrolled in U.A. High School, a prestigious academy for aspiring heroes. You performed incredibly well, earning second place in the final rankings. With your skills and determination, you were ready to take on any challenge that came your way and become a true hero, just like your father figure, All Might

It felt like a chase, a cop chasing the culprit who was the cause of a brutal case and had just been caught. 

He kept running, and running, and continued to run after the green-haired boy who he’d always thought was below him. Bakugo chased Izuku through the halls and to the school roof, panting and slipping on the school's floors. His hands were sweaty and clothes stuck to his body.

He almost felt out of breath. In fact, he fucking was. 

He was going to fucking kill Deku for taking his advice! Yeah, he told him to. But.. nevermind that right now! 

“Deku! Get back here!” he yelled, still running. “If you keep running, I'll kill you! You hear me?!” 

He sounded desperate, very desperate. He really didn’t understand how it all got to this point. “Deku wait!" he shouted. but to no avail. 

Izuku kept running ahead of him. somewhere in the back of his head he's surprised by how fast he's gotten, but that's all fogged up by all of the thoughts rushing through his head. 

It felt like they were running for hours, and honestly, they probably have. Izuku stopped running once he reached the roof. sweat dripping down his head to his chin. his green hair stuck to his forehead as if it were glued to it. 

“Deku!” the blonde stood behind him. “Get away from the edge.” he demanded, his voice hoarse. 

Izuku turned to him, looking at the appearance of his exhausted best friend. He feels bad, but he’s only doing what he was told to. 

“Isn't this what you wanted Kacchan, for me to end myself? to take a swan dive off of the roof?!" Izuku yelled back at him. 

Bakugo just stared at the boy in front of him. They were both sweaty and exhausted. “What about becoming a hero?! Isn’t that what you wanted?!” 

Izuku sadly chuckles, “isn’t that what you didn’t want me to do? To become a hero?” he said, slowly walking backwards. 

“Why change your mind now, Kacchan?” 

Bakugou panicked, stammering. “I–” he tried, but nothing came out. And he couldn’t handle the sad smile on Deku’s face. 

“You don’t have to explain, Kacchan. I know you hate me–” “NO!” 

Izuku was cut off, shocked but listened to what he had to say. “That was a mistake. I never meant any of it!" Bakugo was near tears. “I..” 

Fuck, he was never going to live this down. 

“I’d always thought you were useless, after we found out you were quirkless. When we were younger, even with a quirk I felt like I had to act better than anyone else just to feel validated.

Even now, and I couldn’t stand the fact that even without a quirk. That you believed 

you 

were capable of anything, that 

I 

was capable of anything. Everything you did, you did it with a smile on your face. And I couldn’t accept the fact that someone like 

you 

could be

 so fucking nice

 to an 

asshole 

like me!” 

Bakugou remembers all the times he hit Deku, acted better than him, bullied him, anything really. Then, he’d regret it later. But his ego was too fragile, so he was incapable of showing regret publicly, even the smallest amount. 

He remembers the time he was caught crying by him, he just pushed Izuku away. He’d been unconsciously drowning narcissism and self loath that he could never realize how wrong he was. 

How he had pushed the weakness and hatred he felt on himself onto someone who’d probably risk his own life if he were to ever be in danger. 

He was too sensitive to admit his own feelings, the last time he tried. He’d been called weak, by his own 

mother. 

All his dad could do would comfort him as he cried but neither of them ever spoke about that vulnerable moment again.

 “Kacchan..” 

“I was too afraid to–” he cut himself off, still too weak to admit his own weakness. “I never meant what I said!” 

He’s crying now, he realizes. But he’s too tired to care.

“I never understand why I do or say the things I do. I just crave attention and can’t stop myself from making stupid decisions just because I wanted to be liked in some way.”

Izuku didn’t say anything. His expression was slightly blank with only widened eyes. 

The green-haired boy chuckled, also starting to cry. “Maybe if I go, you’ll get better.” 

His crimson eyes widened, “no..”

He took a step back, smiled back at him and said. 


“I’m sorry, Kacchan…



It’s better this way..” 


Katsuki screamed, running to him. 

“IZUKU!”


He’d been watching, watching as his blonde haired best friend explained his reasoning for bullying him. 

Why he had even harmed him in the first place.

It’s because of him, isn’t it? 

This is all his fault, right? 

Maybe if he leaves, Kacchan will be happy! 

Yeah, happy.. 

Izuku chuckled, 

“I’m sorry, Kacchan…

It’s better this way..” 

He fell back and let his body tumble to the hard concrete ground, the last thing he heard was kacchan calling him by his name.

Now, he realizes. Was leaving the right choice? 

It was too late now. 

As he was currently being welcomed into the cold embrace of death. 


I’m so sorry, mom. 



Kacchan. 



I love you.


“IZUKU!”

Bakugo yelled out to him. but all he heard was the god-forbidden noise of his body hitting the floor.

There had been a loud crunching noise and he’d flinched at it. When he looked down, he saw the dark red ichor make a puddle around a cold resting body. His head snapped, no chance of surviving. 

He sank to his knees, putting his hands to his blood red eyes and sat there. In shock and deep in overwhelming emotions. 

Sobbing until the sun set and his mom came searching for him.

After that, he didn’t leave his room. Not until the green boy's funeral, after his speech had finished he had excused himself to go to the bathroom. 

Little did they know that’d never come out, for he had never even entered. 

In fact, he laid deceased underneath a bridge with a note and his shoes by the rail. Drowning in a puddle of his own crimson liquids.

He felt pathetic, but now. 

He lied there with a pathetic sad genuine 

smile 

on his face. 

Being welcomed into the cold waiting arms of death itself.

Chapter Text
 Per the Villain Reform Act that was passed a few months after the war, the Japanese government vowed to focus on rehabilitation rather than punishment for surviving villains. Rather than serving jail time, government mandated therapy was now implemented for villains who surrender and accept the plea deal. Society was reflecting on the hypocrisy that it had grown too used to, and the debate on the definition of a hero versus a villain was once again brought forth to the table.  Although there was tons of initial backlash about letting the villains go without traditional forms of punishment, what made a difference this time is prominent figures in the hero society supporting the new bill and urging the public to hold on to their empathy and humanity, to truly unite as one for a better future. To see these heroes who bled and sacrificed for their safety vouching for their enemies swayed the opinion of most people who spoke out against the new law. While the general population remained skeptical, their attitude began to shift when they saw concrete evidence of rehabilitation working—numbers don’t lie, crime rate was dropping, people started feeling safe again, and smiles returned to the post-war world as citizens of Japan found their path in rebuilding their society.  Dabi, now Touya Todoroki, also accepted the deal following his defeat on the battlefield. The former villain was hospitalized for a long, long time, as his body suffered from severe injuries that required a large team of specialized medical professionals. On top of that, his mental instability was another cause of concern. The Todoroki family did everything they could to assist in Touya’s recovery, keeping him situated in a private hospital in order to shield him away from the public’s prying eyes.  During the first year of Touya’s treatment, the doctors had advised his family to refrain from visiting him as they were afraid of triggering his trauma. The Todorokis hesitantly accepted, each hoping for the chance to see him when his conditions improved. Yet when the time came and the doctors finally cleared him for visitations, Touya only muttered one name.  “Keigo Takami. That’s the only one I will see. The rest of them can fuck right off.” Although they were disappointed, the Todoroki family respected Touya’s decision. At this point, the fact that he was even willing to see even just one person, is progress that could not afford to lose. 



Keigo arrives at the hospital as soon as he hears about Touya’ request. In fact, he actually dropped everything he was doing and ran here. He was afraid Touya would change his mind and wanted to see him before he did.  The taller man is different from what he remembers the last time he saw him on the battlefield. His wounds have healed, and the doctors are trying out novel treatments for his charred skin, hoping to restore some of his damaged tissues. The medical team also makes sure he is getting all the proper nutrients he needs. He looks……healthier.  Touya is sitting on the bed when Keigo knocks and opens the door to his room, his deep blue eyes fixed on somewhere over the horizon out the window. He seems so focused that Keigo almost feels like he is interrupting. When Touya’s eyes finally land on him, Keigo can feel his heart jump in his rib cage.   “You came.” The white-haired man says, calmly, like he isn’t talking to someone that betrayed his trust and fought him in the war a year ago.  Keigo doesn’t know what kind of expression he should be wearing right now. For such a long time, he acted purely in the interest of others, putting the greater good above all else. Now, after the war, he suddenly realizes he doesn’t even know how he fits in with the rest of the world. Without his hero name,  Hawks , he is just another man that needs to find his path.  “Heard you wanted to see me.” Keigo puts on a tight smile, the tension in his heart threatening to burst at any second.  Touya takes a good look at him up and down, even for someone like Keigo who was trained to be perceptive since youth, his emotions are still completely unreadable.“Your wings.” He speaks again after a long while, “......they didn’t fully come back?” Keigo's wing on his left side flutters painfully at the reminder. “No……There were some uh, complications.” Keigo tries his best to maneuver this conversation, ignoring the violent flashbacks he is getting about the last time he fought Touya. He was going to die that day, he was convinced. Till this day, he can still remember the smell of the Earth as Touya shoved his face to the ground, his boot weighing heavy on his back. Not only did Touya burn most of his feathers, he could feel his hand wrapping around the tip of his left wing. His mind was racing as he realized what he was going to do.  Keigo held his scream in his throat as Touya tore off his wing with a loud snap. He could have lost both of his wings that day, but reinforcement arrived before Touya had the chance to go for his other.  He doesn’t recall the details about the rest of that day, the pain on his back shocked his system into a dazed state, neurotransmitters firing on all cylinders. He only remembers losing consciousness in the arms of his worried student, Tokoyami. The next time he opened his eyes, he was heavily bandaged and found himself at the hospital. Till this day, while his wing on the right side has made a near full recovery, his left wing is healing poorly and remains small. With his left wing in its diminished state, Keigo hasn't been able to fly for the past year.  “—the doctors are optimistic, though. They think physical therapy is going to help, and I already made some good progress so far.” With that, Keigo says cheerfully and offers the biggest smile he can muster. It’s a genuine one, because Keigo himself believes so, too. Things will always get better. Touya goes completely still, even his breathing is hardly detectable, and Keigo’s heart rate quickens with heavy anxiety. He doesn’t know what to do, how to make things easier for Touya. There is no leverage, nothing for him to offer. Most people would not be able to understand why despite fighting as a hero, there is this lingering guilt weighing on top of his chest every day that never goes away. He cannot explain why if he is to be honest with himself, all he wants to do right now is hold Touya’s hand and sob out apologies flowing from his lips. The heroes have always let them down, huh. In this new world, is it too late? Can he still make amends?  “Why did you come here, Keigo.” At last, it is Touya’s question that breaks the silence. Keigo looks up to see the flame-user gazing at him once again. “After all that I’ve done to you……” “I hurt you too.” Keigo answers a little too quickly, racing to remind Touya of the same sins he carried. “You were right, I lied, and I killed, just like you. I wasn’t a hero, never deserved that title.” He looks down at his open palms, thinking of the nightmare he had a few nights ago where he couldn’t wash the blood off his hands no matter how hard he scrubbed them under steaming water. “But yet……I am here. And you are here. We survived.” He exhales deeply, trying to gather the courage to push himself to ask the questions that remain unanswered.   “Why did you allow me to be here, Touya?”  The former lieutenant of the Paranormal Liberation Front runs his hand through his white hair, pressing his lips tight.  “Even when you lied to me, it felt real. Now that everything is over, I just wanted to see you, even though I don’t know why you’d even agree to that in the first place.”  “I……wasn’t lying all the time.” Keigo mumbles in a small voice, offering truth that he kept hidden. During his infiltration mission, he had to bury all his emotions deep below the surface, because emotions mean mistakes, and he couldn’t allow himself to make any more errors than he already did. "And I wanted to see you, too." Touya leans back against his bed, his face remaining closed off, but Keigo can see a hint of self-doubt brewing.  “Two more months.” Seeing the confusion on Keigo’s face, Touya elaborates. “The doctor said I will be ready for discharge in two months, but where the hell am I supposed to go.” He runs a hand over his face, irked, “And I am not going back to my stupid family, for obvious reasons.”  Hope bubbles in Keigo’s chest. “I have a place.”  “Yeah?” Touya glances at him, a ghost of a smile on his lip, a hint of relief. “You going to let me crash at your place?” “For as long as you want.” Keigo promises, his feet shuffling in nervous energy. “I’ll get a few things in order tonight, but you can come whenever.”  “Alright, I think this goes without saying, but I am broke as hell.” Touya scratches the back of his head, and Keigo can’t help but to chuckle. “Don’t expect me to pay rent or anything, little bird.” “I don’t expect anything in return, Touya.” Keigo replies in sincerity, and he swears he sees the other man’s expression soften. It feels nice to call him by his real name,  Touya .  



Exactly two months later, Touya gets the green light from his medical team. Carrying nothing but a backpack, he hops into Keigo’s car parked right in front of the hospital.  “You ready?” The blond asks, and without a word, Touya nods. He watches Keigo step on the gas pedal and drives away, until the hospital completely disappears from his view. He doesn’t know what comes next, but the only thing he knows for sure is, he wants to know the real Keigo Takami. Not the perfect soldier trained by the Hero Public Safety Commission, not Hawks, just Keigo.  The two of them, no lies or deceit this time.    He thinks this is a good place to start.

completion:
Kirishima had always known that Izuku and Katsuki had a complicated relationship. As their classmate and friend, he had seen them argue, fight, and sometimes even team up to take down villains. But he had never suspected that they were in love with each other until their second year of high school.

It was a beautiful spring day when Kirishima first noticed something different about Izuku and Katsuki. They were walking side by side, laughing and joking with each other in a way that seemed more intimate than friendly. Kirishima couldn't put his finger on what had changed, but he could tell that something was different between them.

Over the next few weeks, Kirishima watched as Izuku and Katsuki grew closer and closer. They spent more and more time together, and their interactions became more affectionate. They would touch each other's arms or shoulders when they spoke, and Kirishima could see the way they looked at each other when they thought no one was watching.

At first, Kirishima was happy for them. He thought that maybe they had finally worked through their issues and were building a romantic relationship. But as time went on, he began to see cracks in their newfound happiness.

It started with small disagreements, little fights that would blow over quickly. But then the arguments became more frequent and more heated. Izuku and Katsuki seemed to be on edge around each other, and Kirishima could sense the tension whenever they were in the same room.

One day, Kirishima overheard a conversation between Izuku and Katsuki that confirmed his suspicions. They were arguing about something trivial, but their words were laced with anger and frustration. Kirishima could hear the pain in Izuku's voice as he spoke, and the bitterness in Katsuki's tone.

"You're impossible to be around sometimes, Kacchan!" Izuku shouted.

"Me? You're the one who's always moping around and making everything about you!" Katsuki retorted.

Kirishima knew then that something had gone wrong between them. He didn't know what had caused their relationship to fall apart, but he could see the hurt and anger on both of their faces. It was clear that they were no longer in love, if they ever had been.

Over the next few weeks, Kirishima watched as Izuku and Katsuki drifted further and further apart. They stopped spending time together and avoided each other as much as possible. Kirishima tried to talk to them individually, to see if he could help mend their friendship, but they both seemed too hurt to listen.

In the end, Kirishima could only watch as Izuku and Katsuki went their separate ways. He knew that they would always be important to each other, even if they couldn't be together romantically. But he also knew that their breakup had left a scar on both of their hearts, one that would take time to heal.

As Kirishima watched Izuku and Katsuki move on with their lives, he couldn't help but feel a sense of sadness. He knew that they were both trying to find happiness with other people, but he also knew that their hearts still belonged to each other.

Over the years, Kirishima watched as Izuku and Katsuki got into relationships with other people, only to have those relationships end in heartbreak. Each time, Kirishima saw the pain in their eyes and knew that they were still holding onto something that they couldn't let go of.

But it wasn't until a huge villain attack that Kirishima saw just how much Izuku and Katsuki still cared for each other. The attack was one of the most intense battles that Kirishima had ever seen, and he watched as his friends fought with everything they had to protect the city.

At one point, Katsuki was separated from the rest of the group and found himself face to face with one of the strongest villains. Kirishima watched in horror as the villain delivered blow after blow to Katsuki, leaving him bloodied and barely conscious.

It was then that Izuku appeared, having fought his way through the chaos to reach Katsuki's side. As he cradled Katsuki's battered body in his arms, Kirishima saw the love and fear in his eyes. He knew then that no matter how hard they had tried to move on, Izuku and Katsuki were still in love with each other.

In that moment, as the two boys clung to each other amidst the rubble of the city, Kirishima realized that he couldn't stand by and watch his friends suffer anymore. He approached them, his heart heavy with the knowledge of what he was about to do.

"Izuku, Katsuki," he said softly. "I know that you both love each other. And I know that you're scared to admit it. But you can't keep running from your feelings forever. Life is too short to not be with the person you love."

Izuku and Katsuki looked up at Kirishima, their eyes wide with surprise. They both opened their mouths to speak, but Kirishima held up his hand to stop them.

"I'm not asking you to do anything right now," he said. "Just think about it. Think about what you want, and what will make you truly happy."

With that, Kirishima walked away, leaving Izuku and Katsuki alone in the aftermath of the battle. He didn't know what would happen next, but he knew that he had done everything he could to help his friends find their way back to each other.

As he walked away, Kirishima felt a weight lifted off his shoulders. He knew that he had finally done the right thing, and that no matter what happened, he had given his friends the chance to find happiness with each other once again.

Kirishima watched with joy as Izuku and Katsuki began to tentatively explore their feelings for each other once again. It wasn't an easy journey for them, but Kirishima was there to support them every step of the way.

He watched as they went on their first date in years, and as they started spending more and more time together. He saw the way they looked at each other, and the way they couldn't help but smile whenever they were in each other's presence.

As time went on, their relationship deepened, and Kirishima watched as they fell in love all over again. He was there when Katsuki proposed to Izuku, and he cried tears of joy as they exchanged their vows at their wedding.

But their love story didn't end there. Over the years, Kirishima watched as Izuku and Katsuki adopted children and built a life together. He saw the way they loved their kids with all their hearts, and the way they always put their family first.

It was a beautiful thing to see, and Kirishima felt so happy for his friends. They had been through so much, but they had found their way back to each other and built a life that was full of love and happiness.

As for Kirishima himself, he had found someone special as well. He had married his wonderful wife Mina, and the two of them were incredibly happy together. They had their own family, and Kirishima felt grateful every day for the love and support that they shared.

In the end, Kirishima realized that love was a powerful thing. It could break you apart, but it could also bring you back together again. He was grateful to have been a part of Izuku and Katsuki's love story, and he knew that they would always have a special place in his heart.

I really want to tell you but I'm scared." Bakugo sighed. Frankie rubbed Bakugos back. "I'm scared you're going to hate me.""I could never hate you, you're my best friend." prompt: write a story about Haikyuu!!,  Not Rated Major Character Death Gen 僕のヒーローアカデミア | Boku no Hero Academia | My Hero Academia (Anime & Manga) Dabi | Todoroki Touya/Reader Major Character Injury Character Death Reader-Insert brief mention of burns Hurt No Comfort Angst Heartbreak Inspired by a Hozier Song Dabi | Todoroki Touya Angst no happy ending Abandonment
completion:
He’s now thankful your home is on the outer reaches of the city, tucked in a secluded pocket between the border of the forest and the concrete hell of the city. After what he’s done, there’s not a person in Japan that wouldn’t recognize his face. Had you not lived in the middle of nowhere, he’d already be arrested by some weak police officer or jumped by some rookie hero. 

It’s ironic, the thinks, that his opinion has changed. He hated it, at one point. You lived so far away from his shitty apartment at the time, meaning that every time he wanted to see you, he had to take the agonizingly long train rides. It was like you lived in a fucking retirement community since all the elderly would take the same train, giving him judgmental stares all the while. It pissed him off to no end. And if that wasn’t enough, being in the forest always reminded him of Sekoto. 

But still, he bore it all for you, back before he let his rage consume him. 

Before he devoted himself entirely to revenge. 

Before he started burning himself all over again. 

Before he fucked it all up.

Despite the way he left you, he hopes you’ll be kind enough to him to accept his return, to not instantly slam the door in his face. If he even makes it to your doorstep, that is. Each step he takes feels like a battle between life and death. These heavy and labored movements exhaust him, made worse by the state your driveway is in. Of all the days for it to rain, it just had to be today. The torrential downpours make the path harder to traverse. Mud clings to his boots with every trudging step he takes, threatening to suck him into the earth, burying him at his final resting place. 

The puddles of water settling in the tire tracks of your car show him grim reminders of his appearance, showing him glimpses of just how ghastly he’s become.

He’s a burnt husk of what he once was.

Nothing is left of him now that he's achieved his life’s purpose. 

The only thing that remains of him is this homing instinct to return to you. To go back to the start. 

To give you what’s left of him.

To feel his final sensation of comfort.

To feel loved again.

He’s faced with the reality of how long it’s been when he finally catches sight of your home. In the year he was by your side, he never saw those Foxgloves bloom once, as he met you in the late summer. But now, judging by the towering violet, bell-shaped flowers framing the sides of your window, it’s been three years. It’s in this moment that his mind replays the memory of the following summer, the one in which he noticed you agonizing over the flowerless plant beds. He remembers it, with surprising clarity amongst the mental fog. 

“Why do you bother taking care of those stupid flowers if they never fucking bloom?” He asked you, critically. 

“They’re foxgloves,” you answer. 

“So?”

“So, they do bloom, just biennially, and their flowering season just passed. You’ll see why I keep ‘em around in another year,” you explain. The fact you even implied he’d still be in your life a year from then filled him with a sense of security. Whether you meant it or not, he took it as a promise, and kept it tucked in the darker reaches of his heart. 

Three long years have passed since he left you, since he abandoned you without a word. But he has known you have a patient side to you, he’s seen it in the way you always gave him space in his darkest days, how you allowed him the time to come back to you when he was ready, how you never took his frustrating habit of pushing you away to heart, weathering his toxicity with love and carefulness. Maybe, since you’re so patient, you have been waiting for him. If you welcomed those flowers despite their long absence, maybe you’d accept him, too. 

Normally, he’d sneer at the thought of you turning him into such a hopeless romantic, a weaker version of himself, but considering how there’s nothing left of him anyways, he’s fine with the idea. Maybe the positivity you give him would turn him into something beautiful again. 

He finally climbs up to your doorstep and stumbles against the door. When his shaky and weak hands turn the knob, expecting to be met with a locked door, it turns easily without resistance. Your door is unlocked, which in his state of hopeful delusion, he interprets as you waiting for him. Maybe you knew he would come back. You had made it easy for him to crawl back into your life.

Or maybe you just forgot to lock it. 

He swings open the door as he leans against the door frame. Any other time, the sound of the groaning hinges would grate at his ears, but right now, the sound feels familiar and comforting. It feels like nothing has changed, everything is as it once was. He trudges deeper into your home, shambling past your living room and tracking mud all over your floors. There’s a pit of anxiety forming in his stomach the longer he walks through your home without seeing a glimpse of you. It’s when he approaches the kitchen that he hears you humming, the sound calming his mind. 

His boots thud on your tiled floor, loud, and uneven. He sways as he walks, bumping into one of your dining chairs, the movement scraping the chair against the floor. Your humming abruptly cuts off at the sound and you turn to the source, on high alert, only to see him propping himself up against the walls. A sharp gasp escapes your lungs. 

All he can see is you as the edges of his vision grey out. Against your better judgment, you rush over to him as his legs start buckling underneath him.  

He starts to collapse on the spot. You close the distance and open your arms around him, catching his fall and attempting to bear the brunt of his weight. 

Despite what he’s done, despite how he left you so suddenly, he can still feel your love for him. It’s in the way you try to make sure he doesn’t fall, despite tripping being the least concern to him given his injuries. It’s how your voice sounds frantic as you ask him if he’s okay if he can hear you, if he’s still in there. It’s how you start to sob at seeing the state he’s in. 

You’re so worried about getting him to lie on the ground safely and checking his pulse that you fail to see him softly smiling at how you fuss over him, what’s left of his burnt face forcing out a peaceful expression. 

The last thing he hears, the last thing he feels, the last thing he thinks about, is you.
<<EOFANFIC>>

 An intruder.

He hasn’t blinked a single time. “He?”“The intruder.” Midoriya spoke as if the words weren’t his own, “The man in the hood.”
 Knock knock knock.

 Knock knock knock. 
“Young Midoriya?”Midoriya’s shoulders relax ever-so-slightly at the familiar voice. “All Might…”“We’ll look for Eri.” Iida nods, determined, “Go speak to All Might. I’m sure it’s important.”They run off, leaving Midoriya alone in the loft once more.
 Knock knock knock. 
“Young Midoriya, I’d like to speak with you.” No.No. Something’s wrong.The knock is robotic. Can a knock  be robotic? Close enough to make out all the paint streaks over fine wood. His hand lands on the doorknob, and stays there. Frozen. He makes no move to turn it.“It’s late, All Might.” Midoriya says, testing waters, “And…we have an emergency. Eri’s—!”“I know.”The boy’s brows furrow, “You know about Eri?”“I know.”He knows. “Know what? Midoriya.”The knob rattled.“Your fear. Your fears.”“I know it all.”“I know all.”The knob rattled violently.“Midoriya.”“ Midoriya.” 


“Deku!” Uraraka grabbed Midoriya’s arm, yanking him towards her as they ran the opposite direction, “We have to go! Right now!”“Uraraka, wha—?”“I heard!” She says, nearly out of breath, “Whoever is behind that door isn’t All Might, Eri is missing, and I saw  him .” Her hand is shaking badly, “Th-The man…the man in the hood.” She swallows, trying to push down her fear but clearly proving futile, “I—I don’t know what’s happening but we have to go!”They reach a back door, distantly hearing wood crack and snap. All humans are connected through mistakes that was a lesson he learned early in life.Some people sleep with men that turn out to be murderers.Some pierce their lips with a used needle.Some eat gas station sushi.Some steal from gas stationsHitoshi was the master of mistakes.His whole life had been one mistake after the other.The universe had a pretty twisted sense of humor like that.But he made mistakes again and again and again, learning from them but never listening to those lessons.Which was probably how he ended up here,puking his guts out into the flower garden of someone he had never met before. He stopped long enough to regain his senses then promptly spewed another bout of stomach acid and alcohol. A crowd had gathered and was making collective noises of disgust while likely recording the whole thing to post on their social media timelines at a later time. But Hitoshi couldn’t bring himself to care. He felt a hand on his back and looked up into eyes golden like miniature suns but full of concern.The voice belonging to those eyes asked something but Hitoshi either was too out of it to understand or they were speaking in a different language.“Are you okay?” the boy with the sun for eyes asked, his Japanese tinted with an American accent. That answered Hitoshi’s question. The first attempt was probably asked in English, a language he was competent in when sober but while drunk it’s next to impossible for him to understand.Hitoshi only nodded, not trusting himself to speak lest he vomit again. He finally looked at the other boy fully, he had shocking yellow hair with a black lightning stripe on the left side of his fringe, snakebites, and several other piercings. Hitoshi found himself staring at the snakebites wondering how they would feel in a kiss.“Is that natural?” his stupid mouth asked. Hitoshi internally cursed he just needed to get through the embarrassment of the night.The boy ran his hand through his hair and laughed, “How about we get you home before you ask any more questions.”The American accent was starting to fade the longer he talked, Hitoshi wished it would come back. “But seriously dude are you okay or do you just have a personal grudge against chrysanthemums. Because I don't blame you I might judge you for your flower choice but that’s mostly because I prefer to ruin tulips.”
Hitoshi looked up at the boy, “I can take care of myself from here you go back to the party.”The boy looked him up and down and patted his shoulder, “Whatever man, just don’t go to another party. wouldn’t want anything bad to happen to you.”Hitoshi internally scoffed the whole reason he was out here was because his life was a constant stream of bad things happening to him. His mom dying, the system neglecting him, the streets raising him, you name it, it's probably happened at least once in his miserable excuse for a life. He felt a piece of paper slip into his hand and tucked it into his pocket. He would worry about that at a later date.Losing himself in his thoughts he began the long trek to his current foster hell, The Ito’s or as he was expected to call them Ito-san and Ito-sensei were the latest in an excruciatingly long string of assholes taking him in for the money they would get paid for being such gracious souls and taking on a future villain like him. They had two other victims and probably wished they could take more in so they could get more money. Hitoshi finally started paying attention to his surroundings, it was important for him to remain vigilant in the area he lived in. He never knew who might be lurking and he would rather not deal with certain people on his self proclaimed night off. Arriving at the alley behind the house he was forced to live in he climbed the crates stacked next to the hellscape and slid himself through the bedroom window.A light turned on revealing his sister Yamashita Ayaka in all her disappointed mom glory. “You’re late.”“I know can we talk about this in the morning?”Ayaka looked at Hitoshi with an expression that left no room for arguments and walked over to the window. Opening it and gesturing for Hitoshi to follow, she jumped out and walked to the doorway of the abandoned building on the other side of the alley. Hitoshi rolled his eyes and climbed out the way he came.“Do we really have to talk all the way out here?”Ayaka smirked and tossed Hitoshi his Suorin, “No, but you’re not vaping inside when Asahi’s in there.”Hitoshi rolled his eyes and turned it on, taking a long hit. Exhaling, he said, “So what do you want to talk about?”“Why were you so late? It's three in the morning and you have to walk Suki to school early." Ayaka said, looking concerned."I took tonight off and went to a party." Ayaka gestured for him to continue."Well I got drunk and ruined a few flowers, you'll probably see the video around school. Ended up meeting a guy and walked home."“Wait, say that again.”“I got drunk and ruined some flowers.”“No dipshit, the part about meeting someone.”
“What it’s not like I'll ever see him again, I don't even know his name. All he gave me was a note.”Ayaka sighed as though talking to Hitoshi was causing her physical pain, “Did you at least look at the damn thing?”
“I was more worried about getting back than looking at a piece of paper a hot guy gave me.” He took a hit and attempted to do the Bane trick.“I’m going to sleep maybe when I wake up you’ll have grown a fucking brain.” with that Ayaka scaled the makeshift stairs and slid into the room.Hitoshi spent a few more minutes out there vaping and listening to the sounds of the city before he headed in, “Night.” he said to the shape on the top bunk belonging to Ayaka and layed down on his own bunk.<><><><><>“Good morning mom.” he said holding his nephew so he could see what Hitoshi saw. The ten month old baby had woken up when Hitoshi accidentally bumped into the makeshift crib on his way to the window.Hitoshi felt the diaper grow warm and wet, "Really kid?" He said looking at Asahi.Asahi gave him a gummy smile and gurgled his response."You're lucky you're cute." Hitoshi said laying Asahi on top of the dresser to change his diaper. He knew that most teenagers would cringe away from the thought of changing a diaper but he had honestly been mostly desensitized to the process.Snapping a clean onesie onto the little monster Hitoshi put on a clean sweatshirt and carried him down to the kitchen. He set Asahi on the counter, “Where did she put the fucking formula?” he asked the kid after not finding the canister in the cabinents. Asahi just blew spit bubbles. “Great help kid.” Hitoshi hoisted Asahi onto his hip.“Sahi, how do you feel about going to the grocery store?” he asked, carrying the child to their room to get everything.
<<EOFANFIC>>

Shouta Aizawa always knew he’d die fighting a losing battle. He knew deep in his bones, in his soul, that he’d never lie down easy, and he thought he deserved it. A fitting end to such a terrible person, he’d muse. Everyone around him would argue, would insist, that he was amazing in his own way, a true hero -a student had called him- but he knew better. 



He knew after every nightmare, every flashback, every news story, and every paper. He knew from the recent headstones at the cemeteries, the obituaries, the grieving families and friends. He knew from the crime rates, the death rates, the 

suicide

 rates. What he caused and didn't cause. What he affected and didn’t affect. What he influenced and didn’t influence. He always found fault within himself, and that is perhaps what made him so good at his job. 



How could he let his overconfidence, his ego, get in the way, leave him vulnerable, if it didn’t exist. If he forever viewed himself as worthless, holding himself accountable, then he’d have no hesitation. He’d be able to make decisions that risked himself, his life, his future. Because he deserved it. He deserved it, and if losing an arm or a leg atoned for the sins of his past and present, he’d do it. Without hesitation, forever without hesitation. 



Maybe this thought process is what led to where he is now. Perhaps, viewing himself as disposable for the greater good, is what caused all around him to suffer in pain and grief. He had known realistically, logically, that people cared for him, but how deeply they did, was always questionable. 



Shouta Aizawa could tell you anything and everything about a person and their habits, their choices and their responses, all through analysis. What he couldn’t tell you, is how they feel, how they 

truly

 feel. He would know realistically that they’d be sad or worried if their friend was injured, but he couldn’t tell you how strongly, or if they were actually feeling that at all. He couldn’t tell you 
why
. And that bothered him.



He knew that no one is perfect, it is impossible to be. He knew that, so why did he force himself to be? To strive towards a state of being impossible to achieve, a forever losing battle. If he was perfect, this wouldn’t have happened. If he was perfect, they wouldn’t have died. If he was perfect, they’d have lived a little longer. If he was perfect, he’d feel like a living human being, rather than an emotionless weapon with a dwindling purpose to keep him moving. He was a survivor, but not alive. 



How could he save everyone, protect everyone, if he was just 

human? 

A mere mortal like himself will forever be incapable, unable, to do what he wished, what he begged, to accomplish. A hero saves the day, but never without casualty. He engraved that lesson in his head, carved the words into his skull, and yet, he still fell short. He still strived for a state of being that couldn’t be reached. He was a pebble at the bottom of a waterfall, never to reach the top. Never to graze the sky. 



Maybe this was why he failed time and time again. Maybe the thought, the pattern, of constant disappointment towards himself blinded him from everything else. He missed the signs, the clues, the warnings. Could he even say it was an accident? Here he sat, alone, in the dark of his small apartment. The walls dim and blank of any touch, any emotion or expression. He was dull, just as his house, as his possessions. 


Shouta Aizawa felt empty, felt numb. He was engulfed in a blank space he couldn’t escape, or even want to escape. Why should he save himself? Why should he try? Why fight, to win nothing? To prove nothing? Where was the point? He viewed himself objectively, in 3rd person almost. He was a witness through eyes he felt weren’t his of the life the body that held his tired soul went through. Words were his but weren’t. 


He knew, deep down, etched into his soul, that this wasn’t how someone should live. He shouldn’t feel like a backseat passenger to the life that was driving him far from his values, his purpose, his desires. 

Did he have desires?

 He knew, based off of others, off of research, off of his basic understanding of humans and how they live, that he was doing it wrong. What he was doing, wasn’t living, wasn’t fulfilling, it was simply doing an action because he could. It was chosen for him. Did he even remember why he wanted to be a hero in the first place? Was it to save people? Or was it simply the only job he knew he’d be good at.



How could he be anything different? How 

couldn’t

 he be anything different? He knew his strengths and weaknesses. He knew what he was capable of and what his skillset was. Was it enough? Weren’t humans supposed to strive off? Reach for something to be better at, to be good at. Was exhaustion a daily feeling for everyone? Or was he broken? Was his existence tainted with black? Questions, questions, questions, yet none had an answer. It’s okay, he wasn’t all that curious anyways. He could survive with curiosity, it’d die out soon enough.



Maybe he didn’t need answers. Maybe the things he questioned were worth more than whatever he could offer, even his soul. If he were actually worthy, priced higher than his self-judged amount, then he wouldn’t have these questions in the first place. There’d be no answers, for there'd be no inquiries to begin with. These defining statements molded his life, but if they held no form, no weight, neither did he. Maybe that was why he was like this.



Shouta Aizawa was a hollow human being. No soul, no goal, no drive. 



He thought 

(because did he ever really know?)

 that this was what made him a hero. 



How could he be anything but? If he wasn’t a good hero, he was nothing. 



Maybe he 

was

 nothing. 


Shouta Aizawa was nothing but a body. No soul, no goal, no drive, and no purpose.

<<EOFANFIC>>

Chapter Text

Here’s the thing, Shouto knows he shouldn’t question Bakugou, he knows he shouldn’t insert himself into his life too much, but they were friends weren’t they? 

The word “friends” was a little confusing to Shouto. Had always been confusing to him. He never had one until he joined UA and even now Bakugou will tell him every time that they are in fact 

not friends

. 
But if that was the case then why does Shouto find himself in Bakugou’s room sometimes? Why do they sit on his bed and watch films together? Why does Bakugou take time to explain things Shouto doesn’t understand about the films and he doesn’t get annoyed by it like he does with some of their other classmates?

If they weren’t friends, why does Bakugou take the time to make him meals when he knows Shouto hasn’t had time to try and make something simple, leaving it in the fridge with a label “icyhot” on it. 

Midoriya had once explained what being a friend meant and what friends typically do together, so Shouto was definitely aware he was friends with Bakugou; even after he specifically asked Midoriya. 

Even so, he wasn’t sure if this was something he could ask. He didn’t know all that much about the topic and he didn’t want to end up embarrassing himself or Bakugou for that matter. 
But as he watches Bakugou, he feels the need to want to know. 

“Do you like Midoriya?” He asks quietly, although Bakugou still startles a little from where he had been staring at Midoriya.

“What!? Why are you asking that?” He bites back, a little defensive Shouto notes. 

“You’re just staring at him a lot… it’s the sort of thing I see in those films we watch sometimes.” Shouto says simply.

“What the fuck are you trying to imply here half n half?” Bakugou narrows his eyes at him and if it were anyone else they probably would have dropped the topic by now, but not Shouto. 

“I’m not implying anything, I’m simply asking if you like him.” 

“No. He’s annoying, and if you don’t drop this right now you’ll be just as annoying as him.” Bakugou huffs. 

“I don’t think he’s annoying.” Shouto says and he watches as Midoriya interacts with Uraraka. He doesn’t get it though, Bakugou definitely looks at him like the boys look at their crushes in the movies they watch together. He doesn’t press it further though, not because he doesn’t want to but Aizawa walks in ready to begin the class. 

Throughout the rest of the day, Shouto watches as Bakugou interacts with his friends, he watches as his eyes will always somehow end up on Midoriya. He still doesn’t quite get it, why would Bakugou stare at him so much if he wasn’t interested? Shouto thought about raising it with Midoriya himself, to get some more insight to this whole crush and dating thing but he knows Bakugou would probably actually kill him if he did that. And so, he leaves it. 

That is until they’re back at the dorms and Shouto is sitting on Bakugou’s bed, their knees touching as the laptop is propped up in front of them. Some animated show playing on the screen. Shouto wasn’t paying much attention to this one, it hadn’t captivated him as much as the other stuff he watches with Bakugou. 

“Do you really not like Midoriya?” He asks quietly. He can almost feel Bakugou rolling his eyes in response. 

“Not this again… why are you so pushy with this?” Bakugou replies. 

“Just trying to understand, you were looking at him a lot today… actually you look at him a lot most days.” Shouto watches Bakugou lean forward to pause the show. 

“And why were you looking at me hm? You like me or something icyhot?” His voice is teasing but Shouto thinks he’s still serious. 

“No. I wanted to try and work out what your feelings are for him.” Shouto says simply and Bakugou scoffs at that. 

“I don’t have feelings for Deku.” 

“Okay.” Shouto says and he’s leaning forward to hit play on the show again. They settle into silence between them as they both try to focus on the scenes playing out in front of them until Bakugou speaks again. 

“I’m serious, I don’t like him.”

“Mhm.” 

“Look… if I did have any sort of feelings for him, you’re the last person I’d tell.” Bakugou states and Shouto pinches his eyebrows together as he turns to look at him.

“Why?” 

“Because you’d absolutely go and tell him.” 

“No I wouldn’t!” Shouto defends. He can keep secrets, especially ones that are not his own to keep. 

“Either that or you’d be weird about it and make it so incredibly obvious.” 

“I wouldn’t be weird about it… I can keep a secret.” 

“Ugh… fine whatever. So what, I have a crush on Deku.” Bakugou admits and he looks away from Shouto, his cheeks tinting red. 

“Oh. Okay… and are you going to do something about it?” Shouto’s not sure what he was expecting to feel hearing Bakugou did have a crush on Midoriya but he thinks he doesn’t feel anything notable about the situation. 

“Like what!? I can’t tell him. Heck, I don’t even know all that much about dating more than you do.” 

“Then learn! You know, like in those movies! Sometimes the main character seeks help from a friend… someone who has experience in that sort of thing. Hm but… who would have that experience?” Shouto thinks about it for a while, going through their class and deciding who would be good at helping Bakugou with this sort of thing. 
“Maybe Kirishima? I’m sure he’d be glad to help!” 

“I’m not asking shitty hair to fucking help me with dating. Besides, I don't need help with this. I can figure it out on my own.” 

“Okay… Thank you for telling me.” Shouto says and he has a soft smile on his face. He’s glad Bakugou trusts him enough to share something like this with him. 

“Don’t let it get to your head, doesn’t mean we’re friends.” He says and Shouto can’t help but smile more because yes… he would think this made them friends.

A moment of sharp discomfort, and then the sensation withdraws, before a tinkle can be heard.“Remind me never to get thrown through a window again,” he supplies before he hisses again. Jiro grunts in assent and he feels the brush of a cotton wool swap under the shower head, damp and delicate.The perp they had been chasing had been wanted for a string of robberies at jewellery stores, in possession of a quirk that allowed him to temporarily exert a high-gravity field that could pin any opponent to the ground for a sustained thirty seconds, unable to rise back up.Denki thought his assessment over their previous meetings had finally given him the drop on the man, realising his range was surprisingly limited and only functional against those already on the ground. With that in mind, he had opted for the mid-air manoeuvre to take him off-guard this time.He hadn’t counted on the guy having a mean left foot with so much power behind it.Outside the door, his leather jacket and shirt lied studded with glass fragments, having mostly protected him from the worst of the impact. Pixie-Bob was comfortably bored. 
 
She had just stepped out of the shower and had picked up a book to slowly enjoy for the rest of the night with a glass of wine. Unfortunately, between hero work and trying to hunt down a partner, Tsuchikawa Ryuuko hadn’t exactly had much time to indulge in reading. 
 
However, finding out that whoever maintained this place had kept up-to-date with some astoundingly trashy romance novel series had been a delight that had taken the edge off her anxiety, waiting for whatever fate they had in store for her.
 
She lounged in a green silk robe, sprawled over the couch as she mindlessly flipped through the seventeen terabytes of pirated movies available to her. She scrolled through the menu, trying to find that balance between something bad enough that she didn’t feel bad missing out on, while still good enough that she wouldn’t be driven to distraction by how bad it was; some white noise to read to.
 
Still, she admired whoever designed this place; the interior designer had impeccable taste in both decoration and security. While she couldn’t figure out a way to contact the outside world (polarized windows, very secure doors), she had still found both a well stocked library (digital format and physical books) and pantry (those cookies were delicious) - both of which she picked from as she enjoyed a truly isolating two days off Being An Adult.
 
Honestly, it wasn’t so bad - if only the rest of the Pussycats were here!

,” he shot back, and drank from it without giving her any further chance to argue.

“Housekeeping is competent, even if there’s a bit of a language barrier,” Archive nodded, “and I’m not terribly worried about fighting an unarmed pro hero without access to any earth for her quirk to work with.”




Darn, he certainly called that bluff quickly.

 
“Well, I was thinking about making a different kind of mess,” Ryuuko purred; she preferred more muscly guys, but the example of the male gender in front of her wasn’t offensive to her tastes.
 
“Oh? Did you have something in mind?” Archive asked, eyebrow arching. “I do too…”

Days of ‘she’ll be okay’ abruptly ended at the Pussycats compound as a black and purple portal opened up in the living room.
 
Tiger and Mandalay sprang to their feet as Ragdoll shouted in alarm, right before Pixie-Bob was unceremoniously ejected from the portal and landed on the couch with an alarmed screech.
 
Her clothes soon followed, including her loosened cat ears which nailed her in the face as she tried to say something.
 
Then an arm stuck through, deposited a basket of… something… , and then disappeared back into the shrinking portal, which winked out of existence as quickly as it had appeared.
 
Everyone in the room froze.
 
Finally, Ryuuko broke the silence by brandishing her wrists and the solid-looking handcuffs she had on them. “Get. These. Off.”
 
Mandalay blinked. “Right. Uh, Tiger, the handcuff key is in the gear cabinet. Ryuuko, are you hurt?”
 
Ragdoll ignored the other two as they fussed over Pixie-Bob, instead walking over to the basket that the villains had placed on their coffee table.
 
It was a baked goods arrangement, including a note in impeccable penmanship.
 
[Horny cat. Please spay.]
 
She couldn’t help it: Ragdoll let out a laugh.

Chapter Text
The first thing Killua noticed when he woke up was a throbbing pain in the back of his skull. Despite the pain, he quickly realized he did not recognize his surroundings. He was on a stiff cot in a white, blank room. There was a single window exposing a cityscape. He had no idea where he was or how he got there. Nothing indicated any sort of exact location or time. Killua was in a hospital that much was obvious, from the heart monitor and IV drip, but which one and why? Killua began to panic. Where was Alluka? What had happened? Killua remembered leaving Zaban City with his younger sister. He and Alluka were heading for York New City to meet up with one of killuas frequent clients. Illumi managed to find them despite Killua's efforts to hide where they were and where they were going. Killua struggled to remember much after Illumi landed his first blow against his rib cage. A sharp knock on the door interrupted his thoughts."I see you are awake! What a relief," A woman wearing nurse scrubs exclaimed, entering the small room.After introducing herself as Suzuki Chiyo, she strode towards the heart monitor next to his bed."You gave us quite a scare."Killua scowled. His situation just kept getting more illogical and he was getting increasingly frustrated. Just what had happened?Not wanting to give away just how lost he was, he simply asked, "Where am I?"The nurse looked at him and gave a small sympathetic smile. While replacing his IV, she informed him that he was currently admitted to Osaka General Hospital. His thoughts began to spiral further. Where the hell was Osaka?He decided to move past that for now and focus on a more urgent matter. Giving up on the informed facade was a necessary sacrifice given he had no clue where he was.Killua asked, "Why am I here?"She sighed sympathetically and turned toward him. "Authorities found you passed out on 31st Street a few days ago. You were brought to this hospital, where it was determined that you had suffered a concussion and two broken ribs. We assumed brain damage at first because of your unwillingness to wake up, but testing later that day indicated your collapse was likely due to fatigue."Killua frowned further. This situation was not ideal at all. He was in an unknown location, injured, and was missing his baby sister. Along with this, he had been unconscious for days. Who knows what could’ve happened to her?“Was a young girl recently admitted? Black hair, on the shorter side with a pink kimono on?”“No, I don’t think so. I can check for you if you’d like,” she replied.Killua just shook his head and stared at the wall in thought.The nurse began walking toward the door. " We were unable to identify you, and given your young age, injuries, and the timing of your accident, the police are the ones wanting to question you."Shit. The situation just became a lot less than ideal. What the fuck did she mean by the timing of his accident? Killua was beginning to lose his patience with the lack of answers."The doctor will be in shortly to check on you."Killua paid her no attention. He couldn't afford to be in legal trouble, especially in an unknown country. Killua was well-versed in geography, but he had never heard of Osaka. He wasn't even sure if his hunter's license would work here. Signs were pointing towards no. The people who took his clothes would have found them, and the nurse had not mentioned anything about him being a hunter. His priority was Alluka. He’d find his things and then find her. After processing this information, Killua made the obvious decision to rip the IV from his arm and run.Killua found his clothes quickly. They were in a small closet in the hospital room. The same could not be said for his license, money, and other items. He assumed that his possessions were being kept as evidence or something along those lines based on what the nurse told him earlier. As much as he didn't want to, he could live without them. Alluka comes first; she's the priority. He began to make his way to the back exit at the bottom of the stairs. The exit would take him out to where supplies were delivered, as he'd figured out from eavesdropping on a couple of medical workers, but if his timing was right, which it would be, no one would be there, and he could make his escape. As soon as he heard the truck begin to drive away from the hospital, Killua darted down the stairs and out the door, careful to not face the security camera.“Where do you think you're going?”Killua whirled around. He hadn’t heard anything, hadn't seen anything, and most importantly didn't feel anything. He couldn’t sense any aura around him. Thinking back the nurse didn't seem to have an aura either. What the hell was going on?“Oh I was just visiting my younger brother,” killua smoothly lied, regaining his composure. “He just had surgery to remove his appendix.”The man was a doctor of some sort with his lab coat and stethoscope. Behind him was a man with flaming hair, a beard, and a mustache. Killua had to hold in his laugh. He couldn’t say that was a particularly good style choice.“Why are you leaving through an emergency exit,” the flaming beard man questioned.“Oh, I’m in a rush and my mother is waiting for me outside.”He then started quickly walking towards the crosswalk, ignoring the strong urge to look back. After he was about ten minutes away from the hospital, Killua stopped a middle-aged woman wearing business clothes."Excuse me? Do you know how to get to the library from here? I might be a little lost," Killua spoke, putting on his most innocent, polite look.The woman raised her eyebrows at him, "You most definitely are. The nearest library is about a twenty-five-minute walk from here."She began to dig around her purse, "Do you want to call your parents?" She pulled out her phone, "I can stay with you until they can pick you up. It's pretty late, and I don’t feel comfortable leaving a young kid like you alone?”Killua sighed internally. Wherever he was, the people cared way too much about what absolute strangers were doing.“No, I'm alright! If you could just give me directions, that'd be great,” Killua pushed, still upholding his politeness.She looked skeptical, but after some more convincing and the added lie that his mom had just started working at the library, she eventually relented. Killua quickly thanked her and began to walk in the direction she’d mapped out. She had said a twenty-five-minute walk, but it only took Killua about ten minutes to reach his destination. Once he was there, he automatically went to the computers. Thank God those existed in this here, wherever he was. The first thing he searched for was a world map. It looked nothing like the world maps back home. None of the continents, countries, or cities were the same. That solidified his out-of-world theory. Alluka had transported him and (hopefully) herself to a whole new world. He could only hope Alluka was in the same country as him, but there was no way to be certain. He pushed away that thought. He’d first focus on searching what was known as Japan, where he found he was currently. After about another thirty minutes of learning both geography and the basics of this world, Killua set out. While walking, he pondered the information he had found. It didn’t matter that this world had quirks or heroes or villains; he was set on finding Alluka. He had to.
