Sure, they weren’t able to accomplish their goal flawlessly, and Shigaraki’s transformation was unfortunately interrupted. But they didn’t back down, and a large number of heroes were either killed or severely injured in combat. They also acquired a very special prisoner. Hawks, or now as they know him, Keigo Takami, is now being held in a jail cell underground. All thanks to Dabi’s excellent investigative work, the traitor has been dragged out to the sun to answer for his crimes. Dabi did not pity him as he watched Hawks cry out in pain after being engulfed in his blue flames, his pretty red feathers reduced to mere ashes falling around him like snow. He was choking, coughing violently, his wings desperately trying to shield himself from the cruel touch of fire. The man who is known as the number two hero in Japan now curled up in a fetal position on the ground as he was confronted by his natural weakness; it was truly a pathetic sight. Dabi should have done this sooner. If he did, maybe Twice would still be breathing right now.  It would have been easy to kill him right then and there, but Dabi decided to let him live. He is too valuable of an asset, an important source of information. What happened next all played out exactly according to plan—Dabi allowed his flames to stop, and amidst a thick layer of smoke was Hawks, now lying on the ground unconscious with his body covered in minor burns. He ordered men to retrieve the pro-hero and have him fully examined, making sure that there are no life-threatening injuries so they can make better use of him. To say that the villains did not have much regard for Hawks’ health would be an understatement. The man barely got any proper medical treatment before getting thrown into a cell. From there, Dabi stopped intervening. He knew Hawks’ interrogation would soon follow, and he was just as certain that they would not be able to get anything out of him easily.  He didn’t bother seeing Hawks for the next couple days. There was no way the Hero Public Safety Commission’s finest would yield this easily; it was too early for Hawks to break. 




The next time Dabi laid eyes on Hawks again, a week had passed. Dabi does not have a particular fondness for stepping foot into the underground prison; the air smells odd and stuffy, and the walls are always grimy. It’s hard to imagine someone as acclaimed in the hero society as Hawks to be found in this place. While Dabi may not be present during Hawks’ past few interrogation sessions, he has heard from others about them. Unsurprisingly, Hawks completely refused to cooperate in any meaningful way. In the beginning, he’d put on that fake smile of his and deflected from every question that was thrown at him. Of course, this greatly displeased the villains, and they turned to more traditional methods designed to get what they want out of a prisoner. One remark about Hawks that Dabi frequently heard was his high tolerance for pain; it doesn’t take that much thinking to surmise how the top hero came to obtain that skill.  Even when the beating started, Hawks still didn’t say a word that would provide any knowledge to the heroes’ plans. The violence went on for days, and finally, covered in blood, Hawks agreed to reveal what he knew. The excitement of the interrogators was short-lived, as they quickly realized that the few things that Hawks had told them had all been false intel, which in turns only made them more enraged towards the blond.  His interrogation sessions from that point on tripled in length.  Hawks had to know that they’d find out about his lies soon enough, and that his laughable attempt at manipulation will only ultimately lead to more punishment. Yet he still did it, without an ounce of regret it seems.  He had figured this much anyway, but it seemed like Hawks really is hell-bent on carrying this self-sacrifice bullshit till the very end. How can someone be so brilliant yet stupid at the same time, he ponders.  Dabi’s footsteps echo throughout the long corridor, and he ignores the whimpers and screams from other cells.  “I am here to see Hawks.” Dabi walks towards the guard and lays out his demands casually. Perks of being part of Shigaraki’s inner circle—nobody gets to question him, ever.  “Sure thing.” The guard starts to reach for the key in his pocket. “Just letting you know, he is probably still unconscious right now. They just released him from interrogation.” “It’s fine.” Something stirs Dabi’s heartstrings when he hears those words, but he pretends not to notice. “I won’t be long anyway.”





 There he is, in all his glory. Dabi can personally attest that Hawks has definitely seen better days. The number two top hero is now chained to the walls of the filthy jail cell with heavy shackles around his wrists. Those distinct red wings are a fraction of what they used to be, as most of his feathers were burned by Dabi’s fire. He is still wearing the same black shirt he wore the day he was exposed in front of the Paranormal Liberation Front, which now can hardly be called a shirt anymore with how torn up and stained with blood it is due to the heavy abuse its owner was put through. Dark, purple and blue bruises bloom all over Hawks’ tan skin, in addition to a myriad of lacerations and cuts, many of which are still seeping out blood. His back, his thighs, his abdomen, there is not a part of him that hasn’t been met with a violent touch. His signature well-styled golden hair has lost its shine, now lifelessly falling over his forehead, obscuring Hawks’ pale face from view. At one point, Hawks used to sit in the corner of the cell and greet his “visitors” with that laid-back grin of his. Now he just slumps uselessly against the wall, motionless and unresponsive to his cell door being opened, because he no longer has the strength to hold himself up. It’s only been days and he has already lost weight. From what Dabi heard, the hero pretty much stopped eating, but it’s not like they remember to feed him all that often anyway.  Hawks truly is a pathetic sight to look at right now.Unlike the Hawks Dabi remembers, he almost looks……fragile. Not like someone who is able to save countless people from collapsing buildings. Dabi approaches the hero lying on the ground, expressionless. He came here with plans to hurt Hawks, to draw information out of him, yet his hand reaches for the water bottle he carries in his coat pocket. Hawks’ lips look dry, and he can’t help but to wonder when was the last time he had a taste of water.  He can’t be useful to the league if he dies of dehydration. Justifying his actions in his head, Dabi grabs Hawk’s face and turns his head towards him forcefully, pouring water into his open mouth. Hawks trembles at the sudden touch, but his urgent need for what’s been offered to him quickly takes over his mind, and he gulps down the water like a man who has been lost in a desert. Soon, Dabi’s water bottle is emptied, and he lets go of Hawks to let him collapse onto the floor again.  “I thought I’d have a few more hours before my next torture session……” Surprisingly, it is Hawks who speaks first. Seemingly revitalized by the water, he finds the strength to revert into his role of being the most obnoxious prisoner in existence. A dry, broken chuckle escapes his throat as he forces himself to sit up against the wall. “Is it your turn this time, Dabi?”  Dabi feels the palm of his hand getting warmer, a response to anger. “You look like shit.” He snaps, actively resisting the urge to wrap his fingers around that pretty neck. “How much longer are you going to play the part of being the commission’s dog?” “For as long as I breathe.” Hawks replies without even a second thought, which only pisses off Dabi more.  “That won’t be long if you keep this act up.” He warns coldly.  Dabi doesn’t know how he expects Hawks to react to those words, but it surely isn’t what he hears from the blond’s lips next.




“—Kill me, then.”   For a second, Dabi just stares while Hawks remains absolutely impassive, as if he didn’t just request his own execution. The next thing he knows, his hand is in Hawks’ hair, gripping tight to force the hero to look at him. “What the  fuck  are you even talking about.”  “It should be you, Dabi, if they are going to do it.” Hawks golden eyes are distant, close off, like he is in his own world rather than being one word away from receiving a death sentence. His body is limp in Dabi’s grasp, like a torn up doll.  “What difference does it make to you?” Dabi narrows his eyes, finding it harder and harder to contain the off-putting, illogical emotions on the edge of spilling out of him. “If you are so keen on dying anyway.” Silently, Hawks locks eyes with him, and for the first time today, Dabi knows in certainty he is seeing him. The carefully manufactured persona of the top hero is gone, replaced by something hauntingly tragic yet beautiful in his eyes. Hawks’ lips curve into this resigned, self-mocking smile, saying words that threaten to steal the air from Dabi’s lungs. “It makes a difference, because I’d want it to be you.”“All my life, I have never had any issues with following orders……until this mission.”“Each day I spend with you, learning about you, knowing that I will have to betray you, it makes everything……so much harder.”  Hawks laughs a little, his voice empty of his usual calculations and falsehood.  “Don’t get me wrong, I don’t regret it, but it’s the fact that I experienced doubt……I have never felt this way until I met you.” He closes his eyes, exhausted.  “And that made me question everything. It’s  you  that made me question everything.”  It’s you that made me question everything.  Hawks’ voice echoes in Dabi’s head. Suddenly a castle of memories crumbles over his head, nostalgia rushing into his veins. Hawks’ smile at him the night before Dabi confirmed his true motives and identity, the first one Dabi thought to be genuine, the night when he felt the warmth of his hand, the sleepless nights they’d shared. Fake. Fake. Fake. They were all fake. He lied. He lied and lied and lied. A voice screams in his head. But he knows what Hawks is saying right now isn’t fake, which contradicts everything Dabi wants to believe about him.  As if touched by electricity, he instinctively pushes Hawks away, letting the blond hit the floor once again with a loud thud. Hawks doesn’t look at Dabi again, instead just quietly curls up in his corner. Dabi storms out of the jail cell past the guard, forcing his eyes away from catching the last glimpse of the winged-hero with his peripheral vision before the door shuts closed.  He feels angry, restless, and wishes nothing but to watch his blue flames climb the sky. If heaven does indeed exist, he’d burn it down too, just so he doesn’t have to wake up the next day to learn that the first person he had dared to dream of a future with had been a liar all along.




   If he is to burn all memories of Hawks, would he finally be able to convince himself that he was never in love?

Chapter Text

I was a good man once. I was a hero…once. 


And it cost me everything.

 
***


One year since The Great Battle. 


Hawks sat in the quiet of his darkened cell, eyes fixed on a point past the door, breathing low and slow so that the guards who passed every half hour without even bothering to look in on him would think that he was asleep. He’d grown used to pretending not to be there, shrinking into the darkness and hiding his form so that – in time – they would forget all about him. He 

needed 

them to forget, needed everyone to let the bright winged man fade from their memories. The world had moved on, the way he always knew that it would, and he was determined to make them regret it. 

The floor below him was cold, stone slabs scraping his thighs as the rough bricks of the wall behind him dug into the protruding nodes of his spine. There was no light in the chamber that he’d been left in, no breeze, nothing to mark the time of day bar the passing of his guards. He was alone with the steady dripping of condensation down the walls, the sounds of chains as other prisoners moved around their tiny cages, with the thoughts of what had been, and what was still to come. When he had first been thrown into that terrible place he had marked the passing of every day, counting the changes of the guard religiously, but over time that had become just another pointless distraction. 

Time meant nothing down there in the dark.

How long had it been since someone had spoken to him? Since someone had touched him? He could feel the dark and the solitude changing his body. His nails left untreated had become long sharp claws, feathers pushing through his skin in rough patches across his body, his back hunching with sharp bones jutting just below the skin. He was becoming the monster that they had painted the man to be. The monster that none but a villain could love. When he closed his eyes he could still remember the breeze blowing through his wings when he flew high and free,  the warmth and light of the sun, the way it glinted off of Dabi’s dark hair when they stood out on the deck of his ship together. 

All he had left were the fragments of that old life. Pieces of memory that even the cold and dark couldn’t steal away from him. 

He pushed a long strand of limp hair out of his eyes, grimacing when he caught sight of the loose grey skin on his hands. He used to be a shining beacon, one of the most handsome men on the fleet. Now he was ragged, his feathers dull and his body weakened by the tiny bland meals they gave him. He was almost glad there wasn’t a mirror in the underground cell he had started to think of as home, nothing to remind him of the days when he would pluck and preen to make sure that he always looked his best. He’d been tossed aside. Left to rot away from the sun, away from 

everything

 until he had become little more than a husk of what he used to be. A shadow of the great, respected Captain who soared through the skies at the head of one of the largest boats in the All Mighty Admiral’s fleet. 

But even in his diminished state they wouldn’t keep him forever. They 

couldn’t

. 

The Admiral was a great man, and as far as Hawks had fallen he still believed that as strongly as he had in his first days at the Fleet Training Academy. But he was also – on occasion – a stupid man. Quick to trust, quick to forgive, softer on those who had betrayed him than he had any right or reason to be. And so instead of putting Hawks to the noose as he should have done – as so many of the other captains had loudly demanded – he sent him to a lifetime in the cells. To the one place where he had half a chance of regaining his life. 

Because it seemed that, in his haste to refuse to put to death a man who had once served him passionately, he had forgotten that Hawks was his best spy. Had forgotten that he always had an exit strategy, a means of getting out of even the most dire of situations. For years he had been their most skilled double agent, and he held that role for a 

reason

 even in the days before he found himself tied to the League of Pirates. So he made a decision to wait. He would remain in the cells until the day came when he could finally be sure that his escape plan would work. Until so much time had passed that everyone who might care what happened to him had forgotten that he was there at all.

He spent the first few months watching, learning the routes that the guards took, making sure that he knew every moment that he would be free of them. Then it was putting his feathers to work, slipping the smallest of them into the locks on his shackles, learning the mechanisms so well that he was certain he could do it flawlessly every time. He would let himself out, stretch his arms and legs, keep what little strength he had by doing a few short exercises and locking himself away again before the next guard passed. He was silent, unseen, just the way he wanted.  

With the shackles in hand he turned his attention to the rest of his cell. The door was old but sturdy, designed to survive even the most violent and explosive of quirks. But there were few things in the world that had been designed to resist Hawks. 

Still, opening the door provided him with a new challenge, the finely crafted lock forming half of the issue. Where he found the most challenge was in avoiding the eye of the guards as his feather whipped through the bars and into the great steel mechanism. A few times a cruel hand had snatched his spylet out of the air, making him wince with the pain that came with one of his feathers being so ruthlessly crushed. But as soon as they were released he called them back to him, nestling them into his back where they belonged, for there was no place on earth or sea that his feathers could be taken where they could not return to him. He could feel every one of them, call them forth as he willed even when they were long from his sight. They were his greatest gift, and one that so few understood.

***


“You really want me to believe that you never lose one? Not even one of the tiny ones?”



Hawks had to laugh at the doubt that was all over Dabi’s face. He wouldn’t have believed it either, if he didn’t feel it every day. 



“Want to put it to the test?”



“Not much of a test. There’s no way you could find one and bring it back if you didn’t see where it went.”



“Well, take one, any of them.” He rolled onto his front, stretching his wings wide and letting a couple of his smaller feathers flutter down onto Dabi’s chest. “Take one and hide it anywhere you want, anywhere at all on the ship or out of it. By the time you’re back here it will be back with me.”



“And you can tell me where it was?”



“There or thereabouts.”



“Bullshit.”



Hawks ran a lazy finger down Dabi’s chest, a line of kisses following. 



“Then get out of bed and prove it.”



***


He shook the memory away. There would be time for him to reminisce once he was free. Once he was back at the mountain where he knew he would be safe, where he could begin to plan the next phase. He didn’t have time for nostalgia, not whilst he was still locked in the dark.

But the anger that burned in the wake of the memories, 

that 

he held on to.

The Admiral Fleet had taken Dabi from him. Had stolen away the one fragment of happiness that he had ever known. And though he didn’t hold in his hands the heat and flame of his lost love, that didn’t mean he couldn't burn it all down. He was quiet, and he was fast, and one by one he would take out every member of the fleet who stood on the decks that day. Every sailor who stood by and watched his love be cut down by a mutinous boy and his siren bride. 

He would find what remained of Dabi, take him to a place where he could truly be at peace. And then he would kill every last member of the Admiral Fleet. If it took him the rest of his life, he would wipe them off the dockside once and for all. 

“Songbird.”

Hawks hissed at the voice. At the name that was not for any to use but 

him

.

“You don’t get to call me that, Spy.” He pulled back further into the darkness, not trusting even one who claimed allegiance with the Lost King. 

“Old habits, mon amie. I have what you asked for.”

Hawks didn’t respond, feathers loose and trembling around him for any sign that he was to be double crossed again. But the guard simply dropped a bundle outside the bars and walked away without another word.

“I will be free,” Hawks whispered, more to himself than anyone else. “In the name of the King I will change this world.” His focus returned to the feather in the lock, hardly hearing the words of the spy as he continued on his path. 

“Bon chance, friend. I’ll send news as often as I am able without raising suspicion. Will the ravens know where to find you?”

“They will.”

The sound of boots ringing on stone faded and Hawks redoubled his efforts, closing his eyes and concentrating until finally the lock clicked and the door creaked open. 

By dawn – he thought as he gathered the bundle and made for the stairs – he would be a free man. By dawn the fleet would feel the searing of his vengeance, and mourn as he had mourned for those that he took with him.

More people than I expected were used to having someone else tie it at home and trying to do it themselves led to some… interesting results. Oh, sorry, you're still eating. I have something I wanna do, you okay if I leave early?""Yeah, go ahead. See you in class, Midoriya.""Just. For. Today." Yaoyorozu says as she stares Mineta down with a stern look and quickly ties his tie. He looks like he wants to say something, but the serious expression on her face compels him to simply nod and remain silent. Todoroki, watching from a distance, also would've intervened if he tried or said anything out of line. Though Mineta doesn't utter a peep, he ultimately leaves satisfied when she finishes with a grin on his face. "Is that everyone?" Yaoyorozu asks and looks around.Here is where Todoroki decides to emerge and make his presence known. "Shouldn't Iida be the one taking care of the men and you take care of the women? Isn't that normally how you divide your responsibilities?""I think Iida-san has already left for homeroom. As expected of him, his preparations never begin too early. I would've left as well except for noticing how many people in our class needed assistance in tying a tie. He might have felt extremely stressed by seeing everyone not properly dressed as they walked into the classroom. My job is to alleviate the pressures he is facing in whatever way I can. And it looks like you may need it as well, Todoroki-san?"He looks down at his tie still wrapped around his collar. He did receive some assistance from his sister, Fuyumi, at the beginning of the school year, but she also made sure that he knew the essentials when he moved out (she even gave him an instruction packet), including knowing how to do this. But having it be tied by Yaoyorozu just sounds too tempting to pass up, and she likely won't offer this opportunity again after today.He takes too long to respond, and she follows up with another comment. "I must say; this is unexpected. I didn't expect you to not know how to tie a tie, Todoroki-san."Todoroki neither chooses to neither confirm nor deny her statement. "Do you think you could help me?""Very well. Pardon me." Yaoyorozu steps closer to him and puts her hands on his collar. "Are you the last one?""I believe so.""Coincidence or not," she casts a gaze onto his face that makes him think that she knows what he's hiding, "It's easier to tie it when you do it like this. It's good that you know to have the narrow end on one side and the wide end on the other. Some of our classmates didn't even know that…" She explains as she pops his collar up. "The knot I'm going to do now is known as the double Windsor or the full Windsor. They have the same meaning. It's a large and well balanced knot, which can also be easily released. The knot is firm, so it won't be undone even at the end of the day. The largeness of the knot is quite comfortable as well."'It sounds like the one Fuyumi-nee taught me.' Something about the way she explains things always makes his heart flutter. Realizing that Mineta didn't get this treatment makes it even more turbulent."First, take the wide end over the small end," she drags the wide end of the tie that's on his left side across to his left, "up into the neck loop from underneath," the tie flies straight up in front of his face, "down to the left and around the back to the small end to the right," the knot around his throat tightens, "up to the center, towards the neck loop and then through the neck loop down to the right…" He knows she's almost done and that makes the knot around his heart tighter. "Next, across the front to the left, up into the neck loop from underneath, down through the loop you've just created in the front, and finally tighten the knot by pulling down the wide end..." It's only now that he realizes how close they are. If he had the time, he could count her perfect eyelashes from this distance. "There!" She pulls down his collar. "I should be fine. This is the same knot I- er, that's done for me every morning.""Hm." she hums and stares at him curiously. He's still not sure if she's seen through his white lie or not. "This is just for future reference, Todoroki-san, but if you grow even taller- to be like your father's height," his eye twitches for a brief moment, "I would recommend the half-Windsor, instead. It requires less tie length, so taller men prefer it.""I'd prefer anything that you recommend." He's not sure if he made the right choice saying that out loud or not, but the cute blush on her cheeks makes him lean towards being a yes. "Could you show me how that knot you just said is tied? I never heard of it before." "It's difficult to just explain it, I'll have to show you to make it stick. Do you mind if we undo your knot?""Sure." He bends his collar back up while her elegant fingers release the knot once again. She holds the knot with one hand and lightly pulls on the small end. It is only now that Todoroki realizes that her face is only a few centimeters from his. It's for a second at most, but her onyx colored eyes look as though she is expecting something when they meet his heterochromatic ones. Todoroki can't figure out what it is she's looking for and she averts her gaze with a bashful expression."The first steps are similar to the full Windsor, it only begins diverging at the third step, where the large end goes under the small end instead of over." She begins to explain again."...Is it too much to ask for you to do this for me everyday? Like the characters sometimes do in those Western films you like to watch." Todoroki asks as she flips the large end up the center and through the neck loop, down towards the left."You should learn how to tie your own tie, Todoroki-san." She says firmly, maybe more firmly than the knot that's forming when she drags the large end across the front and over to the right."I do know." Now that she's mostly done, there's no need to hide anything from her anymore. "I just wanted you to do it for me.""...I knew you knew how to tie it!" She squints at him. "In that case, absolutely not. I'm can't give you special treatment, Todoroki-san." "Well, I really didn't know about that second knot you did. I only did the first one no matter the situation.""...The general guideline is that the full Windsor is more for very formal events like weddings and business meetings while the half-Windsor can be used in more informal situations. If you ever need a refresher, just come ask me. But, I won't do this for you everyday." She lifts the large end through the neck loop from underneath and starts pulling it through the created loop in the front."Okay, instead of that… What about the other thing they do in those Western films?""The other thing?"He takes a deep breath. "What about a kiss every morning?"The knot around his neck tightens and he has trouble getting oxygen into his lungs. "S-sorry! My hand slipped from hearing things." Yaoyorozu frantically apologizes. "Could you repeat what you just said?""I asked if we could kiss every morning.""That's something only couples do, Todoroki-san.""You're right." He taps his chin and sees the obvious solution in front of him. "Then, let's be a couple from now on.""...Is this a confession??""I guess it is." Now that he's come this far, there's no point in turning back. "What's your answer?""…Okay. Yes." Yaoyorozu tightens the knot one last time.“Is that a confirmation of the kiss or being a couple?”“I wouldn’t kiss someone I’m not in a relationship with, so... yes to both.” She pulls his collar down to signal that she's done.He becomes confused when she runs out the door. "Where are you going?""We're running late. If you want my kiss for today, you'll have to beat me to class!" She grins at him.He smirks back at her. "You're on." This is one race he'd rather not lose.<<EOFANFIC>>

completion: Midoriya has mainly been alone in his dorm for a good 48 hours.You know this because you checked with Mina, then with Iida, and then you even dared to bother Bakugou about it, to which he told you to 'take it up with the damn nerd himself.'One of these days, you're gonna tackle that ticking time bomb right in his dorm. Just to see what he'll do.Keep readingBut, that's an issue for another day as you creep up to Midoriya's dorm and remain outside. You knock twice three seconds later because your mama didn't raise a wimp—and you refuse to be one. Midoriya answers immediately, voice muffled through the door. "I promise, you guys. I'm alright."So it seems your other classmates were worried about him as well. "Hey Midoriya, I'd like to talk to you about your insurance."  There's a silence at the door, long enough that you begin to wonder if you're actually bothering him, before you hear the query of your name."The one and only!" You confirm, rapping a tune into the wood. "Can I come in?""U-uh, yeah! You can—" You let yourself in before he can finish, shutting the door behind you. Midoriya's laid prone on his bed, staring at what appears to be study material on the floor before him. He scrambles up from the position when you come in, sitting cross-legged and smiling at you nervously."H-hi! Yeah, um, hey." He cracks out."Smooth," you wink playfully, causing a squeak to escape from the green-haired boy. "Now, what's been keeping you inside all day?""Huh?""I haven't seen your bush head step out of your room for two days except to eat and drink. It's un-Midoriya-like of you." Flopping down into his desk chair, you spin in it once before rolling over to him, a question in your gaze.Midoriya's used to your flippant mannerisms. He had to during the first year of high school. But now, the situation's been changed. He's used to responding to you when you're around other people, or just in an open space where he can temporary direct his eyes on something else. But, with you here, in his room—watching him so intently...He's not used to this. Not used to it at all. He can already feel himself start to overheat like an egg in the sun. "U-uh...I've been studying! Yeah, for t-the exam that's in—""Two weeks." You interject softly. "You're a really great student, Mido, I know from the homework you've helped me with—but...our classmates are getting worried, y'know," smiling at him, you cross your arms on his bed. "I'm getting a little worried."You watch as Midoriya seems to freeze for a second, and then his cheeks flush into a timid red. "Y-you are?""Yeah. Does that feel like I'm pressuring you? Not that I'm saying you can't have your bad days, which you are most definitely allowed to have," you stop yourself to swallow, looking out Midoriya's balcony window to gather yourself. "Haha, sorry.""No!" The sudden interjection from him, quite frankly, scares you both. "I-it's nothing like that. I just didn't expect you to...care enough to visit me like this."You glance at him, eyes wide. "Of course I would! You're great. Is there any reason I wouldn't care enough...?"Midoriya looks like he's about to say something before his body suddenly catches up, reducing his voice to no more than a few stammered squeaks and rushed explanations. It's adorable—awfully so—but then you remember why you're here, speaking up so you don't make him any more uncomfortable than he needs to be."It's okay, Mido! That was a dumb question. What I really came here to ask was if you're alright?"The boy stiffens, then deflates like a balloon. His gazes narrows, focusing intently on one of his papers before turning to you, expression gentle and embarrassed. "Work studies have been...difficult."You roll your chair a little closer to his bed, close enough that you lay your elbows on the bedding. "Yeah?"He watches you with wide eyes, exhaling loudly, but if he's uncomfortable, he shows no sign of it. "It just feels like too many people have been slipping out of my reach."You feel your heart soften at that. Of course, being able to save everyone is a skill all of you wished you could train for, but the undeniable fact is it's unattainable.  There'll always be people that slip through your fingers, and while it affects all of you deeply—It is Midoriya that feels the most pain from it. It's like he carves each person he couldn't save into his heart, so it could beat for those who were lost. It's hard for everyone, but it seems especially so for him.And as you look at him now, the hopelessness that he tried so hard to hide, one you've seen a couple times before—Back then, as first-years, you weren't so sure how to handle everything that was Midoriya.But now, you think you do.You stand up slowly, the chair rolling back as you stare Midoriya in the eyes. The despair, the grief, the rememberance, all of it. He stares back, slouched at similar height as you on his bed."You've always felt things a little more than the others, Mido," you start, smiling at him slowly. "As first years, I thought it was a flaw...but, well, you changed my mind. I find it's a thing I liked about you now. You can't save everyone, and I know that's hard for you to grasp, but the class will be there for you on the days that it gets hard. I'll be there, too, if you want me to be." You hold your arms out to Midoriya, a silent invitation. His gaze travels between your eyes and your open gesture, and then something in the boy cracks. He leans forward at the same time you do, enveloping Midoriya in a hug. You feel him tremble before a small cry rises in his chest.You hug him close, and, not knowing how else to comfort him, draw circles up and down his neck and back. You don't care how his tears cling to your shirt the same way he holds you."You beat yourself up over things you can't really control." You sigh into the side of his head. "I think it'd do you some good to get some social time, y'know.""I-I know, but," Midoriya's voice cracks amidst his tears. "I d-don't wanna be an inconveni—"Gently pulling him back, you interrupt his self-deprecation, gazing softly into tired green eyes lined with red. "Don't you know by now? No one's ever been inconvenienced. No one. Not even Bakugou, despite how he acts. It's only you thinking that, dummy." He says your name, so, so softly, like a feather in the wind, a leaf on a pond. Something in you cracks, and quite frankly, you don't know what to do with it. It feels real now, you're here with Midoriya, in his room, and you're touching him, and he's letting you...You let your hands fall to your sides, so focused on not acting too weird to notice Midoriya's expression fall for a millisecond. "I should go," you grin, taking a step back. "But, I'll check in on you. I'd...I'd better see you out in the lounge eventually or I'm gonna drag you out."Midoriya watches you intently as you get farther away, and your hand is on the doorknob before he finally speaks."Wait...can you stay? Please?"Your fingers tighten on the spherical metal. Attempting to keep your expression neutral, if not a little thoughtful. "You want me to...?"Midoriya's face inflames in a rose tint. "Please. I-if you want."Slowly releasing your grip on the knob, you turn toward him with a small smile. Keeping your feelings in check might be harder than you thought. "Okay."   <<EOFANFIC>>

completion: Running up the stairs reaching the roof of the four-Storey building Katsuki spotted what he dreaded most.The sight of a green haired boy in his uniform standing behind rails that separate him from an 18-meter fall onto concrete.uniform and hair heavy from the thrashing rain, Not knowing what to do Katsuki spoke. “Don’t do it Deku “Standing in the freezing temperatures of the thunderous weather. The boy in front of him still standing, staring into what seems to be nothing.He tries to speak again but was promptly cut off. “-Shut up” he said drowned out by the sound of rain hitting the top of the roof.  “What?”“I SAID SHUT UP!” Deku screamed.Voice hoarse and crackly as if he just came from crying his heart out.“You have no right to say anything, to me. “Words laced with a venom like anger. Body tightening as he clenched his fist turning his already pale skin white. “Just get away from the rails Deku”. His words being met with silence only the sound of rain drops and raging winds to be heard.Katsuki holding his head down in utter shame.” I’m sorry okay Deku I never meant what I said!” shouting back at him. Finally turning his head around to face the unusually disheveled boy behind him.Staring at Katsuki with a face of confusion and utter disbelief“You’re sorry?”Now angry he screams.“YOU ARE SORRY!? YOU NEVER CARED ABOUT ME. SORRY ISN’T GONNA FIX ANYTHING!”  tears of despair now replaced with tears of rage. “I- ““I’m sorry” he gritted out voice falling silent. Izuku’s tense shoulders drop “Is that all you have to say to me” still angry. Not knowing if he was tricking himself, Katsuki wasn’t sure if he was sensing a hint disappointment coming from the boy’s face. “I NEVER MENT ANY OF IT OKAY, ALL THE WORDS ALL THE PAIN I CAUSED. I NEVER WANTED TO DO IT!” his turn now to cry, rivers of sorrow and regret built up streaming down his face.Wanting to scream and spout all his feelings to and for Deku but something prevented him from doing so. “We used to be friends Kachan what happened to that” Deku said reminiscing on when they were younger.Hearing the nickname Deku gave to him years ago being said in such a sad broken tone struck his heart in an unexplainable way making him feel more guilty than he already did.Unable the answer he stayed silent. The smell of rain grew strong, and the wind rose as high as the tension between them.Turning back around staring into the dark grey clouds as the freezing rain drops mix with his tears. finally breaking the silence.Sucking up his ego and pride, he says to his former friend.“I always cared about your dumbass.”“I was young and idiotic”.“Wanting to seem cool and live up to everyone’s dumb praise”.“I always thought you were better than me. And when you didn’t get your quirk, it just proved that fact more”.“Even when you didn’t have a quirk you still tried to be a hero, you still helped others. You still tried to help me.”Looking down “I always cared about you, you fucking idiot” he said quietly, watching the rain drops fall on his jet-black shoes unsure whether its rain or tears.“I was fucking angry and jealous. “Ego aside “I’m sorry Deku “he said softly.“I wanted to be better than you. ““I tried to be. ““But I did it the wrong way “There’s another moment of silence between the two past friends. “Wanna know something”. Upon hearing his friend’s rare confession of feelings, He lets out a slight laugh as his body relaxes. Previous anger gone from his tone “I always loved you Katsuki” he said abruptly, giving his own little confession. turning his head yet again letting out a soft laugh complimented by a sad smile on his face, tears still falling unable to stop. Bakugou stood there shocked at what his best friend former friend said to him. “I just wanted to let you know before I finally left ““Aren’t you happy I’m finally doing what you told me “ Finally, the feeling of paralyses left him. He moved forward inches away from the forest green haired boy. barely being able to utter a word Katsuki finally spoke again.“I didn’t mean it”.“Its too late”“What about aunty Inko Deku” Heavy silence comes over them once again, the sound of thunder becoming more prominent as time few by.After what felt like hours, he finally got a response. He gave Katsuki a meek smile “she’ll be fine, she has Aunty Mitsuki and Uncle Masaru to take care of her.”“She wouldn’t have to worry about me anymore.” “What about your dream Deku.” he said despite knowing what he told him, trying to find ways to stall him from jumping. He laughs “you and I both know I gave up on that dream”. turning around to sit on the slippery rails. Now facing Katsuki “You can live it out for both of us”.“I’ve always believed in you Kacchan-” he said, voice soft but still heard by the other over the harsh weather. Katsuki’s heart drops, body getting colder than the gusts wind knowing what’s going to happen next. “Always had. Always will.”  He says closing his eyes and giving him a smile that could rival all might’s.It’s been years sense Katsuki last seen him smile like that. “Through life or death’-” Finishing his sentence                         Saying his final words “-I’ll always love you” he leans back on the rails. “IZUKU” he screamed running towards the boy trying not to slip on the wet surface of the roof. He reaches his arm out to grab the boy before its too late. A sigh of relief leaves him as he Successfully grabs hold Deku’s shirt. But the relief quickly leaves when noticing the boy slip from his grasp. Katsuki stares into Izuku’s dulled green eyes, face still stuck in a sad smile.  his own eyes full of tears of despair not wanting this to be their last goodbye he tries to secure his hold on the boy but inevitably fails. Finally putting aside his pride “I love you Izuku” Katsuki cries. Katsuki stands where Izuku once was looking down as he falls and grows closer and closer to the concrete below as if falling in slow motion.Watching as Izuku hits the floor bones breaking and blood spattering, blood from his head turning his vibrant green hair as red as the liliums growing in the school garden.Not knowing if  he heard his confession.Katsuki stood where Izuku once was not paying attention to how much time is passing in shock and regretting things he’s said and hadn’t said to the now gone boy.<<EOFANFIC>>

completion:
Chapter Text
ugh, another day alone in the house. you’ve watched every movie, played games, painted, drawn, everything. you’ve run out of things to do at the point. you missed your friends terribly, face time wasn’t cutting it anymore and, you’d never thought you’d say this but, you missed school. everyone there and talking and interacting, it seemed like heaven.oh wait there is something that you haven’t done yet! you haven’t been able to catch up on your favorite anime’s in a while! this is the perfect time! you ended up finishing quite a bit throughout the afternoon, eventually starting to feel tired after the long hours of binge watching. you looked at the clock. 2:35am.damn! didn’t even realize how late it was. or, we’ll, early. i better go to sleep.you turned down the lights and snuggled into your pillow with your favorite hoodie. it didn’t take long for you to start drifting to sleep when a sudden whoosh causing you to jump up. you looked at the source of the sound to find at the end of your bed sat a… hole? a hole… in the air… a portal maybe? where did it go to? what is a portal doing even existing!? a knot grew in your stomach… something didn’t feel right. it wasn’t just about the mysterious new presence of the portal that startled you, but the feeling of a cool, sharp object that rested on your neck filled by a firm grip placed on your shoulder. you froze, all of you was numb as if your brain was frozen and your breath was hitched.your brain came back to life after hearing a demanding “get up,” from the darkness. you slowly shifted to stand in front of the man before being let toward the portal. your eyes flickered up and down, back and forth to try to analyze any information you could take in. you looked to at least still be on earth you thought, but you were now surrounded by buildings and street lights. you were able to peek behind you but all you could see was more street. your world was gone; or the way back to it was. you had to focus and not panic but how could you not? tears threatened to spill from your eyes as you heard muffled voices clear up. this is the first time you noticed the other man standing in front of you and your captor. he had long dark hair and a long scarf that wrapped around his neck, he looked awful familiar but you couldn’t quite place it. “Let her go, she has nothing to do with this,” he spoke finally. “oh no eraser, if you want me to let her go, you’ve got to let me go or else…” your captor says looking back at you, “this will get ugly.” wait…. ERASER??!! before you could analyze this new information and the hesitation on his face, you were shoved toward eraser. you almost hit the hard pavement, luckily for you eraser managed to catch you before you completely face-planted the ground. everything happened so fast and the next thing you know, your captor is gone. well shit.“are you alright?” asked eraser. you meant to reply with a “sure” or “yes, thank you” but all you could do was gawk with your jaw on the floor. i mean shit, it’s ERASER HEAD (the finest hero ever🤭). “are you hurt anywhere?” he tried again. “oh uhhh no i’m fine.” “good, we’re gonna have to take you to a medical professional anyway just in case you were effected by his quirk.” wait his what? “i’m sorry what? quirk?” you asked. “yes, he used his quirk to-“ he looked at you with a bit of questioning, then realization, then “oh shit.” he began to ask you a few questions about how things went down from your point of view. things like: where were you when you where taken? what were you doing? where are you from? and about quirks. he then comes to a realization, “so i think i know what’s happened. you were taken by this man, he used his quirk to transport you here, then used you as a distraction and ran. but you didn’t know what a quirk was, and you aren’t familiar with this area,” he explains. “i know who you are though, you are eraser head. you’re… on a show i watch.” eraser looked over at you carefully, then looked away to piece together the information he had with then new information you’ve given. “this has just got a lot more complicated,” he says while rubbing his face, “if what i’m thinking is correct, you’ve not only been transported here from another place, you’ve been transported from some other universe or alternate reality to this one.” you looked up at him, “do you think that’s even possible?”“I’m not sure, but what i am sure of is that you were taken from somewhere wether it’s here or not. the best thing to do is keep you here until we can contact somebody for you and get you home.” hearing those words and that determination out you a little at ease. “so what now?” you ask. “now, you come with me. i know where you can stay until we can figure out this situation. i also need to keep a close eye on you in case something happens.” he then looked at you, “there’s a school where i teach at, it’s a school for hero’s. you can come in as a student in my class and stay in the dorms, that way, we’ll be able to keep an eye on you until we can figure out what to do.” he turned to walk as you followed behind him, “from now on, you are not to tell anyone about what happened. i don’t want any commotion on the matter,” you nodded your head, “how much do you already know about this place? you said earlier in your dimension, we take form in some show, tell me what you know.” to be honest, you didn’t actually know much. you’d only just began watching and hadn’t gotten past the second or third episode. “umm.. i don’t know much. i can’t really think right now with all this happening but if i think of anything important, you’ll be the first to know.” he nodded and you continued walking.andddd with that, you are now on your way to the U.A dorms!! while you where scared and still a bit shaken up, it was nice to at lease be in a place you had some familiarity with. and in one of your favorite shows no less! wait a minute… how are you going to explain to them why you don’t have a quirk? i mean it’s the number one school for hero’s and you come, out of the blue, already a student with no quirk? you’ll have to ask aizawa later because as you look up you are at the entrance into the class 1-A dorms. here we go!
<<EOFANFIC>>

completion:
“Do that again, Toya—“The request was breathy and quick, but Toya eagerly did what was requested, his fingers wrapping through blonde locks of hair and tugging backward to make Keigo’s face twist into a smile so deviously perverse. It drove Toya crazy in the best way.Keigo’s eyelashes fluttered as he melted in the palm of Toya’s hand. Toya had control of Keigo like a joystick, maneuvering his head to start leaving love bites on Keigo’s neck. Placing him right where he wants him.Keigo sighed and moaned to the rhythm of his fluttering wings, and that only made Toya suck harder at Keigo’s skin, wanting the marks to be dark and deep. “Singing such a pretty song for me,” Toya flirted in Keigo’s ear.Keigo hummed in response, overcome with lust. “Keep singing, baby,” Toya whispered before he placed a tender kiss under Keigo’s jaw.“Mmm, may I have a turn,  sir  ?” Keigo playfully asked.“Yes you may,” Toya played along as he let his head fall back, giving Keigo plenty of canvas as he started sucking and kissing Toya’s neck. 
 Bzzzt. Bzzzt. 
 Toya briefly moved away from Keigo to glance at the coffee table where his phone was vibrating. “Do you need to get that?” Keigo playfully asked, thinking he already knows the answer.Toya, leaning from the couch to the table, glanced at the caller ID. It’s Shoto. “He can leave a message and I’ll call him back later,” Toya said, running his fingers through Keigo’s hair, moving to stroke his feathers.“You’re a little occupied,” Keigo flirted, brushing a finger under Toya’s chin as he moved forward in his lap.Toya pushed Keigo back to his lips, suppressing a groan. Keigo, however, was much more vocal, practically moaning into Toya’s mouth. 
 Bzzzt. Bzzzt. 
 There’s the damn phone again. Toya pulled away and dramatically exhaled, making Keigo laugh. Toya smiled with satisfaction as he picked the phone off the table. “It’s Shoto again,” he declared.Keigo’s posture changed. “Hey, if he’s calling twice in a row and not leaving a message…”“Shit.”Toya knew Keigo was right. This  could  be something important. With Keigo still in his lap, Toya answered the phone. “Hey, what’s up?”“Why didn’t you pick up the first time?” Shoto sounded different. This isn’t his normal cadence.“My phone was in another room,” Toya lied. Keigo covered his mouth to hold back giggles, “Is everything okay?”“We did something bad. Can I come over?”Keigo’s eyes widened as Toya now changed his posture, worried. “Shit, yeah, you can stay here tonight if you need to.”Toya and Fuyumi made it clear to Natsuo and Shoto that their apartments were safe havens for them. They even had spare keys in case they needed a place to stay while the duo was out on patrol or on a mission. Still, Shoto always called to ask. If Toya didn’t pick up, he’d call Fuyumi. There’s a spare bedroom in both of their apartments that fits both Shoto's and Natsuo’s needs. What Toya didn’t expect this time around, however, was Shoto’s new request. “Oh, um… can I bring someone else too?”“Uh, yeah, sure.”“Thank you, Toya… we’ll be over soon.”And then Shoto hung up.“Hey…” Keigo gently placed a hand on Toya’s back, “Is everything okay?”Toya shuddered at the soft touch, still not quite used to it, “I don’t know. He didn’t really tell me anything.”“Is there anything I can do to help?” Keigo offered.Toya let out a sigh, “Again, I don’t know. His room’s always ready for him, so I don’t know if there’s much else you  can  do.”“Well… I’m here for you, yeah?”“… yeah.” Toya wasn’t expecting to see that boy from the sports festival when he opened his apartment door. “Hello, it’s so nice to meet you; I’ve been a big fan of Fire & Frost for a while so I wish we were meeting in better circumstances,” He was rambling on and on while Shoto stood beside him, holding his hand, “My name is Izuku Midoriya and I’m in the same class as your brother— oh my gosh, HAWKS IS HERE?”“Heyo,” Keigo leaned over to wave from the couch in the living room.Toya sighed and quietly replied, “Yeah… we’re close.”Izuku’s eyes lit up and he began speaking a mile a minute again. “I had no idea! I feel so unprepared!” Toya gestured for the boys to enter, closing his apartment door behind them.Shoto was smiling, but his gaze was on the floor. And he wasn’t letting go of Izuku’s hand. Toya noticed.“None of that really matters after what happened tonight,” Izuku sighed once the two of them stopped. “Yeah, what happened?” Toya asked, crossing his arms and leaning against the wall.“There was an incident with one of our classmates and Stain,” Shoto explained, “We had to use our quirks to protect him.”"You used your quirks without a license,” Toya connected the dots.“We had to,” Izuku continued, “Our friend’s life was in danger.”“Dad was there,” Shoto meekly spoke up.“Why?” Toya asked, not doing anything to hide his disgust.“I was on patrol with him, then Izuku sent me his location and I ran off to go find him.”“It was just the three of you up against Stain?” Keigo asked, his arms stretched across the back of the couch.Shoto nodded yes.“Damn. How are you all doing?” Toya asked.“Not… not good,” Shoto replied, his breathing shaky.“We’re really worried about being in deep trouble,” Izuku replied, moving closer to Shoto.“The police are bound to work something out,” Keigo added, “You all are just kids, plus it was self-defense.”“We can only hope,” Toya’s cynicism was noted.“Can we just… go to my room for a little while?” Shoto asked, his gaze still on the floor.“Yeah, no worries. Holler if you need anything.”Once the boys were out of sight, Toya made his way back to the couch and practically collapsed beside Keigo with a heavy sigh. He rubbed his face and let out a small groan, causing Keigo to ask “What’s wrong?”“Right now, or in general?” Toya sarcastically retorted.“Right now.““Well…” Toya sighed again, “I know for a fact because of my damn dad that they’re going to get off easy.”“Isn’t that a good thing?” Keigo asked, carefully moving a hand to Touya’s shoulder.Toya shuddered again before settling into Keigo’s touch. “I just… I hate admitting it. We shouldn’t be relying on Daddy and His Prestige or whatever to get us out of shit, but it’s like the only thing I can be grateful for. All the times I— and Fuyumi… no just me, Fuyumi isn’t like me— all the times I fucked up, it’s written off by The Commission because I’m Endeavor’s oldest son.”“And you don’t like taking advantage of that?” Keigo asked, confused.“Not really, no. He was such a shit dad that I really hate being associated with him. Sure, he trained me and Fuyumi to be heroes, but we deserve to make names for ourselves on our own and not just be attached to Number Two.”Keigo’s hand stayed still on Toya’s shoulder as he remarked “Oh. I see.”“I… I know how important of a figure my dad is to you. That’s why I don’t like talking about him. I didn’t want to see you disappointed.”“Yeah… you never really mentioned him before, even after all this time.”“I’ve known you for so long and I know how much you look up to my dad—““Toya…” Keigo held his breath, “You don’t have to answer this.”“Hm?”“How… How bad was he?” Keigo asked in a whisper.Toya sighed and leaned forward, resting his forearms on his thighs. Keigo didn’t let go. “You uh… you know the scar on Shoto’s face?”Keigo had to hold back a gasp, “Did he—?”“Not directly,” Toya whispered back, “Mom was so tormented by what he had done to us— and to her— that she just… snapped one day. Saw Dad in Shoto’s eyes. He was so little.”Toya hadn’t talked about that in a long time. He put his hands to his face to keep his focus away from his tight throat and watering eyes. Keigo shouldn’t see him like this. They were sharing bliss before all of this. “I’ll be back.” He quickly got up from the couch, pushing Keigo’s hand away, and paced to the bathroom.He stopped in his tracks when he heard sniffling coming from Shoto’s room. The door cracked open. Toya’s brotherly instincts kicked in, so he did what he could to check in without interfering.Luckily, it seemed like the two boys weren’t going to look up any time soon. They sat on the edge of the bed, Shoto leaned forward just like Toya was on the couch a few moments ago, face buried in his hands. He’s crying. Toya hasn’t seen Shoto cry in years. Izuku, however, was facing Shoto, rubbing gentle circles on his back. He was just sitting with him, doing something that feels mundane… but it must mean the world to Shoto.Toya, eyes glued on the boys, thought back to their old home. He thought back to all the tender touches he missed because of training. Dad would leave him and Fuyumi to care for each other’s wounds. He thought about how Natsuo would take care of them and Shoto when the burns or frostbite got too bad. Toya thought about when the hugs stopped. He saw Izuku kiss his brother’s head and thought about when goodnight kisses stopped. He couldn’t stop his tears anymore.He quickly turned away and went back to his mission, making his way into the bathroom. He turned the sink’s faucet on and started splashing cold water in his face. He felt pathetic. He looked at his sad reflection and rubbed where the hickies were starting to deepen in color. By Emma Iveli
Aizawa had sent out Izuku to run an errand as homeroom began… everyone could how tell that it was just something to get rid of him for some reason. The entire class was nervous about what he could be telling them.

"Aoyama!" she cried.

"I have a gut feeling." Said Aizawa.
The entire class all stared at him.

Though to be fair several members of the class have to be under the impression that he was robot, so that might have been the case.
"A gut feeling?" asked several of the class.
"WHAT THE FUCK!" yelled Bakugo.
'You have a gut feeling that Midoriya is the traitor." Said Jiro clearly trying not to face palm.
"Yes…" answered Aizawa.
There was an award silence.
"That's it? His notebooks and. Gut feeling?" asked Shoji.
"Are you okay?" signed Koda.
"I'm fine." Said Aizawa, "We need to do something about Midoriya… he is a menace."
This raised so many more red flags.
"We have to do something about him?" asked Ojiro.
"Yes…" said Aizawa.
"And you think Midoriya…" said Yaoyorozu.
"Yes." Said Aizawa, "He is clearly a traitor."
Of course no one believed him.
"There are other people more likely to be a traitor, like Kaminari… I don't trust that his short correcting is real." Said Aoyama.
"Come on man! I'm right here!" said Kaminari.
"Still it has to be Midoriya!" said Aizawa.
"Midoriya… the guy who broke himself saving a kid?" asked Sero.

Almost everyone in the room realized that was true.
"I forgot about that!" said Sero.
"He's even purer than I thought." Said Mina.
"He's too innocent." Said Aizawa.
The entire class stared at him.
"What the fuck does that mean!" yelled Bakugo.
"There is no way that he could be innocent after that." Said Aizawa.
"Why is that?" asked Iida with his eye twitching.
"Because he's too innocent… he too nice…" said Aizawa, "It has to be a cover."

"Darkness seems to have clouded his mind…" said Tokoyami.
Everyone quickly realized that his way of saying "I think he went insane."
"Mr. Aizawa are you sure you're reason? They do seem flimsy." Said Yaoyorozu.
"There is no way my reasons are flimsy, all signs pointed to Midoriya." Said Aizawa.
"There is no way that Midoriya is a traitor." Muttered Todoroki, "After everything he has done for all of us."
"He is a traitor…" growled Aizawa.
Aizawa didn't notice that a few of his students had subtly took out their phones.
"Uraraka would be far more likely to be a traitor." Said Aoyama, "What with her money trouble."
"How could you say that!" cried Ochaco.
"Midoriya is the traitor." Said Aizawa.
"No one believes you!" yelled Todoroki.
"Todoroki please calm down!" said Yaoyorozu.
"I refuse to listen to this garbage anymore…" muttered Todoroki glaring harshly at the teacher.
"You will all listen to me! You are to suspect Midoriya! He is the traitor or you will face punishment!" said Aizawa.
Before anything else could be said… the door of the classroom opened up and two robots entered the room and shot strange gunk at Aizawa and then dragged him out of the room .
Most of the class was horribly confused, however those that took out their phones weren't confused.
That was when Principal Nezu and Izuku entered the room.
"Is everything all right?" asked Izuku.
"How the fuck did you know what was going on?" asked Bakugo.
Mina, Kaminari, Jiro, Toru and Yaoyorozu all lifted their phones to show off that they had texted Izuku.

They explained about how Aizawa told them that Izuku was the traitor (leaving out the fact about the notebooks as evidence as many students had realized that Nezu should know about them, lest he mentor the class cinnamon which was a very bad idea).

"Why Midoriya?" asked All Might trying to his grimace and failing badly.
"I thought that everything he has done… it was all an act." Said Aizawa.
"Even with All Might helping him?" asked Midnight.
"No offense but if I had a list of any student being the possible traitor… the green bean wouldn't be any close to the list." Said Present Mic.
"I know…" groaned Aizawa.
As it turned out the real traitor thought the same thing…
As they found months later when it turned to be Aoyama…
"Wait a second…" realized Kaminari, "When you were bringing up people who would be more likely to be the traitor were you saying those things because you wanted to use as possible patsies?"
As Aoyama was gaged at the moment he just tired not to cry… because it was true…
Even the real traitor couldn't see Izuku as someone who could be a traitor…
Still… Class 1-A believed Izuku could never betrayed them… and that was true for sure…
The End…

Chapter Text
“I don't understand,” her mother says. Mishiko wishes her mother, Yoko Towa, did understand. Like she did. “The other doctors said it was practically impossible.”
“But it's time to face facts,” the doctor continued, patiently. “Even if your daughter does have a quirk, you can't register it if you don't know what it is.”
“What do you mean 'even'? Mishiko could just be a late bloomer!”
“With all due respect, Mrs. Towa.” The doctor's eyes were full of sympathy. “Her sixth birthday has already passed. It's long past the usual window in which a quirk would manifest.” The doctor leaned forward. “There is, however, a possibility. It's rare, but some people are born with what we call 'invisible quirks'.”
“Invisible quirks?” Mishiko turned her head to see a young boy at the door to the emergency ward. He looked slightly older than her and appeared to be dripping in blood. He had introduced himself as Toshiro. “That kind of sounds cool.” Mishiko perked up at his comment and felt hope spark in her chest. As the doctor continued to explain, the girl felt the spark in her chest disappear as quickly as it had ignited.
“That's lame,” Toshiro remarked once the man finished. Yoko was quiet for a moment, lips pursed.
“W-what if… she sees… things?” she asked hesitantly. “There have been occasions where... I mean, she talks about people who aren't there, once she said something about her siblings tucking her in, a-and... and Haruna and Taiyo died just after she was born-”
“Mrs. Towa,” the doctor said patiently. “I know you're worried. And I know you want the best for your daughter, but... it's dangerous to hold false hope. Children have wild imaginations, and if you encourage them to see something out of nothing, it may be harmful in the long run. If Mishiko does have an invisible quirk, then it will either show itself or it won't.” He stood up, putting on a smile that even Mishiko could tell wasn’t fully genuine. “In the meantime, being functionally quirkless will in no way prevent her from living a normal and happy life. She’s in excellent health, and very well-behaved on top of that.” Mishiko wasn’t listening. She was far too busy watching as Toshiro got up from his chair, and strolled out of the room, swatting the jar of cotton buds as he passed.
The jar toppled over and landed with a thud.
The doctor glanced over his shoulder with a frown. “Odd,” he muttered, and went to turn it right-side up again. Mishiko stared at the jar and refused to say a word for the rest of the doctor visit.
No one else can see her friends. That she knows. But that's the first time one of her friends has ever done something that someone else saw. She saw the twins, back when she was three. But Haruna and Taiyo were dead. Toshiro was dripping wet with blood, but the floor was dry and clean. But Mishiko saw him knock over the jar, and the doctor saw the jar fall but didn't see who caused it. As Mishiko and Yoko leave the doctors office, she sees people walking among the doctors and patients. The people were all wearing hospital gowns and looked worse for wear. A man covered in blood came close to the two and vomited. Mishiko hid her face in her mother’s side. Yoko doesn't see what she sees. Yoko has no way of knowing that she's sobbing in fear. Yoko thinks it's because she doesn't have a quirk, or because she has a quirk that's so useless that she might as well not have one at all. However, it is actually because she does have a quirk, and it’s not a useless one. And when they are safe at home and her father is with them, then she’ll tell them why she cried.

Enji himself doesn't have autism— but it wouldn't hurt to get a test too, it'd ease Toshinori to know he wasn't getting singled out.Now, to bring it up to Toshinori... Enji scratched his chin, playing with the pocket button on his jeans. The redhead couldn't even tell that the blond was staring at him, woolly."Hey, we should... Go to a doctor— for a well-being check..!" Enji scratched his head, turning to the blond and shrugging. Toshinori looked at him confused "Ah, are you alright Enji?" Toshinori frowned, scooting closer. Enji nodded, grabbing the other man's hands."Yeah, just thought it'd be a quick and easy checkup." The flame-wielder only meant to have Toshinori take that test, not him... Enji face palmed."Ah, hey! I scored higher than you. Does that mean I did better?" "That's what I'm saying though! Kamui Woods and Mt. Lady don't make a good team because their quirks compliment each other, they work well together because they know each other so well. Your quirk doesn't necessarily have to be compatible with your future hero partner, you do."
"I'm not disagreeing with you, Deku," Ochaco giggled and Katsuki rolled his eyes while opening their lockers a few rows over from Izuku's. "I'm just saying that, regardless of compatibility, a team-up like Kamui Woods and Endeavor wouldn't be the best. They could work around it. I mean obviously they have in the past. But, it's not an ideal match-up."
Deku chuckled, "Okay, you've got me there. But, we're talking about you right now. You could team up with literally anyone and be fine. Your quirk is versatile and I could count on one hand the amount of people you don't get along with, not including villains of course."
Uraraka snorted, "Of course." "You're the only one of us who manages to get along with villains as well as every other extra you meet," Katsuki griped.Deku, much to their surprise, didn't say anything back to that. In fact, he didn't say anything at all. When Katsuki and Ochaco looked over, he was standing completely still, staring intently at a piece of paper that had creases in it where it had been folded multiple times.
"What's that?" Ochaco asked, shouldering her bag and closing her locker.
Deku still didn't move and acted as though he didn't hear her.
"Deku?" Katsuki barked sharply.
"What's today?" Deku spoke abruptly.
"Huh?" Ochaco tilted her head. "What do you mean? It's Friday, obviously. We were just talking about going to the store to stock up on groceries for the weekend."
"No. The date. What's today's date?" Deku was still staring at the sheet of paper clenched in his hands.
"It's April first," Ochaco's brows furrowed in concern.
Deku's shoulders slumped and he crushed the paper in his left hand.
"The fuck's wrong, Nerd?" not that Katsuki cared or anything.
"Nothing," Deku plastered on a smile that didn't quite reach his eyes and shoved the paper in his locker, before slamming it shut and shrugging on his ugly yellow back pack. "Just someone pulling a silly April Fools prank. You guys want to change before we go to the store right? We should hurry so we can get back in time to start diner for everyone."
He took off before either of them could say anything. Ochaco and Katsuki shared a look.
"I'll meet you nerds at the gate," Katsuki said, shouldering his own bag.
Ochaco nodded at him, "Kay! See you in 30?"
"Sounds good," he shrugged, trying to get rid of her, but also trying not to be an ass.
She nodded again and bounded off to catch up with Deku.
Katsuki closed his own locker and took a quick glance around to make sure no one was looking, before opening Deku's locker. If he didn't want Katsuki to snoop, he should change his combination to something harder to crack than All Might's birthday. He picked up the crinkled paper and started to read, eyebrows shooting into his hairline.
He shoved the note into his pocket, slammed Deku's locker closed, and promptly banged his head against it a few times before taking a deep breath and stalking off down the hall.
He only had 30 minutes to hunt down his prey and kick their ass after all. He couldn't waste time thinking about why he even cared to get himself involved with this bullshit in the first place. ———————————-Hitoshi had just changed into some very comfortable pajamas and was getting ready to take a much needed afternoon nap, when his dorm room door was nearly blasted off it's hinges. He didn't even flinch when Katsuki slammed it closed so hard that it shook the frame and knocked a few books from his shelf.
"Can I help you?" Hitoshi drawled.
"You're a fucking idiot," Katsuki growled.
"Oh? And what have I done to cross you this time, oh great and powerful Explosion Murder God Dynamight?"
"Cut the shit, asshole. This is serious."
And Katsuki wasn't screaming or exploding things, so Hitoshi knew it had to be. He sat up immediately and dropped his usual don't-give-a-shit façade.
"What's this about?"
In leu of an actual answer, Katsuki shoved a crumpled piece of paper into his hands. Hitoshi paled when he recognized what he was holding and his expression shifted from shock to panic before settling on fury.
"Why the hell do you have this?" 
Hitoshi shot from his bed to stand toe to toe with Katsuki, positively fuming, but Katsuki continued to speak calmly. Or at least, as calm as possible for the guy who could create explosions in his palms.
"Do you have any idea what today is?"
And that just threw Hitoshi completely off his axis because, "What?"
"Do. You. Know. What. Today. Is?" Katsuki spoke through gritted teeth, clearly starting to lose what little bit of patience he had.
"No," Hitoshi backed off a little. "I mean, it's Friday, that's why I decided to give it to him today, so if he didn't feel the same, any awkwardness could be handled over the weekend, but what does that matter, and why am I telling you this?!"
"So you didn't think about the fact that today is April first?" Katsuki gave him a very exaggerated, pointed look. It was very condescending and very much confusing and pissing Hitoshi off.
"No. What the fuck does that have to do with anything? What the hell are you talking about?"
"It's April Fool's Day, dipshit!" if looks could kill, Hitoshi would be beyond dead.
"Oh," the realization of how stupid he had actually been finally hit him full force and his eyes widened. "OH!"
"Yeah, 'oh'." Katsuki scoffed. "The damn nerd thinks this," he snatched the letter out of Hitoshi's hand and waved it around in his face, "is a fucking prank. 'Meet me in the courtyard at 8?' Really? What the fuck, Eyebags? You couldn't at least sign the fucking thing? Or, I don't know, confess to him in person without a cryptic fucking love letter?"
"Fuck you," Hitoshi tried to swipe the note back from Katsuki but only met air. Katsuki held it away from him like the fucking bully he is. "I don't have to explain myself to you."
"Well you sure as shit better explain yourself to Deku."
"You still haven't explained why the hell you even know about this in the first place. Or how you knew I wrote it!"
"I recognized your handwriting and I was there when he found the damn thing!"
"Oh," Hitoshi lowered his head, and crossed his arms, wishing he was wearing his capture weapon so he could hide his face in it. "What'd he say?"
"He didn't say anything to us about it. Just shoved it back in his locker and said someone was pranking him. Plastered on one of his fake ass smiles and ran off. And... he doesn't know I have it." Katsuki had the decency to look slightly guilty about that last bit of information, but Hitoshi couldn't really fault him for it.
"Guy gets a heartfelt confession letter and automatically thinks it's a joke?" Hitoshi was trying really hard not to sound hurt.
"Have you met Deku?" Katsuki raises an unimpressed eyebrow, and honestly, fair. Izuku has no idea just how amazing he is. Any time someone so much as compliments him, he stammers out immediate protests and starts complimenting them instead.
Katsuki placed the letter on Hitoshi's desk and sighed, running a hand through his hair.
"You know Deku had it rough in middle school, and that was mostly my fault," he clenched his hands and his jaw before continuing. "He was everyone's favorite target on April Fool's and Valentine's Day for fake confessions and other such bullshit. I don't think he ever fell for any of it. But I know he would stay after school late on those days, to clean his desk and locker and trash everything." The 'and cry' was left unsaid.
Hitoshi was horrified. Not because of Izuku's mistreatment, unfortunately he knew exactly how mean kids could be to people who were different. Having a "villainous quirk" was not the same as being completely quirkless, but he was ostracized just the same. Bullied. Left out. No, Hitoshi was too used to the treatment to be horrified by that. He was horrified with himself for being so utterly stupid.
"Awful observant for a bully who claimed not to care," he voiced instead, attempting to redirect.
Something akin to hurt flashed across Katsuki's face, and Hitoshi might've missed it, if he wasn't observing him so closely. As quickly as it came, it left, and Katsuki shrugged, "I've always been observant."
"Clearly," Hitoshi drawled, crossing his arms.
"Whatever," Katsuki turned to leave, "just fix it."
"Why do you care so much?" Katsuki stopped with his hand hovering above the doorknob.
"Because," he spoke so softly Hitoshi had to strain to hear, "the nerd deserves better."
Katsuki swiftly left the room, slamming the door behind him, knocking a few more books from their shelves and shocking Hitoshi into silence.<<EOFANFIC>>
