completion:
Chapter Text





When the snow falls and the white wind blows, the lone wolf dies but the pack survives  
~George R.R. Martin

  


When the first snow of the season began to fall, the sky was etched in smoke. 



Butane lingered in the air as an ember blew into the breeze, tainting the inside of Kazuki’s throat with ash and blood. 



He fiddled with a crumpled package of cigarettes, a lighter in the other hand as he watched the sunset over the tree line.



If only he could afford a view like this. 



Kazuki tisked and closed his eyes before tilting his gaze towards the dimming atmosphere, snow lightly falling to earth. 



Ironically, such a thing is wasted on a pack of heartless killers. 



Life and her seamless riddles. 



Two-gun shots rang out inside the blazing manor, nearly void of human life. 



Kazuki exhaled a sigh and pulled a cigarette out between his front teeth. Typical Rei, turning him into a smoker. The assassin supposed he had formed worse habits. 



The lighter spat furiously at the bare bones of butane but folded after another brisk attempt. The next exhale tasted a little more like ash than blood.  



Snowflakes landed on his torn jacket and melted after a few moments. The tip of the cigarette burned brightly, crumbling as it turned black.



Another gunshot. 




I’m sorry, Miri.




But your Papas have to run one last mission. If we succeed, we can finally be a real family. 



He had been prepared to die if it meant living the rest of his life as a free man. Even if it meant going out with a view like this.




There were worse ways to die



, Kazuki inhaled the smoke deeply. 



Blood trickled down his leg. 



Another gunshot. 



He glanced over his shoulder, searching for any signs of life in the upstairs window.


You better make it back, Rei. 


This battle had been written in the stars for a very long time—they couldn’t afford to mess it up. 



The man was on the verge of resorting to packing developing snow on his leg by the time Rei made it outside. He clung to his right arm and stopped by the flickering lantern mounted at the entrance. Before he could speak, they exchanged one look that said it all.



It was over. 




It was over. 




They were finally free. 




He was free. 




Parts of the drive home were silent. Pink hues had all but faded as the stars took their place. The wipers swept the melting snow away quietly, both parties smelling of sweat, blood, and smoke. 



Kazuki’s thoughts kept circling back to how difficult it would get the stains out of the cushioned seats. 



He glanced a side eye at Rei bandaging his injured arm, before glancing at his own leg and shoulder. 



He laughed quietly. 




They made quite a pair. 




‘
Hey. Did you ever believe in Santa Claus?’



Kazuki sat up straighter as the words popped into his head.




‘Huh? Where did that come from? I don’t even remember my parents. Like hell was I getting any gifts? Why would I believe in Santa?’




He glanced at Rei quickly before returning his eyes to the narrow road in front of them. Trees wrapped around both sides as the road snaked into a series of twisted turns.  



Life and her riddles. What would compel Rei to bring up such a thing, now of all days?



Kazuki’s mind drifted. 



His hands rested 10 and 2 on the wheel, humming almost too quietly for himself to hear. 



Some of his first memories involved a snowfall just like this. 



Kazuki always remembered the snow. He remembered how beautiful it looked, shimmering in the streetlights. 



He always marveled at how it seemingly came from nowhere, the night so black, as if every star had gone out.



Red eyes softened, falling into an unconscious rhythm while balancing the steering wheel. 



He wasn’t really sure if he had believed in Santa at one point.



All Kazuki remembered about that snowfall was that it would be the most beautiful way to die.  



His mind began drifting off completely, and he tisked, where did Rei come up with such things? 



Honestly.



He had been twenty years since his first Christmas out of the orphanage. Kazuki was the type to let things die in the past—if he could help it. 



When was the last time he had thought about that night?



Maybe he really was changing. 



He remembered making a wish to Santa. Maybe the first and probably the last wish he would make to anyone—real or otherwise. 



They were in the age of heroes and the small, frail boy on Christmas Eve could have chosen any Pro-Hero in the city to make his wish to and turned towards the inky black sky in its stead. 


‘Santa- ‘the blonde boy closed his eyes tightly, cheeks frostbitten, ‘Please send me a Mama for Christmas. And a Papa. Or two Papas, or one Mama—as long as we can be a family. Please Santa.’


He watched as white clumps floated around in the artificial halo. 



Large red eyes clung to the image.



And he waited.



His fingers and toes grew numb as the nine-year-old began wandering around the outskirts of Tokyo’s alleyways. 



He continued to wander around, clinging to the shadows as cars and people bustled on by in the late-night life. 



Many men and women and their families walked home and ran to do last-minute gift shopping. Santa couldn’t be everywhere. Kazuki honestly wasn’t even sure if Santa really was real.



Many children in the orphanage didn’t believe in him. None of them had ever received gifts, so the disbelief was natural.



But Kazuki felt like holding out hope that night. Maybe it was the way the ice clung to his clothes, turning the tips of his fingers blue. Maybe it was the numbness that continued creeping in, growing gradually worse by the hour. 



If only he could find something to eat, maybe he’d feel better. Even if it was only temporary. He could come up with a plan. 



The boy knew his best chance was attempting a transformation. If he could find something that could survive this storm, he’d have better chances of surviving outside of the orphanage. 



Kazuki wasn’t the smartest child, but he was smart enough to know that a transformation like that, or any transformation at this time could kill him. 



His quirk depended on having enough fuel to make the necessary physical changes and without enough food available, the boy was running out of options. 



Two bony arms wrapped around his rib cage, his steps bravely carving out a path towards Tokyo’s Street lights with heavier foot traffic. 



 For the most part, the grown-ups ignored him. 



Heavily clothed hips and shopping bags thumped into his short frame once or twice. Kazuki walked faster through the crowd towards a familiar diner. 



He recalled having good luck with their dumpsters earlier that morning. 



The blonde huddled in his brown coat and felt his heart pound in anticipation. If there was enough food left over maybe, he could manage a transformation into a dog or something small like a rodent. 



A rodent would be fairly difficult but the odds of finding a small hole or barrage to hide in were greater compared to the rest of the options available. 



Before Kazuki could move to the back of the diner he stopped by the front window. 



The window filled up the entire front wall of the diner, the awning above it holding piles of snow above the small patio below. 



Stars were growing in his eyes as the large red irises gleamed at the scene inside. 


Christmas decorations covered the walls, and servers and bartenders moved around the tables in a well-lit, cozy, warm atmosphere. 


The boy, however, set his sights on the family eating by the window. A man and a woman looked slightly exhausted but cheery as their four- or five-year-old daughter danced back and forth in her seat. 



They seemed to hold a conversation, occasionally pausing to scoop up hot, heaps of food. 



Kazuki stared longingly at their plates, struggling to think of the names. The orphanage never made food like this. 



He hesitated toward the tall door near him. 



He weighed the odds of getting past the server towards the restroom, even if was only a few moments.



He watched his feet shyly and moved closer, slowly reaching. 



A grownup on the sidewalk bumped into him, before briskly apologizing without a moment's glance. 



As if the physical force jostled him back to his sense, Kazuki felt his courage begin to die out, glancing a few times at the server speaking to the family’s table. 



Everyone looked so happy. 



The wind chilled and roared in the streets. 




He wondered what it would cost to have that. If only for a moment-




“Oi! Kazuki!”



Kazuki snapped back to himself, hands gripping the wheel. 



His heart fluttered at being caught off guard, he must be slipping. The other man must have failed to turn on the car’s heater, letting frost collect on the rims of the window. Did he want them to freeze to death?



“Oi, what’s the idea, giving me a heart attack like that,” Kazuki sighed, briefly closing his eyes, and exhaling. 



Rei frowned, squinting blearily in his direction, eyes bright with fever. While not especially sensitive to pain, the side effects of impulsively blasting his arm nearly clean off his shoulder were causing him considerable discomfort. 

 


Damn immortal bastard.  


“Try not to kill us before we can get back home to Miri,” he muttered quietly, the sardonic irony not lost on either of them. 



Kazuki merely tisked in response and then internally softened as he eyed the reddened bandage on his appendage.



They would probably bleed out before they died in a car crash. Correction: Kazuki would probably die while the other man merely ate some pavement after flying through the windshield. Who had gotten the short end of the Quirk-stick was anyone's guess.



Kazuki wasn’t sure which would be a better way to go. He’d take either over being taken out by the organization. Especially the trigger-happy psychopath back there with his fucked-up kill list. 



Who wrote down people’s last words anyway?



This line of work sure brought the sickos out of the woodwork.



What that said about the two men, he’d rather not ponder. 



Perhaps admitting you were insane was in fact a mark of sanity for assassins. Lord knows Rei and Kazuki had been through enough to claim it. No mentally stable person chose to become a hired hitman. 



In a world of pro-heroes, they had become cold-blooded killers. 



Which was fine, if the heroes had made one thing abundantly clear: people like Rei and Kazuki could fend for themselves.



If the two worlds never crossed over, that would be fine by him. 



It would be more than fine in fact… 




If they hadn’t already.  





End Chapter One.



<<EOFANFIC>>

Chapter Text
     DAYLIGHT streamed down like a golden cascade of warmth onto the dull-colored, structures of Musutafu. A flock of birds fluttered carelessly across the blue canvas sky, and your (E/C) eyes followed them until they drifted out of view.Sporting your choice of school uniform -- a grey jacket over a short-sleeved white button-up and a green pencil skirt, along with white canvas sneakers, walking among unknown people as you near the corner, blending in perfectly.  "The UA rescue training center where the first-year hero course students class took place was attacked." A crowd was gathered around the building giving the newscast, leaving a lot of space as you made your way down the street, "According to police officials, the assailants called themselves the league of villains. Despite this event, the sports festival was still held, and public opinion about the school is very mixed at the moment."You quirked an eyebrow, as your lips settled on a smirk.
'So we've got them talking...'
You could say you're all too familiar with the League, being one of its first members, along with your adoptive brother, Tomura, and your caretaker, Kurogiri.The two of you were taken in by your Sensei at a young age, you couldn't recall anything from your formative years before you became AFO's vessel, but he'd said you were a weak quirkless little girl before he generously blessed you with a quirk and people to call your family.You never understood Sensei's ideology. You never saw a reason for the way he thought or his deep-rooted hatred toward heroes. For fifteen years of your life, you felt like you barely knew anything about him.But you did know that you wanted to please him.So you've put up with the years of rigorous training, both mental and physical, in hopes that one day he would be proud of you. And now, it came time to assume your role in the plan as a student at U.A.In any case, a text to Kurogiri had Warp Gate opening around you.Which is how you found yourself back in the bar, sitting on a stool as you read your classical book, the blue-haired man letting loose a dart into a newly hung-up picture of All Might on the dartboard. "I am this close to killing him!" Tomura said, somewhat hysterically.Kurogiri took that moment to stroll into the bar from the backrooms, hands in his pockets."Patience Tomura." completion:
Damage Control


Shut shit shit! 

It was just supposed to be a bit of cum play. He agreed to let her take her sexual frustrations out on him provided she didn’t get pregnant. That was his only rule. She could call on him any time and any place, post missions be damned. He was available for her personal use.

So when Nemuri Kayama found out she was pregnant with Sekijiro’s child, she had no choice but to break it off without telling him. She considered abortion, yes, but she thought about how she could finally have a family she always wanted on her own. A single mom? Those were everywhere! Blood Quirks could be from anyone. There was no guarantee the child would even have a blood quirk. No one knew about their relationship anyway, who would care about another pregnant teacher? She could go through with it and no one would be the wiser, maybe, if she could get past the morning sickness.

“Are you pregnant?” Were the first words uttered by none other than Mt. Lady when she overheard the heroine throwing up in the staff bathroom.

Nemuri emerged from the stall completely blanched of all color and looking pissed as hell.

“Oh please Yu, an old lady like me?” She smirked as she washed her hands and pulled out a bottle of mouthwash. “You said it yourself I’m past my prime,” she scoffed before she tossed back the Listerine and gargled for a minute and spit into the sink.

“That was just for the sponsors!” The blonde woman looked horrified, “I didn’t mean it like that!” Midnight paused before opening the door to leave.

“That mean girl attitude of yours is only going to take you so far. Remember that, Takeyama.”

…

She slept with a few other heroes just to cover her tracks. Endeavor agreed to entertain her for a week before she switched to a one-night stand with Aizawa—who seemed to really enjoy the encounter. Hitting and quitting Hawks was no problem. Selkie was able to get it up for her without a fuss. Shishido refused to do it raw, but it only mattered that they fucked. 

It was funny knowing that she was sleeping around in her thirties when everyone thought she was doing that on the regular. She was only able to lose her virginity at 25 because she asked Jeanist to do it for her. She requested that he tie her up and blindfold her before he did the deed which he obliged without question. They both acted like nothing happened afterward.

She kept teaching into her third month just before she started showing and put in for personal leave, something she never did in all her time working as a hero.

The request raised the Principal’s eyebrows but he said nothing and approved the leave anyway. He seemed understanding for the need of discretion. Midnight figured a lot of people noticed her change in behavior in spite of her efforts to keep up her persona. She was good but not that good.


Oh well, we can’t be perfect all the time. 


The worst part about her pregnancy was the loneliness she experienced. Doctors appointments, nighttime cravings, parenting classes, all alone. Even her secret photo diary documenting the experience would never be seen by anyone except her child once born. The cute maternity outfits, journaling,  and baby yoga were her favorite parts of the experience.

Then there were the doubts. Could she be a good mother? Would the child like being known as the child of Midnight, the somnambulist hero? The woman who was brash and shameless and was sponsored by several sex shops and taught consent-based sex Ed? Or would they be too embarrassed to admit to such a thing? Would people laugh at her legacy child?

A knock at the door distracted her from her journaling. Who the fuck was knocking at 7pm? She opened the door to see Mt. Lady and Recovery Girl armed with some presents, Yu had a nervous smile.

“Surprise! We thought we’d pay you a visit dearie,” the old lady with a cane quipped with a bit of cheer in her voice. Midnight had no choice but to let them both inside.

“How many weeks are you Nemuri-Chan?” Recovery Girl always called her that ever since she debuted.

“About 30 weeks,” Midnight said after a bit of thought, patting her swollen belly. She led them to the kitchen where she began serving tea and snacks. 

“Thirty weeks?” Yu was flabbergasted, “You look like you’re gonna pop Lady!” RC hit her with her cane.

“Ouch! Not the knee!” Midnight have a good-natured laugh as she served her guests.

“Why haven’t you been keeping contact with me? You know my office is always open!” Nemuri felt her heart sink a bit at that bit.

“I...wanted to keep it a secret,” her face fell, “A lot of my reputation is just me being a brash and shameless woman and…I just wanted to keep something to myself, you know? I didn’t mean to shut you out,” she reached and took the older woman’s hand and gave it a squeeze. Up to this point the youngest woman in the room had been silent.

“Even heroes deserve privacy,” she finally spoke but she said it so softly it almost wasn’t heard, “I didn’t tell anyone that you were pregnant, Midnight.”

“You didn’t?” The other two women were surprised. Usually Mt. Lady was quite a gossip and frequent tea-spiller. For some reason, this was her line in the sand.

“I thought about what you said to me in the bathroom a few months ago. It bothered me at first, and then I realized that I would be in your shoes one day. So I had to make some personal changes.”

“A new leaf huh? I bet you’re throwing everyone off their game,” Midnight gave her a smile and a light punch to the shoulder.

“It is…difficult. I’ve teamed up with other large heroes in order to learn how to cause less collateral damage. I’ve also been taking martial arts classes so I can actually fight now. I can work better with others now, so that’s a plus. Everyone just finds it weird that I’m not talking as much.” The conversation continued pleasantly for a while before RC asked the real question.

“This is important Nemuri, who is the father?” Midnight wanted to say that she didn’t know but that would be too obvious of a lie. RC knew her true personality and her saying that she was just sleeping around wouldn’t cut it.

“What I’m about to say can’t leave this room,” she began. Everyone huddled closely to hear. “Sekijiro and I had…an agreement,” she knew better than to say it was a relationship,”I could use him for sex so long as I didn’t get pregnant. I didn’t do it on purpose, but I cut it off as soon as I found out. I slept with some other heroes to…cover it up. It was all around the same time I tested positive. But he is the father. And I’m not telling him.”

A Tall young man dressed in a trench coat with a high collar, slacks, gloves, dress shoes and a fedora that were all as black as sin lumbered forward as he followed the young woman with blood red eyes and blonde hair wearing a plain dress that could easily be confused for that of a mourner’s under a black cloak with a blood red inside.
 
“I-Izuku! I-i command you, tell me where we are!” The blonde shakily demanded.
 
A beat of silence passed as a swirl of pitch black smoke left from under the hat the young man now named as Izuku wore before he answered the young woman.
 
“As you wish lady Erishkigal, currently we are standing outside the Mustafu botanical gardens. If you wish to enter, they are open to visitors from the third hour after first light till the second hour after the sun falls during the summer season.” Izuku stated to the woman who shared a name with an ancient goddess, but surely that is only coincidence.
 
“Oooh this is a garden! I wonder if they have any flowers- I-i mean, hmm this shall do, Izuku, escort me inside at once!” Erishkigal ordered.
 
“As you wish my lady” Was all Izuku said in response as he held his hand out to Erishkigal to ensure she would not lose sight of him.
 
Erishkigal blushed crimson before placing her hand in Izuku’s.
 
Izuku then began up the stairs that led towards the entrance of the impressive marble building with Erishkigal close behind.
 
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
 
As the oddly matched pair entered the lobby of the building Erishkigal quickly took notice of the wall of chocolate covered seeds behind the receptionist's desk and beckoned Izuku to lean down to her where she whispered her request that Izuku would quickly and diligently follow as he walked towards the desk and loomed over the receptionist before asking for one of the myriad myriad packs of edible seeds behind her, his face concealed in the shadows.
 
“T-that’ll be five-hundred fifty yen plus tax” The receptionist stated to the pair.
 
Izuku reached into his coat and pulled a single solid gold coin before placing it upon the desk and sliding it towards the receptionist.
 
“*SKRRRRRREEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEECH* This should more than cover the expenses-” Was all Izuku said before looking at the name tag that hung from the collar of the receptionist’s shirt and speaking her name “Uraraka” and leaving the young brown haired woman to do her job as Izuku escorted Erishkigal to the gardens.
 
Uraraka, who was stupefied by the solid gold coin soon broke from her trance and shouted to the pair “GOOD LUCK ON YOUR DATE!”
 
Luckily, Erishkigal was too busy inhaling her chocolate covered treat to hear Uraraka for if she had Uraraka’s head would have been cleaved from her neck out of embarrassment.
 
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
 
Erishkigal happily observed the thousands of flowers with Izuku patiently listening to her recite the names and meaning of each flower, perfectly comfortable and happy with observing 
his 
Goddess.
 
“Ah… It seems I still need to work on that apparently, Erishkigal is not his Goddess, she is the queen of Kur, caretaker of those who have passed into her house, the Goddess of death, to deny her from every being living and dead would be selfish and catastrophic beyond measure, yet… no, I will simply have to seek advice upon this maladie of mine when we make our return to Kur.” Izuku thought to himself before having the train of thought banished to the back of his mind when Erishkigal beckoned for him to observe a particular set of flowers.
 
“Izuku, do you know what these flowers are?” Erishkigal softly asked the man she held a myriad of complicated feelings for, briefly allowing her admittedly horrible facade of a young lady to fall to the wayside for only a moment.
 
“I must confess I do not” Izuku stated truthfully as he kneeled upon the ground.
 
Erishkigal laughed cheerily, to Izuku it sounded more beautiful than the bells of the heavens and held more value to him than all the treasures locked below the earth though and all the gold that paved the cities of the heavens, to any passers by it would seem as if one of the two had just told a particularly funny joke.
 
“It seems we have finally found a subject in which I know more than you!” Erishkigal happily stated before drawing Izuku’s attention to a flower with purple petals and a gold ring in it’s center
 
“This flower is an Anemone, more specifically it is a Hadspen Abundance, Anemone’s have a variety of meanings such as Protection against evil and ill wishes, guarding against sickness and illness, or bad luck and ill omens, they are often placed among flower arrangements for the dead to represent fond remembrance.” Erishkigal stated to Izuku as she gently caressed the flower .
 
“I see.” Izuku stated as Erishkigal continued to caress the flower and became lost in thought as she remembered when she met Izuku many winters ago.
 
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
 
Erishkigal was journeying through Kur, walking upon one of the millions of paths she had walked a million times before and will walk a million times after this however though she did not know it this was the last time she would walk these paths alone ever again as an unfamiliar feeling that could only be described as sea sickness struck an unprepared Erishkigal and the world warped and twisted around her.
 
When Erishkigal opened her eyes she saw a terrifying and sickening sight.
 
A young boy with green hair, his right eye missing, his left leg a mangled and twisted mess of flesh and bone leaning upon a blood stained stone mosaic that depicted Erishkigal sitting upon the throne of Kur, the bodies of dozens of other children surrounding him as a man wearing black robes held a young blonde child with red eyes by the neck and prepared to stab the boy.
 
Erishkigal immediately knew what this was, a ritual to summon the power of The Black Flame, the power of the pure human soul, the power she held dominion over and a power that could only ever truly be wielded by one selected by her
 
So in this moment she decided to make her presence known to the young boy with green hair, as time slowed to a crawl before appearing before him as a titan of shadows wearing the finest cloth and jewel’s that had ever been offered to her and asked.
 
“TELL ME MORTAL DOST THOU KNOWETH WHOM THOU HAST SUMMONED!?”
 
Erishkigal gave herself a mental pat on the back at this performance, proud of herself and her perfected introduction that took far longer than she would be willing to admit to master.
 
Unfortunately the green haired boy seemed to like his ancient Sumerian and Babylonian myths as he answered Ereshkigal with “Erishkigal, Goddess of death, Queen Of Kur, Sister Of Ishtar, Patron Of All Non-Binary Persons, and Consort Of Nergal.”
 
The titan of shadows that Erishkigal had formed around herself immediately *Poofed* away, leaving a somewhat irritated goddess standing before the boy with a pout on her face who begrudgingly stated to the green haired boy “Correct on all accounts save one, I’m the former consort of Nergal, and before you ask it’s because he became a soul devouring demon lord of hell.”
 
“Oh… My… condolences…?” The green haired boy half asked and half stated to the goddess.
 
“It’s fine… So, why am I here mortal? And why aren’t you terrified of contacting the goddess of death?” Erishkigal asked the green haired boy.
 
“Well, my friend and I got kidnapped by that guy in the robes” The green haired boy then pointed to the man with robes before continuing “He threw us into this room with the other’s” The green haired boy then gestured to the corpses around him “I tried to make an escape, you can see how that turned out, and now Kaachan is about to be stabbed.”
 
Erishkigal blinked several times in shock at this before saying “You are very calm about all this!”
 
The green haired boy simply said “Thanks, it’s all the blood loss!”
 
After a long stint of silence Erishkigal coughed into her fist and said “Now then mortal, I offer you an accord, I will allow you to draw upon the true power of the human soul to heal your wounds, destroy that man and save your friend, in return you will enter into my service as my bodyguard and companion for all of eternity, do we have a deal?”
 
“Sure, but I don’t really have any choice in the matter though do I?” Izuku stated as he raised his hand.
 
“Not really, still if you do this willingly you will be able to retain your sense of self.” Erishkigal answered as she lowered her hand to shake the green haired boy’s, bathing him in pitch black fire.
 
And the rest is as they say history.
 
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
 
“I-izuku, if you don’t mind I’d like to ask you something.” Erishkigal said to Izuku.
 
“Please, by all means, ask away!” Izuku stated as he looked Erishkigal in the eye’s.
 
“Right then Erishkigal you can do this, just do what Ishtar said and start the conversation with something simple and allow it to progress from there!” Erishkigal hyped herself up before clearing her throat and begining with “Hypothetically, If I desired to… do something with you… outside of the confines of our contract… what would your response to it be?”
 
Izuku quickly answered with “It would depend on what you desired.” dodging the question with the grace and skill expected of The Queen Of Kur’s Guard Dog.
 
“Perhaps I desire… something… like this?” Erishkigal said as she slowly closed the distance between the two of them.
 
In turn Izuku began to unconsciously lean towards her, ready to reciprocate what he subconsciously knew was coming.
 
Unfortunately for the pair it was then that a man covered in a toxic green substance with two far to large nuclear yellow eye’s jumped from the catwalk above, immediately sending Izuku into business model as he picked Erishkigal up and jumped to the side away from the man.
 
“DaMMit! GiVE mE ThAT gIrL! I NeEd hEr tO gET aWay FrOM tHat BaSTarD!!!” The substance screamed before charging at Izuku and Erishkigal as its size grew.
 
Izuku tore off the glove on his right hand before placing it on the ground as black fire ignited and burned his skin down to the bone before consuming the pair in a tornado of black flames.
 
-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
 
A tornado of black flame appeared upon the roof of the garden, revealing Izuku holding Erishkigal.
 
“I apologize my lady, I let my guard slip, it won’t happen again!” Izuku exclaimed as he placed Erishkigal back upon the ground.
 
“It’s fine Izuku, I assume you're going back to fight that thing?” Erishkigal asked
 
“Of course, I do have my professional pride! That and your sister would kill me if I didn’t” Izuku said with a shrug as he pulled off his other glove as flames engulfed him.
 
Soon a massive explosion of pitch black flames occurred, and the Slime Villain was apprehended, half dead, and in a coma for the rest of his life, but alive.

completion:
Izuku had always admired Katsuki's strength and tenacity, but recently he had begun to notice something else - something he wasn't quite sure how to handle. He found himself looking at Katsuki differently, his heart racing when he caught a glimpse of his bright blond hair or heard his voice.

At first, Izuku tried to push these feelings away, telling himself that they were just admiration for his powerful friend. But as time went on, he couldn't deny the truth any longer - he was in love with Katsuki.

But there was no way he could tell him. Not now, when their friendship was still so new and fragile. And especially not when there was a new sidekick in their agency, one who seemed to have taken a particular interest in Katsuki.

Izuku couldn't stand to see the way this sidekick would flutter around Katsuki, using cheap perfume that made his nose itch. He could see that Katsuki was uncomfortable, but he didn't know how to say no without hurting the sidekick's feelings.

It all came to a head at a party the agency threw to celebrate their latest victory over a villain. Izuku watched as the sidekick draped themselves all over Katsuki, getting closer and closer until they tried to touch him inappropriately.

Izuku's blood boiled. He couldn't stand to see Katsuki being treated like this. Without thinking, he started cussing the sidekick out, telling them to back off and leave Katsuki alone.

The sidekick was taken aback by Izuku's sudden outburst, but Katsuki was even more surprised. He tried to stop Izuku, telling him that it was just a misunderstanding and that he didn't want to cause any trouble.

But Izuku wasn't having it. He was so angry that he punched the sidekick, sending them reeling. Katsuki's face twisted in anger as he grabbed Izuku's arm, pulling him back and yelling at him to stop.

Izuku couldn't believe it. He had thought he was defending Katsuki's honor, but instead, he had caused a rift between them. He could see the hurt in Katsuki's eyes, and it broke his heart.

Without a word, he turned and ran out of the party, tears streaming down his face. He didn't know what to do or where to go, but he couldn't bear to be around Katsuki any longer.

It wasn't until later, when he had calmed down a bit, that he realized what had really been bothering him. He was in love with Katsuki, and he didn't know how to deal with those feelings.

But he knew one thing for sure - he couldn't keep them bottled up any longer. He had to tell Katsuki how he felt, even if it meant risking their friendship.

The next day, he went to Katsuki's office and told him everything. He poured his heart out, telling Katsuki how much he admired him and how he had been struggling with his feelings.

To his surprise, Katsuki listened quietly, his expression unreadable. When Izuku finished, he didn't say anything for a long time.

Finally, he spoke. "Izuku, I had no idea," he said softly. "I'm sorry if I ever made you feel like you couldn't talk to me about this. But...I don't feel the same way."

Izuku's heart sank, but he tried not to show it. "I understand," he said, his voice barely above a whisper.

Katsuki reached out and took his hand. "But that doesn't mean we can't still be friends," he said.

Izuku tried his best to put on a brave face and be there for Katsuki as his friend, but it was hard. Every time he saw Katsuki with the new sidekick, his heart ached with jealousy and longing.

Eventually, Izuku couldn't take it anymore. He knew he needed to leave the agency and get some distance from Katsuki and his new relationship. It was too painful to be around him every day, pretending that everything was okay.

So Izuku quit his job and stayed home for days, crying himself to sleep every night. He couldn't believe how much he had let his feelings for Katsuki consume him, how he had embarrassed himself in front of everyone at the party.

It was during one of his walks in the park that he met Monoma Neito, a former classmate from Class 1-B at UA. Izuku had always thought of Monoma as a bit of a troublemaker, but he was surprised to find that they actually had a lot in common.

They talked for hours, sharing their experiences as young heroes and their struggles with relationships. Monoma was surprisingly understanding, even when Izuku confided in him about his feelings for Katsuki.

"I know it's hard," Monoma said, putting a comforting hand on Izuku's shoulder. "But sometimes, you have to let go of the things that are hurting you. It's the only way to move on."

Izuku nodded, his eyes misty with tears. He knew that Monoma was right. He couldn't keep holding on to his feelings for Katsuki, no matter how much it hurt.

Monoma Neito watched as Izuku walked away, his heart heavy with sympathy. He knew what it was like to be in love with someone who didn't love you back. He had been there himself, more times than he cared to admit.

But there was something about Izuku that made him want to help, to ease his pain. Maybe it was the way he talked about Katsuki, the raw emotion in his voice that betrayed just how much he cared.

Monoma knew that he couldn't make Izuku's feelings go away, but he could be there for him. He could listen, offer advice, and be a shoulder to cry on when things got tough.

And so they met up again, sharing stories and laughter and sometimes tears. Monoma was surprised at how much he enjoyed Izuku's company, how easy it was to talk to him.

Over the next few weeks, Izuku tried his best to put Monoma's advice into practice. He started going out more, meeting new people, and focusing on his own goals as a hero.

And slowly, he began to feel better. He still thought of Katsuki often, but the pain wasn't as acute as it had been before. He was able to smile and laugh again, to enjoy the simple pleasures of life without feeling like his heart was breaking.

As the weeks went by, Monoma watched as Izuku started to heal. He still talked about Katsuki, but the pain was less raw, the longing less intense.

And then the news came. Katsuki had started dating the new sidekick, the same one who had tried to touch him inappropriately at the party.

It wasn't until much later that Izuku heard the news about Katsuki and the new sidekick. He had always suspected that there was something more than friendship between them, but it still hurt to know for sure.

Monoma saw the pain in Izuku's eyes, but he also saw something else. Resignation, maybe, or acceptance. It was as if Izuku had already known that this was going to happen, and he had already made peace with it.

They talked about it, of course. Monoma listened as Izuku poured out his heart, confessing his feelings for Katsuki and the pain of seeing him with someone else.

And through it all, Monoma was there. He didn't judge or belittle, didn't offer platitudes or false hope. He just listened, and when he spoke, it was with kindness and understanding.

Eventually, Izuku moved on. He started dating someone new, a fellow hero-in-training that he had met on the job. Monoma was happy for him, but he also felt a twinge of sadness.

He had enjoyed spending time with Izuku, had grown to care for him in a way that he hadn't expected. But he knew that their time together was coming to an end.

And so, when Izuku told him that he was leaving the city to pursue a new job in another part of the country, Monoma was sad but not surprised.

"I'll miss you," he said, his voice soft.
"I'll miss you too," Izuku replied, smiling through his tears. "But I won't forget you, Monoma. You've been a good friend to me."And with that, they said their goodbyes, promising to stay in touch. And for that, he was grateful. <<EOFANFIC>>

He thought that it was only his Hell Class that had problems with getting kidnapped all the time, they even had a tally board for how many times they’ve been kidnapped. But that apparently also applied to him, seeing as he was now sitting tied to a chair in a dark room.
 
“Well, well, well, Eraserhead.” He rolled his eyes as he saw a wanna be thug sitting in front of him. He was sitting as if he was a king, with his elbows on his knees as he leaned forward with a smirk. He wasn’t even wearing a mask because he was that confident, apparently.
 
Too bad that his Hell Class is probably already on their way to get him. They’ve never been able to sit still for too long when someone is missing.
 
“Can we hurry this up? My Hell Class is not to be trusted alone for too long.” Aizawa sighed and it threw the other off.
 
“Your… Hell Class?” He asked and Aizawa snorted as he locked eyes with the guy.
 
“They resort to Vigilantism if someone goes missing for more than three hours.” Aizawa responded, “They don’t trust adults much. Only a couple exceptions, and I’m one of them.”
 
“What… What will they do?” He sounded unsure now, a tell tale sign that someone is new to the profession of criminal activity. If he was actually any good at his job he would sound cocky or smug, maybe even disbelief. But not unsure. Uncertainty was a weakness in criminals, because once they begin to doubt, they’ve lost.
 
“Break out of UA… Track the tracker that’s most likely attached to me somewhere… break in, beat all up your guys, get to you, save me… and then be back in time for dinner as if nothing happened.” Aizawa explained, a smirk as he tilted his head slightly. “They are fiercely protective of what they consider their’s.”
 
“Well,” He was trying not to show his weakness but that was too late. “My men can handle anythi-” A shout cut the man off, the sounds of fighting commenced and Aizawa had to commend his Hell Classes ability to be sneaky when they absolutely wanted to.
 
“They are feral!”
 
“I think one bit me!”
 
“We’re sorry!”
 
“Please don’t kill me!”
 
“Someone fucking shoot them!”
 
“He bit me! Someone get him off!”
 
“I can’t move!”
 
“Why can’t I see my opponent!”
 
The face of the man sitting across from him dropped as his men were slowly taken out. And one by one, the shouts of alarm and fighting quieted down. Slowing to a stop until there was silence.
 
“I told you, my kids are very protective of what’s theirs.” Aizawa shrugged, “They will get detention, have to turn in an essay, but other than that they know I’m proud of them. Now turn around with your hands behind your back, or I will let the Head Problem Child kick your ass.”
 
Instead of listening, the man took a gun out and aimed it at Aizawa’s head. Aizawa only sighed as he shook his head.
 
“Problem Child.” Green lightning and the man was thrown across the room, the gun crushed and left on the ground in front of Aizawa. Bakugou and Todoroki walked into the room at a leisurely pace, completely unaffected by the shouts and cries of the man. Shinso was also with them, and he looked more amused than unaffected.
 
It was also the purple headed child that untied him as Bakugou and Todoroki watched Midoriya, and only when the cries turned silent did they step in. Bakugou to restrain Midoriya, and Todoroki to apprehend the thug.
 
• • • • • • • • • • •
 
“Hell Class.” Aizawa stared down each and everyone of his students. They were all shifting from foot to foot, heads bowed low. Even Shinso, who isn’t even supposed to be a part of his class yet, but that got expedited because Shinso joined his class in helping rescue him. His class would probably celebrate Mineta’s expulsion once he was done lecturing them.
 
“We know disobeying direct orders was wrong.” Midoriya chimed in before he could continue. “But we couldn’t just stand by and wait for our dad to come home.” They looked down, and there were tears in the child’s eyes. “I couldn’t handle it.”
 
“I know.” Aizawa sighed, and Midoriya glanced up slightly as his shoulders curled inwards slightly. Aizawa immediately had a fidget in his hands to pass to the green haired child. “Which is why, there will be essays on vigilantism, and why they are illegal and the normal punishments of vigilante actions. You all are also on house arrest and you have to be accompanied by a teacher if more than four of you leave campus.” He declared and the class took a breath of relief. It wasn’t as bad as he could do, they knew that and he knew that. But it would let them know that he doesn’t want them getting into trouble, and to get them to stop… as much as he could anyways.
 
“Shinso, you are also going to give me an essay on the effects of vigilantism on underground heroism and what the difference is.” The purple haired boy winced but nodded. “Now, all of you. Suicide Runs for today. Go.” The entire class turned and rushed off towards the track as Present Mic and Loud Cloud walked up behind him.
 
“Suicide Runs? On Top of essays? Going easy on them today?” Hizashi asked jokingly as Oboro watched sympathetically.
 
“They meant well, they know that and I know that. But their actions were dangerous, and could have gotten them hurt or killed. They know that.” Aizawa responded and Oboro snickered slightly, a glance told him that Midoriya had jumped over Bakugou to get past him on the track, and now they were racing around.
 
He was glad that they could have fun, even if they weren’t supposed to.
 
“50 on Midoriya winning the race.” Oboro announced and Aizawa snorted.
 
“Nah, 50 on Bakugou for sure.” Hizashi responded, and Aizawa sighed as he spotted Shinso running just a bit faster.
 
“50 on Shinso. Now let’s let them run themselves tired and review the footage later.”

A Boot to the Head

The six that are sitting are Kaoruko Awata, Juzo Maoshi, Mirio Togata, Toshinori Yagi, Eri and Izuku Midoriya.The people who are seated are saddened about this it had been a month since Mirai Sasaki AKA Sir Nighteye had passed away and now they are here for the reading of his will.The Executor of the Will who goes only goes by Kabuto looks at everyone and begins to speak."Alright as the executor of Mr. Sasaki's estate, I have been empowered to read Mr. Sasaki's Last Will and Testament." Kabuto said."Well I'm only here to support everyone." Izuku said"Oh, poor, dear Mirai! Waaaa!" Kaoruko said as she cried."Oh, there, there, Kao-chan." Juzo said as wiped a tear from his eye."God, how the world is predictably boring without you Mirai." Toshinori said."I never worked for a kinder man." Mirio said."If we are all seated, I shall proceed with the reading." Kabuto said."I knew it." Toshinori said with a chuckle."I, Mirai Sasaki, being of sound mind and body do hereby divide up my considerable estate as follows. To my overly emotional sidekick, Kaoruko..." Kabuto"Waaaa!" Kaoruko cried."Kao-Chan, darling, he's talking about us." Juzo said."Oh sorry about that." Kaoruko said as blushed while she rubbed the back of her head."...who grubbed with her boyfriend, Juzo yes I know about your relationship, grubbed for everything they could get from me, and then cried crocodile tears when I needed sympathy...""Hold up. What?" Kaoruko said."...To Kaoruko, I leave a boot to the head.""Hold up a what?" Kaoruko said as Kabuto as a boot flies towards Kaoruko head.*BONK!*"Ow!" Kaoruko shouted as she fell down."Kao-Chan, are you okay?!" Juzo asked as Kaoruko was getting up."...and another boot to her boyfriend, Juzo." Kabuto said.*BONK!*"Ow!" Juzo said as he is hit by another boot and fell down."Hahahahaha." Eri laughed a bit.Kaoruko growled."This is an outrage!" Kaoruko shouted."...ah, but still, you are my sidekick, you have both admired my Rolls Royce, and since I no longer need it..." Kabuto said"Hold up Mirai owned a Rolls Royce?!" Toshinori said."What the hell?" Juzo said."Wha?" Kaoruko said,"...I bequeath another boot to the head." Kabuto said."What?" Kaoruko said as another boot flew to her head.*BONK!*"Ow FUCK!" Kaoruko said as she fell down again."And one more for the wimp." Kabuto said."Ah shit." Juzo said.*BONK!*"Ow!" Juzo said as he fell down again."Next, to my blubbering intern Izuku..." Kabuto said"Hey wait, I don't want no boot to the head!" Izuku said."...to dear Izuku, who has showed me that faith isn't absolute..." Kabuto said."I'm coverin' up my head!" Izuku said as he covered his head."...I not only leave my All Might Collection and but also the wine cellar I own and three crates of my finest whiskey." Kabuto said."Really?" Izuku said as he is both surprised at the All Might collection and the copious amount of Alcohol."And a boot to the head." Kabuto said.*BONK!*"OH!" Izuku said as a Boot hits him in the head."And another for Kaoruko and the Boyfriend." Kabuto said.*BONK!* *BONK!*As both Juzo and Kaoruko were hit by more boots."Next, to my stubborn friend, Toshinori..." Kabuto said."This is so predictable let me guess a boot to the Head." Toshinori said."...Provided by Gran Torino." Kabuto said."WAIT WHAT!" Toshinori said as he was dropped kicked by Gran Torino.*BONK!*"Uh! God damn it!" Toshinori said."Ha take that welp." Gran Torino said."And one for Kaoruko and the Juzo."*BONK!* *BONK!*"Ah, OH!" The both of them said as more boots were thrown at them."This takes care of the unimportant obligations. And now, on to the ones effected by the raid to Mirio..." Kabuto said."Oh, uh, I don't want nothin'." Mirio said as he didn't want a boot to the head."...who took care of me faithfully these last few years, who cared, made me laugh, brought me tea..." Kabuto said."Oh Sir, I didn't mind that at all." Mirio said."To Mirio Togata, I bequeath a boot to the head." Kabuto said.*BONK!*"OH COME ON ME TOO!" Mirio shouted"And one for Kaoruko and the Juzo." Kabuto said as more boots flew towards Kaoruko and Juzo.*BONK!* *BONK!*"AH GOD DAMMIT!" Kaoruko said."OH FOR FUCKS SAKE!" Juzo said."And so, to the little Eri, I leave my entire vast...boot to the head!" Kabuto said as a giant plush boot landed on Eri's head."Huh it didn't hurt." Eri said as she hugged her giant boot plushy."What did you I would actutally hit her head with a real boot?" Kabuto asked.Everyone mumbled at that.Kabuto's eyebrow twitched."Just for that you get boots to the head." Kabuto said as everyone save Eri received a boot to the head.Kabuto took a look only to frown."Sometimes I really hate my Quirk. And finally, to my lawyer, who has helped me on this will, I leave not a boot to the head...but a rabid Tasmanian devil, to be placed in his trousers?!" Kabuto said as he begins to feel said Tasmanian Devil in his pants.The group watches in horror as he suffers for a bit."Ooohhh! Kabuto said as his breathing begins to normalize."Ah is that it?" Juzo asked."That's it?" Toshinori said"I'd complain but I have Mirai's All Might collection along with wine and whisky." His eyes widened at the realization that this was the end of him. The world went blurry. There was no clear picture, just a dull pain in his chest. But what exactly hurt was hard to tell. "yeah, and how could I do that? After all, I'm not a doctor to diagnose myself " Izuku thought grimly, and sat down on the cold and dark sidewalk of the alley, placing his yellow backpack beside him. The black uniform served as a sort of camouflage amidst the pile of garbage bags. Sitting in silence, he prayed and hoped his heavy breathing wouldn't give him away. Tears dripped from eyes, but the silence was beyond my senses. Something rustled in the corner, causing Izuku to turn his head sharply in fear. But a rat popped out of the far corner and immediately disappeared into the far corner of the alley, leaving him alone. And it seems that for the rest of his life, he will be as startled by loud noises as he is by complete silence."That useless Deku, he couldn't have gotten far " I leaned against the wall, chasing away my tears, listening for the distant footsteps. My instincts screamed that it was time to run to a place where I couldn't be reached, where no one would care about me. Or find a place I could call home. "We've got his damn house keys, so he couldn't have gotten far without taking them. Yeah, and we beat him bad, didn't we?"For the first time in months he felt like laughing, "Kachan, don't you think I have a duplicate key?" - Izuku snorted to himself: "I'm useless, but I'm not stupid," but that was impossible to say now. The image of his mother and her tight embrace flashed through his mind. She had been working harder and harder in recent months. Part of me understood that she was rightly angry because I would never be an ordinary person. Everything is always more expensive for him. Even the shoes are different for Quirkless. Everything is more expensive for him. And she's trying to provide for him. Mentally, I understood that this did not justify the fact that she raised her hand insulted, reminded me how useless I was. But at the same time, I knew I couldn't hate her. There was as much bad in her as there was good. And this uncertainty was unnerving, forcing the already injured stomach from lack of food to contract twice as much."Hey Bakugo, I think I found something!" Shit. Leaning with one hand against the wall, it took all of Midoriya's willpower to get into a stable position. It was impossible to postpone it. Grabbing his backpack with his other hand, wincing at the sharp pain, he lowered the wall. He sighed and abruptly ran through the Khrushchev district on the left side of the city. It was an unsafe path to his place of residence, but he had no choice. There was silence behind him. The element of surprise was the best thing he had to learn. He wanted to stop and look at their faces. But in this case, the pain was inevitable. Less than a minute later, shouts were heard behind them. They were wrong when they said they had rubbed it enough. Yes, it hurt, but as long as his legs could carry him, it didn't matter. Just nonsense that he brushed off. It was normal for him.There was nothing special in their apartment next door to Mustafa. Their neighborhood was cheap, which only meant that it was better not to go out at night. Even if the heroes patrolled this place, they could not always come to the rescue. That's what he learned. Going up to the apartment and pulling out the spare keys from under the carpet of the neighbors, Izuku opened the door of his house. It was quiet here. The knife on the countertop glittered as a reminder of the terrible. Looking at him with his empty eyes, he doesn't know what to do. "Mom is alive. She'll be home soon," Izuku sighs. But as for evil, the body he buried that day in the backyard pops up in his head. Everything was out of order.
 "Two months ago, everything was fine. Out of habit, Mom apologized for his uselessness. And again he came back with bruises all over his body. She cooked food, smiled stupidly at him, slowly treated wounds and threw spider lilies out of his briefcase as if it cost nothing. But he saw the look on her face every time she tried to be an example. She couldn't handle it. It was over before it even started. The next day the house was unusually quiet. Kacchan was mocking again, but there was something familiar about it. Not ordinary, but quite routine. Coming out of his reverie and reflections, taking off his red shoes and heading to the kitchen, he noticed a body lying on the sofa. There was a bottle of alcohol naphtha on the table, and the tension settled firmly in Izuku's body. 

"Mom?" The mumbling in the room stopped, and her gaze turned to the boy who didn't know where to look. 

The mother's eyes, usually green, were clouded. Her gaze was wild. Midoriya watched as she slowly stood up, not letting him out of her sight. She slowly approached him. He could smell her perfume, which smelled of spices mixed with smoke. The pupils of her eyes were dilated and even her ragged breathing was frightening. He knew what to expect, but he wasn't ready for it. But was it just his fault? No. No one will ever be ready for violence. Inko's hand seemed to pass him by, and it was only at that moment that he realized what she was going to do. It was already late. Her slender hand grabbed the bottle and hit herself on the head with all her might, forcing Izuku to look at her. Shards scattered across the floor, and some of them fell on the countertop nearby.

 "Izuku, my baby. Your mom is a little sick, do you understand?" the answer was silence. - I'm so tired of you. Provide, work. Everyone says I shouldn't give up, but I can't. People stopped talking to me and it's all because of you, damn it. Please kill me, please kill me..." Midoriya recoiled from her and leaned against the table. 

He was scared. Tears were streaming down his face. Each of them was metal slowly covering his heart. 

"M-Mom, let's go. You have to get up early tomorrow. You need to sleep it off," he began to mutter. It was the first time.

 "I'm sorry. I can't, take this," her hands handed him the broken bottle. "Son, help Mom. Please, I'm begging you, help me," she began to rave, burying her fingers in her hair, trying to pull them out. It was disgusting to watch. His stomach couldn't take it anymore, and he quickly crossed the kitchen. His entire breakfast ended up in the sink. There was an unpleasant taste of bile and toast with jam in his mouth. Therefore, turning on the sink and taking out a glass, Izuku rinsed his mouth, spitting out water.

 "I can't believe how bad I am. Don't, I'm sorry about that, son. I never wanted this for you." A bitter smile touched her lips, and it was the only thing he had time to see before a knife flashed in her hands, cutting her throat. He froze. For the first time in his life, he realized that he couldn't move. when it was necessary. He didn't save his man in time. The mug fell out of his hands and broke into a thousand pieces, just like his soul in this kitchen. It was his fault. He saw how she was suffering, but he still looked away. It didn't save me. This feeling of despair convinced the brain that she was alive and that everything was really good."
 My stomach twisted, and bile rose to my throat again. The kitchen smelled rotten. I took a deep breath, and I didn't understand how I managed to live up to this day.

Chapter Text

“What are your thoughts on power?” A female voice echoed in the dark back alley. A schoolgirl with short white hair who donned a black-red sailor uniform sat on the back of a bleeding man with gray scales who was sprawled on the floor. The only attempts to hide her face were a black face mask and black colored contacts.
 

“P-Please don’t kill me...!” The hulking, injured man begged the schoolgirl whose height reached his neck at best.
 

The schoolgirl plastered a frown at his response but expected it. She ignored his pleading and continued her speech, “I believe power spans across many things you know. Today it is associated with strength and influence within this society.”
 

The injured man was breathing heavily as he bled out on the floor.
 

She twirled a bloody butterfly knife with colors matching the night sky around her fingers. “But, you know, power is so much more.” Her face was consistently deadpan throughout the entire conversation. “Skill is a form of power. Manipulation is a form of power. Scheming is a form of power, isn’t it? Power is defined at the ability to do something.”
 

The injured man was beginning to lose consciousness, but a swift slash to the knee and stinging pain put his brain back into full activation. He quickly responded to his attacker realizing she was asking a question. “Y-Yes!”
 

The schoolgirl, still sat on his back, put on a faux smile and looked down to the side of his head. “I knew you’d agree with me. You see, this society places too much emphasis on the power of quirks.” She shrugged her shoulders. “I know, I know, I’m such a hypocrite. But you see, even though I have a powerful quirk I never stopped gaining power in different forms. You saw my knife play right? I used ze-ro quirks to subdue you. 
 

The injured man tried to nod his head to please his attacker only to groan in pain.
 

The schoolgirl hummed. “Hm... You know I purposefully seek-ed you out. You know? No?”
 

Her statement at once caught his attention, for what purpose would someone look for him? “w-Why?” He said, it was risky to ask a question in such a one-sided conversation, but he was too interested to know. Even if he was currently bleeding out on the ground because of the schoolgirl’s said interest.
 

The schoolgirl folded the bloody butterfly knife and threw her head back. She sighed before resting her cheek on her fist. “Well, my... 

benefactor

 believes your quirk has lots of use for us, use for her organization. I don’t really agree with her, to me you’re just another common thug mugging weaklings for money.” She sighed. “That quirk of yours would be useful for some of our operations, I guess? The way you snuck up on me with it almost made think of you as a villain instead of a common thug.”
 

The injured man looked at the schoolgirl with incredulity. “I-Is that an offer!?” He would probably take it anyways if it meant he could live. Though he hoped that when he did, he wouldn’t just sign up for a secret organization with crimes of human experimentation.
 

He wanted to live even if his life hadn’t been the most glamorous. With the bills piling on him and people’s outlooks on those with mutant quirks, he became a small-time villain mugging people for their money. He was never caught by pro-heroes because of his ability to vanish and his careful picking of location. Muggings also weren’t exactly the most high-profile of cases.
 

It was supposed to be another mugging, a naïve schoolgirl who didn’t know the bleakness of the world wandering the back alleys. He had never seen such an easy picking. It was supposed to be an easy picking, but now here he was bleeding on the ground as she sat on him making him an offer to join some organization.
 

The schoolgirls stared at him—watching him like a hawk with those black(?) eyes—her gaze boring a hole into his soul. She spoke to him in a cold tone, “Offer? Maybe? But if you don’t accept, you’ll be leaving this alley with consequences.” His body shuddered. “Don’t worry. If you do accept, we’ll make sure to give you accommodation. Don’t you want to make a change? Become powerful and revile back to the people who reviled you? My benefactor can make sure of that if you’re willing to put in the work.” 
 

Her words resonated with him; it sounded like something he could only do in his dreams. He suddenly forgot about his earlier fear and asked, “how can I trust you?”
 

He could see a smirk behind that mask of hers, it looked fake, but it was a smirk, nonetheless. She hopped off his body and walked ahead for a bit before making a 180 turn to face him. “Well... if it’s about power aren’t I enough proof?” He looked confused at her statement. She placed a hand on her hip in response. “Please. A young, small girl probably half your age put you into this state without using a quirk once.”
 

Well, that was a good point. He was going to accept her offer either way, it was that or leaving this back alley facing whatever consequences this schoolgirl had planned.
 

He shuffled from his sprawled position and turned his body to face the stary, night sky. He held his hand up and said, “Alright. I’ll... join this organization. But if you can’t back those words up, I’ll make sure you regret ever meeting me!” He tried to intimidate her in the end, but it of course fell flat.
 

The schoolgirl walked over to him and pulled him up with his outstretched hand. “I’m quite confident that she can make you powerful.” 
 

She tossed a burner phone at him. “You’ll get a call maybe... this week?” She walked away until she got far enough where he couldn’t hear her anymore, she muttered under her breath, “Just a few more pawns for my plan. Then the rest of my days will be fun, fun, fun."

Staring at the paper as if it held the answer to life, Aizawa furrowed his brow. Earlier that week, he'd assigned an analysis task to his students. He should have known from the look of pure, unadulterated joy on Midoriya’s face that he'd fucked up, but hindsight is twenty twenty. Currently attempting to burn holes in the fucking essay he'd gotten in response, he felt a plethora of questions bubbling up. From simply flicking through the pages he could tell Midoriya was a prodigy at analysis, but then why couldn't he control his own quirk? "Hizashi?" He called over his shoulder, instinctively ignoring the scattered meows of his cats' attempts to respond. "Yeah? What's up?" The hero poked his head around the door frame that led to his room. "Do you ever wonder why Our Resident Problem Child can totally disassemble everyone's quirk but his own?"  Hizashi let out a soft sigh, "Why don't you ask him about it? I mean, what's the worst that could happen?"  "Probably quite a lot, considering you've just tempted fate." Aizawa grumbled, graciously accepting the apology kiss his husband placed on his forehead. "Hey," Hizashi gently rubbed his shoulders in a calming manner, "It's going to be alright, okay? Just make sure he knows you're there for him."  He flashed his fellow teacher a smile. "You're a great teacher, Shouta, you've got this."    Aizawa was not a great teacher and he did, in fact, not 'got this'. "Midoriya-San, wait!" He called after his student, who had straight up fucking booked it the second he'd mentioned his quirk. He watched helplessly as the teenager disappeared around the corner, far from willing to chase after the clearly distressed boy. "Well, fuck." He hissed.  At least he could ask again after the next lesson. Sighing deeply, he slowly shuffled to the staff room in defeat. Thankfully, his husband was there. "Hizashi, he ran away." He dragged out the man's name as he spoke, shoving his face into the hero's shoulder. "Aw, I'm sorry Shouta. Maybe after next lesson? And if that fails, I'd ask All Might. The kid tells him everything." Aizawa pondered for a moment. "Sounds like a plan." Hizashi smiled widely, and gave his husband a reassuring kiss.    "Midoriya-San, please stay behind after class." He addressed the student, resisting the urge to roll his eyes at the 'Ooohhhh.' Sound the class gave; practically a teenage ritual. "You're not in trouble." He added on after seeing his face pale concerningly quickly. The boy still looked mere seconds from keeling over dramatically, but he nodded anyway. As the rest of the class filtered out, several of them offered the teenager apologetic looks as they left. Midoriya gulped as he was left alone with the teacher, hesitantly stepping closer and successfully looking as if he would rather be stabbed than continue to exist in the presence of the hero. "Midoriya-San, as I mentioned before, I'm curious about your quirk." The greenette somehow paled more, and Aizawa rushed to continue before he could plot his escape, "And I was wondering why you can't analyse it like you do others." Attempting to manifest a shape-shifting quirk, turn into a turtle, retreat into his shell and roll away from the conversation, Midoriya stared at the floor silently. "Would it make you more comfortable if All Might was here?"  The teenager shrugged non-committally. "Do you want to take a seat?" Midoriya slowly dragged a chair to himself, sitting down reluctantly. "I was looking over your homework yesterday," The teacher turned around to pick up the aforementioned work, but when he went to face the boy again, he was gone. Aizawa blinked, and it took him a second to notice that a previously closed window had been opened. The man sighed tiredly, gently moving the chair back to where it had been taken from. He sent a hasty message to his husband to inform him that Midoriya had defenestrated himself and that he'd be going to All Might for help.   In his search for the number one hero, Aizawa learned several things. First was that for such a loud man, All Might could be surprisingly hard to find. Second was that a student had found one of Midoriya’s notebooks and in favour of returning it, had decided to treat it like a deity, presenting it with offerings just because it had quirk analysis of his entire class in it and was borderline stalking Midoriya. The third thing was that he had next to no sense of direction. It was a fucking miracle that he found All Might, and he treated it as such. Instead of barging into the room like he'd originally planned, he found himself with his ear to the door, listening to the man's conversation. "-Been asking me about my quirk, I don't know what to say!" Aizawa's eyes widened as he recognised his student's panicked voice. "It's alright, young Midoriya, he's just curious." "I know, but I think he's getting suspicious about why I run away whenever he mentions it." All Might laughed, a sound that tempted Aizawa to kick down the door just so it could strangle the man. "How am I supposed to tell him I can't analyse my quirk, I can't write down anything about it because it's a fucking national secret?!" Midoriya’s voice broke. Aizawa had to count to ten, just so he wouldn't let out an impressive plethora of profanities. "It's alright, Young Midoriya. Would you like my advice, or to just talk to me?" The hero heard Midoriya sniffle, considering his options. "C-could I have your advice, please?" It took all of the teacher's self control not to cry at how weak his student's voice was. "Of course. I think you should tell him. I know you don't have good experiences with teachers, but Eraserhead," All Might stopped, searching for the right words. "Eraserhead is most certainly trustworthy, and an amazing hero. I have no doubt that the reason he's asking you about your quirk, because it is your quirk now, is because he cares about you." Well shit, Aizawa felt like a massive dick now. "O-okay. I'll tell him when we have time." Aizawa stepped away from the door as he heard the greenette stand up. "Midoriya," All Might called, stopping the boy in his tracks and giving the hero enough time to tactically retreat. "I'm really proud of you, okay? Ah! No, please don't cry!" The man's panicked voice was almost enough to make Aizawa laugh. Almost. (If anyone asked him why he was frantically googling adoption papers, he'd hiss at them. They didn't need to know he was going to fight for custody of Midoriya against the number one hero, it was none of their fucking business.)

completion: Izuku stares. The ground is so far away, exactly how he wants it. All his problems would be over—no more pain, no more uncertainty, no more yearning—just peace.People would wonder why. Izuku has everything; he’s going to U.A., he has many friends, he has a good quirk. How many would kill to be in his situation? The only one who really gets it is Aizawa. He tries. He really does. But it isn’t enough. Izuku is simply too broken and Aizawa too inexperienced. The older man has seen all of Izuku’s pain and suffering, has been there when Izuku bared his soul in its entirety for the first time ever, and it still isn’t enough. What did that mean? It isn’t Aizawa’s fault, clearly. Izuku would be crushed if Aizawa blamed himself, then whose fault is it? He’s always wanted to be a hero. And now that he was mere months away from graduating U.A., he simply couldn’t bear it anymore. Enough is enough. He has tried his best. Tried his best to mend the broken pieces that are his existence. Maybe if he had done this years ago when his trauma first formed, he wouldn’t be in his predicament, but he had been too preoccupied and young to bother with his mental health. He still had hope then. Hope for the future. Hope for himself. Hope for the world. It was brighter, then.Not anymore, though. Now all he sees is darkness and all he can feel is the cold. Not even the smiles and endless cheer of his friends is enough to reintroduce warmth back into his life. The only that ever helped, albeit temporarily and minuscule, is Aizawa’s occasional attention. He has honestly thought that his childhood issues with his dad leaving him had been resolved years ago, but after experiencing a little bit of care from Aizawa, left him yearning and more aware of the gaping hole in his heart more than ever. No matter how much Aizawa tries though, it isn’t enough. He is too busy, has two demanding jobs, and is already sleep deprived as it is. There is only so much time and energy Izuku can receive, and he didn’t dare ask for more. Aizawa doesn’t owe him anything. He isn’t Izuku’s dad, no matter how much he wants him to be. He isn’t even family, just a teacher who cares more than he has to and more than he should. That’s what hurts the most. Izuku’s mom tries her best as well and he knows she’ll always be there for her when he needs it, but it isn’t what he needs. There is no way Izuku could ever burden her with his pain and suffering. She is already anxious enough as it is, and knowing his troubles would only stress her out more. That’s why he’d found so much solace in Aizawa. There is simply something dependable and trustworthy about him, perhaps due to him being older and his wealth of experience with suffering and anguish. Izuku could be himself when he’s with Aizawa. He could shed his smile and just sob like he does on his own time, releasing every bit of past traumas and pain onto his rock. Aizawa would listen without judgment, offering some comments and validation in between each gap in Izuku’s cries, and he’d hang onto those softly spoken words like a lifeline. It isn’t so often that they’d have one of these sessions, but Izuku treasured them more than anything.No matter how kind and gentle Aizawa is during moments, however, Izuku couldn’t help but crave for more. For touch, for Aizawa to take the pain away, for…he isn’t sure, but something more. It just isn’t enough. It never is, and the longing is killing him from the inside out. There is just no one other than him Izuku could rely on for support like that. Not his mom, not his friends, not strangers on the street. As a hero in training, he couldn’t show much weakness, even if it’s the only thing he has left. What’s he to do in a situation like this? What else is there left for him to do? He knows what he needs—Aizawa—but he also knows it’s not for him to have. The pain grows stronger day by day, threatening to bubble over. He feels himself wanting to cry in the middle of class for no reason. He cries the first seconds he wakes. He cries in the shower, when he’s working out, when he does homework. How much more can this go on before he collapses?As he sat, legs hanging off the cold metal railing, he slowly comes to terms with his life. To think that he’d be in this predicament years after Kacchan told him to kill himself--what would he say? Perhaps he had been right. If he’d killed himself then, there would be no one lamenting his missed potential and how much he had to live for. There’d only be a small headline, if any, about a worthless quirkless kid jumping off a roof. He wouldn’t be hurting his new friends, or Aizawa, who had tried the best he could offer.It’s okay, though. Better late than never. They’d cry for him for a few days, and it too, will pass. Life will go on. They’d become great heroes without him, the best, even, and Izuku wishes them the best.  The wind is picking up a little. Izuku shivers, and huddles into his jacket. Leaving on a cold day like this; it is fitting. It is also fitting that it’s April fools. A joke, for the life that he’s had. He sighs and glances at the ground below him once more. It is strangely peaceful and quiet, with the loudest sound being Izuku’s incessant thoughts. Would he be free from that, when he goes? No more thoughts. No more Izuku. Just darkness, forever.The thought doesn’t scare him as much as it did before. Instead, the dark seems welcoming now, and he longs to be in its embrace. He is ready to be taken. Everything else has just been a distraction.  He smiles weakly. Sorry. He is truly sorry. Sorry to his mom. Sorry to his friends. And mostly, sorry to Aizawa. Aizawa would be hurt for sure, but he would move on. He has seen much pain in his career that he must be numb to it now. Still, Izuku would be a failure to him, a student that he couldn’t save despite his best efforts. Or maybe he could’ve, if he had tried harder, but Izuku can’t blame him. He has already gone above and beyond for a teacher. For someone as broken as him, though, it is never enough. It hurts. It hurts more than when he broke his arms and all his fingers during the sports festival. At least then, the pain could be seen, could be healed easily, but what about now? The only one who’s ever seen his pain is Aizawa, and even then, it hadn’t been important enough to prioritise, not in the same way that a broken arm would be. He wants to scream. Wants people to see. Wants his pain to end. He doesn’t want to die. Not really. He regrets ever trying. Trying, trying, trying. All he did in life is try. Try to reach out when he’d depressed. Try to hang out with friends and pretend to be happy in the hopes that it would actually make him happy. Try to act like someone he’s not to be accepted. He can’t anymore. He just can’t. The idea of having to go another day, pretending to be his usual, energetic self makes him want to throw up. Would it be so bad if he doesn’t want to try anymore? If he simply stops?He’s tired. He’s so, so tired. Tired of reaching out and getting nothing in return. Of reaching out and getting hurt, over and over again. It only helps a little, each time. Soothes the pain enough for him to go on another day, but then they leave, and Izuku’s alone again. Alone with his noisy thoughts and urge to end it all. For each failed attempt, he becomes a little more jaded. A little more tired. Sinks a little more into a pit of despair, until there is nowhere left to sink into. His smile fades and he slumps. Who is he pretending for, again? There is nothing here to see his tears except for the cold stars blinking down at him. It offers little comfort, knowing that they’ll still be shining long after he’s gone.If Aizawa really cares, he’d be here to physically peel him off the railing. Izuku would let him. Izuku would tell him anything he asks. Izuku would let him help, with his clumsy yet effective words. But he isn’t, and never will be. Does Aizawa have any idea how much his presence helps? He must, for Izuku has never been good at hiding his emotions, and Aizawa is more perceptive than anyone he knows. If he knows, then why doesn’t he try more? Why doesn’t he give Izuku more of his time? Izuku knows it’s not his to demand, but he still wants it. Wants it more than anything. Is he waiting for him? Izuku still hasn’t jumped yet. Maybe the part of him that wants to survive is stalling for his savior to come; waiting hopefully for the comfort and sheer joy of knowing that someone cares that would inevitably come with it. Yet it never comes, and he feels his heart grow colder every second that he’s not there. It’s futile, he knows, just like the other hundreds of times he has wished for Aizawa to show up in his room after a particular nightmare to offer him peace with just his presence. Or when he’d purposely walk around his office after class hoping that he’d be there, just so they could have a short chat. Again, Izuku doesn’t blame him. He just wishes, and he yearns, and he longs. And that hurts more than anything else. For a second, he let himself imagine. He could almost hear the click of the door to the roof opening. He hears the shout of alarm coming from behind him, his name echoing in the open sky... It is peaceful. He falls. <<EOFANFIC>>
