completion: He remembers the day they first met, clearer than daylight.How could he not?He didn’t have the most approachable appearance for quite a while now. Covered in burns from head to toe, his skin looking almost dead on certain spots. A price he has gotten used to paying for using his quirk too much.His clothes looked rather shabby as well. Dirty shoes, a pair of jeans he ripped a while back running away from a group of heroes. His shirt wasn’t in a much better shape either. Really, even he thought he looked like some feral run-away.That, paired with the fresh blood splattered on his clothes and with the distinct smell of burned meat, he really wasn’t someone to whom people would just walk up.And yet…It was rather late into the night, and he was walking back to his little hide out.At first, he only heard some whispered yelling from a dark alley. It wasn’t really out of the ordinary. Nothing he would have normally not ignored had he not heard a loud slap followed by what suspiciously sounded like a child’s cry.The alley was narrow with barely any light filtering in from the streetlamps, making it rather hard to see anything really. It was quite the challenge, avoiding any and all things that could alert the others of their audience prematurely. But he was getting closer and even thought he couldn’t yet make out just how many people were there, he was now able to make out what they were saying.“You sure about this man?” called one. A croaky voice but female.The question was followed by a hissed, “How many times do I have to tell you to stay quiet?”“I’m sorry, I just-” came from the woman now in a hushed tone, “This kid doesn’t look like he’s worth much. I mean, look at him, he’s so–”“Ratty?” interrupted a low voice of a man. “Well yes.”He was now close enough to see what was going on.Three adults, a woman and two men, towering over the quivering bundle of a child. One of the men crouched down and grabbed the kid by his chin, with fresh tears cascading down on bony cheeks.“He is a scrawny and dirty little street kid, but look at this face.” the deep voiced man yanked the child slightly upwards, so his fellows could see him better. “Give the brat a bath and feed him for a month or two… He’ll be a rather cute fellow, I say. Gonna bring in some pretty pennies for us.”He had heard enough.With a couple of strides he grabbed the other man from behind, hand already covered in blazing blue fire, setting the tall and bony man aflame in an instant, melting the flesh off of his bones almost immediately.The woman let out a deafening screech, the other man dropping the small boy in interest of punching him in the chest with enough force that his body slammed into the wall.“And what do we have here?” rumbled the man, and with three big steps he was in front of the teenager.Hands filled with tiny sparks promising a painful death immediately flew upwards, but the man was faster, and he found himself crashing into a wall again and hitting the ground right beside the child.Turquoise met emerald, and before he could have been hit with another one of those bone shattering punches the teen lurched forward grabbing the child and twisting and suddenly the dark alley burst into a brilliant blue.The teenager dashed out onto the street running with full power towards what he hopes is safety before anyone could come out and see what the commission is about, child still under his arm.He was several streets away and completely out of breath when he finally put the kid down.Taking the moment to just look at the kid, he saw the greenest eyes he has ever seen. White streaks in his curly hair with a similarly green shade, if maybe a bit darker, making his freckled and tear stained face seem almost sickly pale.He wasn’t crying anymore. completion:
Emi Fukukado, better known for her pro hero name, Ms. Joke, couldn't believe her luck when Shota Aizawa, the stoic and reserved hero widely known as Eraserhead, had agreed to share a hotel room with her during their recent mission. She had always harbored secret feelings for him, but never dared to act on them.Despite her bubbly personality and love of making people laugh, she had never been able to find someone who truly understood her. Until she met Aizawa a long time ago.  There was something about him that drew her in, even though he was always so reserved around her in public. She could tell he was a deeply private person, and respected that about him. But there were moments when he let his guard down, moments when she caught a glimpse of the person he was when he wasn't being a hero. And it was those moments that made her heart race and her pulse quicken.  And now, as she lay beside him in the hotel room, she couldn't help but feel a sense of awe and wonder. They had come so far since that night in the alleyway, and yet it felt like they had only just begun. As Emi lay there, watching Aizawa sleep, she couldn't help but smile. It was rare to see him so relaxed and peaceful, without the weight of the world on his shoulders. She knew that being a hero was a tough job, one that required sacrifice and determination. But seeing him like this, vulnerable and at ease, made her heart swell with affection. She reached out to brush a stray lock of hair away from his forehead, marveling at the softness of his skin. It was a simple gesture, but it felt intimate and meaningful. She had never been this close to him before, both physically and emotionally. Emi had always been drawn to Aizawa, ever since the first time they had met. She had been performing at a comedy club late one night, and had stepped outside for some fresh air when she saw him in a deserted alleyway. He was using his capture scarf to erase graffiti from the walls, and there was something about the way he moved that caught her eye. At first, she had been startled by his presence. But then, she had watched him for a while, admiring the way he was so completely in control of his quirk. He was focused and determined, and she could see that he was taking pride in his work. She had always been attracted to people who were passionate about what they did, and Aizawa was no exception. When he had finally turned to look at her, she had been struck by the intensity of his gaze. It was like he could see right through her, and for a moment, she had felt exposed. But then he had simply nodded in acknowledgement, and had gone back to his work. It had been a simple interaction, but it had stayed with her ever since. Over the years, Emi and Aizawa had crossed paths numerous times, both as fellow heroes and as acquaintances in the same social circles. But it wasn't until recently that they had started to grow closer. They had been on a mission together, and had ended up sharing a hotel room due to a mix-up with the reservations. It had been awkward at first, but they had gradually started to open up to each other, sharing stories and secrets that they had never told anyone else. And now, as she lay there beside him, Emi couldn't help but feel like they were on the cusp of something more. She had always been hesitant to act on her feelings for Aizawa, afraid that it would ruin their friendship or make things awkward between them. But now, with him lying there beside her, looking so peaceful and content, she couldn't help but wonder if maybe he felt the same way. As she leaned in to brush another stray hair away from his face, she hesitated for a moment. She could feel her heart racing, and her breath catching in her throat. She wanted to wake him with a kiss, to let him know how she felt. But she was afraid of what might happen if she did. Just as she was about to pull away, Aizawa's eyes fluttered open. He looked up at her, his expression sleepy and content. And then he smiled. "Well, if you won't do it, I will," he said, before leaning in to press his lips to hers. Emi was surprised, but pleasantly so. She had never expected Aizawa to be so forward, but she found herself responding eagerly to his kiss. It was gentle at first, almost hesitant, but then it deepened, and she could feel the warmth spreading through her body. As they pulled away from each other, Emi could see the same sense of wonder and affection in Aizawa's eyes that she felt in her heart. For a moment, they simply gazed at each other, silently communicating all the things they couldn't put into words. Finally, Aizawa cleared his throat and sat up, running a hand through his disheveled hair.  "Well," he said, his voice low and husky, "that was unexpected." Emi giggled, feeling a rush of nervous energy. "Yeah, it was," she said, sitting up as well. "But it felt right, you know?" Aizawa nodded, a small smile playing at the corners of his lips. "I do know," he said. "I've felt that way about you for a long time, Emi." Emi's heart skipped a beat at his words. She had always suspected that he had feelings for her, but hearing him say it out loud was another thing entirely. "Really?" she said, her voice barely above a whisper. Aizawa turned to look at her, his eyes softening. "Really," he said. "I know I'm not the most expressive person, but I hope you know how much you mean to me." Emi reached out to take his hand, feeling a sense of warmth spread through her chest. "I do," she said, squeezing his hand. "And I feel the same way about you." For a moment, they simply sat there, holding hands and smiling at each other. Then Aizawa cleared his throat again and stood up, stretching his arms above his head.  "Well," he said, his voice more business-like, "we should probably get ready for the day." Emi nodded, feeling a twinge of disappointment at the sudden change in mood. "Right," she said, standing up as well. "I'll take a quick shower and then we can grab breakfast." As she headed to the bathroom, Emi couldn't help but feel a sense of euphoria. She had finally admitted her feelings to Aizawa, and he had reciprocated them. It was a dream come true, one she never thought possible. As she stepped into the shower, she couldn't help but think back to all the moments they had shared together. She remembered how he would always watch out for her during their missions, even though she was more than capable of taking care of herself. She recalled how his eyes would flicker with amusement at her jokes, even when he was trying to maintain his stoic facade. But she also remembered the moments when he had let his guard down, when he had opened up to her in ways that he didn't with anyone else. Like the night he had shown her his favorite spot in the city, a quiet park where he liked to feed the stray cats. She had been touched by the tenderness with which he had treated the animals, and the way he had shared that part of himself with her. As she finished her shower and got dressed, Emi couldn't wait to see what the day would bring. She was excited to spend more time with Aizawa, to explore the city of Musutafu together and make new memories.  But most of all, she was eager to see where this new chapter in their relationship would take them.

When Kyoka had been nine, she had asked her mother what it was like to kiss her father for the first time.(There had been a reason for her question, of course. She had just read The Princess and the Frog, and had wanted to assure herself that her father was not some semi-aquatic, egg-laying mammal of action in another life.)She had been rewarded with a soft look and a chuckle.“I thought you might be older when you asked about this,” her mother had told her, before handing her a lollipop and a guitar pick.Kyoka is not sure why this particular anecdote is the one to rise to the surface as she finds herself locked in the walk-in closet with Denki Kaminari, but given her general dearth of such kiss-related memories for her to call upon, perhaps it is only to be expected.“Seven minutes!” Mina calls out from the other side of the door, and there’s a whoop from someone else – probably Sero – amid the generally raucous hustle-and-bustle in the room beyond as everyone else returns to their game of truth or dare.She could slap herself at the… cliché of it all. Locked in a closet with her crush, facing the countdown from her peers outside to see whether she will go through with the deed or not. She knew she should have stayed with truth.But it has been so long since she has seen them all, and the alcohol in her veins has clearly clouded her judgement. Kyoka is not a habitual drinker, save the occasional scotch for a nightcap with Momo back at the apartment they share, but between arriving at Tsu’s for this long-awaited school reunion and being caught by the spinning bottle, she has put more away than she is used to.Across from her, Kaminari is watching her with wary eyes, his gaze slipping out of focus before snapping back to her. He must be as tipsy as her, if not outright drunk, and she won’t tell him how strangely endearing she finds it in his attempts to hide that he cannot hold his liquor like the rest of the boys.“Six minutes!” comes Mina’s voice, a shrill sort of insistence to it. She can make out Midoriya somewhere in the distance, stammering away next to Sato’s booming laugh.Kaminari attempts to place a hand to his side to prop himself up, promptly misses his mark and falls into through a rail of dresses and jumpsuits with a muffled swearword. Kyoka bites down her chuckle, though a bubble escapes despite herself.“Yeah, yeah, laugh it up fuzzball,” he quips from somewhere beneath Tsu’s bomber jacket and she does chuckle this time before leaning forward and throwing a hand down in his general vicinity. He clutches his sweaty palm and lets himself be hauled back up to a standing position.“Cheers,” he half-slurs, and she wraps him on the shoulder with her fist.“No problem, man,” she responds, and her ears tell her she is losing the battle to stay on the right side of sobriety too.“You’ve got, um, hair,” he says after a moment, and points at her head. “Lovely hair, ‘m mean.”She’s let it grow out, dropping beneath her shoulders at the back while setting her bangs just behind her chin at the front. She isn’t fully convinced the look is for her, but she’s spent too long getting it to its current stage to simply chop it all off and start again.Her jacks reach up to curl a strand, but she gets the angle wrong and pokes herself in the cheek instead. “Thanks, man.”“No problem,” he says, and then he lapses into silence. He’s flushed, either by the alcohol or the warmth – with two bodies in here, it is little surprise that the broom cupboard feels like a furnace.“Five minutes!” Someday, Kyoka is going to make Mina pay for this. She should have an affair with Kirishima, see how she likes being put on the spot.“We don’t have to do it, y’know, right?” She refocuses on Kaminari. He is scratched at a phantom mark at the hem of his shirt; dark navy with a small red floral pattern, uncharacteristically effective in catching the eye, not that he ever has to make a special effort for that. “We can just pretend.”
And that’s the kicker, isn’t it?
They could easily pretend. They’ve been in this situation before, minus the alcohol of course. It isn’t the first time they’ve been corralled into an enclosed space and egged on by their more overzealous friends. On those occasions, they’ve either simply held tight until their time was up, or passed the minutes cracking bad puns at each other.But this time around, there’s something different to it all. They’re no longer students fighting to prove they belong at UA. They’re no longer teenagers, caught in a two-steps-removed tango flirting with the idea of confessing their feelings to each other and always changing direction when the beat shifts beneath their feet.“Four minutes!”“Do you,” she starts, and then stops. Takes a breath. Composes herself again. “Do you not want to?”He blinks at her, head tilted, for a moment, before he lets out a dry, solitary chuckle.“I thought I was the one who asked stupid things,” he mutters under his breath. It is definitely a blush on his cheeks now, as he ducks his head and rubs the side of his face in the crook of his elbow.“Really,” Kyoka says, Dutch courage in her veins. “Then let me give you your stupid answer.”She takes two steps towards him and closes the gap. She has just enough of a moment to see the look of surprise in his eyes before she shuts hers, fists the lapels of his shirt and pulls him in.He tastes like cheap beer and rich chocolate, with the underlying tang of copper, like raw static. It’s exactly what she expected from him.It is fucking intoxicating.His hand flaps at his side for a moment, unsure what to do, before it hesitantly comes around to settle at the base of her skin. She pushes further into him and he scrunches the material on reflex, drawing her tighter to him.There’s an electricity in the air, a slight shimmer around them where it bends, like a bubble rising to the surface of the ocean before it pops. Kyoka feels like all of the oxygen in this sweaty closet is evaporating with it.Kaminari makes a noise in the back of his throat and twists his knuckles tighter against the fabric of her top. It hitches up and she feels him place two fingers against the bare skin just above the waistband. She pushes against it, and lets out a contended sound of her own.He grows bolder, slipping his knuckles below the cut of her jeans, slowly at first, giving her the out that is so wonderfully considerate and so thoroughly unneeded. She releases one hand, slips it behind her, grabs his wrist, shoves his palm further into the material until he’s clasped the cheek of her ass.She’s so lost in the moment that she doesn’t notice the closet door swing open. A loud whoop breaks her concentration and she tears her face away, frustrated, to find half of her friends cheering from around the haphazard sofas and beanbags spread around the room.“That’s what I’m talking about!” squeals Mina. “You guys want to wrap it up and come back on out?”Kyoka doesn’t even bother to deign that question with a spoken answer, simply flipping her friend off before she reaches out and shuts the door again. Another chorus of raucous laughter breaks out behind it, but she cannot find it in herself to care in the slightest that they have just seen her in the midst of being terrifically groped.Kaminari looks dazed, drunk and utterly delighted. completion:
Chapter Text

Midoriya Izuku looked relatively normal.
 
In a world where it wasn’t out of the ordinary to see someone with crab claws, or a head that looked like a gun, or just being made out of sludge, seeing a kid with small lines in his skin wasn’t a groundbreaking sight.
 
He was good at pretending to look normal.
 
As good as he could be, anyway. There were lots of little things that he couldn’t change, couldn’t hide.
 
The way his pupils didn’t follow what he was looking at, the way his skin felt smooth and cold, that he didn’t bleed, that he didn’t eat, the faint skittering and buzzing that could be heard if the room was quiet enough.
 
The lines in his skin were the most obvious of the hints at what he truly was. Small canyons where carapace met carapace.
 
It wasn’t always like that.
 
On his fourth birthday, his quirk had manifested, and it had felt horrible.

________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
 
A four year old Midoriya ran behind his best friend, Kachan, giggling.
 
He had just turned four, and now he and Kachan were out playing while their parents were inside baking the cake. A red velvet one. He couldn’t wait to eat it. It would even be All Might themed! Truly, today was perfect.
 
Then, he felt it. The pins and needle feeling that happened whenever he slept on his arm wrong, only covering his own body.
 
His running stopped and his giggling turned into a cry of surprise and admittedly excitement. Afterall, this might be it! His quirk might finally be coming in!
 
Kachan paused his running to look at Izuku, obviously confused. “Why did you stop running Izu?”
 
“I feel all tingly Kachan! I think my quirk is coming in!” He was even more sure of it now, as the feeling hadn’t decreased at all, in fact it increased. More and more. It was starting to itch.
 
“About time Izu! I was starting to think you weren’t going to keep your promise! C’mon, lets go tell Auntie!” Kachan didn’t say anything more and turned back to Izuku’s house, breaking out into a run.

Izuku immediately started to follow, but the feeling was increasing, and it wasn’t stopping. It was starting to hurt.
 
Before he could say a word however, his mind 

split.

 
He was suddenly so much. He was suddenly so…. 

Many. 

 
He cried out, not in one voice, but many.
 

“Kachan!” 

 
He tripped, overloaded with information, and when he hit the ground, his body broke apart, like a lego building dropped onto the floor.
 
He felt the grass and dirt with many feet, he looked up at the disgusted face of Kachan not with one set of eyes, but hundreds of thousands. He heard Kachan scream in fear with not two ears, but so 

MANY. 

 
He didn’t know what happened for the rest of that day, as he passed out at that point.

________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
 
When he woke up, he was in a hospital bed, and he was still many.
 
The first thing he noticed was that he looked normal. The only odd thing were the lines. Small canyons adorning his skin, gradual slopes into a dark abyss that was under his skin.
 
The second thing he noticed was that he could see, but not out of his eyes. Out of the canyons in his skin, he could look out and see the world, looking at it through many small eyes.
 
Then he noticed what he was. It was hard not to. He saw out of the eyes of every single creature that lived inside of him after all, he felt them crawling over each other, chittering and crawling. 
 
He was made up of thousands of insects.
 
Now, for most children, this revelation would have horrified them, perhaps they would cry or scream. Izuku Midoriya was not like most children.



He sat there for a moment. Then tried to focus his attention and make one of the bugs that made up his skin crawl out its place and crawl up and down his arm.
 
He watched as it crawled out its place in the palm of his hand and up his arm. It looked like a large lady bug, only instead of the standard pattern most Lady bugs had, its shell looked like skin. 
 
It wasn’t like ordering something around, it was like moving his finger or taking a step.
 
A quick inspection of his body made him realize all of the bugs looked different. Most of them had at least some resemblance to bugs that weren’t part of his quirk, but it looked like none of them were an exact match to bugs he had seen or read about.
 
Furthermore, the insects that didn’t look at all like insects seemed to be replicating human body parts, like the ones in his throat that seemed to be immobile, and had a series of airways that could close or partially close to produce sound, and a quick test revealed that they served as vocal cords.
 
Inside of his chest he felt and saw centipede like bugs scuttle around, patrolling for foreign materials or invaders into his body, while others scuttling through his chest seemed to be taking care of the bugs that could not move.
 
Without realizing it, he had started a mumble storm. And it wouldn’t stop for a long time.
 
Sure his quirk was a little gross, but it was his, and it felt amazing. He knew he could be a hero with this quirk.
 
So many pro heroes had only sensory quirks that allowed them to scout for enemies or hostages. He had already found that he could split insects off of his body, and send them out. He could use those to scout buildings. Maybe he even had bugs that had some sort of venom that could help him defeat villains!
 
Sure, he couldn’t be like All Might, but most heroes weren’t. If his quirk could help him or others save lives, then he was perfectly happy with it.
 
That was how his mom found him when she returned to the room, mumbling and smiling.
 
Because he knew he could become a hero with that power.

________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
 
Years later, he still knew that was true, but it was hard to feel it.
 
After his quirk manifested, Kach- Bakugou had started calling him 
Henshu which meant Freak. It wasn’t exactly creative, but Bakugou wasn’t exactly known for being a put together or clever person.
 
He got his quirk registered the day after his fourth birthday. He named it Swarm. He wasn’t exactly a creative genius either. He named the bugs that made up his body Swarmlings, as they were entirely different from any other type of insect. They all shared the same genetic code at birth, but after the pupae stage, he could, for lack of a better word, design their adult form, allowing him to create a variety of Swarmlings.
 
And now he stood outside Aldera, ready for his final day at the place that had tormented him for so long, and excited to move on to UA.

completion:
Chapter Text
When Shota Aizawa was 5, his parents gave up on him having a quirk when none appeared to manifest similar to theirs. They'd hoped for a late bloomer when 4 came and went, especially since they'd both gotten theirs at 3. But nothing.The whole little toe thing? That theory was so much junk science and lies.His father wouldn't tolerate a weak, quirkless kid. So at 5 1/2, he enrolled the boy into martial arts classes to at least give him some hand to hand skills and spatial awareness. He knew his child would have challenges being quirkless in an ever increasingly quirked world. He still held out hope that maybe if he got pummeled enough, frustrated enough,  scared enough, the quirk would manifest.It didn't. Shota excelled at the martial program, learning a variety of clinches, locks, positioning of judo, kung fu, krav maga, varied martial arts programs, gaining levels and belts and learning what he could as the class dummy and able to be the general sparring partner for different styles. He was 9 when his quirk finally manifested at school, just as a bully was cocking back ready to hit him and a younger kid and steal their lunch money. The quirk kicked in, his hair standing on end and his dark eyes glowing like an oni from the depths.…Still, he still got his ass kicked because he had no idea how to integrate his quirk with his skills... and the guy had seven other friends. How dare Aizawa stand up to them, but they suffered their own wounds in return. He headed home to get berated by his mother and father for fighting, suspended for 3 days from school (because it didn't matter who started the fight, it mattered that there was a fight and one of the other brats family was on the school board association), and what good was all that martial arts training if he was still getting his ass beat? They threatened to pull him out since money didn't grow on trees and it was hard to come by. But Aizawa begged and pleaded, only convincing them when he promised he'd see if he could work at the dojo for his class cost. His father at least could accept that, as long as his grades didn't suffer. So he did what he could to excel in classes, get his school work done as much at school and on the short train ride home, so he could run home, eat, change and head to the dojo.As far as his parents knew, he was only doing martial arts, cleaning the dojo/gym at the end of the day. But the gym shared space with a dance school, teaching classical ballet and jazz, and occasional special request classes of swing, street, improv and couples skills.He'd  held off watching the classes until an older student told him he could probably excel at it and improve his flexibility so he thought long and hard about it before joining.He found he enjoyed it.It was a similar zen mind set as he learned the positions. And it did help his flexibility, even more than the yoga and tai chi stretches.It helped that the dojomaster's spouse ran the dance studio and they already had a good rapport. He was becoming proficient working with different gymnastic tools like hoops, ribbons, and balls. They took a different level of skill and talents to use effectively and not brain oneself. Again, Aizawa was a quick study for it all, able to learn quickly and, when couples dancing, able to step into the traditional male or female role.It was all fine and dandy until one night his father came looking for him at the dojo and found his 13 year old son dancing with an older teen.The proverbial shit hit the fan.He was forbidden to go to the dojo.It was school or home.Which was mostly ok, it wasn't like Shota had friends.But he missed the activity and music. The ability to burn off all that energy and the emotional swings that seemed to be daily life. So he took to dancing and stretching at home, between the time when he was home from school and his parents were at work…Until his father came home early and found Shota dancing and singing English rock and roll songs while cleaning the apartment. For a traditional family of local renown in Tokyo, that was totally unacceptable. Then it was a class debate club and cram school, until 10pm. He felt his soul die. There was no way this was his life.Then his mother passed from a villain attack, her car going off a bridge, leaving Shota and his father, who even on their best days never saw eye to eye.And now, here they were forced to deal with the other without even a modicum of padding from his mother.His father threatened to send him away to military school as the boy grieved.Instead, Shota applied for entrance to two hero schools, far away from home, seeking the opportunity to be emancipated and free rather than sent away to Germany or elsewhere to toe some small dicked,  power hungry, tin dictator's stupid line on what made a man a man bullshit. No way was he going to tolerate the same awfulness as home, with just a different bully-father type.He put in for a few elite high schools, too, just in case the hero angle failed. His grades were still exemplary and perhaps he could get a scholarship. That was the plan. Anything but what his father wanted. Anything. He was accepted to the high schools. He passed the general studies at UA, missing the hero course by mere points, his quirk not doing much to give him an edge like his years of martial arts training did. And he gathered his few things and left his childhood home, entering an off campus housing complex of other UA students.Again, not optimal, but better than living on the street or at his parents home. Here he could set his own hours (minus the curfew) and set his own expectations. His father came once to see the living conditions, gave him an envelope of a little money and then reminded Aizawa he'd choosen the life he wanted and there was no coming back.Aizawa slammed the door in his face… but he kept the money; 1,000,000 yen was more than he'd ever had. The next morning he headed to a bank and put most of it into savings. The school provided in his room a bed, desk and chair, hot plate, fridgette, toilet, a shared full kitchen and shower/bath space for the students. Not much, but enough. He could scrounge or go to temple sales to find things he might identify he needed. But with school providing a full lunch, he at least had 1 solid meal a day.General studies was… fairly easy. He found himself bored at times that first few weeks, but he walked around the town, seeing what was there.And then the school sports festival was mentioned. He'd seen it on tv over the years, his Sensei having it on the dojo tv when it was that time. He wasn't sure that he'd place, but he did. Again his skills coming to the forefront. Including his gymnastic abilities. His spatial awareness and body awareness putting him towards the head of the pack.He didn't win, but he did place within the top 3, barely using his quirk. He was approached by the heroics teacher and given a few tests, his interests in hero work assessed and measured. And then he was busy, busier than he'd ever been, with new movements taught, an array of weapons tried, before they'd settled on modified ribbon work, as Aizawa showed skills of hooking, climbing, and catching with it, rough as it might be. They'd come to the conclusion that Aizawa's affinity for the ribbon was amazing and he could use an aspect of his quirk--the one that made his hair stand on end when it was fully engaged– to move the ribbon around like a sentient serpent. The heroics teacher was fascinated and wondered where he'd come up with the idea. Aizawa didn't have the heart to tell him he'd seen something like sentient ribbons in an American comic book of his mother's, used by an Angel, of all things. But it worked. It tore the fuck out of his hands, too, but he taped them up and kept going, attempting to integrate the rudimentary quirk of his erasure with the weird staticky charge…

To be fair, he did dye his hair for this.He noted Tomura was very giddy. An unholy sign. Kurogiri filled him in. Tomura choose a student to kidnap, to make them a villain. It was Izuku's bully and class mate Bakugou Katsuki. Izuku was not surprised that they think of the explosive Pomeranian as villain material.Tomura asked if he knows about the explosive wanna-be hero. “Well, as I am not a 1-A student-” What a lie. “-I do not know much about Bakugou. completion: Class 1-A and their teachers laid on the ground. Roughed up and dirty, stained by the blood of fallen heroes and villains. Even All Might was down. Not dead, but like them, he couldn't stand. Only Midoriya Izuku was somewhat standing, but even he was weak. He breathed heavily and stared to All for One. The man stood in front of him, Tomura and Kurogiri by his side.“The tables turned, Deku. What a fitting name.”, said All for One. “I could kill you now, but I am a businessman. I have an offer for you.”“Like what? My quirk against my life?”, spat Deku.“Why yes! Your quirk is my brothers, I want it back.”, confirmed All for One. “In exchange, I'll give you a different quirk. I doubt you want to be Quirkless again, do you?”“Like what quirks?”, asked Izuku.“Young Midoriya, are you seriously considering?”, asked All Might, but Deku igniored him.“Anyone I am willing to part with.”, replied All for One. “But if this isn't enough, I would let your class life. They aren't a danger.”Deku was silent. Tomura noted this. “Oh, he seriously considers!”Deku spoke up, “Fine.”“Young Midoriya! Don't!”, yelled All Might. Not that his voice could make much noise.“Good boy.”, praised him All for One. He took a streak of Deku's hair and cut it with a claw quirk. He than ate it. Class 1-A was disgusted by this. They knew what One for All was, how it can be transferred. But seeing someone eat hair was still disgusting. The quirk settled and All for One made some sparks on his hand. “Finally, Yoichi's quirk! Now my promise. What quirk do you want?”“Which one would you be willing to part?”, countered Deku.“I would part with a few healing quirks-Ah!” His sentence was interrupted by a pained yell. Sparks similar to Deku's green appeared. His breathing got heavy. “What is going on? When does this stop?”“I don't know, this didn't happen when I got One for All. But I used to be quirkless, so...”, replied Izuku.“What do you mean?”, asked Tomura, walking to his sensei's side.“Simple. The other holders got slowly killed by One for All. But only the ones that already had quirks. The faster with each new carrier.”, explained Izuku. “They only had one, each. But your sensei, he is a walking quirk. One for All acts faster, One for All is the eleventh holder and quirked. And maybe the vestiges help as well.”“You mean my brothers quirk-”“Is killing you? It is destroying you.”, interrupted him Deku. “It is killing you, your quirk and itself. And you can't stop it.” He chuckled a bit, just slightly scaring his class and some of the villains. “If I fall, I drag you with me.”All for One was kneeing on the ground, breathing loudly and uneven. Tomura on hhis side, unsure what to do. “Sensei?”“Kurogiri, send me and the boy to my office.”, said All for One. Kurogiri didn't wait and made a portal besides All for One. Izuku on the other hand tried to run, but he was stopped by Tomura.The villain walked in front of him, a hand around Uraraka's neck.“Just walk in and I won't kill her.”, he said.Deku was frozen. Should he comply? He doubts Shigaraki won't kill her when he is out of sight. Or the rest of the class. He could see Shigaraki pulling a sick joke, letting Uraraka live and kill the rest. While in thought, he didn't notice how Kurogiri made a portal under him. He only realized it when he was falling.He landed, like All for One demanded, in an office. Of sorts. He saw no windows. It looked more like someone put a desk into a basement. On the desk was All for One, on a chair. Still breathing up a storm. He didn't look threatening, but like he was dying.“All for One, why are we here?”“Talking in private. Without the buffoon, without Tomura interrupting us, Deku.”, replied then villain. “One for All does not harm you, right?”“On default, no.”, replied Izuku.“Well, then. Take it back.”, spoke the villain.“What?”, asked Izuku more than just shocked. “You want me what now?”“Take it back. One for All kills me, but not you. I may miss Yoichi, but I would miss my life more.”, said All for One. “You remind me of Yoichi. You keep the quirk, I keep my life. And you replace Tomura.”“Looks like the old man is senile, why would I want to join you?”, countered Deku. “And replacing Tomura. I doubt he'll like that.”“Who cares what Tomura thinks, he was just a rare tool, courtesy to being Shimura's grandson. He has no real goals, too impulsive for his own good.”, replied All for One. “But you, you can use Yoichi's quirk, you're analytical. I assume you gave One for All to me as a trap?”“Maybe. This still doesn't answer why I would join you.”“Simple. You did give it to me. They aren't aware why. They may consider you a traitor. Or as an useless quirkless.”, explained All for One.“Then, I have nothing to loose.”“So, you accept it back?”, asked All for One, “Even if it means that I survive.”“I have nothing to loose. But gain a quirk.”, replied Izuku.“Good, but we will do the DNA transfer differently.”, said All for One. “I have a syringe in my desk.”Deku used the syringe and took a bit of All for One's blood. The man was unbothered by the syringe. But Izuku did feel a small pain point.“I feel One for All leaving.”, said All for One, sounding releaved.“And I can sense the vestiges being angry with me.”, said Deku. “Nothing new. Are you sure just One for All is leaving you?”“Yes. I... I...” All for One realized, it was not. His life left him as well. He lost the signals of his quirks. Search, he couldn't sense Izuku. “What...”“Don't you remember, senile old man? Remains of transferable quirks tend to linger.”, revealed Deku. “My second trap. I get the full quirk back, it even got strengthened by you and you still die. Time to rip Tomura a new one.”“You little...” All for One spoke his last words. “They still see you as a traitor.”“Nothing to loose.”, repeated Deku. He saw All for One's body loosened. “Now, how the heck do I leave this place-Oh.” A portal of Kurogiri opened.Tomura looked at the portal. Instead of his sensei, Deku walked out.“Just for your information, All for One's dead.”, he spoke. He activated One for All. “And I got One for All back.”“This can't be!”, yelled Tomura. He ran into the portal, only to find All for One's lifeless body. He returned and attacked Deku. “How did you kill him!”, he yelled.Deku didn't answer, he just grabbed Tomura's arm and slammed him to the ground, breaking his arm. “Like I said, One for All kills the quirked users. Some slower, some faster.”<<EOFANFIC>>

More Like DAD MIGHT Parental Yagi Toshinori | All Might Inko Midoriya is a scary woman Wingfic set during the beginning of season 1 Izuku just makes everyone fall in love with him tbh Anxious Midoriya Izuku
completion:
“Listen, kid, if we’re going to do this, I need you to focus. Your full attention. No goin’ back now.”
 
He blinks, snapping out of his thoughts. All Might is staring at him, his expression somewhere between annoyed and concerned, his head tilted ever so slightly. 
 
“Well?” The older man asks, shifting sideways. “The beach?” 
 
“Right!” He stands up, dusting the sand off his shoes and pants. “Right, well, but–”
 
“But?” All Might frowns. 
 
Izuku rolls his shoulders once, then again– slower. The pain is manageable, a soft ache that rises into his neck and falters there. He’s dealt with it for only a few days now– he can handle it for a little longer.
 
“I’m alright,” he says, flashing a smile. “Promise!”
 
All Might turns. “You remember what we talked about, don’t you?” 
 
“The beach.” He turns, stretching out his arms. “It’s almost clean! We’re halfway there.”
 
“You’re a glass half-full kinda person kid, I like that.” All Might’s claps his hand across Izuku’s back. “You– hey, hey kid! I didn’t even hit you that hard!”
 
He’s on his hands and knees, the pain spreading in a burning wave across his upper back and shoulders. Mere seconds have passed before he can hardly stand to move. Breathing hurts. He inhales in shallow gasps, exhaling shakily, his whole body unsteady. 
 
All Might bends down. “Tell me where it hurts.”
 
“My back.” He grits his teeth, fingers curling into fists under the sand. “F-feels like it’s on fire.”
 
“Can you stand?”
 
“I don’t… I don’t think so.”
 
“Sit up? Take off your shirt?”
 
He shakes his head. 
 
“Sorry about this,” All Might mumbles from somewhere behind him. 
 
There’s a tearing noise– the wind that hits Izuku’s back is cold, even though the rest of him is covered in sweat. He flinches, and the movement is the last straw– he curls into a ball and tucks his head in close to his knees, rolling onto one side. 
 
“Shit,” All Might murmurs. Izuku can see him better now– he has one hand covering his mouth, and his eyes are narrowed deep in thought. 
 
“I really liked this shirt,” Izuku mumbles, half-delirious with the pain. 
 
Gently, All Might reaches out and lifts him up. “I’m taking you back home.”
 
“My mom… she can’t know. I haven’t told her anything.”
 
“We’ll deal with that later, kid. This is important.”
 
“Am… is there something wrong with me?” 
 
A beat. 
 
“All Might?” 
 
“Do you… want the honest answer, kid?”
 
“Um… yes?” 
 
“You’ve got something coming out of your back. Two red spots, like bad bruises, right at your shoulder blades.”
 
For a long, terrible moment, Izuku is scared he misunderstood. The words coming out of All Might’s mouth can’t… possibly be about 

him. 

 
“I don’t know what kind of quirk this is, or why you’re getting it so late. But whatever’s happening needs to happen where no one else will be able to see. And I’ll explain things to your mom, kid. Don’t worry about that.”
 
He is too sore and too tired to think about much of anything, really. He shuts his eyes and shifts his back until All Might’s arms are just between his shoulders, perfectly settled. 
 
And then he falls asleep. 
 
~
 
“Mrs. Midoriya–”
 
“Just Inko is alright,” Midoriya’s mother interrupts him quietly, adding, “I haven’t been married in some time now.”
 
Toshinori nods. “Right. Look. You’re aware that your son wants to get into UA.”
 
Her eyes water immediately and he has to suppress a sigh– like mother, like son. 
 
“It’s this hopeless dream of his,” she murmurs, curling her hands around the wad off tissues in her lap. “I keep hoping he’ll give it up, decide to go after something safer, something… possible! But he hasn’t. I just… want him to be okay.”
 
She has tears rolling down her face, and her lips are quivering. She doesn’t look at him– looks anywhere else, anywhere but his eyes.
 
He knows he doesn’t look like much– that few things can explain what he knows. But… well. 
 
This won’t be the first lie he’s told, and it won’t be the last. 
 
“I’m a mentor of sorts,” he begins. “I’ve been teaching pro heroes for years now. Your son and I sort of… ran into each other on the streets– he told me what he wanted to do and… I’ve been training him.”
 
He isn’t sure how to take her reaction– her gaze sharpens in a way that is terrifying and motherly at once, but she doesn’t say anything for a moment. When she does speak, her voice is level– calm. 
 
“Well,” she says lightly, “I guess that explains why he’s been eating so much.”
 
And Toshinori can’t help it– he laughs. “He’s a good kid,” he says, leaning back in his seat. “Genuine. Kind. He cares about this world and the people in it.”
 
“To a fault,” Inko murmurs, and Toshinori nods. 
 
“He’s a good kind, Inko,” he repeats, “which is why I’m encouraging him to apply for UA’s hero course.”
 
“What? But he’s quirkless! He can’t possibly even try such a thing, he’d be killed! Flattened! Squished to death by some sort of monster or who knows what– maybe another child! You can’t–”
 
She drones on, her voice dropping into a soft mumble. 
 
Yet again, he can see where Midoriya gets his bookish qualities from– and his anxiety, perhaps. 
 
“There’s something you need to know,” he says, and now he is the one who cannot meet Inko’s eyes. He can feel her glaring at him all the same. “Your son isn’t quirkless.”
 
“That’s… impossible.”
 
“When he collapsed today… when I carried him here. There are… two red marks forming on his back, like something has sprouted beneath his skin. I… have reason to believe he’s been in pain for a while now.”
 
Her eyes water, and her hands muffle the sob that escapes her as she clutches them over her mouth. 
 
He can’t tell if she’s relieved or desperate– or ready to strangle him– so he keeps talking. 
 
“Now, if he’s… well, they could be anything, really. But based on the location… I think they’re… probably wings.”
 
“Wings,” she whispers, and now he can see the relief in her eyes– the pure joy. “Oh… my little boy…”
 
Toshinori scoots the tissue box on the table a little closer to Inko. “I know this is a lot to take in, but I believe your son has potential. I’d like to keep training him, once he recovers. He can be a hero, Inko.”
 
She sniffles. “It’s all he’s ever wanted…” she breathes. “But it’s so dangerous…”
 
“Can I be honest?” Toshinori asks, steepling his fingers under his nose and chin. “I’ve only known the kid for a few months, but I know this. There’s going to be no stopping him once he wakes up. He knows what he wants. This quirk, whatever it is, will only push him further.”
 
“I know,” Inko nods. “Which is why… it’s why I’m glad he has someone to look after him.” Her gaze sharpens once more, and he’s startled by the steely light in her eyes. “Promise me that you’ll look after him.”
 
“I promise you, on my life,” he says. He’s never meant anything more. 
 
“Good.” she leans back into the couch cushions, smiling brightly. “He should wake up soon. Would you like some tea?” 
 
“I… of course,” Toshinori chokes out, his thoughts racing. “Thank you.”
 
Inko stands up and walks into the kitchen, humming to herself as if she hadn’t just been prepared to murder him on the spot. 
 
He leans his head back and stares at the ceiling. “Talk about scary…”
 
~
 
He wakes up on his stomach, one hand tucked under his chin, the other splayed at his side. 
 
It feels like he’s being pinned down by something heavy and warm– like a weighted blanket– but he can feel his sheets tangled over his waist and legs, so the weight isn’t the same. 
 
He rolls over, and his back doesn’t 

hurt, 

but something like pain twinges hard in his back, and he grunts as he forces the rest of his body to move along with him. 
 
A picture frame falls off the wall. 
 
He looks over his shoulder with a frown. He forgets how to breathe. 
 
He has 

wings.

 
They’re long and green colored, so dark that they almost look black instead. They don’t move– not for a few moments at least– but once he remembers to take a breath he tries to get them to move a second later and they 

do– 

a slow lift to his shoulders, a strangely easy moment of concentration before they fan out to their full length. 
 
The wings are longer than his arms, touching the walls on either side of the room. 
 
He closes his eyes, then opens them. 
 
The wings are still there. 
 
And then he 

screams. 

 
All Might and his mother appear a second later, and before he can reckon with 

that 

revelation, his mom is touching his arms and feeling his forehead, talking so fast he can hardly keep up with what she’s saying. 
 
All Might stands in the corner, watching. There’s a weird look in his eyes– pride? For… him?
 
“I’m so glad you’re okay,” his mom whispers, burying her head in his shoulder. “I’m really, really glad you’re okay.”
 
“I have a quirk,” Izuku rushes out, holding her hands. He flings both arms outward, nearly whisking her off her feet. “I have a quirk!”
 
“You have a quirk,” she agrees, smiling. “Oh, Izuku, I’m so 

proud!”

 
He grins– they hug again. 
 
And then All Might steps closer. 
 
“Hey, hey, kid,” he says in that slow, patient rumble of his. “Can you stand? Walk?” 
 
He does– slowly. It’s… harder than he thought it would be, but he manages to account for the new weight on his back by shifting the rest of his body forward. His center of gravity is different– it makes sense, giving how big the wings are…
 
“Midoriya,” All Might sighs, “you’re doin’ it again.”
 
“Oh!” He tangles his hand through the hair on the back of his head. “Sorry.”  
 
It’s several minutes of explaining– of walking around the apartment and trying pointedly to not knock things off the walls– before he squeezes out the door and into the hallway. The front door closes, and All Might turns to him with a wide smile. 
 
“I’ll be honest, I didn’t see things happening this way,” he says. “I’ll have to reformat the plan I gave you, make sure you don’t overwork yourself while compensating for your new… wings.” He laughs, shakes his head. “You sure as hell know how to surprise this old man, Midoriya.”
 
“You’re not old,” he says, grinning right back. He looks at the floor. “This… changes everything, doesn’t it?”
 
“Everything and nothing,” All Might answers. “I meant what I said, kid. You are worthy. It’s just going to take time. And a lot of work. A 

lot 

of work.”
 
Izuku groans. 


“But you have a quirk now,” All Might says, ruffling the hair on top of Izuku’s head. “You 

can

"Tsutsumi, he's a traitor. He's colluding with villains. He's too dangerous to keep around. And we can't afford to arrest him, or the villains he's working with will know we're onto them. This is the only way to keep the city as safe as possible," a voice encouraged through her earpiece.
Her body was entirely still, calmed by her intense training and frozen by her internal conflict. It wouldn't be the first time she's killed somebody, just the first time she's killed a pro hero. "How will killing him cover up the fact we're onto them?" she asked, searching for any hole in the logic to excuse canceling the operation.

"We've set it up to guarantee the blame will fall on a vigilante notorious for not working with us or the police," the voice explained. "We already briefed you on this. We've been sending anonymous threat letters with enough threads that link to the vigilante, saying they know of his collusions."

Kaina was lying flat on her stomach on the roof of a building, propped up on one arm. Her other arm was raised up so her elbow was at face level, her arm bent and her hand near her shoulder. Protruding from her elbow is a sniper rifle, its sight trained on the hero in question. He was older, old enough to warrant being retired, but he still patrolled the streets of his county. Hearing that his death would be pinned on somebody else who was innocent didn't give her much comfort. "Does sniping him match the scapegoat's M.O.?" was her next question.

"Tsutsumi, shoot. That's an order," the voice hardened in her ear. "This is your job; if you can't do it, we will replace you."

It wasn't just a threat to her job, it was a threat to her freedom and maybe even her life if she did anything to try to expose what she knew. If word got out that the Commission was willing to kill people rather than follow the legal order of procedures...Her mouth opened slightly, a wisp of breath escaping her lips as she fired. She looked away as soon as it was done, not wanting to see the splatter of blood or the body falling limp. Looking away didn't prevent her from seeing it, though. It played out in her head, after every kill. She had seen it so many times, it was like an image burned into her retinas.

"It's done," she said, but she didn't hear her own voice. It was somebody else's voice, reporting in after a mission. Her mouth was dry and she didn't feel it moving. She felt numb all over.

"Great, we'll handle the rest," the voice said. "In the future, follow orders without questions. You're lucky he didn't catch on to the fact he was being hunted; your hesitation could have resulted in a failure."



Kaina didn't go to hero conventions often. She thought it was cute and comforting that pro heroes have so many supporters and could meet them in person at such conventions. But after going to her first two or three, she figured it wasn't her scene. She had been raised to be humble, and having hundreds of people praise her work felt awkward. The one she walked through now wasn't one she was holding any panels at; she had simply intended to just wander and get her mind off her recent assignments.

Unfortunately, existing in public without recognition is near impossible for one as successful as her. Before she had even entered the venue, people were whispering, "That's Lady Nagant, right? Should we go get an autograph?" Luckily, her thoughtful and pensive expression encouraged most to leave her be, but it was inevitable that people started approaching her. And once one person approached, others started to too.

Kaina thought she would get a moment of respite at a food truck outside the venue. She was leaning against a telephone pole with her cheap meal, trying her best to look unapproachable, but two teenage girls walked up, one looking eager and the other hesitant. "Hey, Nagant! We met a few years ago at this convention, do you remember me?" the eager one asked.

Kaina was quick to analyze her and recall their previous interactions. She had been one of the people who had paid for a quick five-minute discussion at a table Kaina had been running. She had used the time to give the pro hero a plush of herself. It was a crude but cute recreation made of felt and stuffing. The plush still sat on top of a bookshelf in her basement. "Yes, I recall," she said, smiling politely.

"This is my sister, Lili. She hadn't been able to come to the convention all those years ago, but she's a huge fan of yours. She's actually the one who made that plush of you, and has made a new one she's been dreaming of giving to you," the girl continued, introducing the shier one next to her. "Li, now's your chance, pull it out."

"H-Hello," Lili said. "Sorry for bothering you, we'll be quick then we'll leave you alone." She unslung her bag from her back. I instinctively flinched, resisting the urge to react aggressively. I wasn't on duty right now, the girl wasn't about to pull out a weapon. Her bag was bulging, full to the brim with something. Unzipping it revealed there to be several plushes of different heroes, all with the same materials and skill level. Just from the pile of plush, Kaina could tell her sewing skill had improved since the last plush she received.

Lili had to dig around in the bag to find the plush, which was apparently buried at the bottom. As she pulled it out, several others spilled out of the bag onto the pavement. "Oh no," Lili expressed, concerned about their cleanliness. She started collecting the ones that had fallen out. Kaina didn't pay attention to whom she had made. Her eyes were glued to one, in particular, one that had rolled to her feet. Kaina made no effort to scoop it up or help Lili out, instead staring down at the one plush. The hero she had killed the day prior.

"You're a fan of Gourmet?"

Lili stood up straight with a bit of a blush spreading across her cheeks. She hadn't collected the plush at Kaina's feet, not wanting to get so close. "He helped me, once," she said in a small voice.

"Helped?" the sister scoffed. "More like saved your ass. Nagant, Lili owes Gourmet her life. We were in a burning building once in the middle of a battlefield between heroes and villains. The building collapsed, and a girder was going to kill my sis, but Gourmet showed up, unhinged his jaw, and swallowed all the rubble that was falling toward her."

Kaina squatted down, scooping up the recreation. That was when she noticed it was a puppet, not just a plush. She slipped her hand inside, opening and closing his mouth a couple of times. "He passed away yesterday," she said absentmindedly, without thinking.

"He didn't pass away," Lili said, her voice suddenly a lot more emotional. The emotion wasn't sadness or grief, though. It was anger. "He didn't just die in his sleep peacefully. He was murdered. Somebody murdered him, in a way that didn't even offer him a chance to fight back. He was murdered by a coward."

Blood splashed across Kaina's vision, splattering across Lili and her sister's faces. Kaina's breathing grew labored as she quickly tore the puppet from her hand, tossing it at Lili and fleeing. The girls watched her run away, confused. They were clean. The "hero" hid in an empty alley, leaning against a wall and trying to catch her breath and calm herself down. She looked out to see Lili and her sister meandering their way back into the convention's venue. When she looked back down the  alley, it was littered with the bodies of her victims.

Her breath hitched once more, and she squeezed her eyes shut. Even in the faux darkness, blood dripped down her vision. She had killed the man that had saved Lili's life. A man who had probably saved many others' lives. How many more lives would he have saved? Did he need to die just so villains could be caught? How many pro heroes' deaths were at the hands of other pro heroes? How was the Commission able to hide all this from the public? How did she end up in this role? Who had preceded her, and how many did they kill? What happened to them? What would happen to her?



Jun nearly jumped out of her skin when the phone at her desk rang. The phone was reserved for the Commissioner, and he never called her. She scrambled to answer. "Yes, Shachou, how can I help?"

"I need you in my office immediately. It's about Tsutsumi," he said before hanging up immediately. Jun quickly put anything confidential in a safe, locked drawer before making her way to the Commissioner's office. She slipped in, closing the door behind her. "Tsutsumi is AWOL. "How can I help?" Jun inquired. "I can see if I can bypass whatever method she's using."

"Take any means necessary. But first, I need you to retrieve-"

completion:
There’s a point in every summer vacation where you find yourself with nothing to do: You’ve watched all the TV shows, read all your comic books and spent so much time playing outside that your legs are completely covered in mosquito bites. Yoichi Shigaraki had reached that point days ago.

Currently, he was lying on his sweat-drenched bed, staring at clouds moving outside the window.  A cloud that looked tantalisingly like a glass of lemonade floated by, making Yoichi remember just how thirsty he was. Man, would it be nice to have a cool, refreshing drink…

Wait -Yoichi perked up. He was pretty sure the kitchen had everything he needed to make some lemonade. Plus, he had an idea for something to do….

Twenty minutes and a nice cool glass of lemonade later found Yoichi struggling to move a stack of plastic cups, cardboard, markers and a cooler filled with lemonade, all of which was shakily balanced on top of a fold out table.

He had greatly underestimated how hard it would be to carry so many things outside. Yoichi grunted and yanked on the table, which turned out to be a mistake. The table folded in, glasses rolled down the hall, markers flew through the air and Yoichi fell on the ground with a thump.

His brother appeared from upstairs almost instantly. “Yoichi! Are you hurt?”

“No,” Yoichi slowly got up. He looked around at the scattered cups and the juice slowly seeping into the floorboards. “I guess I underestimated how much I could carry.”

Hisashi still didn’t look all that relaxed. “You know you should always ask me for help. What were you even doing?”

“I was gonna set up a lemonade stand.” Yoichi sighed. There went his plans for the day. It was going to take a while to clean everything. “Where’s the broom again?”

“Don’t worry. Why don’t I set up the stand and you…” Hisashi looked around at the equipment. “You can draw the sign!” Hisashi handed Yoichi the cardboard and a red marker.

“Well…” Yoichi hesitated. Just because he had messed up once didn’t mean that he couldn’t do anything to help …But it would be nice to spend some time with his brother. Recently Hisashi had been so busy, Yoichi couldn’t remember the last time the two of them had done something together. “Sure!

He took the cardboard, but switched out the red marker (red was his least favorite color) for a green one. Selling the lemonade would probably be more fun anyways.
 
Yoichi had never made a stand before, but he thought this one looked pretty good. 

Yoichi bounced on his feet and grinned at Hisashi. “This looks great. Thanks, big brother!”

Hisashi didn’t smile back. “Doesn’t it look a little… basic.”

“Uh, I guess.” It was a kid’s lemonade stand. How fancy could it be? 

Hisashi shook his head, and ruffled Yoichi’s hair. “Just give me a few minutes. I’ll get you the best lemonade stand ever.” He took out his phone and started dialling.

Yoichi glanced back at their stand. It was pretty good already, wasn’t it? Suddenly the little doodles he had made for the sign seemed less cute and a lot more childish.
 
Apparently Hisashi's idea of a good lemonade stand was what most people would just consider a shop. Yoichi gaped at the construction site their front yard had been turned into. How had his brother managed to get so many people to come here, and so quickly?

It didn’t look like Yoichi could ask Hisashi because he was currently busy yelling instructions at the big burly workers. Yoichi slumped against the white table and poured himself a glass of lemonade. 

Hisashi a few years ago, maybe even a few months ago, wouldn’t have cared how the stand looked. But he had started acting weirdly recently: staying out longer, talking to strange people, coming home with gifts way too expensive for them to afford…

“What’s that?” 

A boy with spiky hair who looked about Yoichi’s age leaned against the stand. Behind him another kid was staring at one of the huge worker’s moving a steel beam with seemingly no problem.

“My brother,” Yoichi blushed a little. “He thought the stand we made wasn’t good enough, so he’s, uh, making a better one.”

“That’s a 

stand

?” The boy looked appropriately stunned. “Really?”

“I guess.” Yoichi took a sip. He offered the boy a cup. “You two want some lemonade? I don’t really feel like selling anymore.”

The other two boys shared a look. “Could we have it then?”

Yoichi stopped drinking. “The stand?”

They nodded.

“I don’t really know either of you….” Yoichi trailed off hesitantly. Even though he wasn’t planning on using the stand anymore, he didn’t want to lose the table.

“You can come with us then,” the spiky haired boy offered. “That way, you can make sure we give everything back.”

“Well….” Yoichi looked back at Hisashi, who was still busy pacing around the site. Clearly his brother wouldn’t miss him. “Sure, why not.”
 
The three decided to move the stand to a busier street a few blocks away.

As soon as they had everything prepared, the kid with spiky-hair (whose name Yoichi had learned was Nichigo) jumped on top of the table, which miraculously didn’t buckle under his weight.

“Lemonade!” Nichigo yelled. “Who wants lemonade? Only 20 yen!”

Yoichi leaned in towards the other kid, Mitsuo. “Isn’t that too little?”

“This is just to get interest,” Mitsuo whispered back. “We’ll increase the price later.”

Which would have been a great plan, 

if

 they had managed to increase the price before running out of lemonade.

Nichigo looked at the empty jug. “I guess I underestimated how thirsty people were.”

Yoichi looked at the small pile of money on the table. “I don’t think we can buy more ingredients.”

“I could go to the store and check?” Nichigo said.

That sounded like a pretty good plan to Yoichi. While Nichigo ran to the store, Mitsuo sat on the ground and started drawing on the back of the sign. It was an action scene, of a hero facing a huge demon. The hero’s clothes were tattered and he was struggling to stand up. It looked kind of familiar…

“Wait, is that Captain Hero?” Superhero comics had been a lot less popular since the glowing baby had been discovered. Most people wanted nothing to do with meta-human related things, fictional comics included. The only Captain Hero fan Yoichi knew in real life was Hisashi.

Mitsuo looked at Yoichi. “Yeah. Do you read the comics too?”

“My brother and I have read every issue at least three times,” Yoichi said. Well, Hisashi refused to read the ending, because apparently the villain getting defeated was ‘too cliche’ -Yoichi was pretty sure his brother was the only one who thought that.

“Who’s your favourite character?” He asked, sitting down beside Mitsuo.

Mitsuo put down the sign and turned to face him. “Gosh, that’s so hard to pick. Maybe Kid Sidekick?”

Yoichi grinned. Maybe he would finally have someone else to talk to about Captain Hero with who wasn’t his brother.
 
By the time Nichigo got back, Yoichi and Mitsuo were deep into conversation about their favorite superheroes. 

Nichigo didn’t look like he was bringing good news. He glumly set down the bag “Okay, so there wasn’t enough money for everything, but I did buy lemon juice.”

Yoichi took the container out of the bag and took a small sip, then immediately spat it out. “This is way too sour.”

“Maybe it’ll taste okay if we watered it down?” Mitsuo suggested.

Yoichi knew it wouldn’t, but Nitsuo looked incredibly regretful already. “We can go back to my house to get some.” And if they got lucky, there would be some sugar left in the pantry.

The three decided to leave the table where it was, since they would be back soon enough. 

“Yoichi likes Captain Hero,” Mitsuo said, as they walked back to the house.

Nichigo’s eyes lit up. “Really?”

Yoichi nodded.

Nichigo’s expression became more serious. “Please tell me your favourite character isn’t Kid Sidekick.”

Mitsuo shoved him. “Kid Sidekick’s a great character. Anyways, you like the Demon King. That’s worse.”

“No it’s not,” Nichigo said sulkily.

Yoichi giggled. “No, my favorite character’s Captain Hero. But my brother loves the Demon King.”

Nichigo frowned. “I’m not sure if I want to have anything in common with someone who thinks ‘lemonade stand’ means building a whole ‘store’.”

Speaking of which, the construction seemed to have paused. As the three approached Yoichi’s house, Yoichi saw Hisashi angrily talking with a policeman.

“My brother is missing and you’re fining me for not getting a food permit? ” 

To his credit, the policeman seemed unfazed by Hisashi’s yelling. “Sir, you said you saw your brother an hour ago. That is not long enough for him to be considered missing.”

“Well, where else would he be?” Hisashi gestured around the place angrily. “It’s not like he’s-” His eyes locked on Yoichi’s.

Yoichi resisted the urge to hide behind his two new friends. Hisashi’s face was flushed with anger, making him look eerily like the Demon King.

“What were you thinking?” Hisashi said, stalking towards Yoichi. He grabbed Yoichi roughly by the arm and started dragging him back to the house. “You could have been hurt. Or kidnapped! Or even dead!”

Yoichi struggled against his brother’s hold. “I was only three blocks away!”

“You still should have told me!”

“Well, you looked too busy!”

The policeman stepped forward, his expression concerned. “Sir, you still-”

Hisashi turned to glare at him. “I don’t care.” Then he turned back to Yoichi, face still hard. “If you’re going to run away everytime I’m looking somewhere else, maybe you shouldn’t be trusted alone anymore.”

“But I-”

“No buts. You’re staying home for the rest of the summer.” Hisashi pulled the door open and shoved Yoichi inside.

Just as the door was about to close Yoichi looked out and saw Nichigo and Mitsuo waving at him. He barely made out Nichigo mouthing ‘meet you later,’ before the door closed.

Yoichi settled against the wall as Hisashi launched into a lecture about the dangers of the outside world. Despite his imminent grounding, Yoichi didn’t feel too bummed.

 He had a feeling he would not be stuck inside for long.
<<EOFANFIC>>

prompt: write a story about Haikyuu!!,  Teen And Up Audiences Major Character Death Gen 僕のヒーローアカデミア | Boku no Hero Academia | My Hero Academia (Anime & Manga) Bakugou Katsuki & Kirishima Eijirou Bakugou Katsuki & Todoroki Shouto Bakugou Katsuki Kirishima Eijirou Todoroki Shouto Angst Depressing Letters Goodbyes POV First Person cause you know it's a letter this made me cry ngl
completion:
Chapter Text
Um, I’m not sure how to start this honestly. I’m not sure what I should even say. You know me and you know I’ve never been one for emotions, but, I just–you deserve something more than the shitty goodbye I’m bound to give you so here this is.Hey Shitty Hair, you must be pretty happy that I’m gone huh? Okay, that was pretty rude of me. I know you must be bawling your eyes out, throwing up on the floor missing me but you can cool it. You’ll see me in, like, sixty more years. When I see you again, you better have had five kids with Mina and triple the grandkids. I want them all to know about me too. Me ‘n Deku, of course. I want you to tell them about us. About how their favorite uncle and how amazing I was.I know you already have two now and I’m sorry I never got to actually be around them. I missed out a lot with my depression, huh? I’m sorry. You better highlight that because I don’t say that. Ever. Deku’s the only one special enough to hear it from my mouth, and I  guess  you’re special enough to read it in my sloppy ass handwriting.I’m getting off track. Back to my point, I’m sorry I was only around your brats for a little while. Now that I’m actually dying and I know that I’ll get to see Deku, I’m at peace. I know that I’ve been myself lately and that I’ve actually got to hang out with everyone’s brats, but that doesn’t make up for the time I lost and will miss out on. You know, when I was in the midst of my depression, I’d have my highs and lows, but during my highs, I’d sometimes daydream. Don’t you tell a soul what I’m about to tell you, but… I wanted our kids to be friends. Best friends. Your’s and Mina’s and mine and Deku’s. We could’ve adopted or something, but regardless, I wanted us to raise ‘em together, you know? Back in high school, briefly–the briefest conversation we’ve ever had–Deku brought up kids. He asked if I ever wanted any and I told him I’d be a horrible father, but it got me thinking that night. A life with kids and a husband? As if. But I wanted it.I could’ve maybe had it if I moved on, but I couldn’t. I don’t know why and it was unnatural this love I have for him, but I’m okay with that. I’m just sorry you’re getting hurt in the process.I will tell you that I was happy sometimes. Genuinely. Rarely, but it happened. Your wedding was one of them. When you asked me to be your best man, I panicked you know. You, you fucker, decided to get married right out of high school basically right when everything was fresh as can be. It was so hard to keep my mask up then, but… when that Sparky fucker threw that bachelor party, I’ll concede justly  slightly  that it was fun. It got me to really smile, but it was being your best man during your wedding that made me happy.Yeah, I was also very depressed, but when I saw your face as Mina was coming down the aisle, I got to forget, you know? I told myself that this was your day. I didn’t need to be locked in my head for that and that I needed to be there for you.You know my infamous speech that I said I’ve had prepared since we were fifteen? I lied. Sorry you had to hear it from a dead guy but I totally lied. I spent so many nights wondering what the fuck I was going to say, but when I saw how you looked at her, I just knew. That was one of the few times I was honest with anyone. I know you got it fucking recorded somewhere too and probably are going to go back and watch it with Pinky the moment you get through reading this, so just know I fucking  owned  that bitch.Anyway, I just wanna say, thanks, Kiri. You… you really were the best friend a guy could have. You were there even when I pushed everyone away. You were so stubborn and you kept my head above water when I would’ve sunk years ago. I–I know that you’re going to hurt and that I hurt you but thank you for loving me. I love you too, you know. I’ve always been a single child, but you were the closest thing to a brother I could get. If I ever had a wedding, you’d be the best man, never doubt. If I actually had children, you’d be the godfather. I’m sorry I wasn’t godfather material for yours. That was probably for the better, though. I am certainly not father material. Couldn’t even keep myself alive. Heh. Get it?No? Okay.I guess I better get to writing the others’ letters. You fuckers are a lot, you know and I don’t mean in your hovering. We were a fucking big friend group and I know every one of you fuckers is expecting a letter even if I did push you away. Sparky would have a mental breakdown if he didn’t get one.I love you, Kiri. You were my brother and my friend. I’ll see you in sixty. Sincerely, Your best bro, KatsukiP.S. I want a kid named after me.
<<EOFANFIC>>
