completion: Hitoshi stepped off the bus onto the hot sidewalk of the little town. He hiked his small backpack up on his shoulder more, wincing as it dug into a still fresh bruise. He was finally free, well as free as he could be for the moment. The sun beat down on him as he walked down the quiet main street, his stomach growling in hunger. It'd been three days since he'd been able to eat and his head was starting to spin with exhaustion. Three days of looking over his shoulder and moving as quickly as he could.A cozy little diner was up ahead and he decided he could spare a little bit of his small stash to get something substantial to eat. Maybe someone there would know where he could get a job too. The bell over the door let out a cheerful little chime as he walked in. A black haired boy was wiping down the counter and he looked up at the noise, smiling cheerfully."Hello there! Welcome to Sunny Side Up! Take a seat and I'll be right with you!"Hitoshi slid into a booth, glancing around at the few others in the diner, mostly older couples out getting an early lunch. He plopped his backpack on the seat next to him. The black haired boy bustled over with a menu, flopping it on the table."I'm Sero! I'll be your waiter, can i start you off with any water or coffee?""Coffee please." Hitoshi mumbled, glancing at the menu."Sure thing! I'll be right back with that!" Then Sero was gone again, happily bustling around checking in on the other tables as he went.Hitoshi let out a long sigh, letting the tension in his shoulders ease a bit. It was alright, no one here would be able to tell he was a runaway. No one would care enough to send him back. He was 18 now. It was fine. A steaming cup of coffee was set in front of him and the warm, rich smelling steam was enough to make him want to cry."Here you go! Are you ready to order?" Sero asked, smiling brightly."I'll have the Country Side omlet."Sero scribbled on his notepad. "That'll be right out! Anything else I can do for ya?"Hitoshi swallowed down his nerves. "I'm kinda new in town and I'm looking for work. Do you know of anyone hiring and a cheap place to stay?"Sero frowned in concentration. "Hmmm, I've got a friend who could really use a helping hand right now. He's got a ranch and is having a rough go of it with fixing things up lately. He's not real big on accepting help, but you could try. And if that doesn't pan out you can come on back here, I could probably find something around the diner you could do, though the ranch will pay better. I'll write down the directions for you. We've got a nice cheap hotel just down the road too, though the rooms are crap if I do say so myself."Hitoshi shrugged. "Anything is fine as long as it's got a roof." Anywhere as long as it wasn't there.Sero tapped his pen on his paper. "Alrighty, I'll go get this for you and write down that info."Hitoshi took a long sip of his coffee as he leaned back in the booth. It was almost comfortable enough to fall asleep. He must have ended up actually dozing because he snapped awake to the clink of a plate being placed on the table in front of him. The delicious smell of cheese and mushrooms hit his nose, as well as the hashbrowns and sausage. Sero tucked a piece of paper under the corner of the plate."There ya go, man. I hope it helps. The bill's there too, $14.45.""Thanks." Hitoshi mumbled, trying to give a small smile. Sero went back to his work and Hitoshi tucked into the food. It was delicious, one of the best meals he'd ever eaten and he forced himself to eat every bite even as his stomach protested the onslaught of food. After he had finished he dropped some money on the table with the bill, gathered his back pack and the slip of paper with the directions, and headed back out into the warm day. The walk down the rest of the main street was pleasant and he slowly made his way out of town onto the gravel roads of the countryside, stopping occasionally to check that he was still on the right track according to the directions Sero had given him. Finally a long dirt driveway came into view, picket fences and pastures lining the sides. The breeze kicked dust up into swirls as he continued down the long lane. A red barn and a sprawling ranch house greeted him at the end. Clanging came from the barn, so Hitoshi nervously peeked in there.A spikey haired blonde was banging a hammer onto a bent gate pipe, trying to get it to go back into place. A steady stream of curses accompanied the ringing of metal on metal. Hitoshi gulped. This was probably the worst time he could have picked to stop. He stepped backwards, going to leave and tripped over something, falling flat on his back with a surprised yell. The blonde's head snapped up, crimson eyes narrowing in anger as he shoved the gate against a wall."Who the hell are you and what the fuck are you doing on my property?"Hitoshi had sat up, and flinched back in fear at the harsh tone, flashes of screaming and fists and blood running through his mind. There was a loud indignant meow and a calico cat flopped into his lap. He stared down at the creature dumbly. So that's what he had tripped over."HEY, dumbass I was talking to you!" The blonde stomped over, glaring down at him.Hitoshi forced his tongue to make words even though it wanted to give out on him. "I- I was told at the diner in town that you might be hiring so I walked out here to ask if you had an application or anything, but I see y-you're busy so-so I-I'll just go."The blonde sighed, red hot anger seeming to deflate into mold annoyance. "Damn it Sero, couldn't even give me a heads up. Alright, what's your name? Unless you want me to just call you dumbass.""Sh-Shinsou Hitoshi, sir." Hitoshi whispered, scrambling to his feet and dumping the cat off his lap, who let out a yowl of protest."Cut it out with the sir shit. The name's Bakugou Katsuki. Can't believe you actually walked all the way out here. You really are a dumbass. You stay right there. I'll be right back. Don't touch anything."The blonde walked away, sitting on a hay bale and pulling out his cellphone angrily punching in a number. Hitoshi stood there awkwardly, petting the cat as she rubbed against his leg."What do you think you're doing dunce face sending extras out here?!" Bakugou growled, not even bothering to try and be quiet. Hitoshi gulped, ducking his head. He shouldn't have come here, he shouldn't have bothered the man. There was a long pause as Sero presumably said something. Bakugou let out a loud sigh. "You and your bleeding heart for strays. Fine. Whatever, I'll give him a chance but you owe me one." The phone was stuffed back in a pocket as the blonde slouched back over."Be here at five tomorrow morning. We got shit to do, I'll give you a shot but if you slack off I've got no problem kicking your ass right back into town."Hitoshi nodded quickly, biting his lip and rolling the piercing there with his tongue. Bakugou gave him a feral grin. "You're gonna be so sore tomorrow you're not going to be able to move, pretty boy. Get a good night's rest. You're gonna need it."And with that ominous sentence, Hitoshi was hired as a ranch hand for Dynamight Ranch.<<EOFANFIC>>

completion:
A normal day for Tsukauchi Jin starts with a call from her younger brother, Kyoya, who lives in America. He tells her about his day while he gets ready for bed and she prepares for school. She tries to ignore the trembling of her hands that comes with just thinking of the awful institution. Jin doesn't speak during the call, rarely does she voice anything at all nowadays. Kyoya never seems to mind, well aware of the reasons, he knows his sister will listen no matter what he talks about. She’s proven she cares for him without a shadow of doubt. Once Kyoya bids her goodbye, Jin will proceed to quietly leave the house. More often than not she’s successful at not disturbing the other residents of the house, Haruhi especially hates seeing her face so early in the morning. On the rare occasions that she  is  caught, well, it certainly isn't pleasant. If she’s particularly lucky she’ll just be lectured and receive a smack to the back of her head. One unfortunate incident lead to her being kneed in the stomach and thrown out the door. Today is a good day, it seems, after checking to make sure everything is prepared for the day, she glances in the mirror to make sure any wounds on her body are hidden. She tries not to look at herself too much; finds her appearance to be vaguely disturbing, her eyes in particular cause disgust to rise in her gut. They look dead, completely dull, unable to catch any light, unless her quirk is in use, and the unsettling spiral pupils she inherited from her mother. The murky brown color is just about the only thing she likes about them, being so much like her fathers. She knows for a fact that people hate to look into her eyes just as much as they despise hearing her voice.  Her thigh high socks cover the bruises on her legs, and the school sweater hides any marks on her arms. The mask that covers the lower half of her face keeps her split lip from the view of curious eyes,  no need to drag more negative attention to the family than I already do. With the confirmation that she appears as uninteresting as possible, she grabs her school bag and tiptoes through the house and out the door, stopping for a moment to pick up her shoes to put on once she's out, unwilling to test her luck and potentially get caught. Very gently she shuts the door, listening for the soft click before she’s moving away, quickly shoving her feet into brown school issued loafers. A chirp draws her attention to her phone, catching her uncle's name on the screen. Jin’s lips pull into a tiny smile, Tsukauchi Naomosa is one of the few adults the ten year old trusts, followed closely by the underground hero Eraserhead her personal hero, who she met the year prior. He texts her a good morning, like he does everyday, and tells Jin to be safe on her walk to school. Her uncle often says he wishes he could drive her, but his hours don't allow it.  It’s a nice thought, but unnecessary the school is only a thirty minute walk, and she carries a taser on the off chance she’ll need to protect herself. She breathes slowly through her nose in an effort to settle the nerves that rattle her body. Jin hates feeling so fearful of her peers, helpless in the situations she finds herself in during school hours. The brunette has long since accepted that children are cruel and ruthless, they’ll tear you down any chance they get in an effort to feel better about themselves. Unfortunately they find Jin lacking in most areas, her quirk though, seems to get the brute of their scorn. They call it villainous, not just the children, but the adults too. Jin wishes she could hate her quirk, it’s caused so many problems in her life and guaranteed to bring more. She just can't find it in herself to hate something that she’ll have to live with her whole life. People can spit at her and her quirk all they like, but she’ll cherish these pieces of herself, quietly, and alone. The young girl can feel the wary hostility directed towards her as soon as she steps through the gates of the school. She hastens her steps towards the classroom, thankful that no one stops her. The desk she frequents is, unsurprisingly, covered in slurs, insults, and inappropriate doodles as it usually is. Jin is well aware that her classmates hate her, that they find her disgusting, a waste of life so she’s been told. On her darker days she’s inclined to agree. Regardless, Jin quickly gets to work cleaning, resolutely not reading anything that might be written on the wooden surface; it wouldn’t do well to bring herself down so early in the day, her peers will do that for her. She buries the hot bubbling monster deep in her heart, encouraging a familiar numbness to take hold of her person. The empty pit in her chest comes easier the more she uses it. The strange floaty feeling that follows is a pleasant reprieve from the heavy feelings she carries with her, disconcerting though it may be when she eventually comes back to herself. It’s almost like an out of body experience, going through the motions of a normal day, while feeling like it's another person in control of her body. Jin ignores the stares of her peers, ignores the malicious whispers around her, ignores the spit balls and crumpled papers that are thrown at her, all the leers, sneers, and jeers.  It’s not happening to me, I’m  not here, Jin doesn’t exist … the teachers of course don't acknowledge the bullying, they never do. She’s just glad she doesn't get beat up, the school is very strict about that, physical bullying wasn't allowed, nor was quirk usage, that’s where they draw the line. By lunch Jin feels ready to leave, she hates this place.  Quite honestly, Jin would have preferred to be ignored. It certainly would have made actually learning while in the classroom possible, but she can’t find it in herself to be mentally present during school hours.  Mechanically, she climbs the steps upwards to access the roof, intending to eat the melon pan she had purchased from a vending machine. She’s always the only one up there, no one willing to put up with her presence. She's grateful for that. She turns to look over her shoulder, back pressed against the fencing that borders the ledges, taking in the vibrant colors of the city, slowly eating her snack and allows her mind to wonder. Eyes drawn to the three story drop, she idly considers her prospects.  Not worth it. The gentle chiming of the school bell signals for the end of lunch. She sighs quietly through her nose, knowing and dreading that she’ll have to leave this little safe haven and return to bleak reality. Pursed lips hidden behind a sick mask, she resigns herself to the next few hours of torture, reaching one more for the yawning pit that swallows her soul, however temporary it may be.  
 One day…one day life will be worth living, I just have to have hope.  
 <<EOFANFIC>>

Licks of blue flame hiss up his arms and he relishes in the stinging numbness of his quirk, in the dull strain of his staples protesting against the half-grin crawling across his lips. Soon the room fills with thick smoke and the crying of the fire alarms.Not once, from the moment Hawks carved open a man about to gouge out Dabi’s eyes to them splitting ways in the fading light of the setting sun, does the hero let go of his feather made into a killing weapon.A week and a half later, Dabi still thinks of how Hawks’ feather sunk into the man’s chest, smooth as silk, and ripped back out in one powerful slash made all the worse by the feather’s natural serrated edge. Flesh and bone surrendered with unnatural ease to the inflicted brutality. How does it feel when that red knife tears through skin and muscle? How does it feel when the bone cracks, when the blood spills, when the soft organs are rent open by a symbol that promises false security to a willfully blind mass of civilians clinging to their ill-gotten happy lie of a society?Dabi still thinks of those feathers, those wings the next time he dials Hawks’ number from another payphone with its rusting privacy walls dented by some harsh blow lost to the past. He still thinks of them as he snags the day’s meal from a tiny anonymous restaurant where the guests and staff never need to see the tangible proof of each other’s existence beyond the exchange of cold cash for hot noodles.He thinks of them and their scarlet violence the next time he and the hero meet up on the roof of a condemned apartment building long abandoned by its landlord and tenants after the final destructive fight slamming against its walls that proved too much.For reasons Dabi refuses to linger on, Dr. Ujiko’s preying on small-time criminals and the scum of society no one cares about for his experiments leaves a bad taste in Dabi’s mouth. The noumu aren’t his only options for his path forward on his revenge, so he feels little issue in sending Hawks hunting after biker gangs and underground fight rings under the pretense of asserting the League’s dominance over their competition in the criminal world. When Dabi shoves Hawks in the direction of shutting down a sex trafficking ring dressed up as another hostess club, it’s just the prudent destruction of a lucrative source of income for a rival gang mired in plenty of other strains of humanity’s filth. It’s business, pure and simple, no matter how Hawks may playfully tilt his head at an angle a little too wild for domestic society and his piercing eyes may pick at the loose chinks in Dabi’s armor.The hero doesn’t need to know about the times Dabi trails in his wake, a ghost of ash, and watches the darting flashes of red. He doesn’t need to know about Dabi running his thumb over the deep groves gouged into walls and trees from feathers pinning targets in place and unable to run. He doesn’t need to know about Dabi picking idly at a loosening staple and imagining the soft whisper of a thin red feather wriggling its way under the metal and flicking it loose.He doesn’t need to know, but it seems the spy is too good at his job, to Dabi’s grudging annoyance and respect. There aren’t many other explanations for the smirk dragging the rest of the hero’s facial features along as Hawks flexes his crimson wings and knows that Dabi can’t tear his eyes away, like any other of the hero’s dozens of insipid fans.One evening, as Dabi greedily takes up the hero’s time when they’re both fully aware of the day packed with events looming for Hawks at the arrival of dawn, Hawks says, “You’re not the first person that wants to touch my wings.”Dabi ignores him in favor of the bowl of chicken katsudon in his hands. Going by the fried vegetables and egg thrown in and the fact that the rice doesn’t make up almost all of the bowl, Hawks must have bought their dinners from a more upstanding restaurant than Dabi can ever set foot in. It’s some of the best food he’s had in a while and against the December chill, the warmth of the fried chicken settling in his gut isn’t that aggravating.He can’t ignore the wingtip that suddenly flicks over his left arm.“Anyone ever tell you that you can be pretty singleminded?” asks Hawks with a laugh.Yes, Dabi doesn’t tell him. Instead, he says, “Don’t lump me in with your groupies.”Hawks laughs harder, his head tipping back, the lines of his neck on clear display. Dabi shoves more rice into his mouth, the sauce’s tang only a muted memory to his burned tastebuds. The wing that broke his concentration twitches back into place at Hawks’ back. “Of course, of course,” Hawks says, the teasing blatant. “Fanclubs aren’t really your scene.”Then when Dabi sets down his now empty bowl, Hawks leans in, eyes too sharp in the hazy dimness of the city at night. His predatory smile promises nothing good as it drags a carving knife at Dabi’s defenses. The light flush Dabi can barely see dusting the hero’s ears and nose from the cold does nothing to diminish the threat.“Well? Are you going to try?” In defiance of the distant call of an emergency vehicle’s siren, the susurrating murmur of Hawks’ wings shifting in display clearly reaches Dabi’s ears.Dabi never did waste his time acquiring a camera. He doesn’t need to, when the image of red feathers against a starkly blue sky is already pressed firmly into his mind. He doesn’t need a photograph to recreate the memory of thick red pooling in the wake of the hero’s capacity for deadly violence. No film strip will ever substitute for the sensation of warm, impossibly sharp keratin picking his seams like a tailor ripping out the mistakes of his existence. He doesn’t need photographic evidence of the way Hawks can peel him apart with his feathers.Unbidden, he remembers the tortured phantom of his mother and her encyclopedic knowledge of flowers. Of an afternoon spent luring his younger brother away from a destructive boredom with pictures and soft words of deceptively ornamental flowers deadly to the touch.He doesn’t indulge the government spy’s taunting challenge. Not this time.<<EOFANFIC>>

completion:
Katsuki had always seen people. Well, not necessarily always, but for the majority of his life he'd seen them. Migi had been with him the longest.   By seeing people, he meant people no one else seemed to see. They were real though, everything pointed to them being normal.  Except the ghost-like inability to affect the living world.  Katsuki didn't dare tell anyone about it, he'd mentioned as a kid a few times and he was told to stop believing in imaginary friends.  So it was his little secret.  "Hey 'Tsuki! Let's go on an adventure!" He heard Migi say. He let his gaze shift over to wear the boy sat.  'No talk in class' He tapped out on his desk. 'Lunch'.  The boy nodded with a pout, but decided on something that had his pout morphing into a smug smirk. Katsuki sighed, watching the boy jump up to stand on top of his teacher's desk.  He'd watched the boy preform these acts many times, it had taken practice and lots of mistakes for them both to figure out how to handle the 'tricks'.  Katsuki used to tell the boy not to, but that had caused many unwanted attentions over the time it took to retrain himself to keep silent. Migi, on the other hand, had spent much time on learning how to do various different actions.  The boy couldn't really get hurt, they'd found out. Migi had thought he was real for a long time, but the whole 'can't interact with anything' thing really set it in stone that he wasn't.  They'd then moved onto the theory that Migi was a ghost. They'd searched for years before abandoning the idea. There was no way to figure it out.  So he sat there and watched as the boy practiced backflips from his teacher's desk.  "Bakugou? What are you looking at?" He blinked, gaze quickly moving away from Migi. "Nothing, just bored" "Me too" He heard Migi complain. "I'll go look around the school! I'll be back!" As much as he didn't want to, he shifted to once again watch Migi. The boy patiently waited for someone to walk in or out of the classroom to slip out the door. No one did and he could tell the boy was getting antsy.  "I'm gonna go to the bathroom" Katsuki casually announced as he stood. His teacher was asleep, having given the simple instructions to 'complete unfinished work', so he didn't need to formally ask.  Migi beamed at him, hopping from foot to foot as he waited for him to near. When he left the room, lingering for a moment to let Migi go first, Katsuki let out a sigh.  "If you're not back by lunch, I'm leaving your ass here forever" "My big brother; my loving, caring, bestest friend. You'd never do that. You love me this much" The boy spread his arms out with a bright, cheeky smile.  "I'd leave your ass here in two seconds, don't kid yourself" The pout was back. "Fine! I'll be back by lunchtime. Not like I can do anything anyways" "Migi?" Katsuki said as the boy turned to leave. "I'll find a way to make you real, I promise" The boy simply shrugged. "I know" When Migi skipped away down the hallway, Katsuki found himself feeling bad. It'd been years and no matter how much research they put into it, there wasn't even a shred of hint as to if they could make Migi real.  He knew the boy had given up, all hope gone long ago. It was obvious but Migi pretended to be just as hopeful as he'd first been.  "It's okay" Katsuki looked over. "I'll keep an eye on him" "Where have you been?" He asked. Iya, the middle aged woman who always took care of them, smiled at him.  
"I had to find Jin, they ran off last night to visit the library"
 He huffed, "And? You left them there?"They'll
"They'll be fine, they're gonna stay nearby the campus now"
 "But..." Iya leant over to smooth her skirt. It was a habit if hers. She couldn't change clothing, but she couldn't dirty it either. She complimented the ability a few times.  
"Nana's around"
 With that said, he nodded. She gave a mock salute and left to locate Migi. She had joined him not long after Migi, promising to always be there and watch over them. Nana came during middle school, Jin having joined his posse within the last year.  Jin was different, though. Jin was real. He didn't know how, but they could also see and communicate with Nana, Iya, and Migi.  When he returned to class, having given enough time to have actually pretended to go to the bathroom, the room was quiet.  Too quiet.  In his seat sat a young man; late teens, early twenties, Katsuki never bothered to ask.  "I tried to stop them, I'm sorry" Nana stood nearby. The window was open.  "Jin, what the fuck are you doing?" Katsuki asked, his eyes narrowed at the obvious intruder. "How'd you get past the gate?" "That's a dumb question. Where's Migi? I have something for him" He pulled Jin up and out of his seat, leading him to the classroom exit.  "He's around, come back later" Katsuki pushed them out it the classroom, beginning to close the door. "As in 'never' right? It's important" The door he'd been closing halted. "Then..." Jin gave a serious nod. "I found something" He turned to glance at his classmates, then to Nana. She had a grim look, her lips pressed together tightly.  
"We found him. We found who he was"
 Katsuki could only let out an 'oh'. This was both amazing news and a horrible realization that he couldn't make the boy real. There was no way to tell how Migi would act.  He looked from Nana to Jin a few times before sighing. "Fine, go find 'im. Should I come?" Nana shook her head. "I think it would be easier if we went" With a barely noticeable nod, Katsuki moved aside for Nana to pass through the doorway. Once she'd crossed the threshold, he closed the door.  "Bakugou, are..." He turned, his teacher was staring at him with his lips pulled tight, eyebrows furrowed. "Are you schizophrenic?" "Hah?" Katsuki blanched. "I'm not a schizophrenic! They're just..." "Invisible?" Hagakure quietly voiced. "Can you see them? Can you see me?" He kept quiet, he'd never found an explanation as for how he could see Migi and the others. It wouldn't make sense to just say he saw ghosts without it being a quirk. Unless he had a second, undiagnosed quirk...  He couldn't see Hagakure, though, so he shook his head. "It's different, but I don't have schizophrenia" "How long have you seen them?" Aizawa pressed, seeming to ignore Katsuki's firm disagreement on being schizophrenic.  "Forever, I guess" His eyes widened as he thought about it. His stomach twisted. Migi might not be a real... No. No, he could see Nana, he knew who she was. Jin could see them too. He had to word this better.  "I can see Nana Shimura, I'm not schizophrenic" He finally said, pushing back the small voice in his head that whispered that there was no proof of Iya being real.  Jin found something about Migi, and he knew for a fact that Nana had been a real person. Who was Iya? Was Iya a hallucination?  No, she just hadn't been found yet, just like how he searched for Migi's true identity.  They were ghosts. Souls that remained here to walk alongside the living.  "I can see ghosts" He finally said. "I don't think it's a quirk, I've always been able to see them" "Did you have a near death experience? Or maybe you actually did die for a few minutes. You could be a half ghost" Katsuki eyed Ojiro. "That sounds stupid" "No! It would make sense! If it isn't a quirk, then you've probably died" Ashido burst in. Katsuki sighed. He'd ask his mother after school.  What a pain, why couldn't Jin have waited until he left? Katsuki didn't want to spend centuries talking about his ability to see the dead.  So annoying. <<EOFANFIC>>

completion: The battle is wearing them thin. Every last student, every last hero, fighting tooth and nail, right down to the very bone and even beyond, all to corner All For One in this one final moment.The moment they will cinch victory.His face was handsome, once upon a time, as they can so clearly see now with the effects of the rewinding serum beginning to wane, fading to what must be over a century this monster’s junior.“It’s over,” Izuku snarls, upper lip curling in disgust. He is bloody and damaged, but his limbs are whole. He has enough power to pound this monster’s face back into dust as his mentor did before him.This time, Izuku will succeed.With his family, his friends, the people he loves most at his side, Izuku can achieve anything. Anything.The fight with All For One alone, however, is disturbingly lacklustre. Without the centuries of quirks at his behest, he puts up no fight against the might of One for All and the quirks within it. In fact—“Surrender!” the man begs, pleads, wails, hands trembling as they climb to the sky. It isn’t a demand for them. It’s his own. “I – I surrender. You wouldn’t begrudge an old man his last surrender, would you?”There is only an instant, a microsecond, fleeting, painful, where Izuku suspects it to be a trap. Then there is a second where he considers it to be truth. He knows which of the two is more debilitating. Izuku vowed to protect. To save.“All I wanted—” the man coughs, choking on his own blood and spluttering it into the ground. At his back, his friends hesitate.He leads the charge in more ways than one. When he moves, they move.“I wanted knowledge.” It’s whispered like a prayer. Like something to be revered, like gold or something greater, like a gift freely given. “You know what that’s like, don’t you?”And he reaches for Izuku, slow, shaky, hand fisting in the material of his suit before Izuku kicks the man’s hand off of him, baring his teeth, snarling.“I know what that’s like?” Izuku repeats furiously. “We – we are nothing alike.”And his rejection makes the man, the monster, falter, expression breaking into something far stronger than simply grief.“But you understand,” he begs, barely above a whisper. “I was wrong, before. You are the only one who could understand. All of those people, they didn’t know what they had, ande I wanted only to understand it. That’s all. Why was that a crime?”“It was a crime because you killed people,” Izuku’s voice shakes, but he is unwavering. He will not be moved on this. “It wasn’t knowledge you wanted. It was power, and don’t pretend otherwise, All for One.”His eyes are big, shining with tears beneath the blood trickling down his face, swimming too in the crimson pools of his iris. He reaches for Izuku again.He doesn’t stop reaching for Izuku.“That’s what the saying is, isn’t it?” All For One pleads with him. “Knowledge is power, knowledge is power. When I was your age, I feared them, the Commission, and what they would do with my brother if they found out I was a meta. I was only protecting him. You understand that, right?”“You weren’t protecting him,” Izuku hisses. “You were the one that killed him. He died by your hand.”And the monster’s face hardens, and he rises again, slow, careful, from the ground, watching Izuku with something that he can’t read beneath it. It’s not fear, it’s not anger, it’s not a plea, it’s not victory, it’s not defeat, it’s something that Izuku is not quite ready to name.Something he’s not willing to.“The Commission,” and All for One spits the title like it has offended him more than Izuku’s existence does, more than his possession of the quirk he holds so dear. “Has always been a stain on our society. Since I was a child. Since you were one.”“Our Commissions differed by many things,” Izuku says darkly, finaly losing patience and reaching out with Blackwhip in a quick, well controlled movement that startles half of his friends.“They’re united now,” All For One struggles beneath his binds, but he never once looks away from Izuku even as he’s closing in. “They had a motto when I was a child. I never forgot it, even to this day.”“Knowledge is power?” Izuku scorns, turning back to his friends and giving a short, sharp nod, beckoning them over with a single hand and stepping forwards. “It’s over, All For One.”Before his foot hits the ground— “Scientia Potestast Es.” There is nothing beneath Izuku’s feet. He feels as though he is falling, but he is fastened securely in place. There is a box around him, and Izuku cannot see it, he cannot touch it, he cannot feel it, he cannot break it. There is a box around him. “Knowledge is power,” All For One whispers. He is not bound by Blackwhip. His hands are free. “Orders not found.”The voice is clinical. It is not Izuku’s voice. “Awaiting orders.” “He has a brainwashing quirk—” someone screams. The Izuku that still exists somewhere in this tiny box recognises that it’s Jirou’s scream. “Do you recognise me, child?” His eyes flicker. He scans the handler. His reply is monotone, standing at attention. “Handler not recognised. Authorisation code required.”“Omega-nine-four-tango-six-two-hotel.” A blink. A code of the highest order. The soldier affirms the code. “Awaiting instruction.” A sigh. The potential handler shakes his head, and his hand finds it’s way to yank at the soldier's chin, forcing it's gaze to meet the handler's. “I am so glad they kept this,” the handler says. There are still screams at his side. Someone attacks the potential handler, but he does not scream. The soldier and his handler are protected. “It took so little convincing to take on the quirkless' training too... activate the Bellona protocol.” “Authenticate.” His handler laughs, and it is fond, spinning him in place so that the soldier’s back is to his handler. They are surrounded by hostiles. Two dozen, at the soldier’s count. They are all in various states ofinjury. “Three-one-three-five-two-Foxtrot-three-zero-three-seven.” His handler whispers in his ear something quieter, not a code, not a string that the soldier accepts as new instruction, but merely a comment. “You and my brother share a birthday, you know.” The soldier’s heart pumps even and strong. “Deku!” one of the hostiles screams. The soldier recognises the word. It means useless. The soldier is not useless. “Authenticated.”  “No mercy,” the handler whispers this time. This time, it is an order. “Kill.”  It is not programmed to hesitate. The Izuku that exists in a tiny, claustrophobic glass box, suffocating in his own screams, begs the soldier to hesitate.                   It does not.<<EOFANFIC>>

completion:
Chapter Text

Aizawa Shouta liked to think he was a decent hero. Now, that being said, he wasn’t anything special. He went out, and did his best to save people in need. That was it really. He had wanted to be a hero his whole life, even when he was told he would never be anything but a villain. Some could say he became a hero purely out of spite, to prove all those people wrong, and he couldn’t exactly say they were wrong.

Aizawa had been through many situations where he genuinely considered giving up being a hero for good, however, every time those thoughts would enter his head, along would come a particularly special case that would remind him why he wanted to be a hero in the first place. Looking back on it, this was probably the time that would motivate him to continue being a hero through the trying times that would surely come after.

His night patrol had started off well, it always did when he followed his routine. Get home from teaching. Snuggle with the cats while grading homework. Eating dinner with Hizashi. Cuddling with Hizashi as his husband read one of his English books, and he read the news while listening to music. Getting ready for patrol. Promising Hizashi he would be safe and come home. Giving Hizashi a kiss. Leaving. Hopping rooftops. All down to the routine. Routines were good. Stable. 

However, his routine would be quickly changing.
 
“Fuck!” Cried the villain as Shouta slammed his knee into the guy’s head, having him caught up in the capture weapon. The offender hit the ground like a sack of bricks, out like a light. Shouta made quick work of tying the guy up and notifying the police of his capture. As he sent off the alert however, there was a noise in the darkest corner of the alley he had just finished the fight in. Immediately alert and ready to fight, he gripped his capture weapon and activated his quirk, slowly making his way towards the noise. As he got closer, all of a sudden, there was a young and terrified voice crying out, “Stop! Please! D-don’t come any closer!”

A child? “Hello?” Shouta called out to the darkness. As he did so, a small boy with violet hair peaked out into the light of the nearest street lamp. The boy was covered in filth, dirt covering most of his features, and clothes run ragged. Shouta couldn’t tell exactly how old this kid was, but if he had to guess, he would say maybe around 7? Maybe 8?

“Hey kid, are you okay? What are you doing here?” Shouta asked as softly as he could, not being able to entirely cut out the gruffness of his voice however. The kid looked him up and down, almost like he was examining the hero.

“You’re a hero.” The kid stated, hesitance written all across his face. 

“Yes? I’m a hero, although you might not have heard of me. I work underground.” Shouta confirmed, trying to ease the boy’s nerves at least somewhat.

“Eraserhead.” The boy said again, this time looking less like a terrified kitten. Shouta looked at this kid in shock, most hero’s didn’t even know who he was, much less pre-pubescent kids.

“Yeah, uh how did you know that?” Shouta asked, this time the kid had almost no hesitancy in his voice as he spoke. “My friend. He’s really smart. He likes to analyze heroes. He told me about you, to make me feel better about my quirk.”

“Is that so? What’s your quirk?” Shouta asked, curious. Immediately the kid froze and went back to looking absolutely terrified.

“None of your business!” The kid cried. Shouta raised his hands to show he meant no harm and backed up a step, trying to make the kid feel less scared.

“Hey, hey it's okay! Don’t worry alright? I don’t have to know I was just curious alright? You don’t have to tell me. I wouldn’t have really cared anyways to be honest with you.” Shouta said, being honest. He didn’t really care about what quirk the kid had. The child looked at him disbelievingly.

“Oh yeah? What if I was quirkless, huh? Would you care then?” The kid asked him, fire raging in his eyes - like he was challenging Shouta. Challenge accepted fluffy.

“Not in the least. Quirks are tools. They don’t make a person.” Shouta stated blatantly. The kid looked shocked for a moment, staring at him, trying to figure out if he was being honest or not.

“So. So you wouldn’t hurt a quirkless kid? You'd want to help?” Fluffy asked him, almost pleading with him. Shouta looked at him shocked for a second, before replying seriously, “I would never. Kid, are you okay? Do you need help?” Shouta knew the answer already, but he wanted the confirmation.

“Not me. My friend. He's sick I think, but he won't tell me what’s wrong with him. I don’t know how to help him…” The kid told him, trailing off. Well that’s, concerning?

“Does his parents know?” Shouta asked the kid, almost not wanting to know the answer.

“Hah, what parents?” The kid laughed without humor. Shit.

“Okay…okay can you take me to him?” Shouta asked fluffy. The kid looked up in alarm.

“NO! No, I-I promised him no heroes. Heroes won’t…they won’t help.” Fluffy said sadly. 

“Hey. Listen to me kid. I already said I don’t care about quirks right? I will never, ever hurt someone just because of a stupid thing like a quirk. I swear on my hero license, I will help your friend in any way I can alright?” Shouta said as sincerely as he could. The kid looked at him surprised again, but after a moment, slowly nodded his head. “Okay then, where’s your friend squirt?” Shouta asked him, holding out his hand for the kid to grab. The kid looked at him indignantly before shakily grabbing his hand and standing up. Now that the kid was almost completely bathed in light, Shouta saw how 

tiny 

this child was. His hands were incredibly bony, and his wrists were so thin…

“Hey kid, uh, how old are you?” Shouta asked, even more concerned. The kid ducked his head.

“10.” He stated simply. 

10? 

Jesus christ.

“Okay, okay. Okay. Uhhh, what’s your name?” Shouta asked.

“Hitoshi.” Fluffy stated, monotonous. 

“It’s nice to meet you Hitoshi, I’m Aizawa.” Shouta told him, hands still clasped together. Hitoshi nodded at him and began pulling him down the dimly lit street.

Their walk was quiet, Hitoshi pulling Shouta along like a man on a mission, and Shouta trying to figure out where the hell they were going. Soon enough, the pair reached a small abandoned shack.

“We’re here.” Hitoshi stated, immediately dropping Shouta’s hand.

“Alright, and do you live here Hitoshi?” Shouta asked, concern sky rocketing for the small boy.

“Yes.” Hitoshi said, pushing open the creaky door. However, after his eyes adjusted to the darkness, Hitoshi immediately started running as fast as he could to the middle of the small room. Shouta followed hot on his heels until he saw another small boy, even smaller than Hitoshi if that was even possible, collapsed on the floor and looked extremely pale. 

“Izuku! No Izuku, please! Wake up! No! You can’t leave me! You promised! WAKE UP!!” Hitoshi cried, shaking his friend on the floor.

“Hey, hey. Kid you need to move okay? I need to figure out what’s wrong with him.” Shouta said, gently moving Hitoshi out of the way. Hitoshi nodded, and scrambled to find the worn down lamp that was hiding in the corner. After fiddling for a second, Hitoshi managed to light the lamp, showing just how bad ‘Izuku’ looked. The kid was far too pale, his lips tinged slightly blue with a bit of blood and maybe vomit surrounding his mouth, his dark freckles contrasting greatly to the tone of his skin. Shouta immediately checked for a pulse, thanking the gods when he was able to find one. Granted, it was a weak one, but it was there. Next he checked the breathing, very labored. Then Shouta noticed how much the kid was sweating, however the child didn’t seem to have a fever. Shouta quickly started looking for any signs of a possible trauma done to the kid, however when he went to lift the kids shirt to see if there was any bruising, Hitoshi immediately scrambled up and grabbed his hand to stop him.

“DON’T TOUCH HIM! DON’T YOU DARE TOUCH HIM LIKE THAT! YOU PROMISED YOU WOULD HELP!” The kid screamed, frightening Shouta a bit. Shit - the kid thought…

“Oh god kid no! I would never! I was just checking for any signs of bruising, I promise. He’s showing signs of either a severe fever or internal bleeding. I want to rule out all the worst possibilities first okay? Look, you can sit right here beside me.” Shouta said, trying to placate the kid next to him in any way he could. These poor kids, what have they gone through? Hitoshi calmed slightly, but made no move to let go of Shouta’s hand. Shouta gently pulled Izuku’s shirt up to reveal severe bruising on his abdomen.

“Shit, kid, we have to go to a hospital.” Shouta said, immediately going to stand before Hitoshi grabbed him again.

“No! You can’t, they won't treat him. They refuse service to quirkless people. They say it’s a waste of medical resources. Trust me, we tried when Izu broke his arm again.” Hitoshi told him, seething.

“Fuck…okay. Kid come with me, hop on my back. I’m going to carry your friend in my arms and I’m going to take you both to UA okay? There's a healer on staff who lives on the campus. You might know her as Recovery Girl. She will heal him, I promise.” Shouta said, urgency in his voice. Hitoshi looked scared, but quickly nodded as he saw the state his friend was in. Hitoshi jumped on his back and was quickly secured with the capture weapon - making him light to carry, even though the kid on his own weighed almost nothing. Next Shouta carefully collected the second kid into his arms, being extremely careful of the wounds the child was sporting. Shouta then ran faster than he thought he ever had.

Oil is a very important substance, and its use dates back hundreds of years. In the 1700s it was whale oil that was used mostly, its uses ranging from making lamps to making perfumes. In 1846 kerosene oil was invented from coal, bitumen, and oil shale, making lamps and being more cost-effective than whale oil. A decade later in the 1860s crude oil was found and people drilled for it. Later in 1901, the Spindletop oil geyser was discovered, making the crude oil business boom. By the mid-1900s, it was widely used in space heating, electric power generation, and transportation fuels. Oil is truly amazing; it made people rich and helps maintain vehicles, metal objects, and wood. Oil is truly one of the most important things on the planet. When quirks came around it became even more valuable, support Companys couldn’t get enough of it, and it was needed for hero costume maintenance. There was a reason I-island was on top of one of the best oil spots in the world.
But this story is not just about oil, it is also about a legend as old as quirks starting in the year 2104 when the self-proclaimed “old western states” decided they wanted to go back to the times of cowboys and broke off from the United States. The United States government couldn’t do much about it, since the world was in a state of panic, the quirked all over were rising against the world governments due to unfair everything. So North Dakoda, South Dakota, Nebraska, Kansas, Oklahoma, and Texas became their own nation called the “Wild states of the West” which the people to the west of them didn’t like, but they ignored that, and continued. Around that time, a man who worked at a big oil company in Texas manifested a quite powerful quirk: the ability to make any sort of liquid out of any solid. This man went to the deepest parts of the Wild West and made the purest oil deposit for the most amount of profit, but due to some poor life decisions he made a list of instructions leading right to it, instead of the more reasonable option of making a proper map, and then forgetting where the oil spot was, he decided just to sell the instructions for a high price and just give up on oil. He tried for a while to sell the guide and finally was successful with a visiting tourist from Japan.
Yoichi Shigaraki was tired from fighting his evil older brother and so decided to go on vacation to a place that was recommended to him by one of his few friends, a nice place called Texas. It was a good vacation, if not for the old man who kept following him around town, insisting he buys a guide for an oil deposit so pure he’d make millions if not billions of dollars, but Yoichi did not care, he had no use for money, and definitely not dollars from a place he’d likely never go again. The old man was getting desperate and started pushing harder for Yoichi to purchase the document, but the Japanese man did not budge. Eventually, the old man just grabbed Yoichi and spoke “Look boy, I know you care not for money, and oil but just take the paper, and keep it in good condition, I don’t care if you never look at the paper, but just take the paper, people have already heard of the oil, but they can’t find it without this paper. They don’t want the oil for any reason, but you, I can tell are a good person, so please just take the paper and keep it out of their hands.”
Yoichi looked down at the paper and looked at the man who was obviously desperate and gently took the paper from his hands and thanked the man for the paper, putting it into his pocket. Yoichi didn’t know this until he was dead, but this was the second time he ever used his original quirk, transfer. Yoichi was given a quirk from his brother that combined with his original quirk transfer to create ‘One for All’ but that was just one form of transferring. His quirk was the ability to pass down anything, from items to his power, with the extra ability for all transferred items unable to be stolen. This ability merged with the paper and made it so it could only be able to be transferred willingly.
Over time the Quirk and the paper were transferred down together for all the one for all users. Every single of the one for all users showed at least some interest in the legend apart from the first three who did not have enough time to search for something in a different country, as well as having no use for it. The one who came closest was the fourth user, Hikage Shinomori who had the most time away from Japan due to the singular fact that he thought he did not have enough power to stand toe to toe with all for one, or even survive a battle long enough to pass on the quirk, and thus had enough time to go to the new Country to make a useless search. Of course, he never found it but he got about a quarter of the way there until he started getting weaker, and that’s when he decided to go back to Japan, passing on the quirk and paper and never getting to see the oil.
Over one hundred and fifty years have passed since then with the one for all users never getting closer to the final goal, and more and more people seeking to be rich coming to the United States of the Old West, for the legend of the oil, none finding it due to the many instructions and puzzles needed to get to the final reward of the pure oil field.
The current holder of one for all is hailed as the symbol of peace and is unable to search for the oil field but a single green haired Quirkless boy is about to set in motion a series of events completely unrelated to the power of one for all, but highly related to the great oil field, and will set him to be one of the most influential people in the world.<<EOFANFIC>>

completion:
Chapter Text
Izabelle was eight when Death visited her for the first time.  She had woken in the night during a particularly miserable winter, coughs racking her small frame, for illness swooped fast and cruel through her small town, and she was one of the many children to be infected. Her death was assured, and her parents piled her bed with moth-bitten blankets and didn’t shy away from her touch as the other villagers did, because she was the only child to survive the year, and the only child they had left.  She had had siblings, once, an older brother who tickled her belly and a younger sister who would drool on her clothes. But they were gone now, stolen away in the night, by the very same sickness that clung to her skin and dulled her hair and took her voice.  He was a frigid thing, Death was, dripping in the filth of humanities beliefs and surrounding himself with baleful hovering lights of green and gold, ( souls, though she didn’t know it yet), too beautiful to be real and too cold to be kind.  Shadows danced across him, enveloping his form and dimming the blinking lights. He was every bit a figure built upon nightmares and false hope and lies, and Izabelle had held her breath as he reached past the canopy protecting her, the sheer fabric parting in a cold betrayal, and grasped her small hand in his own.  He said nothing, a voiceless apparition in the night, but cocked his head like a curious bird, and withdrew from her hold.  Death left, and Izabelle recovered the very next day. 


─────────

The second time she encountered Death was only a scant few months later.  The local stray had bitten one of her friends hands when he had gone to pet it, and she had chased the filthy thing down the street and onto the road, braver than any of her schoolmates, and filled with a vengeful wrath uncouth for her age.  Neither of them had seen the truck coming, and between one second and the next, the miserable creature was smeared across the road, and she had blood spattered across her face and new dress.  Izabelle didn't scream. She didn’t cry or throw up like any regular child would. Instead, she quietly crouched down and observed the puddle of viscera that was creeping along the pavement. It stained the hem of her pretty new dress and crusted on the soles of her shoes, but she was wholly apathetic.   She watched and she waited, with bated breath, as the blood congealed in the sun. 



He came for what was his, and did not spare her a glance. 


─────────


It became an obsession.  She started innocently enough, crushing rat skulls under her heel and snapping the necks of stoats and possums, things people wouldn’t miss.  He would come, always. Reaping what was owed to him, never acknowledging, never  noticing  her, though she would wait doggedly at his heel and breathe praises for him and him alone.  The escalation from rats to birds, and then birds to rabbits, wasn’t a conscious decision. The mice and rats disappeared from her town, their absence startling enough for the locals to pick up on, although they never complained.   Let them be hunted,  her mother said one night while tucking her into bed,  whatevers taking them can go after the magpies and rabbits too, damned vermin.   It was as much of an invitation as any.  Only when she found herself slitting the throat of her neighbour's dog did she recognize her obsession for what it was.  It didn’t change anything. But when Death appeared that dusk, draped in satin and glittering with gold, she didn’t speak. She observed him, drank in the sight of the lights that hovered around him (they had grown in number since she began, and the warm orange orb that tucked itself into his side reminded her distantly of the friendly tabby cat she had killed that spring) and carefully noticed that he stayed longer this time.  Thalia was a large dog. A boxer. Something cold nestled itself in her throat. He left all the same. 


─────────


Izabelle never got to test out her theory personally. Two weeks after her tenth birthday ( two years since their first encounter, two years since she had chased that stray to its demise, two years since she had first crushed the skull of a mouse under her boot, two years since she had taken up killing the animals just inside the treeline of the forest that surrounded her village.) (a year since she killed the tabby cat that had huddled on their doorstep for shelter) (six months since she had killed Thalia) her grandmother caught a particularly nasty case of the flu.  It shouldn’t have been as deadly as it was. But the harvest was weak that year, their neighbouring villages had withdrawn from contact and their hospital had been flooded a scant few weeks before. The medicines in Izabelle’s father’s study had disappeared along with him when he had abandoned them for a new life, outside of Whales, and away from Izabelle and her mother.  So her grandmother had struggled through roughly two weeks, degrading in front of their eyes, and passed away that spring.   Death had slipped to her bedside, invisible to Izabelle’s mourning mother, and passed a hand over her eyes. The light in the room had dimmed and the shadows deepened, fingers of darkness crawling along the walls and floor and ceiling; clamouring for the attention of Death,  her  Death, who’s glowing companions fit perfectly into the absence he created and whose silken robes melted into the dark.  He had remained with the corpse for three days and three nights, a wraith at her beck and call. Corpses didn’t speak, but he would tilt his head as if listening to something, and the tinkling of bells would brighten as if they were laughter.  The funeral was held, and Death vanished with the body when it was sealed beneath the ground.  The soul that had left with him was  beautiful.  Amber and pink and gold, swirling together like flame, and as large as young Izabelles fist. Death ran a gentle finger over its surface, and it laughed like heat and smoke.  Izabelle watched all of this with empty eyes and a longing incomparable to anything she had ever felt before. 


She slit her wrists the next morning. 

When she woke again, bandages were stark against her skin, and the scent of failure suffocating. 


─────────

In her seventeen years of life, Izabelle would attempt suicide eleven times.  Death would never come for her.  She bore witness to the fall of her village; the same sickness that had stolen her siblings reared its head once more, and took with it the crumbling foundations of her home. Her mother would die, terrified and in pain, for Death crept through closed doors and sealed windows, his misty visage imprinted behind her eyelids even as she screamed for help from a daughter who wouldn’t aid her.  She was the only one healthy, after all, and a nursemaid for the forty people who she had known all her life.  Naturally, the children went first.  Six-year-old Arvel who would have turned seven that winter, the twins from down the street, the newborn Lowri; each died in quick succession with her as their witness and Death as their kind guide.  She had helped them all she could, but Izabelle was not a saint. Death had rejected her twice now, and betrayal was bitter on her tongue. She had no time for her wailing neighbours, so she left them, marinating in their own filth, surrounded by disease so pungent she soon stopped visiting them altogether.  Those who were healthier would watch their families die; their children rot, attracted flies, decay before either very eyes. They would spy Izabelle as she passed, trapped in a hell of their own making, and scream for recompense.   Let Death take her  , they howled in the night,  let he lead her to the bowles of the Earth where she will suffer a fate like ours!   Yes,  she thought,  let him.  

He never came for her. 

When the last person of her village died—Siân, a dear friend from her youth, whoes skin shifted as the larva underneath moved and who spat vitriol at Izabelle even as her soul coiled around Death’s neck—Izabelle fashioned a noose out of rope and looped it around her neck.  The chair she climbed onto was as old as she was, and it buckled under her weight before she could right herself. The rope pulled taut, stole her breath, ripped into her throat, and— It was  agonising.   Death was not meant to see her like this— crying and thrashing, not quite dying but close enough that the edges of her vision blurred, and spots danced in front of her eyes and the world dimmed and dimmed and dimmed, till she couldn't see or hear or think, till she felt Death cup her cheeks and breath on her lips and—


The rope snapped. 

She landed on her side, heaving for breath, blood searing her hands where she pressed them against her throat. 

Death had refused her. 

And that was the last time she saw him. 


She left the village that night.  Bandages stood out against her skin, almost fluorescent in their purity, wrapped around her throat like a warning.  The hands of the past  , said the wind as its long fingers tangled in her hair,  the hands of those you condemned.  And they were. A reminder.  (Later, when the wounds would heal, the gnarly scar that painted her throat looked an awful lot like two hands encircling her throat. The coincidence wasn't lost on her, and if the phantom feeling of a rope tightening around her neck was accompanied by the pungent smell of decay, then the ghosts of her past hadn’t forgotten her either.) She followed the worn path through the woods with only the clothes on her back and the taste of Death on her tongue as company, wandered out past the beliefs of her village, the dystopia they condemned themselves too, and into a world bustling with colour and sound and taste all for the taking.  At thirteen years old, Izabelle ventured past the borders of her world. 


She would die only four years later.
<<EOFANFIC>>

completion:
Hitoshi sighs as he walks out of his favorite coffee shop, travel cup in hand. 

It’s been a long day and it’s going to be an even longer night and as such a trip to his favorite shop was warranted. 

Though perhaps he’s being too kind calling the place his favorite. The coffee itself is just bordering on decent— little more than a steady drip that sits on reheat all day long. He’s pretty sure it sits on reheat even longer than that but hasn’t been able to prove it yet. 

Honestly the only thing it has going for it is the guaranteed anonymity of patrons and the speed at which orders are filled.

And the fact that underground heroes can set up accounts there as a business expense. 

Hitoshi nods to himself and takes a long drink.

Tax Write Offs are a bitch and a half so yes this truly is the only reason he keeps coming back for the thick brown coffee-flavored sludge.

Days like today Hitoshi feels like he is literally two steps away from following a stranger home if they promised him actually good coffee.

He grimaces as he takes another sip— conjures up a lecture from Aizawa on stranger danger to dislodge the thought from his mind— and then runs through the details of his latest case instead to change the subject. 
 
A building in the more unsavory parts of town. 

Crimes take place and the police are called and… 

And by the time anyone gets down there to investigate nothing is wrong or out of place. 

Whoever has made the calls vanishes into thin air. The logs show signs of hacking, the entries and phone numbers completely erased and the suspicious apartments in question are now filled with newer tenants.
 
It’s baffling. 

Mind Boggling. 

And though people at the precinct have taken to ignoring the calls to this area now as some kind of perceived prank Hitoshi can’t shake the feeling that someone is trying to help and the authorities are simply arriving too late.
 
Voicing this theory had landed him with the case dumped solely on his lap though so honestly who is the real victim here?
 
Hitoshi is lost in thought, already planning to stake the area out once he’s officially clocked in. 
 
And that’s when a distracted blond man that looks very vaguely familiar bumps into him with enough force to knock him to the ground.

“Oh! I am so sorry! Please, let me help you!”

Hitoshi sighs, staring forlornly at his shirt and the rapidly spreading coffee stain across the entire front of it. Damn this is what he gets for wearing an actual shirt instead of his usual dark sweatshirt today.

The man before him is still waiting expectantly so he sighs again and slowly gets to his feet. “No no. It’s fine. I should have honestly expected this from today. Don’t worry about it.”

The blond is not so easily placated. 

“That makes me feel even worse! I know! I’ll get you a new drink to apologize for spilling this one on you!”

“That’s really not-”

“Nope. I’ve made up my mind. Anywhere you want.” 

Hitoshi grumbles internally as he bends to pick up the ruined cup and toss it in a nearby garbage can. He can practically 

hear

 the reluctance in this guy’s voice, why the heck is he being so pushy about this?

He decides to test it just a little. “Fine. If you insist. But it doesn’t need to be anything too special. It was really only drip coffee, so anywhere is fine.”

The blond frowns at that and Hitoshi resists the urge to throw up his hands in exasperation. This dude is weirdly familiar but Hitoshi can’t place it and that plus the guy’s weird behavior is starting to piss him off.
 
And then, the man blurts out an emphatic, “Come home with me!”

Hitoshi looks up from his attempts to wipe at his shirt and stares.

“No thanks. I’m not that kind of man.”

The stranger blanks, before frantically waving his arms, a light flush making its way up his cheeks and suddenly it clicks where Hitoshi knows him from.
 
That suspicious apartment building. 
 
This man is Kaminari Denki, one of the tenants that live there, and a quirkless one to boot.
 
“Wait no! That didn’t come out right. I mean like to have coffee. Nothing else! I wouldn’t do…Well I mean…It’s just that…”
 
With the new information now bounding through his head Hitoshi finds that he can’t resist.
 
“Relax. I’m messing with you. And if you are any good at making coffee, I’ll accept.”

Kaminari blushes furiously at that. “Alright, and I’ll have you know that I make great coffee.”

He walks off pouting and Hitoshi follows after him, chuckling to himself at the veritable boon of info his investigation is now facing.

“Lead the way, oh coffee god.”
 
***
 
“Lead the way, oh coffee god.”

Denki can’t help the flush that rises up his cheeks and quickly turns his head away.
 
He can’t believe that worked.
 
After so long of calling things in and being ignored he’d finally stumbled right into the hero that’s now in charge of the case. Literally!

Finally he’s in a position to actually fix things in this shitty building he calls home. And it doesn’t even matter that he’s quirkless!

“So welcome to my humble abode. Mi casa es tu casa.”

The hero looks around with a frown and Denki lets him as they take the stairs up to the fourth floor. Denki’s pretty sure someone got whacked here last night so the more info the guy can glean about all this the better.

“It seems a bit run down,” the hero finally says. “Are you sure it’s safe?”

Up ahead on the landing Denki grins and decides to test the waters a bit. “Of course. I haven’t gotten that beat up here yet.”

“Alright then.” 

The hero speaks slowly as if testing the words as well. “I believe you as long as you aren’t the one doing the beating up.”

Denki laughs. “Of course not. I’m quirkless after all so I could never. Besides, since I don’t make much I don’t have much, so no one messes with me since I have nothing.”

He shoots a quick glance at the hero in time to catch a short nod. His heart races in his chest. So the hero knows who he is then. That’s… good… maybe…

They reach his door and the hero pauses.

This is it. Do or die. Will the hero trust him knowing who he is? Or was this whole elaborate ruse for nothing?

“Are you coming?” he can’t keep the insecurity from his voice and the rush of relief when the hero responds is nothing short of freeing.

“Of course. You still have coffee right?”

“Um…yes?”

“Then why would I leave? Come on.”

The hero strolls past him and into the house and it’s all Denki can do to stare.

 “Come on. I’m waiting.”

He can’t actually like coffee that much can he?

Denki pushes the shock down and heads for the kitchen with a wink and a finger gun. “Right. I’ll get right on your coffee then. I promise it will be the best you’ve ever had or your money back.”

Not that he’s charging. But he’s probably keeping the hero from clocking in so does that count? Whatever, it’s coffee and save-the-building time!

Denki nods to himself as he goes to pour the grounds into the machine. He makes sure to use the best stuff he has. He also grabs his milk and sniffs it. Since it smells fine, he decides to steam some up to make foam art.

He decides to add some vanilla and draws a small Pikachu on top before sprinkling cinnamon over it all.

“Here you go! The best coffee ever. I would’ve added espresso if I had any, but sadly I’m all out. Tell me what you think.”

The hero accepts the coffee without a word, obviously trying to hide the fact he’d been snooping through the papers on Denki’s coffee table. 

Jokes on him though, Denki had actually wanted him to see it.

“This building seems pretty cheap,” the hero finally says once he’s stopped inhaling his beverage like it’s some kind of lifegiving elixir. “Know of any vacancies at the moment?”

Denki meets the hero’s eyes as he takes another sip of his coffee and it clicks. 

He knows.

She’s never lived away from home before. It’s a little bit frightening, a little bit euphoric, a little bit scary and a little bit sexy.Kyoka had never really been one to hang with the quote-unquote “in crowd” before she came to UA. In her early teens, her passions had firmly remained rooted in music – and when her love of rock suddenly fell on unfashionable ears, her drive to become a professional hero.But she had been invited to social situations here and there. One time, she had gone with a gaggle of girls, and a couple of lunkheaded – if admittedly physically pleasing – guys to a haunted house attraction at the amusements on the edge of town.Her companions had been scared witless, screaming at every little spider and silly ghost that had swung on wires around them. To her inordinate pleasure, one of the boys had been an even bigger coward too; he’d leapt around and eventually taken to grasping at her arm, trying to shrink behind her smaller frame.As experiences go, it was the only time Kyoka could recall feeling such an amalgamation of emotions surging through her – until now, at least.The lights are down, long since shuttered in the dorms, and the emotional outbursts of her classmates following their room contest – and apologies – have long since faded away. But she’s still here, staring at the ceiling, amped up and too filled with cake to even consider dropping off.Kyoka had assumed she wouldn’t move out from her parents’ nest until it had been time to get a place of her own properly in the working world. She’d been quietly apprehensive that her parents might have put up more of a fight – but both, as always, had been stridently supportive.Her phone buzzes abruptly, and she withdraws her jacks from the socket to glance up at the notification that has interrupted her tunes. She’s got a clutch of unanswered messages, but the new one is perhaps more of a surprise – from Kamiari.
Hey. U still up?
She frowns. I am if you can use correct grammar.The response is near instantaneous. Only if you use EXCESSIVE PUNCTUATION!She snorts despite herself. To what do I owe the pleasure?There’s a beat before his response this time. Come out to the common area? It’s lonely out here.She can feel a headache forming somewhere behind the bridge of her nose. Why are you even out there, dude? It’s past curfew.The pause is longer this time, and when it comes, the answer is a short non-answer that piques her interest – and concern.
It’s weird.
Kyoka feels her and Kaiminari have come a long way – longer than she would have expected – and she knows he isn’t often given to cryptic statements or midnight melancholy.
I’ll be over in a minute.
Just over ninety seconds later, slippers toed on and an atypically pink fluffy dressing gown secured around her waist, she enters the common space to find him perched not on the sofa, but at the breakfast bar. A mug of something steaming is cooling next to him, and his eyes light up when he sees her.“You came!” he exclaims, and she blinks at him.“I did say I would,” she responds, and she gets an exaggerated shrug in return.“Yeah, well,” he gestures, “I didn’t know if you would.”“Always the tone of surprise,” she murmurs, and crosses to stand opposite him. There’s no high barstools on this side, but she doesn’t feel hugely like she wishes to intrude around the other side and invade his personal space. “What’s up?”“Huh?” he says, and she resists the urge to facepalm.“You said something was weird, man. That’s why I’m here.”“Oh, that,” he says, and his tone drops again. “Yeah, I just…. I dunno, it’s weird, isn’t it?”Kyoka isn’t always the most patient of people, a fact she can be acutely aware of. She consciously stops herself from gritting her teeth. “You’re going to have to be more specific, Kaminari.”“Just… being here,” he says, gesturing around again, and all of the air seems to whoosh out of him at once. He brings both arms down on the table, with an almost stilted gentleness, in between them.He’s right. It is weird – it’s why she’s still wired tonight in the first place. But from the way Kaminari looks, a little faraway and more pensive than she can ever recall, she is guessing his version of weird is different from hers.“Do…” she starts, and then shakes her head before trying again. “Do you want to talk about…whatever’s weird?”Kaminari looks up at her, and then to a spot somewhere in the distance behind her. After a moment, his eyes flick back to the mug – some kind of herbal tea, by the scene – and then to his hands.Kyoka has battled her share of social unease. She knows an avoidance tactic when she sees one.“I’d…” he eventually begins. “I’d kind of hoped my parents would have… made more of a fuss.”She blinks. “Did they not want you to come?”“Oh, no!” he says, waving his hands. “No, no. Um… quite the opposite, in fact.” He scratches his head. “I think they were glad to have me out of the house, y’know?”
Oh.
Well, that was unexpected. Kyoka doesn’t want to jump to conclusions, but his whole tone and mood suddenly slots into place like a piece of a jigsaw.She knows she is very lucky to have loving parents. She knows a few of her classmates from 1-A share in that same fortune.But it stands to reason not all of them necessarily do. She hadn’t ever really thought to ask Kaminari about his family before. What does he think of them? Is he an only child? How did they react to their son’s career choice?Kyoka squashes down a highly inappropriate mental image of Kaiminari in a housecoat and rubber gloves with ruthless intent. It is neither the time nor the place – nor particularly feminist, at that.She rests her forearms onto the counter between the two of them and looks him square in the face. He recoils slightly, in surprise at her sudden proximity, and upon belated realisation, she shuffles back a few inches too, willing her face not to flush with embarrassment.“Well,” she says, idly twirling a jack. “We’re happy to have you here.”He smiles, a slightly watery effort. “You won’t be saying that this time next week.”This time, she reaches her hand out, plops her palm straight on top of his closed fist and grasps it. He looks up, surprised, but there’s a light in his eyes.“Dude,” she says. “I’m gonna prove you wrong.”<<EOFANFIC>>
