When he first heard the yelling, this was not the image that came to mind.“Nah, see, you can get fucked. This is some fatherless behaviour, you fuckwit.” It was almost glorious, the way you stood like some warrior of a forgotten time – wearing slides and a dressing gown, bright orange energy drink clutched in hand and grey hair pulled into a messy bun. The glow of the convenience store illuminated you from behind, as you crossed your arms and leered at the man before you with piercing yellow eyes.“Hey, you ugly bitch, don’t talk to me like that. You should know your place.” His words were slurred, losing clarity as his volume increased, but the harsh edge was clear. Bakugou was used to the type, another drunk salaryman wandering the streets. Usually they were fairly harmless, just slumped over somewhere, but sometimes they got rowdy like this, picking a fight with someone who didn’t know how to back off.What was unusual was the anger of the… interaction before him. The otherwise quiet night patrolling the city streets seemed a distant memory as he watched you continue to yell at the man, unsure if you were drunk or stupid.“My place? You’re the drunk idiot wandering around, I live here! Go home, you loser.”“Yah, loser? You’re the one wearing pyjamas, you homeless slut. I bet you’d like to come home with me, huh?” The man made a grab for your arm, but you pulled back out of his reach before kicking out at him – right at his crotch.Bakugou had seen enough. “Hey, back the fuck up, you two. What the fuck are you doing?”  He lifted the cringing man off the ground and pulled him back a few steps. He reeked of alcohol and cigarettes, his body heavy as he struggled to hold himself up.Bakugou could hear you huff from a few metres away. “What the fuck am I doing? I’m just minding my own fucking business, and then this dickhead came up asking for a smoke and wouldn’t take no for an answer. Fucking asshole.” You tsked in a way that, for a brief moment, made him understand why the drunk man currently sitting at his feet was so peeved.“Hey, fucking chill, woman. Do you want to go to the drunk tank, too?” He didn’t really think you were drunk – really, he just wanted you to shut up and let him get on with his night.“Drunk? He’s the drunk one, I’m fucking fine.” Yeah, because that sounded like something someone who was fine would say. God, this night just kept getting better – now he had to deal with some upset woman.“Tch, just go sit down while I deal with this idiot.”“Don’t fucking tell me what to do.” You stared each other down for a moment, before you relented, slouching onto a bench outside the store and pulling out a smoke. God, he was fucking irritated, the way you lashed back at him with every word made him want to launch at you just to see that stupid brave façade crack for a moment. He glared at you a moment longer before pulling out his phone to call the police.By the time they arrived, you had more than made yourself comfortable. Cigarette ash littered the ground around you, empty can fallen on its side on the table as you sat locked in a staring match with the fuming hero in front of you. You refused to let even a hint of discomfort through, and already it was paying off. For a hero, he really did have a short fuse.“The fuck is your problem, woman?”A smile began to spread across your face, all teeth and gum. “No problem, just enjoying the view.”“Huh?!” A smattering of small explosions loosed from his hands, fisted by his sides as though to keep from launching at you.You couldn’t help laughing at him, even as he growled at you threateningly. “What are you going to do, hero? I’m just an innocent civilian – even better, I’m a victim! Come on, protect me, Ground Zero.” The teasing in your voice was so obvious, but God, it riled him up.“Yah, shut the fuck up, you lunatic. God, why are all the psychos out tonight?” He rubbed a hand over his face roughly, wondering what he had done to deserve this.Luck was not on his side, though. You kept talking. “How do you not blow yourself up? Seriously, it’s your sweat that’s explosive, right? But doesn’t that mean you’re just leaving flammable liquid all over the place? I mean, gross, but also dangerous, right?”“I don’t have to tell you anything, just shut up. The cops will be here soon.”You grinned at him once more, pulling out another cigarette, lighting up and blowing smoke in his direction. His small cough and scrunched face were more than rewarding. You couldn’t stand assholes like him, people that thought they meant something just because the state awarded them a license for violence.Soon the police did arrive, quickly loading up the drunk man, but as you stood up to give your statement, a burning hand gripped your upper arm.“Breath test this one. She seems drunk, too.” You looked up at him and saw in his face the satisfaction of someone who knew they had won.“Huh?! You fucker, you’re just doing this for kicks, aren’t you?”“See what I mean?” He sighed in exasperation only partly faked and pushed you toward the cop, before releasing you and turning the other way. While you were taken through a breath test – which showed only the single beer you drank earlier that evening – the hero signed the necessary forms for handover and disappeared back to the streets of Musutafu, oddly silent in his departure. As you stared at your reflection in the mirror, you huffed and poked yourself in the face. Why did you have to be so mean? Sure, you were upset about the whole situation, but now you regretted your own escalation of things. Some of the things you said, the way you acted – it wasn’t often that you lost control of yourself like that. Men generally pissed you off, you knew that, even though you knew it wasn’t always helpful and you could understand the systemic reasons they acted the way they did. Knowing that didn’t stop you from being a bit of a hater sometimes, though.Right now, you could see in your face the leftover fear from the confrontation. The wildness. Everything had been fine before then, another night spent working late, followed by your routine break to the convenience store for an energy drink and a smoke. You could technically smoke in the apartment, but you didn’t like the way it made your home smell. Keeping the stench outside made you feel a little more in control of your habit, contained to a small part of your daily life.Then he was in your face, putting his hands on your arm, asking for a smoke, and then asking for more.Part of you knew that going out late all the time meant this sort of thing was more likely to happen, but what were you supposed to do with that knowledge – just not go out? Give up your freedom because of fear of other people’s actions? The very idea pissed you off.In that moment, your rage at every moment you’d felt afraid or paranoid because of men had come out of you. You’d wanted to tear that dumbass man limb from limb, and the fact that you couldn’t had only pissed you off more.Then that hero had come along. Another reminder of your own inability to protect yourself, his presence had only angered you more. What did he have to be angry about? He was a successful, powerful hero, celebrated by society even with his trash personality. Another reminder of how unfair the world was. A “hero-based society”, what a joke. Just another reminder of the fuckery of capitalism and the state’s blatant monopoly on violence.Now, though, in the darkness of your apartment, your anger and fear left you tired. With faltering steps, you collapsed onto your couch, the familiarity soothing your mind only a little.It was confusing and hard to figure out what to do in a world like this. You tried to sort your thoughts, figure out what is the best thing to do in this situation. How could you respect your values even as society pushed contradiction after contradiction at you?One thing you were sure of was that you had unleashed yourself on the hero more than he deserved. A blush rose to your cheeks as you remembered the more suggestive comments you made, testing different avenues to frustrate him. Fuck, that was a bit silly, wasn’t it? Adding more hate to the world was something you took seriously. As much as you strove to be honest and do what was right, keeping in mind the most important thing was something you sometimes forgot.Love. For someone who kept so much to themselves, love was the one thing you knew was real in this world.With a frustrated shriek you rolled over and pushed your face into the pillow. Exhaustion flooded your body. Work could wait until tomorrow. For now, you felt only the weight of your heart.You felt a small sense of resolution, too. Should you see the hero again, you knew what you had to do.

'~Just do it~'
 
'~He's right after all~'
 
'~You're just a useless, quirkless, DEKU!~'
 Taking his shoes off and setting them off to the side, along with his backpack and burnt notebook, he took the final few steps to the edge of the roof.  Shouta usually knew what to expect on his evening patrol --a few muggings, random wannabe villains running around-- but a short broccoli looking figure standing at the top of a fifteen story abandoned building was not it. He blinked and suddenly the person was falling, immediately his instincts kicked in as he shot out his capture weapon toward the building, wrapping it around a railing surrounding a balcony, and pulling him with. Landing on the railing, he made the gray material wrap around the falling figure, and tugged the person to him. Once he had secured them, he lowered them and himself to the ground. When they were safely on the ground, Shouta finally looked at the person he had saved. "Fuck," he muttered, "this is a kid." 
'God, kid, what made you want to do this?'
 The kid couldn't be more than ten years-old, if he was then he was extremely malnourished. In either case, he needed to call Naomasa.  Izuku opened his eyes to see a man with shoulder length black hair facing away from him. Wait wasn't he supposed to be dead, is this the afterlife? No, he concluded, it wasn't, once he realized the man was on the phone. "No, I have no idea what his name is, Naomasa" There was a long pause, "Got it, I'll ask him as soon as he wakes." The man hung up the phone, and slowly turned toward Izuku. He widened his eyes when he saw that Izuku was awake. "God, okay, I'm a hero, but not super good at this kind of thing. So, you're going to have to work with me, okay?" Izuku gave a small nodded. "Good, first I need you to tell me your name, can you do that for me, kid?" If he told this nice man his name, would he still be nice when he found out that Izuku was quirkless? Probably not. Apparently the man had decided that he was taking too long to answer, because he started to talk again. "Okay, what if i tell you my civilian name first, yeah?" Izuku considered this, the supposed hero seemed to really want to know his name, so much so that he was willing to tell him his civilian name. Yes, Izuku decided, he will tell this man his name. If only because he was being so nice to him, and he knew he didn't deserve it. "Okay," he said so softly that he almost couldn't hear himself. "Yeah?" the man gave a small smile, "Mine is Shouta Aizawa". He inhaled, "Izuku," he exhaled, "Izuku Midoriya". "Thank you, Midoriya, now can you tell me what you were doing at the top of the building?"  As Shouta hung up on Naomasa, he turned back towards the kid, only to find him staring up at him with wide, fearful eyes. 
'Shit, where is 'Zashi when you need him?'
 'Well,  regardless I still need to try' "God, okay, I'm a hero, but not super good at this kind of thing. So, you're going to have to work with me, okay?" The kid nodded slightly. "Good, first I need you to tell me your name, can you do that for me, kid?" The boy seemed to drift off into thought at that, so Shouta decided to offer something in return. "Okay, what if i tell you my civilian name first, yeah?" The kid raised his eyebrows, and looked as though he was considering it for a few minutes. Shouta almost didn't catch the soft okay that came from the boy's mouth. "Yeah?" he tried to give a reassuring smile, though he most likely failed, "Mine is Shouta Aizawa". The green haired boy took a breath, and again something so soft was said, it was almost inaudible, "Izuku," "Izuku Midoriya". Thank the gods, the kid actually answered. Now to figure the fuck out what exactly this problem child kid was doing up there. When he asked, Midoriya seemed to panic a little bit. "N-nothing, s-sir, I w-was just look-looking at the view, when I-I slip-slipped and f-fell, th-thank you for saving me". Yeah, Shouta didn't believe that for one second. This kid, had somehow managed to get to the top of a locked, abandoned building, and then proceed to jump off it.  "You're welcome, kid, I was just doing my job, but I can't help you if you lie to me. And all I want to do is that". "But I'm n-not ly-lying, sir" Shouta just stared at him, unbelieving. Midoriya didn't seem to care, because he just stared right back. He sighed, he wasn't getting any sleep tonight was he? Don't answer that. "Okay, kid, can you at least tell me how old you are?" The boy seemed to consider this for a minute, and soon nodded to himself. "I'm 14, Mr. Aizawa, sir"

completion: It was a warm night as the three of you sat around the fire, listening to the sound of nature as you waited for your companion to return. Bakugou had disappeared between the bushes a few minutes ago, grumbling under his breath, as he searched for today's dinner, also to cool off his head from a certain blonde bard you three had met on your journey.Thanks to the invitation of a certain redhead, said bard, known as Kaminari Denki, would tag along with you for the following days, much to the displeasure of the blonde prince.He and Kaminari knew each other since childhood, and Bakugou knew that he wasn't a bad person, he was just annoying and seemed to have a certain interest into you, adding to his already tense relationship to him. Bakugou had already pulled you away from him a few times when he had snuck a flower behind your ear or wanted to walk next to you.You couldn't say if he was just jealous or overly-protective of you, so it was kinda surprising that he left you two alone just like that. Well, Kirishima was still there, naturally, but the dragon didn't intervene as aggressive as the other. Perhaps it was due to his gentle nature or the fact that you didn't seem to be uncomfortable with Kaminari being around you.He seemed to be a free spirit, an old friend of Bakugou even, and everyone who managed to regain the title of "Prince Bakugou's friend" couldn't be a bad person.Besides, he might have some intel of Bakugou, an option and golden opportunity to find out some of his weaknesses (if he had any at all) or embarrassing things from his childhood, for teasing of course - stealing his cape became anticipatory and you were still too weak to beat him in a one-on-one tickle fight.You sat on the fire, lost in thought when you heard a grumble. "Ahhh, hopefully Bakugou will return soon, I'm getting hungry~" Kirishima whined, his stomach growling in agreement once more, making you giggle. He really was a little glutton. "Don't worry my scaly friend, I'm sure Kacchan will return shortly, with a big catch," the bard said, letting himself plop besides you.Your eyes met for a second as you looked a him and he gave you a smile. "That's a cute laugh you got there, may I seen some more of it~" he said, poking your side and making you squeal. "HahHah... dohoHn't~" you giggled, rubbing the spot, already feeling your face heating up. Why does everyone you meet assumes you're ticklish?"Oho what was that? ...A bit ticklish, aren't we?" Kaminari teased and you gulped. Kirishima, who had watched the whole thing, sat on your other said, grinned over to the bard. "They're super ticklish and their laugh is soooo adorable~" he said almost proudly, squeezing your other side as well. "HyaHah! ...K-Kiriii~" you whined, seeing where this was probably going.Agh! Where was Bakugou when you need him. "See, I told you~" he affirmed. "Adorable~" He pulled you into a hug, nuzzling your neck, and you had already forgiven him, you just couldn't be mad at him. "Okay, ohohkay, leeEht goHo~" you laughed, his hair tickling your sensitive skin. Kaminari watched you two hugging with a teasing smile on his face."... I see, I see, so they're quite sensitive, hm~" he laid a hand on his chin before his face lightened up. "Say, can you hold them like this?" he asked Kirishima, his grin getting wider and more playful. "Hey, wait, wh-" "Sure, I love hugging them~" "Kiri I-" "Perfect, you won't regret it, hehe both of you~" You were ignored, just like that.Well, at least Kirishima felt comfy as you laid against his chest, knowing that it wasn't worth the effort to try breaking free from his grip now that the dragon's interest was aroused. You just hoped that Kaminari was right with his statement, though deep inside you already knew what was about to happen, albeit not like this."I always wanted to try this sort of magic~" the bard sing-songed and manifested a guitar. A guitar? Why does he need a guitar? you thought. Your eyes must had given you away because the blonde just smiled at you. "You'll see- well feel it in a second. Make sure to hold them tight, red~" he spoke to the dragon, and you could feel him cuddling more against you.…and with that, he began to play. A soft tune filled the night and with it came your high-pitched giggles and chuckles as you suddenly felt ticklish hands on your entire body, lapping around your neck, sliding up and down your sides, wiggling over your stomach, squeezing your thighs and scratching your soles inside your boots, all at once."WHAhahaht ihiHis thiHis?!" you laughed, squirming in Kirishima's hold, complete caught off guard by the sudden tickle attack. Kaminari smiled at you, delighted by your reaction. "Oh, just a kinda spell I invented myself~ Feels good, doesn't it?" he said, hitting the strings causing a new wave of laughter brushing over you."AhhHahah, i-iHit tiHihickles, noHoHoot myhAh... hAhahAhah~" you laughed, turning from right to left, but the invisible hands were following you non-stop. It felt strange, different when either Bakugou or Kirishima were tickling you, but those hands seemed to know exactly what they were doing, as if they had a mind of their own.Your head was spinning, the overstimulation of God-knows-what how many fingers tickling you in all kinds of ways driving you crazy, and yet it felt oddly familiar. The dragon giggled, his tail wagging behind him, he was excited."Wow that's amazing! They're laughing so hard~ Do it more, do it more!" he said, his eyes sparkling, enjoying hearing you laugh way too much. "DohOHon't praise hiHim, aHHahA~ NoHoho!" you whined, feeling yourself blush like an idiot.You squeezed your eyes, trying to blend out any other sensation, but it only made it worse. "Did I promise too much? Hehe tell me where it tickles the most~" the bard teased, switching to a slower tune and you felt the hands getting slower as well. "Y-You suHuck~" you giggled, tears of mirth flowing down your face."Traveler, how could you~" Kirishima fake-gasped from behind before you could feel a new pair of hands on your sides. "He's playing his instrument so well~" Feeling the hands overlapping, tickling the same spot at the same time gave you the finishing blow and you break into a new wave of chortles. "NohoHot you toHoho... I'm soHohorry~""You better be handsome, it doesn't fit your beauty getting so cocky all of a sudden~" Kaminari agreed, hitting the strings again at a quicker pace, feeling your laughter rise up again. "Besides, if you want it that way, then well..." His melody changed again, and you sucked in your stomach when you felt something wet on your bare skin.You couldn't really describe how it felt, maybe like the tongue of a little cat, many cats, but nonetheless it tickled like hell. "OOHoho m-my GoHooHod! I- I ahAhahha~" you laughed, and a slight moan escaped you when the tiny tongues licked near you belly button."Ahh...Ahhaha... B-BaHakugou~" you almost screamed, calling for him out of habit, the ticklish sensation just being too much for you handle. Kirishima's ears perked up and he stopped his tickling, feeling a presence coming closer."THE HELL, DUNCE FACE!" a very angry Bakugou suddenly hissed, as he appeared like the knight in shining armor out of the darkness, letting your dinner - some rabbits and berries - fall on the ground as he gave the blonde a headbutt, pulling him away from next to you, making the tickling stop."Oww, what was that for?" the bard whined. "I think I told you before not to touch them," Bakugou said as he stood protectively between you two. So, that's how it is, interesting~ the bard thought, a glimmering smile in his face."Technically, I didn't touch them, you see," he explained, summoning his instrument once more, "I just did this~" he said in a half-teasing voice, playing a chord, causing the blonde to tremble as he quickly pressed a hand on his mouth, a pair of invisible hands squeezing his lower sides."PfHfhfh... y-yoHohu're deEhead~" he growled before he jumped on the surprising blonde and well... wormed his fingers in-between his ribs, tickling him as if he knew exactly where to attack. "WAhahAh K-Kacchan, whahaat?""Take that Dunce Face, how do you like it hm? Don't think I forgot how damn ticklish you were back when we were kids. Haha serves you right, they're mine- ehem ours all alone, so there's no place for you~" he said, after a quickly glance to Kirishima, tickling the hell out of the bard, probably not realizing the indirect confession of love he just did.You watched the duo wrestling around as Kirishima still hugged you from behind, gently stroking you, apologizing for being a bit too mean today. You reassured him that it was okay, squeezing one of his hands, feeling him purr silently as you watched Bakugou and Kaminari engaged in a playful tickle fight.You could see the blonde prince smile carefree, no hint of real anger on his face. So, they are friends after all, you thought as you looked up into the night, their laughter still ringing in your ears.<<EOFANFIC>>

completion:
Chapter Text

Hundreds of years after quirks first appeared, ‘cancer’ simply wasn’t a word in most people’s vocabulary anymore. Humans had evolved to have different bone structures, less susceptibility to common colds and flus, and of course, they developed a way to prevent diseases like Alzheimers, heart disease, and cancer. Although outliers unfortunately did exist, it was extremely uncommon to be diagnosed with such a thing in this day and age. In fact, the chances of being diagnosed with such a horrible disease only slightly increased if you happened to be born quirkless, which was a rarity in itself.

Aizawa Shouta was not quirkless - he could remember the day he got his quirk as if it were yesterday. He had been in the kitchen with his mother when it happened. She had been using her quirk - a telekinetic one to bring a plate down from the cabinet when he had felt his mind 

pull 

and the sound of glass breaking quickly followed. He had been five.

After a quick visit to the Doctor to confirm that he had indeed developed his quirk and that he was as healthy as can be, Shouta lived as normal of a life as he possibly could with a single mother working two jobs to keep a roof over their heads. He supposed it was lucky that they were both very healthy - there was only a handful of times in his childhood where he or his mother had caught an illness, and so there was never any need to waste money on medicine. Even when his quirk caused him to develop painful migraines, he suffered through it.

Whether he was five or thirty years old, Aizawa Shouta knew one thing for certain: his headaches were not supposed to be so painful he wondered if he 

couldn’t 

suffer through it. The pain in his head used to simply be best described as a dull, throbbing sensation. It hurt, but he could deal with it. One month ago, however, he had his first headache where he genuinely wanted to die. It was still a dull type of pain, but it 

really 

hurt.

Shouta chalked it up to overusing his quirk. He 

had 

been using it more often, after all. And as the days went by and the pain continued to come more frequently, he didn’t change his opinion on the matter. Things were 

fine, 

he was as healthy as he always had been. Or so he thought.
 
—----------------------------------
 
Today, his headache was being 

stubborn.


Shouta rubbed at his head as he stood in front of his class, talking about the upcoming sport’s festival. There wasn’t a lot to say, really. Once a year, UA would make all of their students participate in a tournament where the hero students get a chance to show off their potential to heroes in an attempt to make them want them as their interns, and everyone outside of UA tunes in for entertainment purposes.Shouta didn’t actually 

care 

all that much about it considering he worked as an underground hero, but from what he can recall from his time as a student, it was something to be looked forward to. And maybe he’d have a better opinion of it if it wasn’t preventing him from curling up in his sleeping bag to nap to hopefully get rid of the throbbing in his head. He hadn’t even really used his quirk yet, so the fact that the migraine that was undoubtedly developing even existed was illogical and confusing.

If he were anyone else, he might’ve said that it was 

concerning. 

But Shouta’s been completely healthy his entire life, and it wasn’t like he’d ever eaten too much junk food or didn’t exercise enough. He’s a hero - it’s necessary for him to be in top health for it.

“Alright,” he droned. “Any questions?”

Five hands went soaring up. Shouta sighed.

“Kaminari?”

“How come we’re not allowed support items?”

He stared at him and because his headache was making him more impatient than he normally would be, he replied; “Because those are the rules, they are exactly the same as they were last year. Ashido?”

Ashido tilted her head to the side. “Who do you think will win, Sensei?”

Shouta gave her a deadpan stare. “I’m not going to answer that.”

In all honesty, the entire class had a good chance of making it to at least the top ten. Their experience fighting real villains in their first year made up for the lack of classroom education they had because of it. But still, there 

were 

a couple of students that definitely had a higher chance of winning this time around. Namely, Midoriya, Bakugou, Todoroki, and Uraraka. Not that he’d ever say that out loud or tell them specifically. Hizashi on the other hand probably wouldn’t 

shut up 

about it. He hoped they wouldn’t ask him the same question.

Bakugou grinned. “He doesn’t 

have 

to answer your question because he knows I’m going to beat all of you extras.”

Shouta watched as Todoroki turned towards him. “I’m not averse to using my fire anymore, Bakugou. I think I can beat you.”

Uraraka laughed. “I almost beat Bakugou last year. I’ll try my best and maybe I just might win against 

both 

of you.”

She had been competitive last year, and everything the class went through seemed to have just made her need to win 

worse. 

Judging by the appreciative glint in Bakugou’s eyes, he didn’t mind that fact so much.

“Careful, Pink Cheeks, or I might just pull a Todoroki and challenge you in front of the entire class.”

She smiled at him. “Not if I challenge 

you 

first.”

The rest of the class 

oohed 

as if they were a bunch of little kids.

For the love of God, Shouta cannot pinpoint when exactly the two of them became friends, but he deeply regretted that he wasn’t there to 

stop 

it.

“Enough,” he said, ignoring the increased throbbing in his head. The class became silent, and that was that. “Does anyone else have any 

good 

questions?”

Mineta’s, Jirou’s, and Hagakure’s hand dropped back down.
 
—----------------------------------
 
The first thing that Shouta saw when he walked into his house was a 

disaster. 

Pillows and blankets littered every inch of the floor and, right in the middle of what seemed to be some sort of throne sat Eri in her pink princess dress with her stuffed dragon beside her.

“Hi Dad!” She chirped, jumping down off the pillows to bound over to where he stood staring in shock at just how much 

mess 

she had managed to create. Distantly, he internally remarked that her tiara was crooked. “How was your day?”

“Fine,” he said. “Eri, you know the rules, yes?”

“Huh?” She tilted her head before her eyes widened in understanding. “Oh, you mean my castle? I’ll clean up when I’m done, don’t worry!”

He eyed the pillows warily. “Okay… Where’s your brother?”

“Hitoshi went up to his room as soon as we came home!” She said, grinning mischievously. “He’s probably talking to his girlfriend

.”


Shouta whipped his head back around to stare at her. Despite trying everything not to, he still blurted out; “His 

what?”


Eri just laughed, skipping away while he fought the urge not to go snooping. Chances are that Eri was making the girlfriend thing up anyways, since she had taken to doing the same thing with Hizashi. 

Multiple times.


Not that he’d disrespect Hitoshi’s privacy even if he

 was 

actually 
talking to his girlfriend. Or boyfriend. Or Partner.
Shouta snorted when he remembered the pure panic that had spread across Hizashi’s face when he had practically ran into their bedroom to tell him that Eri had said Hitoshi was talking to his boyfriend on the phone a few nights ago. And then the night after, she had told him he was talking to his girlfriend. The next time she tried it on him, he didn’t believe her. So now she’s moved on to him.

‘

Do we have to give him the talk, Shou?’



Shouta had outright laughed at that. ‘No, he’s sixteen, not ten.’


Shouta’s smile turned into a wince as his head gave a particularly painful throb. He needed to lie down. He looked at the mountain of dirty dishes in the sink and swore that he’d apologise to Hizashi for not doing them the moment he got home.
"Hitoshi?" He called out. "Can you watch your sister for a little bit?"
 
—----------------------------------
 
“Shou?”


His head throbbed.


“Hm.”

“Shou, you have patrolling duties tonight. You have to wake up.”


Shit.


Shouta opened his eyes… and immediately screwed them shut. 

Fuck.


He knew Hizashi was looking at him with a ton of unnecessary concern. He was 

fine. 

“Are you okay? Do you have a migraine?”

He swallowed. His throat was dry. “Yeah.”

“I’ll call in for you and say you’re not feeling well. And don’t argue with me,” There was a teasing lilt to Hizashi’s voice. “Did you overuse your quirk today?”

Shouta frowned. Had he? He didn’t think so… No, he 

hadn’t. 

He only used it two or three times. “No, I didn’t. Same as last time.”

“Maybe you should go to a doctor. This has happened more than once this month.”

Shouta opened his eyes to glare tiredly at Hizashi. Hizashi glared right back. “I’m serious, what if there’s something actually wrong with you that they can fix so you don’t get these horrible headaches?”

“I’ll only go if you really want me to.”

“I 

really 

want you to.”

“Fine.”

And so along with calling in sick for him, Hizashi also scheduled a doctor’s appointment.
 
—----------------------------------
 
At first, they had smiled and said that it was probably nothing to worry about, but that they would schedule him for an MRI just in case after doing an exam.

The next time Shouta went, their smiles became strained. They did another neurological exam on him. They told him that there 

was 

something not quite right and that they wanted to biopsy his 

brain 

next. So Shouta did what they asked of him, and soon enough they got their sample of… whatever it was they were looking for.

The last time Shouta went, the Doctor looked at him gravely.

“You have Cancer.”
.....
And everything Shouta thought he knew fell apart.

completion: Izuku was running late, he had been so focused on his next HeroTube video, which was on the relationship between poverty and the ‘villain’ rates (which were staggering and made Izuku think that the way to keep people safe from villains wasn’t with flashy hero fights after all), and had ended up not sleeping the night before, and now he was late to homeroom.It was bad all on its own, but today was the day that Aizawa-sensei had said their surprise hero visitor was supposed to come. A hero was coming to visit their homeroom class, and Izuku was LATE! Running to his classroom from the dorms, while simultaneously throwing on his blazer, ‘tying’ his tie, and eating a banana. All of which were going rather poorly. But needs a must Izuku supposes. Five minutes late may not seem like a big deal, and to a lot of his classmates, on any other day anyway, it wouldn’t have been. But Izuku liked to be exactly on time, to the second. If he was early, it would be easy for the bullies to harass him before school, and if he was late the teacher(s) would practically send him to the wolves. So, right on time, best option all around. He got to the classroom, threw out his banana peel, opened the door… and froze. Standing at the podium right next to Aizawa-sensei, wearing blue and black spandex and Kevlar covered in flame motifs and electric blue army-style boots, was America's number three hero Ignius, the cerulean flame hero. Ignius, or as Izuku knew him Midoriya Hisashi. Aizawa glanced over to look at where the door now stood open, and seeing Izuku he seemed to lose a little tension in his shoulders. “Ah, Midoirya, come on in a take your seat. We were just introducing-“ While Aizawa was talking Hisashi walked over and stopped in front of Izuku. Izuku still sat there, frozen in place looking at his father. “Zuku? What the hell are you doing here?” The man’s voice had changed, it was rougher and deeper like he had been smoking his whole life – which, in a way, he had been so the change was likely just a side effect of his quirk. He stood only a couple of inches taller than Aizawa and was not the hulking all might-like figure that he remembered, looming feet above everyone else. He was lanky-er than memory said as well, but still with definite bulk to him. His black hair was short and simple. Like the hair was trying to make the wearer blend into the background, which was kind of a moot point – what with the flamboyant neon colors of his costume. His eyes, on the other hand, his eyes drew all the attention. They almost glowed, they might actually glow – if only at a low level. They were the same blue as the hottest flame. His stare was heated and strong, his glare seemed to burn the skin – which could be another side effect of some kindlikewithaizawa’sscarforsomthing…. Izuku blinked. Then, taking a small step to the side, so he could avoid the hand coming up to rest on his shoulder as subtly as he could manage, he turned to face Aizawa-Sensei and managed a quick bow and an apology for being late. Taking another quick glance around the room Izuku noticed that along with his whole class and Aizawa, Mic-sensei and the principal (probably introducing the accomplished alumni in the first place) were also in the room.“Zuku! Answer the question.” Izuku snapped his gaze back to Ignius. “I’m a student here. What are you doing here.” Izuku asked, walking around the man toward his seat. Predictably, Ignuis followed him over – Izuku was glad they changed around the seats each year, so Bakugou was at the other end of the room instead of directly in front of him for their third year. Bakugou loved Hisashi, and Izuku didn’t want to be in the middle of all that would turn into. “And what is that supposed to mean?”  He stood hovering over Izuku, who had taken his seat and was looking in his bag for his notebook and pencil case, with his arms crossed and a frown on his face. Suddenly he seemed to prosses the first part of Izuku’s statement. “Wait. Wait, wait, wait. You what now?” “I go to school here. I am currently enrolled at U.A. High. This is MY hero academia.” Izuku didn’t look up, having found the notebook he opened up to the page he was writing his HeroTube script on. “Why didn’t you tell me? Wait. So you got your quirk then?” at this Izuku did look up, looking Ignius in the eyes and realizing, not for the first time, that his own father couldn’t care less. “Hisashi” at that address the man in front of him twitched, and Iida made a scandalized gasping sound and his hand started doing his hand-chopping stimming thing “Midoriya! You should not address heroes like that! It is disrespectful!” Izuku sent a smile over to his friend before looking back at Ignius. “Hisashi, can we just get to the homeroom visit? I really don’t want to do this.” “If you’re here, is that freaky kid here?” Izuku twitched, staring at his desk, and trying very hard not to lash out at the words. Hisashi looked at each of his classmates before turning back to Izuku. “Is he in the other class then? Or was he not accepted?” He chuckled before speaking again. “Honestly, I’m glad you’re not in the same class anymore. He was a bad influence on you, and I have always said so. Your mother never saw it of course, but kami I sure did, that boy was always lurking around, he was a shifty lowlife creep, and I didn’t want you anywhere near him. I mean, what if he… corrupted you.” With each new word, it was harder and harder for Izuku to keep from snapping. Izuku could hear the insinuation under what he was really saying, the ‘freaky kid’ Hisashi was talking about, Ayumu Akio was pulled out of the closet at school and by the end of the day the whole neighborhood knew he was Queer. But Akio was Izuku’s friend. His first friend since before he was diagnosed as Quirkless, and listening to his father talk about one of the people Izuku cared for most like that… made him unbelievably angry. Izuku finally looked up at Hisashi again, glaring he pitched his voice low and deep “He wasn’t a ‘shifty lowlife’ anything, he was ‘lurking’ around because he was socially awkward and found you completely intimidating, and while you may not have liked him he was my first-“ Before Izuku could finish Hisashi was slamming his hands on Izuku’s desk and lowering his face so they were eye to eye. “You kissed that freak!” He looked downright rageful. And that’s not what Izuku meant, Izuku was going to say he was his first real friend. But it also wasn’t wrong, because before Akio was outed, he and Izuku had had long discussions about what it all meant, and how they felt about their gender and sexuality, and they had eventually decided to test the waters with each other, and Izuku probably could have ended up wanting a full out relationship with him if he hadn't... well Izuku will never look at a bottle of pills the same way again.So… “… well, I suppose he was my first in that regard also, but that’s not-“ Again, Izuku was cut off before he could end his sentence which was getting rather old. “YOU LET HIM FUCK YOU? Are you telling me my only son is some sorta fag freak?” Spit came flying out of his mouth from the force of his yell, and the breath on Izuku’s face felt warm. But at this point. Izuku. Was. ENRAGED. So he did what he does best. He acted like a little shit. You wanna be a homophobic piece of trash? Well, guess who gets to be publicly humiliated in front of at least three teenagers with their phones set to record? “I guess I am kinda smokin’, but I don’t see what cigarettes have to do with anything.” Izuku swore he could hear a pin drop on the other side of campus. “…What?” Hisashi had frozen, looking confused, which was fair since most people who use that slur don’t know what the dictionary definition for it is. He probably also doesn’t know the dictionary definition for faggot either… Izuku tilted his head just slightly to the right, before letting his eyes widen just a fraction “OH! Did you mean the bundle of sticks definition, because I do have some pretty great wood if I say so myself but I feel like that’s kind of an inappropriate thing for a father to say about his son.” Again, except for a stifled snort from Mic-Sensei and another offended gasp from Iida, it was silent. Hisashi was still obviously confused, but his frustration was really starting to shine through. “… I’m asking if you’re a fucking homo.” … My gods… how many of these loophole slurs is this man going to use? Izuku couldn’t help himself… “Everyone in this room is a homosapien, except the principal, I guess. Don’t see what that has to do with anything either.” Speaking of whom, he seems to have pulled out a him-sized chair and tea set… from nowhere. Hisashi looked like he was going to pop a blood vessel. His face was turning red, his scowl was probably permanent, and there were slight tendrils of smoke coming out of his mouth. He took a breath, let it out, and whispered a soft “kami”  before yelling once again “ARE YOU FUCKING GAY!” Which… wow.Izuku couldn’t… not take this one. In for a penny, in for a pound, right?“… gotta say, I was a lot happier before you walked in.” a full snort from Mic-Sensei this time, and whoever was recording this was going to get a lot of views on HeroTube. Hisashi snapped, Izuku’s desk cracked under his hands, and a huge trail of smoke gushed out of his mouth before he clenched his jaw tightly. He stood to his full height, recrossed his arms, and turned to the door. “I’m fucking done with this Izuku, if you really do like to take it up the ass then you’re no son of mine. It’s unnatural and I will have nothing to do with it.” He said as he started walking away. And… Izuku. Izuku really should leave it there. Let Hisashi have the last word, and be done with this conversation… but. Gods, Izuku never thought he’d have a good use for this particularly traumatic moment, and he will likely never get a chance like this again. Fuck it.“First of all, it’s pretty presumptuous to assume I’m a bottom. Secondly, are we just going to pretend that I didn’t walk in on mom pegging you when I was ten? Because you didn’t seem to think it was all that ‘unnatural’ at the time. In fact, if memory serves, you were moaning like-” Hisashi slammed the door behind him. “SO, IS THAT A YES TO PRETENDING IT DIDN’T HAPPEN?”<<EOFANFIC>>

completion: The lace, all red, bright, and itchy, beneath the bargain bin, looked sad in its abandoned pile. There must have been an employee who passed by with something strong, because a saccharine rose clung to the fabrics despite the way it was buried. The seams looked flawless—no fraying ends, better than Tomura could say about the rest of the fabrics he ended up dusting in disgruntlement. Magne would know whether it was usable or not. The phone that she insisted he carry (a sliding phone, an ancient relic, that he accepted with a sneer) weighed in the front pocket of his raggedy jacket. When he bent forward, it rolled out, glaring back at him from the sun.He picked up the phone and it subsequently dissolved into dust. It was no such loss. He grasped the lace a little more carefully and threw them into the little basket that a worker in the front had shoved into his arms.The cashier gave him a beleaguered look as he approached the register with his head low, drawn in, and half-hidden by his hand clenching the zipped-up collar of his jacket. Shigaraki fished out a twenty-dollar bill that Kurogiri had given him while teleporting a ranting Dabi away (you sack of shit, we need that money for supplies, don’t use it on something as stupid as Toga’s—) and placed it on the countertop, along with his basket.He thumbed the corner of his jaw, barely skimming it with his nails as the cashier processed his purchase. Though he had no reason to rush, it felt like the cashier was deliberately unfolding the fabrics to find a label of some kind as slowly as possible. He would glare at them if it would not have drawn attention to his eyes—red and bloodshot. Instead, he glowered at the floor as though it had any responsibility. And it must have, because it seems to frown at him back, at the fact that it was still underneath his feet.He didn’t know what to make of it. He itched harder. The cashier handed him his purchase in a plastic bag and waved him a faux friendly have a nice day. He did not think he would..Toga Himiko was made of cracking dreams held together by her friends alone. That much she knew. The concrete between the lines wore away with time. Inevitable. She had a shrink once. They didn’t know where to begin with her; they weren’t very helpful in the end. But there was one thing she learned from them: everyone needed a friend, no matter how black their heart had become.That was why she kept hers close. Really, really close. Enough to smell their blood, their life, grin around the little pinprick teeth marks she made in their limp skin. She could smell their fear; read the loss on their face—who rejected them? Died? Maybe it was their mother. They had such a refined purse that they clung to like a lifeline. A present from a lost mother? Toga couldn’t imagine grieving over parents. She remembered sharp relief, as sharp as her knife covered in their blood. Her imagination filled the blanks in for her.Her favorite song rang as she propped up her new friend against the concrete wall of the new school built just last year. It was still so sterile, and Toga’s inner artist could not bear to leave it empty. She picked up her phone to her ear, where Magne’s voice came through from the other side with sweet excitement in her voice. Toga giggled along, more than curious about what surprise (Magne didn’t call it that, but Toga could hear it from her voice) was in store. She lovingly wiped her finger across her new friend’s neck and drew a thin heart on the wall. It ran out halfway through, a grim sign in terms of their friendship. Toga balanced her knife on one finger. It fell with a damning thud.“I’ll be back in a few,” she promised to the cellphone..The door swung with an obnoxious creak. Spinner hacked dust on the age of it. Something bacterial had festered in the air too, but he willfully ignored it. Of more immediate concern was the ceiling patched with rotting, wooden boards that threatened to collapse at any moment. He glared at it before feeling pathetic for blaming the non-sentient building for their misfortune. A loose phrase of turn. It was easier to think of that than the reality. It was like the knives he didn’t have that he promised Toga and the puke in the back of the van that he preferred to pretend wasn’t there—on his mind but left unaddressed until they went away.He tried to remember what it was like to believe in something. It felt like a lifetime ago that he watched that shaky video. Stain’s convictions, singular; Shuichi, given purpose. He rummaged through another shed, looking for anything that the league could use or sell. He was doubtful that he would find anything in here, but they were also desperate. How grim their situation had become after Kurogiri left a month ago. Meanwhile, god knows where Dabi was. He had all but abandoned them to burn thugs in alleyways, allegedly for the cause, but really because he was bored. Some fellow Stain follower he was.Then again, Spinner was a paltry imitation who threw his lot in with a cause that didn’t resemble Stain’s, and he was feeling more and more like a failure every day. If he could just recall that instant of connection, an electric realization that he was part of something greater. He counted the cracks in his immediate vicinity and kicked over the trash bags in his way. Meanwhile, Shigaraki was moping back at base. He missed Kurogiri—they all did—and they already lost… So Shigaraki didn’t inspire, Dabi didn’t care, and the rest were off elsewhere.There was a feather on the floor, spindly and auburn, spilling from the torn bags. He picked it up and brushed it off, realizing that it was a brighter red than he initially thought. It looked pitiful on its own, though it must have rightly been part of a magnificent plumage. He stared at it with questions unasked. His answers, not in front of him, he dropped it and tread over the forlorn feather..It was a peculiar thing, what Magne could see that no one else quite. Threads, red, that lapped the world in its weight.She used to try to tug on them but only found herself in a man-made wasteland. She wandered for a time, often in the dark, before she happened to fall, and Shigaraki, Kurogiri, Toga, Twice, Compress, Spinner, and even Dabi caught her. When she opened her eyes, Magne was amazed to see the strings that connected them. When she reached out, they accepted her.So it was strange when one of those threads snapped suddenly, and she was flung across the room in bits and pieces. That last part didn’t quite register at first, but she had died. Was floating. Without saying a word to anyone you leave. This is normal behavior for you and it’s way passed my bedtime.

Sharky”Your fist clench around the letter as you sink down your door to the floor. Your heart is breaking. Tears run down your face as you angerly wipe them away. You scream “FUCK!” As you slam your fist in the ground.

The one from the sports festival from our first year.You pull your copy of it out of your wallet. You’ve treasured this picture for years. completion: Shota Aizawa, a highly respected and experienced hero from Japan, never thought he would find love while on a mission in the bustling city of Atlanta, Georgia. But that all changed when he stumbled upon Eric Bittle's bakery. As soon as he tasted one of Eric's famous pies, he knew he had to meet the person who created such a delicious treat.When Shota walked into the bakery, Eric was in the back, flour dusting his apron as he expertly kneaded dough for his next batch of pies. As soon as Eric turned around and saw Shota, he was struck by his rugged good looks and mysterious aura. Shota, on the other hand, was immediately drawn to Eric's warm smile and bubbly personality.The two of them hit it off right away and quickly bonded over their shared passion for their work. They spent countless hours talking about their lives and their dreams, and they soon discovered that they had more in common than they ever could have imagined. They both valued hard work, integrity, and the importance of taking care of others.As their relationship blossomed, Shota found himself opening up to Eric in ways he never thought possible. He had always been a closed-off person, keeping his emotions and thoughts to himself. But with Eric, he felt safe and comfortable sharing his innermost feelings. He told him about his troubled past and the struggles he had faced as a hero, and Eric listened with a sympathetic ear and a kind heart.For Eric, being with Shota was like a dream come true. He had always been drawn to strong, silent types, and Shota fit that bill perfectly. But as they spent more time together, Eric discovered a softer side to Shota that he never knew existed. He saw that Shota was a caring and compassionate person, who would go to great lengths to protect those he loved.As their love grew stronger, Shota knew he had to make a decision. He couldn't stay in the United States forever, and he didn't want to leave Eric behind. So he made a bold move and asked Eric to come back to Japan with him.At first, Eric was hesitant. He had never been outside the United States before, and the idea of leaving his bakery and his friends behind was daunting. But in the end, he knew that he couldn't bear to be without Shota, so he agreed to go with him.The two of them settled into a new life in Japan, with Shota showing Eric the sights and sounds of his homeland. Eric fell in love with the culture, and he quickly adapted to his new life. He even began to learn Japanese so he could communicate with Shota's friends and family.Years passed, and Shota and Eric grew old together. They faced many challenges along the way, including dangerous missions and personal struggles. But they always stayed strong and supported each other through thick and thin. They continued to run Eric's bakery in Japan, where they made pies that became just as famous as they were in the United States.As time passed, Shota and Eric's love continued to grow and deepen. They were each other's rock, and their love only strengthened with each passing day. They shared everything together, from the joys of running the bakery to the struggles of being a hero.Shota had never been happier than he was with Eric by his side. He loved waking up to the smell of freshly baked pies and the sound of Eric humming along to the radio as he prepared their breakfast. He loved the way Eric's eyes would light up when he talked about his latest pie creation or when he saw a customer take their first bite and smile in delight.For Eric, being with Shota meant having a partner who understood him completely. Shota was the only person who had ever seen him cry, and he was the only one who could calm him down when he was feeling overwhelmed. Shota was his safe haven, the person he could always turn to when he needed support or encouragement.As their bakery grew in popularity, Shota and Eric became a beloved fixture in their community. They were known for their kindness, their generosity, and their delicious pies. People would come from all over Japan just to taste one of Eric's creations and to catch a glimpse of the mysterious hero who had fallen in love with the charming baker.But their idyllic life was not without its challenges. Shota continued to face dangerous missions as a hero, and Eric worried for his safety every time he left their home. But Shota always returned to Eric's warm embrace, and they would hold each other tightly, grateful for another day together.As they grew older, they knew that their time together was limited. Shota's body had started to show the wear and tear of a lifetime spent fighting for justice, and Eric's hands had begun to ache from years of kneading dough. But they refused to let age slow them down. They continued to run the bakery and fight crime, side by side, for as long as they possibly could.And when the time came for them to say goodbye, they did so with the same grace and love that had characterized their entire relationship. They held hands as Shota took his last breath, surrounded by the warmth and love of the family they had created together. Eric knew that Shota would always be with him, and that their love would never die.After Shota's passing, Eric found himself struggling to continue running the bakery without his beloved partner. But he knew that Shota would want him to keep going, to keep sharing their love for baking and for each other with the world.So Eric continued to bake pies, just as he had with Shota by his side. But he also found a new purpose in life, inspired by his love for Shota and his commitment to justice. He became an advocate for hero rights, working tirelessly to ensure that heroes were treated with the respect and dignity they deserved.Eric's work gained recognition throughout Japan, and soon he found himself invited to speak at conferences and events all over the country. He spoke passionately about the sacrifices that heroes made every day, and about the importance of supporting them in every way possible.And through it all, Shota was with him. Eric could feel his presence in every pie he baked, in every speech he gave. He knew that Shota would be proud of him, that he would have loved to see how much he had accomplished in his memory.Years passed, and Eric grew older, but he never forgot the love he had shared with Shota. He continued to run the bakery, and to fight for hero rights, until his final day. And when he passed away, he did so with the same grace and dignity that Shota had shown before him.But their legacy lived on. The bakery continued to thrive, passed down to a new generation of bakers who had been inspired by Eric's love for baking and for Shota. And hero rights continued to be championed, with Eric's words and Shota's memory as a guide.Their love story had touched countless lives, and had left an indelible mark on the world. It had shown that love and justice were not mutually exclusive, that two people from vastly different backgrounds could come together to create something beautiful and meaningful. And it had shown that even in the face of loss and hardship, love could endure, and could inspire others to do great things.<<EOFANFIC>>

completion: ‘Irrational fears’ was written in chalk on the board.“For today’s art exercise, you young hearthrobs will be painting your fears on an eight by ten canvas!” Midnight cracks her whip with a resplendent aura, licking her lips sadistically.“In an event where you encounter these fears, a good hero never waver! The exercise will help you learn to get over them, and bond together as a class,” She pauses dramatically, “Because at the end, we’ll be sharing our wonderful artistic skills on the podium!”There was a stopwatch on the teacher’s podium that she clicked, adding an additional sound with her whip as the class groaned in unison.“Oh come on! My irrational fears are so stupid, I can’t just present them to everyone!” Shoto looked on as Kaminari nervously started groping Ojirou’s tail.Kirishima leaned back in his chair, huffing quietly. “I mean, it would be kinda manly to defeat our fears like that… they are irrational for a reason, aren’t they?”“Aizawa-sensei would be proud…” Jirou sarcastically said, picking up a paintbrush.Some people brighten at the thought.“A good hero…” Midoriya repeated Midnight’s words, softly nodding as he rolled up his sleeve.“Classmates, please remember to keep messes to a minimum! We would bring shame to the school and all our peers if we needed to replace our fine desks and chairs!—”“—Shut up four-eyes! We know that!—”Shoto ignored the amicable shouting between the loudest people in the class, instead taking off the school blazer and choosing the correct shades of an all too gray kettle.“Already starting, Todoroki-kun?” A feminine voice asked.He turned to Yaoyorozu.“I know what I want to paint.”It’s true; Shoto doesn’t have many irrational fears. He has true, heart-clutching nightmares that have real chances of coming to fruition. He knows nobody is going to use a tea kettle as a weapon against him anytime soon, (Truly creative on his mothers part) so, yes; a fear of kettles is most certainly irrational.The shape has been ingrained in his brain by now. It was steel, shining under the kitchen lights. A handle, a cylindrical sprout, a closed lid and steam. The fire to boil it was blue, he mixed it until it was the right shade. The counters were white, and before the remodel, the walls were pastel tile. Some plants, vents, and— ah. He was done.Shoto’s heartbeat was a little frantic, and the paintbrush shook a little. He swallowed some saliva and looked to his side to see Yaoyorozu at work, drawing something pretty morbid with dark reds and caucasian skin.She fared plenty better than him, just a tenseness in her slim shoulders.Shoto looked to his other side, Sato was finished as well, giving him a hesitant thumbs up.Odd.Shoto doesn’t talk to his classmates much beyond the Midoriya inner circle. Even then his sentences were short and blunt. Sato has sat beside him since the beginning of the year, a sweet, sugary scent always welcomed him.The taller man is loud, not as much as the chihuahua in disguise or Iida, but gusty and kind.In fact, the class was utterly silent. He could hear paint meeting canvas, sighs, and sounds of frustration clearly.Very odd. In fact, the glint in Midnight's eyes may be surprising.Beep, beep, beep, beep-She made the alarm stop with a click and turned to the class.“All right, who would like to go first!” She grinned.Predictably, nobody did.Heads were turned menacingly as if asking are you going to be the sacrificial goat? It’s not gonna be me, no way!The hero’s mood didn’t sour from the rejection, easily keeping her face straight, staring at some of the shyer students with an ‘it’s okay, you can do it!’ look.Someone finally caved.“I’ll do it!” Kirishima raised his arm, grabbing his drying artwork without hesitation. She nodded and walked to the corner of the room.“My irrational fear is… not really manly at all! Neither is the drawing, but…” Shoto looked as the canvas was flipped, to reveal a needle.“It’s super irrational, now that I'm thinking about it. My quirk is literally hardening and I'm scared of something being stuck into my skin.” His face soured, red creeping up to his skin.“I guess in my mind, it’s like— not really a needle thing at all. Just things poking into me in general? When my quirk isn’t activated? I guess,” He scratched his head.“I know I can just… stop it but—yeah. That’s my fear.”Nobody said anything for a moment.“Pardon me for being blunt, kero.” Tsu raised her hand. “But I kind of expected something along the lines of that. Fears that contradict someone's quirk is actually pretty commonplace. Your not alone,”The green-haired girl went up to the board besides Krishima, showing her picture of a frozen landscape, a line across the middle, and a dry desert.“My irrational fear is being stuck in harsh climate conditions, like a desert, kero, tundras especially. My tongue gets frozen pretty easily, and one time my body was forced into hibernation because it was too cold for my body to handle.”She tilted her head in thought. “It’s like you said, kero. I could just avoid these conditions, bundle up, but I can’t control the weather.”After her brave intervention, other people lost their hesitance, Shoto remembers Ashido skipping to the board.“My irrational fear is melting through my bed!” She gave a thumbs up. “I don’t get accidents anymore, but it could still happen!” She cheekily pointed to Sero, demanding he goes up after she did.“My irrational fear is running out of tape… losing my ability to make more? Tomato tomato,” He rubbed the back of his ear.Shoto resonated heavily with those trains of thought. He didn’t want to know what could happen if he lost control of his ice— god forbid, his fire.The fears that truly shocked him were Midoriya and Bakugou.“My irrational f-fear is losing… strands of my… hair?” He phrased it like a question, his painting illustrated a scene of fallen green locks on the ground.“Whaaat? Mido-bro, is your hair falling out!?” Kirishima said what everyone was thinking, and the perfect head of green hair shook at the thought.“N-No! It’s j-just a side effect of my quirk andifsomeoneeatsit—” His muttering became incomprehensible.Next, Bakugou stalked up to the board like he wanted to kill it, never mind that it was an inanimate object.His face was calm and cool. Shoto didn’t think that it was possible, and he said loud enough for him to hear; “Muzzles, gags, things that cover my mouth, numbskulls.”He didn’t explain further, walking back to his desk with an arm in his pocket, though his shoulders looked like it carried less metaphorical weight.Other people went next, and maybe it was silently agreed upon that Uraraka’s fear of floating into space when she was asleep was fully expected.“...I always keep a roof over my head!” She said after her rant, and Mina high-fived her on her way back.“I’m not the only one with sleeping-quirk-accident-related fears, yeah!”Painting after panting, consoling tones and friendly cheers later, Shoto was the only one left, and they all looked at him expectantly.At the podium, he met many anticipating faces. Hell, Bakugou didn’t look like he was bored out of his mind. He felt sorry to let them down.“My irrational fear is tea kettles.” He said, flipping his dry canvas to the class.“Loud whistles,” he added after a silent beat. Shoto looked to Midoriya, the only one in the room with context, and he nodded to him proudly.He inhaled.“It was how I got my scar.” His eyes met Midoriya’s, the class, Midoriya’s.“Oh gosh, I thought you like— burned yourself, or something.” Uraraka kept the conversation going.Shoto shook his head. “That wouldn’t be possible. My left side can’t be burned by flames unless they’re past a certain point. My scar is a freezer burn, anyway.” Little by little, his heart fluttered, drumming in his ribcage.“So you tried to ice it after you spilled it on your face?” An invisible arm went up.He shook his head again. “No, my mother did—but it made it worse, making it a freezer burn.” He explained.Oh no, why did he mention his mother? He saw interest spark in some of their eyes.After his fifth birthday, Endeavor's wife stopped attending social gatherings—stopped being mentioned altogether, vanishing. The media talked after it was noticed, but father shut them up quickly.(Like he does everything.) He’s very good at that.“Your mom?” Jirou picked at her long earlobe.“Yes,” He keeps talking. “She poured it over my face.”Oh no, he can’t take that back.“But— it wasn’t her fault.” He cemented.“Sorry, Todoroki-kun, but it sounds like it is?”  Yoayorozu put a hand in the air. “I mean– unless it was an accident—”“It was,” he glared. “an accident. It wasn’t her fault, he made her do it. She was sorry— she tried to ice it, she didn’t mean to.” He defended.She saw his eyes, she feared his eyes, feared Toya’s. Shoto just— looked at her wrong. She said so herself.His voice was hollow as he explained his thoughts. Some people shuffled in their seats.“My old man,” he explained, feeling around his left eye. “Had this look in his eyes sometimes. When he was mad, angry— Toya too. She… saw them.” He paused. “Through me, through my left side. I was five, and scared, and she didn’t want to. They made her. I just… looked at her wrong, and she broke under the pressure.”There, now they should get it.It was always his fault. It was his fault for Dabi’s creation. His fault when mother’s sanity broke. His fault for making Fuyumi and Natsuo question their mere existence as failures.This fact really shouldn’t surprise his classmates.Ever since the first year, there was some context to his former home life, some hints. Dabi crashed through the door with cold, hard facts and tried to kill him and the old man on live tv.Multiple times, he might add.He looked back to their solemn faces.Did they not understand?“She’s better now, I visit her when I have the time. My siblings too.” Shoto didn’t have any other explanation for them, so he impatiently awaited their reaction to that bomb drop.It was quiet, and— shame washed through his bones.Did they think less of him now? Did they—“You’re very strong for enduring that, Todoroki!” Iida chopped the air.He is?“Yeah! Very manly to forgive her like that, Todo-bro!”He was?“An inspirational picture. You need to have a lot of might to still come on top of a difficult childhood.” Tokoyami nodded. “Revelry in the dark.” He praised.“Tch, your dad’s a shitty bastard, icyhot.” Bakugou shrugged.That meant a lot, knowing him.Shoto fiddled with his painting, now unsure, balancing relief at their understanding and shame at their pity.“Thank you,” He whispered and took his painting back to his desk.<<EOFANFIC>>

completion: Kirishima flies on red wings above the bloodied battlefield. Corpses litter the ground. From this height they look like red poppies in a field of trampled earth. Kirishima slips between air currents and drops lower, the better to assess their losses. Miraculously everyone on their side is still standing, some wounded or maimed, but standing nonetheless.We did it. We won.Kirishima lets out a bellow and matching gout of flame. His friends and allies cheer. One voice is missing from the choir.Bakugou …He scans the masses: skirmishes from stubborn holdouts too proud to surrender, first aid stations for the wounded, the enemy generals taken prisoner and under guard. His dragon eyes can even pick out the flies on a horse’s ass, but not him. Where is he? The battle had been so massive it covered the entire trampled plains, extended into the forest, and up a towering mountain where Shigaraki’s castle stands—a smoking ruin—at the peak.There! A red cape flutters in a rocky clearing in the forest at the base of the mountain’s cliffs. Izuku runs forward, a moving splash of green amidst the verdure, and catches him.“Bakugou!” Kirishima roars, knowing it’ll only sound like wordless noise at this distance. Ignoring his own aches, pains, and injuries, he tucks his wings and dives. There isn’t enough room to land where Bakugou is, but he can alight in the river and run through the woods in his human form.Shifting hurts, as it always does: scales soften and meld into skin, bones and muscles and sinew rearrange themselves. His wings vanish in a cloud of red smoke and draconic magics.Bakugou’s in safe hands with Midoriya. Collapsing onto a trusted companion is totally normal after battle! Hugging is manly! If he hurries, they can all hug and celebrate together! Because Bakugou’s fine! Everyone else is, so he has to be too!“Bakugou!” He calls cheerfully; with all the air his pitifully small human lungs can hold. What amazing creatures, to survive with such a handicap.Kirishima can just catch sight of his friends through the trees. Bakugou’s back is to him and he’s leaning against Midoriya in the center of an empty stone circle near an ancient, broken pillar; a relic to some long-forgotten religion beyond even draconic ken.“Bakugou!” he hails again. Then, frantic, “Katsuki!”His weak human ears pick up a choked sob from Midoriya and … nothing.Kirishima returns to his dragon form before he realizes it. Shrubs and small trees bend and snap beneath his claws. He pounces into the clearing, snarling at the blue clad man who dares touch his king. Bakugou lays in Midoriya’s arms at the center of a growing crimson tide while the man—Tsunagu—frantically stitches skin and raw muscle.Something’s wrong. Very wrong … too much blood. It’s not his—can’t be his—please.He curls himself into a tight circle, trying to be as near Bakugou as possible. Izuku raises a tear-streaked face toward him and silently lays Bakugou on him. Like he knows …Kirishima’s attention is fully on Bakugou. His heart beats … but it’s so faint … weak and struggling, like a baby bird fresh from the egg.Izuku sobs brokenly. Despite knowing Bakugou only a short while, the peasant hero considers the coarse barbarian king his friend.He can’t be dying. He can’t! He has to live—to return home and reclaim the throne with his unbreakable dragon at his side! He promised! Kirishima’s thoughts fly in circles like startled bats. He’d slept for a year to recover from the trauma of his branding, and a whole decade to heal his wounds after escaping the fighting arena! Maybe … maybe Bakugou just needed to sleep! Kirishima would wait for him. He could be faithful for a hundred years—for a thousand! He could—he would …Tears blur his vision. He raises his third eyelids to wipe them away, not wanting to truly blink and miss seeing Bakugou’s last—no—he will survive. He has to!A noise echoes, through the forest and across the battlegrounds. Belatedly, Kirishima realizes it’s a mournful keen from deep in his own throat. An instinctual dirge. His view narrows to the rise and fall of Bakugou’s broken chest. Black thread under tension crosses it in uneven stitches. He doesn’t know whether to thank or curse Tsunagu; despite his efforts Bakugou still lays dying.His cry summoned a crowd: the sorceress Ochako, the knight Iida, the cursed prince, even the wandering king. Tsunagu, a great healer and Bakugou’s one-time mentor draws Kirishima’s eyes away from the gaping wound on Bakugou’s chest. He bows low and backs away to stand behind Midoriya.“This is beyond even my skills.”Edgeshot, a shinobi Kirishima knows only through reputation, approaches Tsunagu and rubs his shoulder consolingly. “I know much of the human body, being skilled in the arts of destroying it … this is beyond any human ability to repair.” Edgeshot remains behind Izuku, because few dare approach a dragon—even one as young as Kirishima—and speaks, “Lord Kirishima, only you can save him. There is a way. The draconic heart holds much power.”Kirishima remembers the tales from before the fighting pits, when he was an egg-wet hatchling surrounded by dozens of kin. The legend of the Dragon’s Heart … when shared it could—he could—“I can’t! It’s forbidden.”Izuku, unaware of the specifics, begs, “It’s the only way. Save him. Please, Eijirou, you’re the only one who can.” Fat tears roll down his round freckled cheeks.“The last time a dragon shared his heart … it ended in great tragedy. It’s why we have the taboo in the first place. I … I can’t.”Edgeshot falls to the ground, bowing, and protests, “The reason it failed is the human was not pure of heart.”Jeanist remains calm—only because he’s seen more deaths than sunrises in his life—and speaks, chastising Kirishima, “Do you believe in Bakugou? Do you trust him? Is he worthy?”Izuku sobs brokenly, with his friends gathered at his side.This is the closest this many humans have ever come to Kirishima without fear, all because of  Bakugou. Mentally he’s panicking. Of course he does—trust and believe in Bakugou, that is. Of course Bakugou’s worthy of living, but this is his life force! His life! This is dooming Bakugou to eternal  life—dragons are incredibly long lived. A life so long would corrupt most other creatures. Bakugou is brash, and violent, prone to outbursts and attitude, but … he’s also kind, loyal to a fault. Kirishima trusts him, wholeheartedly. He loves him wholeheartedly.Decision made; Kirishima cuts into his own chest. One sharp claw scores deep, weaving between the scales. Muscle and sinew tear. Blood leaks out and splatters on the stone; a trivial amount to him, but more than was in Bakugou’s entire body before he began bleeding out in this ancient temple to a forgotten god.Pain! Which shouldn’t be a surprise. He’s carving out his literal heart after all. It hurts no less than losing Bakugou, his metaphorical heart. This will all be worth it … if it works. He’s never done this before. But … it’s a dragon thing, draconic magic … so it has to. He hopes it works, he prays, though he doesn’t know who to, or if they would listen. He breathes flame onto the sliver of heart; a healing flame. He doesn’t know what makes it so, but holds the intent in his broken  heart, and imbues it into the missing slice. He remembers that much from the old tales: this magic relies on intent … and in some tellings, love.The raw flesh throbs, beating in tune with his own aching heart. Does this mean it’s working, or is it the twitch of a newly dead creature unaware of the cessation of its existence; that it is now nothing but meat. With his other claw he cuts open the stitches running down Katsuki’s sternum, Tsunagu’s best attempt to save the doomed barbarian king. Kirishima places the still pulsing slice of himself into Bakugou.“Heal his heart, save his life,” Kirishima hums in old draconic. It’s simple, but he can’t think of more.Nothing happens.All he feels is the pain of a missing piece of his heart. He doesn’t think of healing his own wounds. Exhaustion grips the edges of his mind. But he can’t sleep to recover, he won’t, Bakugou needs him …Bakugou …It didn’t work.Bakugou lies still. He feels cold, so cold, against Kirishima’s scales. He’d often complained of the cold, cloaking himself in furs even beneath the summer sun. His sweat back then smelled like home. Now it was cold and drying on his skin, pinking the edges of crusted rivulets of clotted blood. Kirishima raises a tattered wing to protect Bakugou’s body from the midday sun. They often napped like this, Bakugou draped atop him, with Kirishima playing bedwarmer and sunshade. Despite Bakugou’s praise of his warmth, Kirishima always thought Bakugou felt and burned brighter than his own inner draconic fire.Now … now he’s gone … and Kirishima will once again be alone. Maybe … if he had just died in the fighting pits Bakugou would have found another dragon, slain it, and returned home safely, avoiding all this mess. Avoiding—Kirishima keens once again, a screeching sound high in his throat. He swears he can feel his heart breaking. Everything aches all over. He’s in so much pain; his entire body is wracked with it. Pain … throbbing … to the beat of his heart.Bakugou gasps and his chest heaves; a proper breath.Kirishima’s lungs burn like he’d taken his first breath after diving for hours. These aches, he realizes with a shock, aren’t his. They aren’t his!It worked! The bond exists. Bakugou is alive. And he’ll remain so as long as Kirishima is.Golden lashes part and red eyes meet his own. Kirishima could almost imagine it being an effect of the magic if they hadn’t been red from the day he and Bakugou met. Now he could convince himself it is fate. Maybe … maybe they’re destined to be together, and life isn’t just a series of choices and chance. They stare at each other in wonder, unblinking. Bakugou’s eyes appear—miraculously—more red, more vibrant and alive.Alive … for as long as Kirishima lives.Did he make the right choice? Will Bakugou hate him now that he’s back among the living. Now that Kirishima’s robbed him of an honorable death in battle with glory.“Hey,” Bakugou says with a pained and raspy voice.Kirishima’s heart feels like it’s going to burst. There’s love in his voice, in his eyes, in every fiber of his being. He knows this intrinsically; feels it in his bones. The bond works, he’s feeling everything Bakugou feels.It’s love, pure love.Kirishima transforms in a rippling wave of flashing scales, shrinking down to his human form, and hugs his lover tightly in his arms. “You’re alive!” he cheers.Bakugou winces—Kirishima can feel the ache in both their ribs—but doesn’t pull away. He snakes his hands up to hold Kirishima’s cheeks in his palms. “So are you.”His voice is gruff.Their time traveling together has taught Kirishima that is Bakugou’s way of expressing awe. Through their bond, he can confirm it. Awe and love. They’re warm bubbly feelings. Red like their eyes if he had to put a color to it. And if asked for a sound—Bakugou kisses him, silencing his racing thoughts. “My idiot,” he growls possessively, parting only enough to enunciate against Kirishima’s lips.Kirishima grins and gazes deep into his eyes. He doesn’t need their newformed connection to know what that means.Without a word they kiss again. Nothing more needs to be said. They can just enjoy this moment, and being alive … together. They have their entire future to work out what comes next. A very long future. There is no rush, and they’ll face it all together.<<EOFANFIC>>
