completion: This was a big way to start off your summer break!For two whole weeks you and your classmates get a break from school to enjoy your summer for a bit! However you, along with Bakugou, Todoroki, and Deku, you were told by Aizawa that you five are going to help some pro heroes-including him on a mission. You were actually pretty excited about this! You get to be working out in the field with REAL pro heroes on a REAL mission! And you were happy to be working alongside Bakugou! You’ve had a crush on him for a while but you haven’t told him for obvious reasons! But for now you were just happy to work with him and work on this mission! However you and your friends had no clue what it was about and we’re suppose to find out today when they go with Aizawa to the meeting place to plan this mission. It was this big tall building, pretty professional looking.You guys head in and then walk down one of the many hallways until you arrive at one of the conference rooms. Walking in you’re met with Hawks, Endeavor, and Mirko. You honestly tried hiding your excitement when you were meeting some of the most popular heroes in Japan! “Good. Everyone is here. We can begin.” Endeavor says in his booming voice as everyone sat down at the table in the middle of the room while a bunch of pictures and information was written on the whiteboard in front of them. “Now, let me explain what is going on, as I’m sure your teacher hasn’t told you yet.” Endeavor continued. “There’s been this terrorist organization on the rise recently called The Truth Bombers. They apparently plan on releasing a very explosive and dangerous bomb called Fatality 11, or F-11 for short. We found the location of their base so we have to infiltrate them before they can set it off.” He explains.“We’ll obviously have to split up once in their base to cover more ground quicker, so we got some communication gear so we know where everyone is at all time.” Hawks says before handing out earpieces to all of the students and the other pros. “That way we can also notify the others if we found the bomb and where it is!” He added. You guys slip the ear piece on to your ears. “Speaking of if one of you students find the bomb, do NOT approach it and try to remove it yourself! Contact one of us and we’ll come help! But if one of us finds it, we’ll tell you guys to get out of the building.” Mirko explains to you and your classmates, nodding in agreement.“Alright. Go ahead and prepare for a few minutes before we head out.” Endeavor finishes.-“This mission sounds really intense!” You comment while standing in a circle with your friends. “Yeah, there’s a lot of pressure!” Deku agrees, which only earns a scoff from the blonde one. “You guys are just wimps! This will be a cake walk!” He retorts in his normal way. “It doesn’t mean we should let our guard down. They could still be very dangerous.” Todoroki points out.Just then Aizawa walks up to them. “It’s time. Let’s head out.”-“I can’t believe I got paired up with YOU!” Bakugou complains albeit a bit more quietly than usual so the villains didn’t hear you guys. When you guys arrive at the facility, you all split up in twos. Endeavor and Hawks paired together, Mirko and Aizawa, Todoroki and Deku, and of course you and Bakugou. “Well how about you stop complaining and actually try and help me find this bomb??” You hiss back as you looked around, opening every door you came to and carefully peeked inside to see if it was there. “Yeah yeah whatever..” he grumbles and begins searching too. So far you two have found nothing, even though you’ve searched everywhere on this floor. “We’ll have to go up to the second floor and see if it’s there.” You tell him as you started heading for the stairs. “No, it would make sense that they’d have it in the basement! Which is below us!” Bakugou argue back. “Fine then! You check the basement! I’ll check upstairs!” You tell him and run up them, ignoring Bakugou’s calls for you to come back.He grumbles and follows after you. “Y/N?? Come on we have to stick together!” He calls out, looking around for you. But he stops as his blood ran cold to see your ear piece lying on the ground smashed and broken. But you were nowhere in sight. No sign of a struggle, yet Bakugou instantly knew one of those idiotic villains must’ve jumped you and taken you somewhere. And now mans is PISSED! He doesn’t care about being quiet anymore! He runs around yelling your name, cursing the villains, and practically blowing doors open to find you. And from how quickly you disappeared, one of the villains must have some sort of teleportation quirk, otherwise he would’ve heard you struggling and calling for help. This place wasn’t very sound proof.But he only stops once he hears a very faint voice. He listens closely. “Kat..?”His eyes widen. That was you! He followed the source of your voice and finds you sitting on the floor of a giant empty room. He ran in only for the big metal door to shut behind him and lock. He ran towards it and banged on it, trying to blow it open too! But it wouldn’t budge. “DANG IT!! UGH!!” Bakugou yells in anger. “Uh Katsuki..?” He turns his head to see your face getting paler. “I.. feel.. kind of faint..” You tell him before you lie down on your side. “Hey!! Hey stay awake idiot!” He tells you as he ran over and kneels down to you. You were panting and sweating, despite being ice cold. He felt your forehead and his eyes widen. “You’re burning up!!” Just then he found a piece of paper and picks it up, reading it out loud. “‘She was just injected with a certain kind of poison we made! You have an hour to get out of that room and find the antidote before she dies!’”Bakugou raged and blew the paper to ash. “I CAN’T BELIEVE THIS!! We need to get you out!!” Bakugou yells as he ran back over to the door, doing whatever he could think of to try and get it open! But he couldn’t! He probably could with a big blast, but would end up hurting you really bad if he did. So he just had to try some other way. Just then he gets an idea and turns to you.“Do you still have your earpiece?!”“N.. no.. I don’t.. the villains broke it as they attacked me..” You reply, casing Bakugou to sigh. He tries his but nothing would come or go through. “Ugh! It doesn’t work in here anyway!” He sighs in frustration and keeps telling any of the heroes.-About 10 minutes have passed, but it has felt like forever!Your state has worsened too. You laid flat on your back while you took on short breaths, eyes barely being able to stay open as you were sweating more than Bakugou. Bakugou let’s out a sigh as yet no one has come. He turns to you and sees you slowly closing your eyes. “Hey I already told you to stay awake!” He reminds you as he went over and knelt down next to you. He grabbed you and helped you sit up a bit in his arms. You rested your head against his chest, taking in his sweet caramel scent that kept you awake. “I’m trying… I.. don’t feel… Great..” You manage to comment. Bakugou was starting to panic. He didn’t want you to die! He still needed to tell you how he feels! Like it or not he will get you guys out of here!-“ANYONE THERE?!? COME ON!!!” Bakugou yelled with anger, banging on the metal door that locked you both in here. He glanced over at you and gritted his teeth. You weren’t getting in any better shape. In fact, you were worse. You were flat on your back, sweating more than him, face stating to flush red, and labored breathing. Your eyes were shut tight almost in pain. You felt as if your skin was on fire yet you couldn’t move. Bakugou ran back over to you and knelt down, pulling you into his arms once again. Your breath slow slightly as you smelled his burnt caramel scent.He could feel you relax a bit but not too much that it seems like you’re passing away. You still had 10 minutes left after all. “Listen up you idiot… You..ugh YOU HAVE TO LIVE OKAY?! Because I love you!!” He yells angrily, finally confessing it. Your eyes open and look at him. You had to make sure you heard that right. Once you see he was sincere, you smile and close your eyes again. “I… Do.. as well..” You say between your breaths. He was about to get up and try calling for help again when he heard a familiar voice. “Hello? Is there anyone there It was Mirko! Her muffle voice came from the hall. Bakugou got back up and ran to the door banging on it. “BUNNY GIRL!!! WE’RE IN HERE!!!” He yells, having Mirko run over. “Bakugou! Are you in there??” She calls through. “YES BUT Y/N WAS INJECTED WITH SOME WEIRD POISON! SHE IS GOING TO DIE IN 10 MINUTES UNLESS SHE GETS THE ANTIDOTE OR SOME HELP!!” He yells back.“That’s probably what this syringe I found is for!” Mirko says looking at it in her hand. “In that case stand back and stay out of the way!” She tells him and he does so, getting you and himself out of the way. “Ready!!” Bakugou tells her. Suddenly she back kicks the door and it goes flying off of it’s hinges and slams against the back wall. Mirko runs in before dashing over to you where you lay flat on your back. Mirko takes the syringe she found and injects it into you. Bakugou watches all of this and starts getting anxious once Mirko went silent. “Well?? Did it work?!” He asks. “Only for a few minutes. It’s just slowing the poison down. Let’s get her out of here!” Mirko explains before picking you up. Bakugou followed her out to see the other pros who came along having already captured all of the villains and secured the bomb. Bakugou watches as a bunch of medics run up to Mirko and strap you down on to a stretcher. All he could do was stand there as he watched them load you into the back of the ambulance.Stay with me Y/N!!-You wake up with a numb headache and felt a little dizzy. Other than than, you felt fine! You look around your hospital room and notice a vase of flowers on your stand beside your bed, along with a plate of orange slices. But what about Bakugou? You thought as you remembered what he said to you. As if on cue, the door opens and Bakugou walks in. “Good. You’re finally awake.” He says but in a much softer tone than usual before he sits in the chair beside your bed. “So… About before..” You begin nervously. “Ugh, don’t make a big deal out of it! Once you’re out, we’re going to that cafe you like! Deal with it!” Bakugou tells you, catching you off.“Oh… Okay.” You say smiling.“It’s a date then.”<<EOFANFIC>>

completion: A lonely figure wandered through the streets of a narrow street, shadows growing and diminishing as it walked under the streetlamps. It didn’t seem as though it had a destination, simply roaming aimlessly around the streets of what is usually a lively neighborhood. But it hadn’t been, not as of late anyway.Aizawa Shouta didn’t know what to do anymore. He had tried everything, but none of his usual methods were bearing any results. He couldn’t think of anything better to do than to parole around the neighborhood, wishing against hope that his presence alone would be enough to deter whoever it was that was wreaking havoc in this city.He finally saw a small and dim neon sign that sparked his interest- a bar. He should probably go in; it was doing him no good to be outside in the cold and he would probably only scare anyone who looked out their window. He stood in front of the doors pondering his options. He appeared to be older than what he was; the years and experiences were a heavy load and it was starting to show, as his shoulders sagged under the weight. His hair had never been lustrous, but the straw-like (they had once been wavy, he reckoned, but not anymore) locks reached his shoulders and broke off at the ends. His beard, too, was in heavy need of some care. All of him needed some, he had to admit.He threw his head back and sighed. Okay, okay, whatever. A drink and he would go home he thought, going in.Shrugging off his coat and placing it along with his hat on the rack at the entrance, he took a moment to scan the place, tired irises lazily taking in his surroundings. It was a dimly lit small place, with a bar with stools on the right and some tables scattered here and there. There was a stage and a door that led to the bathrooms at the end. It wasn’t well decorated really, but Aizawa thought about the state of his apartment and concluded that he was in no position to judge. There were a few clusters of people hanging around some of the tables, almost all of them men of course. Women didn’t venture out at night anymore, not since the authorities had announced the string of murders around the area a few months ago. He had been assigned to the case after it became obvious that more people were going to die if the murderer wasn’t caught. He was a seasoned detective that had experience with serial killers after all.He made his way towards the center of the establishment and took a seat at a table.It wasn’t like his involvement in the case was helping close the case anyway. It seemed like no matter what he did, the killer kept slipping through his fingers, one step ahead of him at every turn. Time went on and women kept showing up dead and there was nothing to go off of; no clues, no patterns, no evidence, nothing. It was driving him mad, really. Aizawa loosened his tie and signaled the waiter for a drink. Whatever would be fine. Anything to take his mind off this case.He leaned back in his chair and stared at the ceiling. Maybe he should give up. Maybe he should make space for someone that would actually be of help. Yamada kept telling him that he was good, that all they needed was another lead. But he couldn’t see it so clearly, he lacked the optimism that his best friend managed to keep around even in their darkest times.It was as these thoughts were starting to settle in his mind that he saw someone walking up onto the makeshift little stage that had a piano next to it at the end of the bar. It was a woman. Surprised, Aizawa trained his eyes on her. He couldn’t really make out any of her features, what with the lighting being so dim. He could tell, however, that she had wavy chestnut hair and what seemed to him to be fair skin, along with an attire consisting of a simple black dress and what he assumed were black heels. She didn’t look special, but she sure was brave. People had to work, sure, but hanging around a bar surrounded by men was not the smartest choice in his opinion. Still, who was he to judge? She wouldn’t be in danger if he had done his job right. She felt eyes on her and met his gaze, scanning his figure. He couldn’t really tell, but it kind of looked like her eyes widened for a second before returning to normal.She made her way towards the microphone stand and looked down at the person that was sitting down at the piano. They gestured to each other back and forth a couple of times and finally nodded to each other in understanding. She tapped the microphone and smiled. ‘So, we don’t have the guitar here today because Jenny refuses to show up anymore’ her words were met with grimaces and a sigh or two ‘but that doesn’t matter because it’s the same with only a piano and I just couldn’t start today without this one.’ She rubbed her hands on her sides, probably nervous because she knew it wouldn’t, in fact, be the same with only a piano. ‘I’ll bring my acoustic one next time, but for now, here we go.’There's gotta be a record of you someplaceYou gotta be on somebody's booksThe lowdown, a picture of your faceYour injured looksThe sacred and profanePleasure and the painSomewhere your fingerprints remain concreteAizawa couldn’t lie, he hadn’t paid attention to the whole song, as the waiter brought him his drink and realised he was a detective, asking details Aizawa could not share with him even if he wanted to. But as the girl neared the end of the song, he turned to her and realised that she was looking straight at him, almost pleading for him to listen to her. And listen to her he did.A three-chord symphony crashes into spaceThe moon is hanging upside downI don't know why it is I'm still on the caseHe couldn’t mask the surprise apparent on his face.It's a ravenous townYou still refuse to be tracedSeem to me such a wasteEvery victory has a taste that's bittersweetHis palms went clammy, and trembled as he tried and failed to take a swig of his drink. His body trembled all over and he could feel ice shooting through his spine, as if cold water had been dumped on him. She had his undivided attention now, and she knew it. She kept her eyes fixed on his, steady and unrelenting.And it's your face I'm a looking forOn every streetHis stomach dropped. He knew it was for him, as she neared the end of the song. He knew she was asking for help and it made him sick. Sick with guilt that he wouldn’t be able to do anything even if he tried his damnedest and looked under every rock and went down every road and followed every clue down to the very end and-Yeah, it's your face I'm a looking forOn every streetThe piano started playing the guitar solo and he only half registered that it didn’t sound half bad. But he couldn’t concentrate on anything that wasn’t her. That brave girl standing on that little stage with her sad eyes demanding that he do something. He stood up shakily and her eyes widened, like she hadn’t expected him to do anything other than order another drink. How could he drink after that? How could he do anything after that? he didn’t look back at her, he couldn’t possibly.As he gathered his coat and hat and headed into the cold, the ice in his veins turned into steel. He couldn’t believe he entertained the thought of giving up. He was going to do something. He had to.It only occurred to him as he sat in his desk the next morning while inspecting various piles of possible suspects that had arrived that very morning from testing the only DNA sample recovered from the many crime scenes that perhaps that woman from the bar hadn’t tried to tell Aizawa anything the night before.He ultimately decided that it didn’t matter. Someone up there had sent him a message to keep looking and he intended to do so, no matter what it cost him.<<EOFANFIC>>

completion:
Chapter Text
You stand on the stage with nine other women. They dressed you in red with a matching lip to make you stand out more. The chains around your wrists and ankles felt heavy even just standing still. When the red curtain parts, your eyes scan the audience. You watch the lavishly-dressed monsters laugh and chat amongst themselves while you contemplate whether you’d even survive another day at the hands of a noble. They were notorious for killing their blood slaves and quickly replacing them, which is why these auctions happened every month. Your heart races, drowning out the auctioneer’s introduction. You swallowed. Your eyes fluttered for a moment. You prayed that you wouldn’t pass out on the stage and end up back in their captivity. Your eyes fix on a gentleman in black towards the back in low candlelight. He’s shrouded in a dimness except his golden eyes seem to glow as they observe you. You watch a corner of his mouth curl into a smirk before turning away from him. The auctioneer approaches you, and you smile. You try to keep your focus on being appealing for the audience, but you can feel his eyes on you. Your eyes dart back to him and he grins, flashing his fangs. His blonde hair was swept back and seemed purposely messy. His skin was like porcelain with sharp features, and that stare. That stare pulled you in like a moth to a flame. You tried so hard to ignore him until he spoke. He bid on you, and your heart skipped a beat. He was still smiling because he could probably hear your heartbeat from where he was sitting. With the strike of a gavel, you were forcibly brought back to your senses, “Sold to Mr. Takami for three hundred thousand yen!” The audience clapped as the auctioneer moved on to the next girl. You felt lightheaded and suddenly your body was feeling heavier and heavier. All you could hear were surprised gasps from everyone as your body collapsed on the stage.You woke to the feeling of cold hands brushing the skin of your face. When your eyes came to focus, you saw him pull his hand away. You looked around and realized you were lying in a car. The light vibrations of the seat under you indicated that it was moving. “The quality of blood slaves has been declining recently. They’re all sick, underweight, or damaged by their keepers.” You furrowed your brows at his words. “Those chains left some marks. They also failed to care for you before the auction which is probably why you fainted.” You looked at your wrists, rubbing the marks with your thumb before sitting up. “Anyway, I never got your name.”“Y/N..” you replied. He didn’t seem to care for the way you introduced yourself and gestured to you to continue. “My apologies, I am Y/N L/N.” You sat up straight in the seat on the opposite end with your hands in your lap.“Much better,” he grins. “I am Takami Keigo, but you may call me Master Keigo or Master Hawks.”“Hawks?” You questioned.“It’s just a nickname I was given.”“Why do they call you Hawks?” You asked with a smile.“Well, hawks are smart, fast, and keen hunters like myself.” Something about the way he responded made you shiver.Not long after your conversation, the car pulls up to a huge mansion. Keigo waits for the driver to open the door before allowing you to go first. You stared up in awe at the Japanese-styled mansion before you. You followed behind Keigo, greeted by the servant at the sliding door. Upon entering, you and Keigo both remove your shoes at the door before continuing forward. The house had many windows which allowed the soft light of the moon to spill into the hallway. There were lanterns dimly lighting the halls with the flames flickering upon their wicks. “A few rules,” he begins as you follow him down the maze of hallways, “You are prohibited from being outside of your room during the day. You are to attend every breakfast and dinner. You are to dress and act accordingly, especially when we have guests.” You stop at the door of your room when he turns to you. “Lastly, you are to give blood when you are asked. There will be punishment if you refuse. Do you understand?” You nodded and swallowed nervously. His golden gaze was fixed on you, “Any questions?” You frantically shook your head. “Excellent,” his tone lightened, making you feel slightly relieved. “A servant will let you know when dinner is ready. In the meantime, you should get settled.” You nodded and watched him walk away before sliding the door open to your room. It’s a traditional Japanese room to match the rest of the house. There’s some artwork on the walls, a plant in the corner, and a platform bed in the middle of the room. The walls are green and the doors are sheer to allow in any light from the hallway. You walk over to the small closet and change into a floral-patterned Kimono robe. You find a mirror and remove the red lipstick along with the eye makeup they used on you to make you look more appetizing. You understood that someday you would be auctioned off like many other girls your age, but the weight of it all didn’t hit you until you were actually sold. You knew you would never see your family again. You knew you would eventually die here. You had no choice but to give that monster every drop of your blood whenever he wanted it. You would be lying to yourself if you said that you weren’t afraid, but you had to almost come to terms with your mortality. Your insignificance in a society of vampires. Your status was the lowest of the low even if you were owned by a noble. You were a food source and nothing more.A soft knock interrupted your train of thought. Upon seeing yourself, you wiped the tear resting on your cheek. “Yes?” You answered.“Miss L/N, dinner is ready.” A soft voice said through the door. You could see her silhouette through the sliding door.“Coming,” you said and dried your eyes. You followed the servant to a dimly-lit dining room. You watched Keigo along with a woman join you in the room. The woman, who you assumed was Keigo’s mother, looked more disheveled than Keigo. Her hair was unkempt and messy. Her clothes were very plain-looking for a noble. Her eyes were empty and sunken in like she hadn’t fed in a while. You waited for everyone to take their place before kneeling at the table a chair away from Keigo.“Where’s father? Out doing god-knows-what again?” Keigo asked his mother. She seemed to ignore him as the servants placed food at the table. Keigo and his mother received a meat dish that didn’t seem cooked while you received a pork belly dish with a small bowl of rice and topped with halved eggs. It smelled delicious. You didn’t realize how hungry you were until your mouth started to water at just the scent. You waited for Keigo to start eating before picking up your chopsticks. You had to restrain yourself from vocalizing your enjoyment upon taking a bite of the tender meat. All they fed you in captivity was bread, stale crackers, and you’d be lucky to get some kind of watered-down soup. They just provided enough to barely keep you alive, but a lot of the others looked malnourished. You could feel his eyes on you again. His gaze burned into you, slowing your chewing for a moment. “‘Well if my mother won’t introduce herself, I will. Y/N, this is my mother, Takami Tomie.” She barely acknowledged you and continued eating until she was finished. She was the first to leave the table without excusing herself. “You’ll have to excuse my mother, she doesn’t care for my company.” You continued eating along with Keigo in silence. You tried not to think of the possible human meat in his dish, accompanied with the blood-mixed wine in his glass. “Are you enjoying the food?”“Yes, it’s delicious.” You smile which makes the corner of his mouth curl into a smirk slightly. “I haven’t had any kind of meat in a long time. They just fed us stale bread and watery soup.”“That sounds awful,” he says, but he doesn’t seem that sincere. A vampire like him could never understand what it’s like to be starved, watch others be beaten or fed upon, and be secluded in a small cell without being able to see the sun rise or feel its warmth on your skin. You had never been bitten by a vampire before, but you’ve seen the pain in the eyes of the women who have. Keigo noticed your heart rate increase at the thought of two sharp teeth piercing your neck. You touched your neck, swallowing and breathing shallowly. Just watching you and hearing your heart race made Keigo thirsty. He wanted to at least wait until you got settled before attacking you like an animal, but he lacked the patience and self control to be that courteous. He wouldn’t feed on you here, so he decided to stand. You stared up at him as he offered his hand to you before cautiously taking it. You didn’t know what he was planning to do, and that made you tremble. He leads you away from the dining room and into a separate room. You barely had time to ask what he was doing before he swiftly moved to pin you to the floor. He was on top of you with his knee between your legs. You blushed upon noticing your position. “I apologize for my behavior, but I simply can’t control myself. Have you been bitten before?” You shake your head, “Good, I can be the one to claim you.” He tugs at the collar of your kimono to open it to expose your pure neck. He leans down, taking in your scent with a snarl. He gives you no warning before tearing into the flesh of your neck with his fangs. You try to scream out, but it's caught in your throat. You could feel your flesh slightly tear from the impact of his bite. You can almost feel him draining the life out of you. He swallows greedy mouthfuls of your blood until he feels a shift in your breathing and heart rate. He stops the bleeding by running his tongue over your fresh wound. You’re barely conscious when you hear him whisper, “Sleep now, little sparrow.”

completion:
Tick. Tock. Tick. Tock.

 

 

Jacket sat in his cell, bouncing his one allowance of a toy boy against the wall over and over, catching and repeating the throw in a practiced rhythm. The clock just outside the visibility from his cell continued to tick and tick, reminding him of the ever-present seconds going by, the seconds they thought he was distraught at wasting in prison.
 

The truth was that he couldn't care less.
 

He did his job. All the bastards who were a part of the Russian Mafia were dead. Gone. Butchered. Cremated., if it were even possible. His goal was accomplished, and now he was here in accordance with what the law said he had to pay for his actions.
 

 


Tick. Tock. Tick. Tock.

 

 

Izuku wondered what his parents thought of his actions, or if they even cared. The few clips he had seen of the news, they had allegedly declined to comment. Strange, but he had no reason to question it.
 

It didn’t take an idiot to realize Jacket missed some targets, and some very important information.
 

The public wouldn’t care if he did reveal what he saw though. He let Jacket take over, and all the public saw him as now was a violent, quirkless criminal who decided to try and make history because he couldn’t handle that he was a relic of the past. That was the sentiment broadcasted in most foreign countries.
 

The North American ones at least had the decency to tell it as it was; vigilante justice taken too far.
 

Of course, too far was a matter of perspective, and Izuku didn’t think Jacket went far enough.
 

 


Tick. Tock. Tick. Tock.

 

 

Jacket thought about the various letters he had found dropped by those damned cleaners near the sights of his work. As single-minded as he had been, he wasn’t stupid enough to completely disregard them, so he had collected them before the police could.
 

Those letters, in the context of everything, could only spell one thing:
 

 


IWASBORNINTHEUSA

 

 

He had no clue what it was for, but he imagined it had something to do with that copycat group he got associated with. ‘Hotline Miami’ the media had dubbed it.
 

Jacket found the name stupid, but fitting.
 

If the rumors he had heard in his blood-thirsty frenzy were true, then the hyper-nationalist scumbags needed to get their heads out of their own asses before they got a lot of innocent people hurt. Because the only thing worse than an angry crime family was an angry country from which that crime family came from.
 

 


Tick. Tock. Tick. Tock.

 

 

This was stupid. Everything about this was stupid. He shouldn’t have let Jacket take over. He shouldn’t have ignored those stupid signals. He should’ve tried harder to find those damn letters. He should have done his best to ensure that entire fucking mob was dead.
 

There was a lot of things Izuku regret in his life, and his current situation was just one of them, and only because of what he heard over the radio.
 

The bloody mafia was back. He missed the son of the leader, three rings of grunts, and 

two fucking ring leaders.

 The only thing that made the news sting more was the description of how those two ringleaders dealt with those who crossed the mob.
 

It didn’t matter, in the grand scheme of things. His mother and father have been dead to him for years. It’s his own fault that he didn’t make it official for everyone else.
 

 


Tick. Tock. Tick. Tock.

 

 

Jacket continued tossing the ball, having resigned himself to his own mistakes, with no opportunity present to be able to fix any of them. There was no point in trying to change anything if he couldn’t reach it. It had been drilled into his head for a decade, after all. He was just finally realizing how powerless he, a quirkless person, was in the grand scheme called life.
 

He whipped the ball at the wall as hard as he could in a flash of anger, only for the ball to hit a growing mass of purple cloud, disappearing through it as though it were a portal. Curious, Jacket stood, making his way over to the cloud and reaching his hand through it, only to feel open air.
 

An escape. Presented right in front of him. He didn’t care for it.
 

Before he could pull his hand back out, something grabbed onto it and pulled him the rest of the way through, the portal immediately disappearing behind him. Whipping his vision around, he was met with the sight of a purple, beaked beast with an exposed brain, a cloudy man shaking slightly as he pulled a needle with traces of a green liquid in it out of his arm, and a man covered in severed hands. Glancing around further, he found that quite the crowd of criminals and hero-trainees had gathered in a dome structure, and enclosed roof over top.
 

“Kurogiri, hand Jacket his shit.” The command was raspy, but the voice still cut into Kurogiri’s mind, the cloudy man nodding before opening another small portal, depositing Jacket’s belongings in front of him.
 

A knife. A lead pipe. An American brand of quirkless sneakers. Jeans with small cuts in them. A blank, white tee shirt with red droplets on it. A green and gold Letterman varsity jacket. And a rubber rooster mask.
 

Ignoring the nervous looks of the villains around him, he immediately rips off his prison jump suit, dressing himself in the comfortable, familiar threads of the clothes he wore before he was arrested. Before he doomed Izuku to a fate of being useless, stuck behind bars.
 

It was extremely empowering.
 

The heroes began to move, a man in a black jumpsuit jumped down the stairs of the dome and the villains readied themselves for a fight. There were loud murmurs coming from the teens, but Jacket didn’t care to hear it, more concerned with finishing his preparations.
 

As Jacket picked up his stained lead pipe, the hand-covered man began to speak again. “You’re gonna help us kill some kids, Jacket. So, you help me bash in the head of the hero who’s charge us, and Kurogiri will spread the kids out for you to hunt down, got it?”
 

The command in unheard as Jacket reaches into his pocket, feeling the plastic texture of his tape recorder. “Hey, are you dumb?” the leader yells, taking a step towards Jacket as Kurogiri heads to the front entrance. “Answer me, you dumb, quirkless fu-”
 

The yells are cut off by Jacket whipping around and swinging the pipe harshly into the man’s head, the crack of bone echoing across the entire building as the villain fell to the ground. More echoes of harsh, painful hits occurred as Jacket brutally beat the man’s skull in, until there was nothing left but a splattered mush and broken hand. One particularly stupid villain tried to avenge the leader, readying a projectile to fire at Jacket, only to be met with a kitchen knife expertly embedded in his skull.
 

The throw was nearly too fast to be seen. Everyone stood, frozen in absolute fear as the blood-covered mask turned to look at them, and Jacket reached into his pocket to pull out his tape recorder. He pressed the fast-forward button, listening intently before stopping on his chosen lines.
 

And he pressed play. 

“Stay calm and don’t panic.”

 he says through his tape recorder, a feminine voice stating the sentence for him. 

“Who do you want to be today? You can go anywhere, you can be anyone, who do you want to be?”

 

Every villain in earshot took the hint and put their hands up in surrender, shaking as they watched the blood continue to pool around his feet. The hero and Jacket remained in an unbroken stare down until the heroes’ backup arrived, the only one with a remotely positive reaction to seeing the violent criminal being the notorious principal of UA High.
 

He didn’t fight the heroes as they began to escort the criminals away. He was the only one not in cuffs, at the request of Nezu, who claimed it would be a safety risk to everyone there. Not a group to disobey orders, they listened, bringing him out of the dome and to an escort vehicle. As they passed the ground of shaken teens, Jacket lifted his mask, staring the whole group down until his eyes caught on one blonde head in particular, where his blank eyes turned to a scowl, and he returned to wearing his mask.
 

As he was put into the vehicle and the rat principal began to drive them to UA’s main building, the teen’s thoughts ran about the potential ways this new group of people could decide his future. The fact he didn’t fight them again meant a wild array of different ways his fate could be decided.
 

And if Jacket didn’t like that fate? Well, he wasn’t keen on being in an orange jumpsuit or chains ever again.

Chapter Text
    
Too many sounds. Too many lights.
 

Why did it have to be this way?
 

Why did it 

always

 have to be this way?
 

Katsuki just wanted to fucking exist, to just breathe, without being overwhelmed. But that wasn’t possible.
 

Everyone just had to yell, everything had to flash at him. Nobody cared if it affected anyone.
 

God-fucking-damnit.
 

“C’mon, brat, we gotta get ya some for your new dorm.” Katsuki’s mother strolled ahead, oblivious to his breakdown. Maybe because when he was overwhelmed (which was basically all the time), he acted grumpy, snapping at everything that dared to direct sound at him.
 

“Why the fuck do we gotta get new stuff?” He didn’t want anything new. He liked what he already had. He wasn’t up for adding anything else, something that he’d forget about later. 
 

“It’s to celebrate or whatever. Why aren’tcha grateful?” Mitsuki scoffed at his words. 

I’m better than you,

 she seemed to breathe into it, 

and you’re better than this

.
 

“I don’t fucking want all this shit,” Katsuki answered honestly. Wasn’t honesty supposed to help? Would his mom understand now?
 

“Well, you’re getting it anyway. You’ll thank me later, kid.” And she turned away, not even bothering to look for his reaction. Not that she cared anyway. It would be nice to think that she cared, but she never seemed to. 
 

Katsuki didn’t think she was a bad parent; any adult would treat his bullshit like this. He just had to do better.
 

His scowl deepened.
 

He didn’t really pay attention to most of the shopping trip. He couldn’t really afford to; he was already blocking out that one shop that had so many scents in it. He wanted to blow all of it up. He didn’t want to fucking deal with it. He didn’t even know where they went after. The only proof that they even did were the bags in his mother’s arms that had somehow materialized.
 

Why did his mom have to drag him here? She could just pick out some shit, and he could act like he was going to use it and throw it out when she wasn’t around.
 

“So, are ya excited? Ya get to basically live at school now!”
 

Mitsuki offered him a grin. Maybe she did care. Maybe she could see, even if only a little bit, that he was struggling.
 

But Katsuki didn’t want to think about it. He didn’t want to imagine living around a bunch of idiots he didn’t even know that well. Hell, he knew Deku pretty well, and he couldn’t even put up with his fucking idiosyncrasies. How the hell was he supposed to add eighteen other people to the mix?
 

Fuck. He hadn’t been paying attention, he had let his heart pound louder, his breath speed up. Shit. He couldn’t do this in public. He couldn’t show anyone that he was weak. He wasn’t allowed to be weak. Even if his mom was okay with it, everyone else would lose their shit. The UA idiot that brought down All Might, the cocky bastard claiming to be all that and a goddamn bag of chips, crying in public? Unthinkable.
 

“I-” Katsuki’s voice seemed stuck. His throat always closed up whenever he actually needed to talk. Why did it have to be this way? Why could he only use his words when it was unimportant?
 

He tried again, forcing out whatever he could. “I gotta- gotta use the bathroom.”
 

His mom sighed, maybe in frustration, maybe in pity. Fuck. Katsuki wished he could know. But he didn’t understand, no matter how much he analyzed it. No matter. He turned on his heel, trying to find the nearest bathroom without making it look like he was running.
 

Everything blurred until nothing was defined. The world had too many parts to it. He couldn’t tear it apart, inspect each facet until he understood it all, no matter how hard he tried.
 

So he shut it out. None of it’s even there.
 

He blinked, not realizing that he had already locked himself in a bathroom stall. Thank fucking god, since tears were running down his face. They were oddly warm, but salty as always. He could feel his panic rising, hoping that he wasn’t making any audible noises, the strange ones that arose when he was out of control. 
 

The light and sound of the bathroom was stable. No one else seemed to be in there. It was just him, his tears, and the quiet hum of the radiator or something. Katsuki was able to take a breath. And another. Just air flowing in and out. He didn’t need to worry about someone hollering at him, or a flashing light in a store display blinding his eyes. It was just him.
 

Alone.
 

It would be alright.
 

Just as he thought he had finally composed himself, his phone vibrated. For fuck’s sake. Did his mom not understand how to fucking mind her own business? He answered it without looking. She needed to get off his case.
 

“Hey, hag, fucking leave me be-”
 

“Bakugou?”
 

Katsuki was taken aback. Why didn’t he see who was calling? Why did he overlook that, and assume it was his mom trying to get a hold of him? He didn’t know everything, why did he think that, why would he act like that, it was going to ruin him and his life as if it wasn’t already torn to shreds and set on fire-
 

“Whaddya want, Kirishima?”
 

His friend laughed over the phone, the sound familiar enough to soothe Katsuki’s pride. “What did you do this time, man? Why’s your mom after you?”
 

“She’s not, idiot.”
 

“Mhm.” Kirishima’s smugness was quickly replaced by another giggle. “Hey, do ya think we could hang out or something?”
 

“Why?” Katsuki asked instinctively, wanting to take the words back the second he issued them out. Crap, he was too harsh, he didn’t want to dissuade Kirishima, he just didn’t know why someone would ever want to hang out with him, shit shit shitshit

shit-

 

“Oh wait, you’re still on house arrest or whatever, right? Sorry, man, I forgot...” Kirishima trailed off. Fuck, did he upset him?
 

“It’s not your fault,” Katsuki muttered, hoping that his words were only barely audible on the other side of the line. “I’m out with my mom now, anyway. The bitch got permission to take me fucking shopping. Not sure if Aizawa is sadistic or what.”
 

“Wait wait wait, like that one guy from that one comic!” Kirishima blurted. “Like, someone’s dad or whatever. It’s like, a western comic, but the dad’s always like, ‘Suffering builds character’ or whatever!”
 

Katsuki let out a silent laugh, trying not to show it at all, even though Kirishima would accuse him of it anyway. (

no weakness, no weakness, no weakness-)

 

“Calvin’s dad? Like from Calvin and Hobbes or whatever?”
 

“Yeah! That one,” answered Kirishima. “Y’know, you kinda look like Calvin.”
 

Katsuki couldn’t help himself. He let out a small laugh. He was okay, he could go back and deal with the shit of reality. “Yeah, fuckin’ whatever.”
 

Kirishima didn’t say anything about it, though. Maybe he could tell. Maybe he could see it. “See you in a few days, bro?”
 

“Oh fuck, I gotta see 

you

 soon? Why wasn’t I told I had to go to hell twice in three days?”
 

“Aw, c’mon, man. It’s not gonna be that bad. And if it is, we’ll get through it together.”
 

“Alright, whatever.”
 

“Glad to talk to ya, man.”
 

Katsuki wasn’t sure what to say in response. “Yeah.”
 

He wasn’t sure if he heard a small laugh out of Kirishima or not. Maybe he was just imagining his grin. 
 

The line clicked, the call over.
 

How the fuck did Kirishima know? He took all of Katsuki’s bullshit in stride, always seeing right to his core. Was he transparent, or did Kirishima know what it was like? Either way, he knew. He knew that Bakugou didn’t mind seeing him, he just didn’t want to deal with everyone. Knew that he was trying so 

fucking

 hard to keep up his façade of scary and mean and stubborn and toxic. Knew that even Katsuki wasn’t sure how much of it was a façade, and how much of it was who he actually was. 
 


We’ll get through it together.

 

Maybe it wouldn’t be that bad.
 

… Oh, who the fuck was he kidding? It would totally be that bad. It was always that bad.

prompt: write a story about Haikyuu!!,  Explicit Graphic Depictions Of Violence Rape/Non-Con 僕のヒーローアカデミア | Boku no Hero Academia | My Hero Academia (Anime & Manga) Takami Keigo | Hawks Hakamata Tsunagu | Best Jeanist Tokoyami Fumikage Original Male Character(s) Original Female Character(s) Hero Public Safety Commission Bashing (My Hero Academia)
completion:
PROLOGUE

     KEIGO JUST WANTS  to close his eyes and go. His bone-thin fingers prick into his Endeavor plush, attempting to dispel the unease vibrating into his flesh. He squints his eyes against the measly light slinking in under the door, but it only forces the tunneling to worsen. His body shifts intangible as his skin feels to crawl inside him, his flimsy being spinning in and out of center, swaying violently until he slams shut his eyes. The loss of sight throws his trembling limbs into a painful lock and drives his feathers to quiver.  ’It’s too much,   too much,   TOO MUCH!’  He flinches back, oversensitive skin dragging against the rough blanket scrunched behind him.       Keigo bursts into the closet door, out of it, and into the damp streets.      The darkness hushes over him. Envelops him in a safety. He shivers at its cold touch, welcomes it nonetheless. He doesn’t remember his rush out of the shack. Doesn’t remember the last time  its  darkness comforted him. Doesn’t remember what comfort even is. He walks, callused feet silent against the rain-swept pavement. The blanket of warmth that his feathers are drape over his quivering shoulders, twitching spastically. Edges and shadows envelop him in their invisibility, clutch him close, hold him protected from drunkards stumbling the late-night streets. From undesirables strapped for cash; villains who wouldn’t hesitate to mount a live prize for sadistic eyes to peel apart, to watch struggle to its final moments.     Keigo’s eyes fixate on a glint, caught in his peripheral. A feather darts out, snatches it. A moment of pause. A squint. A . . . coin.     . . . It’s  money .     He pockets it before it can attract attention. Continues walking. Continues finding coins. Continues pocketing them. He stops in front of a conbini; his coins jingle in their hiding place. His stomach cramps, rumbling in his prickling ears, vibrating heavy in his feathers, and he’s stepping inside. He freezes in the bright light, and doesn’t know what to do. He stares at the  options  and the  people.  They’re staring  back  , and his vision tunnels. He bolts, rushes to grab inexpensive ingredients, cheap canned goods. He hides himself in the short line, terrified of the gazes that burn behind his flesh, quick to put his spoils before the cashier. He sees the price tag and gets rid of several items he  needs  but doesn’t, and the final price drops within the range of his budget, so he discards his bounty, hesitantly, on the counter. A bag is handed to him and he scurries from the conbini.     The light scorches over his too-small shoulders, sends him blending again into the secure embrace of the darkness that saw him there. It sees him go where he’s expected. Sees him back to a sham-safety; a mere few miles from whence he came. His feathers finally calm, pliant like he is. Sharpen. A headache, drumming into his eye-sockets, squeezing his eyeballs with the goal to  pop!  , drives his lids to a sudden, clamping close. Violent vibrations shock images into his brain, flash behind his lids,  ba-DUM  an even harsher tempo into his skull. Dread sloshes into his stomach, zaps his spine, comes to the forefront of his brain before he understands what it’s seeing. Before he knows it, he’s moving, hand thrown out at the street, convenience store bag swinging from his other and then dropping to the ground in his surge forward. His feathers spring from the bones mounted in his shoulders, cut through the sky faster than the cars speeding head-on into a collision; gather the people inside to the side of the street just as thousands of kilograms of metal  crunch  together in a spark of terror.     When the sound fades, when the people frozen jump into action and panic, only a glimpse of fluffy red is caught preceding its disappearance. Authorities like flies swarm the scene soon after. 
↭
      He thought he’d gotten away fast enough, that no one saw him.  Thought the darkness clinging as a second skin to him would have kept him hidden.     It did not.     Thudding footsteps shrieking the floorboards, the knock that caused them, the sudden  silence  hushing over the dingy shack, is proof of that. His failure. Proof of his  disobedience  . The door creaks open. It slams shut and the shack  explodes  into noise. Covering his ears has never helped, so he doesn’t. A box is shoved into his arms, and his mother’s hand pushes at his back, shuffling behind him. A rhythm,  da-da-da-da-da , thumps into sagging wood. A hush. A hand again at his back. Passing streets, people. A subway station, and then one of its walls.     His mother asks him why he was born.     He thinks  ‘To help my mother.’  But he hasn’t really helped her. Not really. He’s only ruined her life, and he knows that.     So he settles on “I don’t know.” and quietly thinks instead,  ‘So I can help  people  .’  He doesn’t think what for. Doesn’t need to. Just knows that it’s all he’s meant for, to do.     And three days later, people in sleek black suits walk up to them, introduce themselves as officers for the Hero Public Safety Commission. He thinks it’s fate. Instead, they tell them what they already know: The Takami Thief has been arrested. Keigo thinks he likes the name when the Suits mention a Hero named  Endeavor  achieved the arrest. The Suits notice, say they saw what Keigo did beforehand; saw him save people from a car and truck swerving too fast towards one another. He lights up and just as quickly fades. The Heroes from the TV screen are  real  and these people want him to become one. But he also illegally used his quirk. He did, and they  know  . His blood runs cold. Runs like it does whenever his mother speaks of him. Like it did whenever he had his back turned to his father. Never  on  , always  to  , but never meaning different things to the man; always the same to him. Keigo’s mouth doesn’t pause in the face of repercussions. Instead, his heart asks the question—a question the meaning of  Endeavor  evoked, the distinction between the Suits’ use of “save” rather than “endangered”—that would forever chain him in misery before his brain could catch up:     “Can I become someone who saves people? A Hero like Endeavor?” He doesn’t dare hope.     Their answering grins give him more of an answer than their words do. And maybe just a little bit of that fluffy feeling slips into his heart.     “Of course, little guy. However . . . to be a hero, you have to abandon the name  Takami Keigo .”      “Can you do that?”     He nods, shy, into Plush Endeavor. He doesn’t mind. The Suits seem to know that.     They take him away and he doesn’t see his mother again until he ranks in the Hero Billboard charts.     It takes eight years.<<EOFANFIC>>

completion: The coffee shop is one of those small, quintessential hotspots with exposed brick, a shiplap accent wall, and industrial light fixtures hanging from wooden beams crossing the ceiling. Everything from the muted but tasteful artwork to the spindly rattan furniture looks like it’s been plucked straight from an IKEA floor display and placed here in the exact same position. Its scent of freshly ground coffee and sheer number of houseplants decorating every conceivable surface gives the place an impression of being a living, breathing Instagram post. Not that that’s a bad thing, necessarily. Eijirou enjoys the shabby-chic vibe as much as anybody else looking to chill and recharge with a cup of coffee and a pastry they can’t even pronounce. Which, of course, living in the city and near a college campus, accounts for basically everyone and their uncle on a Saturday morning. But right now Eijirou’s more concerned with finding an available outlet to charge his dying laptop before he misses a ( very important ) submission deadline than standing in line with a bunch of harried med students and aspiring young authors. The house special  Triple Mocha Rocket Fuel  does sound pretty tempting, though.  No. Work first, indulge later. Biting back a frustrated whine, he shoulders his way through the crowd and promises himself a coffee  after he secures his tenure. Only employed instructors can afford lattes. There’s only one open table and it has Eijirou’s name written all over it. He makes his way over with a sigh of relief and sends a prayer to the gods when he notices it’s next to an available outlet. Maybe he won’t lose his job today after all.  That sense of relief is depressingly short lived when said outlet is roughly claimed by someone shoving a phone charger straight into it. Eijirou lurches to a stop.  Shit. Fuck. He has exactly five and a half minutes to submit this form on a battery that won’t last for more than forty seconds before he’s forced to beg for spare change on the street corner - or worse. What if he has to sell his body? He might be overreacting a bit. But he sure as hell doesn’t want to explain to the department head that he forgot to set a reminder for this deadline when it came out over  two months ago.  Fuck it. He slings his bag higher on his shoulder, takes a couple of deep, fortifying breaths, and speed walks over to the plug table. He sits down across from the other person before he can change his mind and quickly claims the second plug for his dying laptop. When he looks up again, a young blonde man is staring at him with an offended, murderous glare. And Eijirou immediately recognizes him. “Bakugou!” Bakugou blinks and looks like he nearly swallows his tongue realizing it’s his own professor seated across from him - in his place of work, Eijirou notes, taking in the green apron and visor that had hidden his face before with the coffee shop logo embroidered on the front.  Eijirou gulps. Bakugou’s just as cute in uniform as he is in the hoodies and baggy jeans he typically wears to class. “What the hell are you doing?” Bakugou asks. Oh, right. Eijirou has just stolen half his table. With a nervous hum, he rapidly pulls the form back up on his screen and digitally signs it with minutes to spare. Bakugou clears his throat. “I said - ” “This was the first table with an open plug I could find,” Eijirou explains. “And my laptop is seconds from dying and I have to submit something before the deadline in…” he checks the time and feels his heart leap into his throat. “Three minutes,  holyfuckingshit. ” “So you just sit down without even asking?” Eijirou looks up from the email he’s drafting with the signed form attached. Bakugou’s hair looks soft beneath his visor and his cheeks are a healthy shade of pink. He’s so attractive it hurts. It’s more distracting than it should be.  “Sorry,” he apologizes. “I kinda want to still be your instructor by the end of the semester and to do that I have to send  this, ” He hits ‘send’ on the email and slumps bonelessly back into his chair, legs splayed. “To make sure that I am.” Their knees knock together under the table and Eijirou notes with no small amount of curiosity that, other than a slight shift in surprise, Bakugou doesn’t pull away. He gives Eijirou’s laptop a shrewd look. “How are you going to deduct points from your students for late work when you can’t even get things in on time yourself,” he complains. Eijirou grins and adjusts his glasses with an innocent eyebrow lift. “Do as I say, not as I do?” Bakugou scowls. “Whatever.” Not for the first time, Eijirou resists the urge to reach out and smooth that familiar frown with his fingers. Bakugou always looks so flustered and angry during class, and it’s definitely reflected in his grades lately. Eijirou had offered to help tutor him a couple times a week, hoping that a more one-on-one approach might help him understand the fundamentals of biomechanics easier. So far it hasn’t made a difference. If anything, it seems to have made things worse. It’s also made Eijirou’s crush on his student a lot harder to ignore.  He nudges Bakugou’s knee under the table with his own. “How about I get you an apology muffin for stealing your table?” “An apology muffin?” he repeats. Eijirou nods. “And then I’ll leave you to enjoy your break in peace.” Bakuguou looks down at his apron like he’d forgotten he works here. He looks back up at Eijirou with a slightly less murderous glare.  “You don’t have to do that.” Eijirou laughs and scrubs a hand back over his hood, tugging it forward a little more over his hair. “I want to.” He starts to stand but stops midway, grimacing at the line that stretches out the door. “Though I might have to bring it to you when we meet for tutoring next week.” Bakugou follows his gaze and then rolls his eyes. “Just…hold on,” he says, and then he’s gone, walking behind the counter toward the shop’s display of baked goods. He’d left his phone charging on the table and Eijirou stares at it, wondering if he could text himself from it and get Bakugou’s number instead of just having his student email. But that would be unethical, or whatever, so he doesn’t. Sighing, he sits back and watches his student fiddling with something at one of the coffee machines. His chest goes warm when he realizes Bakugou is making them both a coffee. He returns shortly after carrying two to-go cups with a plated muffin balanced on top of one of the lids. He sets them down with the plate in the middle, nodding at the muffin as he takes his seat again.  Oh. It’s not as good as having Bakugou’s phone number, that’s for sure, but he’ll take the offering. Gladly. It’s basically a coffee date. “Thank you,” he says, hoping the grin on his face isn’t as dopey as it feels. “But I was supposed to buy  you one.” Bakugou ignores him and pulls out two forks rolled up in napkins from his apron. He sets one next to Eijirou’s coffee.  “You don’t have to leave,” he mutters, avoiding eye contact in favor of glaring at the muffin like it personally offended him. Eijirou’s stomach gives an excited little flip. “You want me to stay?” Bakugou shrugs, like he’s trying to look casual and failing miserably. “If you want.” That’s really all the invitation he needs. Eijirou unwraps his fork and cuts the muffin in half, oddly grateful he’d left his apartment that morning without eating any breakfast. Not that it would’ve stopped him from enjoying this now, not in the slightest. “Thank God. I still have to build a lesson plan for Monday’s class and I can’t remember what I assigned as the topic of discussion. Maybe you can remind me?” Bakugou stares at him, incredulous. “You’re the worst fucking teacher, you know that?” Eijirou snickers around a mouthful of muffin, nodding in wholehearted agreement. * Later as Eijirou is leaving, he goes to throw away his empty coffee cup when he notices something written on its side, hidden under the protective sleeve. Curious, he slides the sleeve off and reads the message beneath. It’s a phone number.  And scrawled under it:  I’m off tomorrow @ 3 - Katsuki   He jerks his head around to look for Bakugou - for  Katsuki  - but he’s busy taking a customer’s order at the register. He doesn’t look over at Eijirou gaping at him from the door with the empty cup clutched in his hands.  But he’s blushing, and it looks like he’s trying to contain a smile. And it’s fucking adorable.<<EOFANFIC>>

completion:
Chapter Text
Kiyoshi Riku or who was better known as the Pro-Hero, Eclipse, rolled out of their bed, in their little apartment at 5:30, at the ass-crack of dawn.  But why were they getting up so early? Especially with the way that their patrols took place in the evenings or late at night. Well, the answer to that question was simple, they had gotten a job at U.A. and today was their first day working as a teacher. And of course, being a teacher meant you had to be there unbelievably early so you could prepare for the day. It wasn't like he regretted getting the opportunity to teach students how to become good heroes, no that wasn't it, he just wasn't a morning person. In fact, he hated getting up so early, hated having to wake up at the literal ass-crack of dawn. And if Kiyoshi definitely needed some coffee and probably a hot, steaming shower to wake him up, if he wanted to make it through his first day of being a teacher. Surely, but slowly he made it to his bathroom, that was connected to his bedroom and began his morning routine. Which was mixture of brushing his teeth, washing his face, putting on a little make up, teasing the shit out of his air, and putting a shit-ton of hairspray in his hair. And soon enough he had his hero costume on, he had his coffee, phone, wallet and keys and he was practically ready to start his day as teacher. And boy he was not prepared. But all he could do was hope for the best and put on his signature smile and head out for the day. God, he really hoped that today would be a good day.Kiyoshi blinked rapidly in disbelief. Nezu did NOT tell him or specify that he'd be a co-teacher, teaching a class WITH someone.He wasn't complaining or anything, he wished he would've specified that he was co-teaching with someone, specifically with someone that he hasn't talked to in a couple of years, regrettably so. And that person being Aizawa Shouta, who was also standing a couple feet away from him, also staring at him in disbelief. and god, the lanky, black-haired exhausted man looked so much different the last time he saw him, and he was sure he looked way different the last time had Aizawa had seen him, which was after they graduated. oh god. He hasn’t talked to Aizawa since graduation. Fuck. he felt like fucking worst friend ever, he had stopped talking to the older man for at least 10 years. and he just showed up in front of him out of the blue, in U.A. ten years later. And honestly he wouldn't blame him if he hated him, not with the way he left after graduation and hasn't spoke a word to him or Yamada. It was honestly a really shitty choice that he had made at least 10 years ago, and boy does he regret it. But it wasn't like he had a choice, he really didn't want to leave and not say a word to the either of them, but he couldn't do anything about that now and he wasn't able to do anything about it then, but hell, he certainly felt like the worse person on earth, and probably was.  He stiffened at how the awkward tension was so thick that you could literally cut it with a knife. God if he stayed quiet for one second in the awkward silence, he was gonna lose his fucking mind. He needed to say something, needed to say anything that would get rid of the awkward silence in the room. And he did so grinning(which hopefully looked real) before greeting the erasure hero, like it hadn't been 10 years since they talked.  "Ah Aizawa! Hows it been??" He grimanced at how nervous he sounded, it was fine, especially since its been ten years since they last spoke.  "Riku."  Aizawa spoke firmly in a monotone voice.   Kiyoshi winced at the tone of his voice, yeah he expected that.    "Uh- its been a while since we talked huh?" he finally got out after a few moments of silence. He rubbed the back of his neck nervously, averting his eyes from the taller, tired mans gaze.   "Yeah. It has. What are you doing here in this classroom riku?" Aizawa asked with a sharp, firm tone, the one tone that always made Kiyoshi flinch at.  "Always right to the point huh? Well uh, im here simply because i just got a job here as a teacher. " a nervous smile slowly made its way across his face.  Aizawa's eye's narrowed, but he accepted the answer with a grimance on his face.   "Riku. When I ask this, answer honestly. Why are you coming back now? Why the hell did you stop talking to me- to us?" He asked Kiyoshi or rather snapped at him angrily. And honestly? He deserved that, he expected for him to ask that, especially with the way he just showed up right in aizawa's face right out of blue. Aizawa Shouta had every right to be angry, to be upset.   The grin that had been on Kiyoshi's face slowly dissolved into a frown.  Kiyoshi sighed as his hands fell to his sides, he wasn't sure how'd he would explain why he stopped talking to them out of the blue, he wasn't sure if he could. But Aizawa deserved a explanation, and Yamada did too.  "Right, um that- look um-" he stammered, not bothering to see the look on Aizawas face. He didn't think he could bear to see the upset, angry, hurt look on his face.  "I'm so fucking sorry aizawa, I- i didnt mean to- didnt want to stop talking to you guys- and I was so wrong for not talking to you guys for so long, not being in contact with you guys, and basically ignoring you guys-" Kiyoshi shut his mouth as soon as he saw the look on Aizawa's face.   
"Look im not sure how to explain it all too you at the moment, m' not sure if i can. Especially since the school doors are gonna be opening soon, but i promise i will, its the least i can do." Kiyoshi fidgeted with strands of his bright green hair under Aizawas stare. 
 
Aizawa glared at him, crossed his arms but accepted his answer with a grumble. 
 
"Whatever" he grumbled, which kiyoshi grinned at. 
 
'Still the same the last time i saw you huh aizawa?' Kiyoshi thought as he sat on the floor near the board that was in the front in the room behind a podium. 
As the Class 1-A student entered the room, he could feel their stares on him and hear them whispering, wondering what he was doing there. Kiyoshi finally stood up, stretching his legs, standing next to Aizawa as he glared at his class, which got them to quiet down rather quickly. "Quiet down. This is Kiyoshi Riku, The Pro-Hero Eclipse. He's a new teacher at U.A and he's gonna be helping me teach you problem children. Be respectful." He glared at the whole class, telling them to behave in a non-verbal way before he disspeared into his bright yellow sleeping bag momentarily.

completion: Outside, it was a cold, rainy night in Musutafu City. There stood a tall tower near the city’s center, the heart of the bustling streets. Though the structure wasn’t any average building, it was the main headquarters for one of the largest agencies in the country: the Deku Squad Agency. Every light on the building was lit like a Christmas tree, all but one.The room was dark, nearly pitch black except for the palette of colored lights emitting off the TV. Sat alone in the room was a young adult with green hair, bundled in a blanket. His face looked different, though, than what you would expect for a hero. His expression seemed more of a sad one, basking in nostalgia.The television repeated its program that it was set to, a male voice spoke as the TV played.“Tonight, we will look at a mystery that still to this day boggles people’s minds. Nobody has found the true answer on why or how this group of prodigies seemingly split apart only after a few days of enrollment. That’s what we will be trying to answer today.”Still continuing, the screen changed to a camera panning over a tall glass building with fencing around the prestigious structure. It was UA. Once the camera panned, multiple photos of students were shown on screen.“This story begins at UA, a hero school that is known as one of the best in Japan and the world. The school is known to educate many teenagers from the age of 15 to 18, so that they can become heroes and protect our streets. In one of the first year classes, 1-A took on 19 new students, all eager. Everything was well for the first few weeks, until one morning, at least six students left the academy without notice, seemingly going rogue as food and other supplies were stolen on the same day. What’s known is that the rest of the class continued on as normal, and the empty seats were never filled. The runaways have not been found yet; if you know anyone who has information on the following shown on screen, please call this number-...”There was a creak, as if a door was opening, with the screen turning black afterwards. The young adult looked behind him and saw a feminine figure standing in the doorway, the light behind her only turning her into a silhouette.“Deku, are you okay? I was wondering where you were,”  girl spoke as she walked toward him after flipping a lightswitch. The girl had brunette short hair that was tied into a bun, and auburn eyes that matched her hair. She looked concerned, making her way to him and kneeling down to be on his level.“Yea, I’m fine. I was just…” Midoriya spoke after being revealed, he only spoke for a moment before being cut off by her quickly.“You were watching the same news report? Right?” She finished his sentence, asking a question to confirm what he was doing. As it was correct, he nodded in confirmation. The girl glanced down, closing her eyes only to think of what to do now. She was concerned for her love; he’d been stuck on this one report for a while, remembering the past of what happened, only questioning what could’ve gone differently.“Deku-... I’m sorry, I don’t know how to say this. You and Bakugo have known each other for a while, like since you were kids… I know it’s rough…” Ochaco spoke after sighing. She took many pauses, trying to speak her heart, but had no idea on what to say.“Thank you Ochaco, it’ll be okay. I just want to know why he did what he did, he was so happy with us, right? Or am I just seeing this through rose tinted glasses? I don’t understand what went wrong, what did he see or hear that we didn’t?” Deku thanked the girl for what she could do to help. Though, he was left with a question of what happened in the past with Bakugo. Meanwhile, Midoriya thought more on this, after he already spoke but was caught slightly off guard by Uraraka.Looking at her, she cuddled with him while he was covered by a blanket. In response, he gave a soft smile and lifted the blanket to let her in, so they both could be covered. The two lovebirds sat on the couch while covered under a blanket. With the TV silent and the room being lit, you could hear the rain dropping on the windows outside. It was a soothing experience.Even through a low moment, she was still there. It seems that the two connected right when they first met at UA. Each time one of them was in peril, the other was there to be a hero and save the day.The silence wouldn’t stay for long, as the couple were interrupted by a man running up the halls and busting through the door with alarming news.“Midoriya, there’s something you should see. It’s Bakugo…”  man spoke calmly, his face with a large burn on the left was rested but ready. The lovers on the couch took off the blanket and quickly turned to see that it was no other than Shoto Todoroki. Deku was confused at first, since Bakugo was mentioned and questioned immediately.“What is it, Shoto? And how is Kacchan involved?” Deku asked while getting up off the couch; Uraraka did the same.The three ran out of the room with Shoto leading. The trio of heroes ran down a few stairs, to enter a room that featured a large monitor on a wall with a desk in the middle. Chapter Text

The entirety of the League was lounging in the living room of their new base. A spacey warehouse they had moved into a few days after Izuku had brought in the remaining members of class 1-A. The TV was playing in the background while they each did their own thing, some working on different projects while others held quiet conversations or played on their phones. They were all interrupted, however, when the TV suddenly started blaring. They all jumped while Himiko and Tooru yelped in surprise. 
 
They all had their attention on the TV as “Breaking News” spread across the screen and a newscaster appeared standing in front of the gates of UA. Izuku grabs the remote and adjusts the volume so they can all hear her as she starts talking. 
 
“Breaking news. We have just been informed by principal Nedzu himself that the five remaining members of the infamous Class 1-A, who have been making the headlines of every news story the last few months as the search for the UA traitor continues, have joined the League of villains. It is unknown at this time whether or not they were all part of the League before entering a portal on campus or if the traitor was among them, convincing them to join.
 
“It is still unknown who the original traitor was but-”
 
Suddenly, Nedzu appears beside her,
 
“If I may?”
 
He asks, gesturing to the microphone in her hand. 
 
“Oh! Of course.”
 
She says, handing it to him. The camera pans down so he can better be seen as he speaks. 
 
“Considering the fact that we have not heard from or seen any other former member of hero class 1-A they are all to be labelled as villains under the assumption they have since joined the League. Please inform local law enforcement or nearby heroes if any of them are spotted at any point. They are to be treated with the utmost caution as they are dangerous.”
 
He’s about to hand the microphone back to the woman when she pauses,
 
“Actually, sir, would you mind answering a question or two?”
 
Nedzu nods slowly,




“I suppose.”
 
The newscaster grins,




“Firstly, what do you believe drove the members of class A to join the League?”
 
They watch as the mammal takes the time to think it over, likely trying to find an answer that won’t further incriminate both UA and the HPSC.
 
“Well, it’s likely fueled by the fact that-”
 
“Do you think it could be because they felt UA was unsafe after how many times they had been attacked? Or maybe because of how many of them were being picked off as the traitor under accusations that were later proven false? Something else altogether?”
 
Nedzu opens his mouth but he doesn’t get much farther before she’s interrupting him again. 




“How do you feel knowing that the most popular hero class since All Might’s has turned villain? Have you heard any word from the parents of the two legacy children formerly in class A?”
 
Nedzu finally gets a chance to answer as the newscaster pauses. 
 
“It is quite disappointing that class A has turned to villainy, I must admit. They had great potential for hero work. I have not heard from any parents but, even if I had, I would not be able to tell you what they said. Legalities and all that.”
 
Katsuki snorts,
 
“Like hell, he hasn’t heard from parents. Lying son of a bitch.”
 
Shouto nods,
 
“Yes. It is quite frankly impossible that Endeavor has not contacted him.”
 
Izuku nods as well,






“I don’t think mom or auntie Mistuki would be taking very kind to it either.”
 
They all turn their attention back to the screen in front of them when the newscaster asks her last question,
 
“What do you plan on doing with them once they are captured?”





Nedzu freezes and they all notice the subtle way in which his smile becomes just that little bit unsure.




“They will be dealt with accordingly I assure you. Now, I must be going. Please clear the UA gates so students may come and go without being bombarded.”
 
Izuku switches off the TV and chatter immediately erupts in the small room,






“Everyone else saw how his demeanour changed, right?”
 
Mina asks, looking around. They all nod,




“He looks unsure, like he didn’t know how to answer.”
 
Denki says, looking over at the now dark TV screen. 




“Does he not know what to do if we’re captured? Wouldn’t it just be standard procedure, like we learned in class?”
 
Sero offers. Izuku shakes his head,
 
“I think he was unsure because he doesn’t know how the public would react.”
 
The air becomes heavy as they all come to the same conclusion,





“He wants to hurt us.”
 
Jirou says, staring at the screen in disbelief.
 
“We’ve ruined the image of his school.”
 
Izuku says.




“He’s been cultivating the school’s public image for years and we ruined it in a day.”
 
Hitoshi’s face morphs into a scowl. 
 
“But he was deteriorating it by accusing us all.”
 
Izuku shrugs,
 
“He likely knew everyone was defecting to the League. He would have caught evidence of one of us with them eventually, and when he did he could show everyone that he was right. UA’s image would be restored, likely even boosted, and then when he brought us in he’d be revered.”
 
“But we ruined it.”
 
Satou says, holding out his phone.




“Already there are articles theorizing that we defected because of everyone being accused.”
 
Izuku nods, 
 
“Meaning he wants us to suffer. And he doesn’t think the public will take to it.”
 
“New rule, everyone.”
 
Yaoyorozu says, looking around worriedly,
 
“Don’t get caught.”

I just—”“You just what?” Katsuki asks, indulging“Love you,” Shouto says, like it’s obvious, because it is. It should be. “I love you and I know you love me and I don’t hate myself anymore because of it, because you showed me how not to, and I want—I want you. All the time. Always. But—I won’t deny you’re, ah, particularly appealing right now.”“Particularly appealing,” Katsuki repeats, and his mouth is twitching like he can’t help himself, can’t help the urge to smile. “Thank you, your highness. Your loyal servant lives to serve. And to provide the appropriate amount of orgasms at the necessary intervals.”“I hate you,” Shouto says, but he doesn’t, he doesn’t, he doesn’t. Could never force himself to. He loves Katsuki so much it hurts. So much that when he has to sleep alone because they’re apart for work he wakes up and reaches towards the empty side of the bed on reflex alone. Katsuki fills him. Fills him up. Paints over the cracks in his soul with gentle hands and loving words.Katsuki smirks. “I know,” he says, stroking Shouto’s cheek. “I know, baby.”“I’m yours?” Shouto asks, because he needs it, needs to hear it, needs to know. To know that he’s loved and cared for and enough. Enough for Katsuki in return, the same way Katsuki is enough for him.“Yeah,” Katsuki says, promises. “All mine. And I think I’m gonna carry you to bed and make sure you never leave. That okay?”“You’re not supposed to ask right now,” Shouto points out. “You’re ruining it.”Katsuki pulls back. “Cute,” he says. “You and your repressed fantasies about being taken against your will. And Shouto belongs here, pressed too close, with Katsuki’s hands on him, bending down to peck Katsuki’s mouth. “Is that how it went? You were nice enough to touch my dick?”“Yeah,” Shouto nods. “And I think that whole overachieving thing you had going on might have been contagious because I decided I had to give you my virginity too. Just—stay with me. Okay?”“I’ll put on a nurse outfit for you,” Shouto promises. “One of those really objectifying ones. Short skirt and thigh highs and everything. Pinky promise.” He even extends his pinky for good measure.Katsuki makes a strangled sound. “Sweetheart,” he says. “I think I need my blood a little, you know, higher. For other things.”“Yeah?” Shouto asks.Katsuki laughs. “Yeah, brat.”“Don’t worry,” Shouto says, dragging the tip of a chilled finger along the side of Katsuki’s neck. “I’ll cool you off.”“That so, princess?”“Promise.”“I love you,” Katsuki says, fond, fond, fond.“I know,” Shouto says. “I love you too.”Katsuki arches an eyebrow. “Even if I still hand in my reports on time?
